HEADLINE: Ex-Alcoa Boss May Become A Man of Steel; 
Paul O'Neill Leads Effort For Bush Administration As It Weighs Trade Curbs

BYLINE:  By LESLIE WAYNE 

 BODY:
When Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill was chief executive of Alcoa, the world's largest aluminum company, a glut of aluminum had flooded the market and profits were falling. His solution? In 1994, he almost single-handedly persuaded the major aluminum-making nations to produce less. Aluminum prices rose and have remained high, and Mr. O'Neill is seen as the savior of that industry.
 Now he is trying to apply his magic touch to another metal -- steel. He is at the forefront of the effort by the Bush administration to aid the ailing United States steel industry and, just as with aluminum, he is promoting the idea of an international agreement to reduce global production. 
 In addition, he is solidly behind the administration's effort to investigate whether steel imports are hurting domestic steel makers, the first step to any steel-import restrictions. 
But just as aluminum is not steel, nor are the two industries the same. As a result, Mr. O'Neill may be bumping up against some hard realities as he begins his efforts.
Most importantly, where the aluminum industry is made up of several big companies that could more easily agree on global production cuts, the steel industry is fragmented among many smaller companies in dozens of countries. The United States accounts for only 12 percent of the world's production. With so many global players in so many places, it is more difficult to achieve an agreement -- and make it stick. By contrast, the United States accounted for more than 20 percent of the global aluminum output in 1994 and most of that came from one company, Alcoa. 
Still, Mr. O'Neill pursues his goal. This month, he raised the idea of steel-production cuts along with the threat of steel-import restrictions in a meeting of finance ministers in Rome.
"We have been struggling with the problem of the steel industry almost universally around the world for the better part of 40 years," Mr. O'Neill said in a statement provided by the Treasury Department while he was on vacation and unreachable for comment. "Perhaps by discussing the issues and coming into agreement on the facts, we can fashion a solution that would be better than the possibility of protective action."
But Mr. O'Neill's efforts are already coming under fire from trading partners like Japan and the European Union, which say the United States is trying to protect an aging industry that has done little to help itself. By contrast, they say they did the hard work in their countries to modernize their steel industries and do not understand why American steel makers cannot do the same.
"The facts will show that imports are not the problem with the U.S. steel industry," said Bertus Van Barlingen, trade counselor with the European Union in Washington. "The signals from the Bush administration have not been good. It is not good to come to discussions with a big stick waved over your head. We are disappointed about that."
Moreover, the Bush administration's emphasis on cutting imports comes as steel imports have fallen steadily for three years. In May, the month for which the most recent data is available, imports were 28 percent lower than a year earlier.
And, though it is seldom mentioned in the Washington debate, more than one-quarter of all steel imports are bought by American steel makers, who buy raw steel slabs from foreign makers and turn them into finished products like pipes and sheet metal for the domestic market. For this reason, steel makers only want to block entry of finished steel products and not limit slab imports -- making the industry appear more self-interested than principled.
The final reality facing the administration, a political reality, is that steel users -- automakers, construction companies and machine manufacturers -- vastly outnumber steel makers. While employment in steel-using companies is measured in the millions, the steel industry currently employs only about 150,000, down from 600,000 two decades ago.
Steel users have nowhere near the political strength of the steel industry and its unions. But users are beginning to organize and have lined up leading companies like Caterpillar, Emerson Electric and Michelin North America to lobby for them. And while they have yet to get a meeting with any high-level Bush administration official, they have begun to make the rounds in Congress. 
"Our concern is that we will not be able to obtain high-quality steel at world-competitive prices," said Jon Jenson, chairman of the Consuming Industries Trade Action Coalition, representing steel users. "We think restricting imports causes far more harm than good. It's a cure worse than the disease, and we are trying to make everyone aware of it."
Compared with aluminum users, steel users are a more formidable bunch. Far less aluminum is used domestically -- under 10 million tons compared with over 100 million tons of steel. And, since there are so few aluminum makers, aluminum users must stay in their good graces and not challenge them. 
Some steel users, like the Gentzler Tool and Die Company in Green, Ohio, say they are concerned about the administration's steel initiatives. Last year, for example, when the government imposed restrictions on the slit-rolled-coil steel that Gentzler uses to make parts for computers and household appliances, the price of these coils from domestic steel suppliers shot up 12 percent.
"We were affected in a big way," said James Evans, a purchasing agent for Gentzler. "Basically, the steel mills gouged us. With no steel coming in from the outside, our prices were higher than in 10 years. After the imports were allowed back in, prices dropped and the steel mills started crying."
There is much to cry about in the American steel industry, which is a shadow of its former self almost everywhere except in Washington politics. Despite modernization efforts, much of the industry is saddled with costly and outmoded open-hearth blast furnaces, the technology of a bygone era, and is barely staying alive.
In addition, the combination of a well-paid, unionized work force and a large number of retired steelworkers to support means the labor costs for American steel makers are among the highest in the world. The labor cost per metric ton of steel is $155 in the United States, compared with $138 a ton in Europe, $123 a ton in Canada and $69 a ton in Brazil.
In the last five years, 18 steel makers have sought bankruptcy protection. The only healthy segment in the industry are the modern minimills, which make finished steel products from recycled steel through a newer electric-arc process. Largely nonunionized, these minimills have steadily taken market share from big "integrated" mills, whose blast furnaces transform raw iron ore into finished steel.
"The big old steel companies are dying and there is no hope for them," said Robert Crandall, a steel-industry expert at the Brookings Institution. "They have a technology that is outmoded, uneconomic and will never be replicated. We don't need to protect domestic steel because it doesn't need protection. The large companies cannot be protected. They will die anyway."
So far, Mr. O'Neill's door has been open to the steel industry. A steady stream of members of Congress from steel-producing states have visited Mr. O'Neill to press the industry's case, as have steel executives and the leaders of the steelworkers' union. 
The main message is that the domestic steel industry can compete in the global marketplace, but foreign imports have pushed down prices to levels making it hard to turn a profit. The problem is not of technology, they say, but of global prices and overcapacity.
"Domestic steel companies are not earning the profit they deserve because of the onslaught of product from overseas," said Nancy Gravatt, a spokeswoman for the American Iron and Steel Institute, a trade organization. 
What Mr. O'Neill is trying to preserve is an ever-shrinking part of American business. The entire American steel industry has a market capitalization of $10 billion, the value of all outstanding shares of all steel companies. This pales against the market value of single companies like Microsoft at $369 billion or General Electric at $483 billion.
"Imports are not the primary issue facing the domestic steel industry," said Mark L. Parr, a steel analyst with McDonald Investments in Cleveland. "The industry should be focusing on costs, especially at some of the older mills, which are some of the highest-cost producers in the world."
When Europe faced similar problems in the 1990's, older, uneconomic facilities were closed, restructured and consolidated. About 730,000 steelworkers lost their jobs and steel-making capacity was reduced by 1.9 million tons. But Europe now has five of the world's 10 largest and most efficient mills, while no American company is in the top 10.
Part of the reason American companies have not undertaken the consolidation to gain economies of scale and shutter uneconomical plants is because of what the industry calls "legacy" costs. This is the enormous burden of pension and health care benefits for 700,000 retired workers and their dependents any new owner of a steel mill would inherit.
Right now, for example, the LTV Corporation, which filed for bankruptcy protection in December and is losing $1 million a day, is seeking to scale back retiree benefits, which it says cost $137 million a year. LTV's efforts face resistance from the United Steelworkers of America. The company has threatened to cease operations and fire its 7,700-person work force.
Leo Larkin, a steel analyst at Standard & Poor's, said the irony of the administration's initiative was that it might prevent a slow shuttering of facilities beginning to take place among marginal steel makers.
"It may have the effect of keeping a lot of uneconomical capacity alive," Mr. Larkin said. "The industry would be better off by letting uneconomical production cease."
Theories abound as to why the Bush administration -- so squarely on the side of free trade -- would make such a protectionist move. Some say it is to reward voters in the steel-making state of West Virginia, which President Bush narrowly won, and to woo voters in Pennsylvania, where he narrowly lost. Others say it is to win organized labor support as the administration seeks to gain "fast track" authority to easily negotiate trade agreements.
Had the president not acted, there was a good chance Congress would have. Just before President Bush announced his initiative, 220 members of the House co-sponsored legislation to impose steel quotas for five years and allow the Department of Justice to reject any merger that reduces jobs or eliminates steel-making capacity -- two goals of any merger.
"Consolidation is happening everywhere in the world," William Barringer, a Washington lobbyist for Japanese and Brazilian steel exporters, said. "U.S. steel had better start to aggressively address the issue because the bad mills are going to drag down the good ones."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 26, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on July 17 about efforts by Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill to aid the United States steel industry referred incorrectly to the use of open-hearth blast furnaces. Steel companies now rely on basic oxygen furnaces to transform raw iron ore into steel; they do not rely on open-hearth furnaces. The last such furnace closed in 1991.

HEADLINE: Market Place; 
Nurse Shortage Puts a Premium on Staff Agencies

BYLINE:  By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
HOSPITALS across the country are struggling with an acute shortage of nurses, but the hospitals' problem is a big opportunity for a handful of nurse staffing companies. 
 These companies recruit thousands of traveling nurses who typically agree to work in hospitals on 13-week contracts. Thousands of other nurses take temporary work for a daily rate, often through a local, mom-and-pop employment agency. 
 Nurse staffing is a lucrative corner of the rapidly growing health care economy. Hospitals paid $7.2 billion last year for temporary employees, mainly nurses, according to The Staffing Industry Report, an industry newsletter. And spending on medical staffing is likely to increase more than 20 percent a year, it says, to $8.7 billion in 2001 and $10.6 billion next year. 
Now, despite depressed share prices on Wall Street, two companies that dominate the traveling nurse business are planning initial public offerings of stock. Cross Country, which says it is the largest provider of traveling nurses, filed an I.P.O. registration statement last Wednesday. And AMN Healthcare, which may soon overtake Cross Country, filed yesterday. Together, they have about 80 percent of the traveling nurse business. 
Barring unexpected snags at the Securities and Exchange Commission, the two companies will each make presentations to investors after Labor Day and sell stock by early October. Company officials would not comment, citing S.E.C. rules.
Cross Country, based in Boca Raton, Fla., hopes to raise about $143 million, or $20 to $25 a share, valuing the company at approximately $500 million, according to an analysis of the S.E.C. filing. AMN's offering is expected to be about the same size, according to people close to the company. AMN, which includes American Mobile Healthcare, and Cross Country were attracted to the public markets by the performance of the RehabCare Group, the only publicly traded company that gets most of its income from nurse staffing. 
Last year, RehabCare, based in St. Louis, was the top performing stock on the New York Stock Exchange, rising 384 percent, to $52.50 a share on Dec. 2 before ending the year at $51.375. The company raised nearly $50 million in a secondary offering last March 14. 
Analysts argue that many health care businesses stand to benefit from growing demands for care from aging baby boomers. Three of the six I.P.O.'s with the best returns in the second quarter were specialized health care companies, according to Hoover's a business information firm. Shares of Select Medical, which operates physical rehabilitation clinics, rose 111 percent; United Surgical Partners International, an operator of walk-in surgery centers, rose 71 percent, and Unilab, which runs clinical laboratories, rose 58 percent. 
As for nursing, as more nurses reach retirement age the next 20 years, the shortage will worsen, according to a study published last year in The Journal of the American Medical Association by Peter I. Buerhaus, a researcher and associate dean at the Vanderbilt University School of Nursing, with Douglas O. Staiger and David I. Auerbach. 
"It's not just a short-term trend," said James D. Forbes, a health care investment banker at Merrill Lynch, who advised RehabCare and other companies in the industry.
Rehabcare, which is predicting 20 to 25 percent earnings growth this year, fell 15 cents yesterday to close at $49.94. 
RehabCare draws on a national roster of per diem nurses -- those working for a daily rate -- for 80 per cent of its nurse staffing business. But Alan C. Henderson, the chief executive, said RehabCare's traveling nurse unit, which accounts for the rest of its nurse staffing business, was growing more rapidly. Nurse staffing generated about 57 percent of RehabCare's $153 million in first quarter sales. The company also runs rehabilitation and skilled nursing units for hospitals.
Large private equity funds have been investing in the nurse staffing business for several years. Charterhouse Equity Partners, based in New York, helped executives of Cross Country buy the staffing unit of W. R. Grace for $190 million in July 1999. Six months later, Cross Country was merged with Travcorps, a staffing business owned by Morgan Stanley Private Equity and Travcorps employees, who acquired the company for about $111 million in 1995.
Haas Wheat & Partners, an equity fund based in Dallas, has a stake in AMN, based in San Diego. Another equity fund, the Carlyle Group, helped Intelistaf, a privately held company based in Oakbrook, Ill., buy the staffing business of Gentiva Health Services for $65 million last fall. "We like the business," said Bob Dahl, head of health care at the Carlyle Group, which manages $12 billion of private equity capital. 
Bankers will be busy arranging more mergers and acquisitions in the nurse staffing niche over the next two years, said Randy Mehl, a health care analyst at Robert W. Baird securities in Milwaukee. 
The traveling nurse companies charge the hospitals $40 to $50 an hour, and more in high-cost cities. The companies pay for apartments and other amenities, including liability insurance and health benefits for nurses who work a minimum number of weeks. They keep extensive databases on the certificates and credentials held by the skilled nurses who are in the greatest demand.
Hourly pay for the nurses average between $20 and $30 an hour. They can often pick their region, for example, Florida, Arizona and California in cold weather. "It's all about how you attract the nurses," said Vikram Malik, an investment banker at Banc of America Securities who is an adviser to staffing companies. 
The nursing shortage is at the heart of the staffing companies' prospects, but it is also a risk. "Currently we are unable to recruit enough nurses to meet our clients' demands," which is a drag on potential growth, Cross Country said in its S.E.C. filing. Competition for nurses is intense, it added, pushing up costs and potentially squeezing profits.
In fact, Cross Country, RehabCare and AMN are all eager to import foreign nurses to meet demand. But the nursing shortage is international, and there is even talk in the industry of sending American nurses abroad to English-speaking countries like Britain and Australia.

HEADLINE: The Big City; 
$25,000? I'm Leaving Today

BYLINE:  By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
THE modest proposal in last week's column for easing New York's housing crisis -- use a computerized system like Priceline.com to arrange buyouts of rent-regulated tenants -- provoked a deluge of mail, mostly enthusiastic. "I would leave in a New York minute if offered a buyout," wrote one of the many tenants willing to leave town for the right price. Landlords rhapsodized about getting rid of rich tenants paying low rents. A developer in the Poconos wrote to tell New Yorkers that a $25,000 buyout would make a fine down payment on one of his spacious homes.
 But there were complaints, of course. Lawyers who now negotiate buyouts objected to being replaced by a computerized arbitrator. Some landlords angrily vowed never to buy back their own property and said they were holding out for the end of rent control. (Good luck.) Some tenants denounced the notion of leaving New York and vowed never to take a buyout. (Fine, stay. The buyouts would be for only those who wanted them.) 
 The chief complaint from tenants was that the vacated apartments would be too expensive. "After landlords have paid out all that money to tenants," Miriam Laskin wrote, "are these same landlords going to offer the apartments they've just 'bought back' from the tenants to anyone who isn't wealthy?" Dr. Laskin, a librarian who lives in a rent-stabilized apartment in Gramercy Park, predicted that the rent on her two-bedroom apartment would rise to at least $3,000 per month, triple what she pays.
Most vacated apartments probably wouldn't cost that much, because most neighborhoods are less expensive than Gramercy Park. But rents would indeed rise. Landlords can raise the rent at least 20 percent when an apartment is vacated, and Dr. Laskin's apartment could go up to $3,000 if her landlord did a major renovation and removed it from rent regulation. Such a change, many tenants complained, would be a loss to the city's stock of affordable housing.
But how would that loss affect anyone? Right now the apartment isn't available to anyone but Dr. Laskin. If she were ready for a buyout, what public good would be served by keeping her in an apartment she no longer wanted? It wouldn't help any other apartment-seeker. It would merely delay the day of her exit, at which point the landlord would raise the rent anyway. 
So the buyout certainly wouldn't deprive New Yorkers of affordable housing. And even if that $3,000-per-month apartment is beyond most people's reach, everyone benefits indirectly from a process known to housing theorists as filtering. If, say, a stockbroker moved into Dr. Laskin's apartment, he would be leaving a slightly worse apartment available for someone else, who in turn would be moving out of a slightly cheaper place, and so on, until the chain affected low-income tenants.
An increase in the supply of vacant apartments would push down the market prices across the city. In fact, as several landlords and economists noted, the biggest obstacle to the buyout scheme could be landlords' fear of falling prices. They're so used to a tight market that they wouldn't know what to expect from a surge of vacancies.
MANY of the landlords and tenants who wrote were especially fond of having the city subsidize the buyouts. You could call that idea an unfair windfall for certain landlords and tenants. But then, you could say that about every other program proposed by the mayoral candidates to add housing. They typically plan to spend $50,000 per dwelling, and that doesn't even include all the tax breaks, gifts of city land and other subsidies. 
A buyout program could be much cheaper, according to landlords and lawyers who currently negotiate such deals. Dan Margulies, executive director of the Community Housing Improvement Program, a trade association of building owners, estimated that the average buyout today costs the landlord about $25,000 in Manhattan, and half that amount in the other boroughs. 
Some buyouts are much higher, and some tenants would never settle, but we're not trying to make a deal with all tenants. Buying off just a small percentage would make a huge impact, and the city could close a lot of deals by offering just a small subsidy -- say, by promising to add 20 percent to the landlord's offer. 
That would average out to less than $5,000 per dwelling, a pittance compared with other housing plans. But while tenants have reacted enthusiastically, the politicians and advocates who claim to represent tenants' interests have been notably silent so far. They don't call. They don't write. What could be stopping them?

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS; 
4 Salt Lake City Charges Dismissed

BYLINE:  By JO THOMAS 

 BODY:
A federal judge threw out 4 of 15 felony charges in the Salt Lake City Olympics bribery case yesterday and indefinitely postponed the July 30 trial of Thomas K. Welch and David R. Johnson, who were indicted last year in the vote-buying scandal that had threatened the future of the Olympic Games. 
 United States District Judge David Sam, the senior judge in the District of Utah, said the Utah commercial bribery law on which the federal racketeering charges were based is "ambiguous and unconstitutionally vague as applied in this case." His ruling set aside the recommendations of the federal magistrate, Judge Ronald N. Boyce, who had been hearing the case. 
 Welch and Johnson, who led Salt Lake City's successful effort to win the 2002 Winter Games, said yesterday that they were delighted with the judge's ruling and that they hoped he would dismiss the remaining charges. Chris Watney, a spokeswoman for the Department of Justice, said the department was "reviewing the judge's order and considering our options for an appeal." 
In his ruling, Judge Sam said he would explain his reasoning more fully in a memorandum he would issue later. He said he intended to study other issues raised by the defendants and might call a hearing on their request that he dismiss the remaining 11 counts.
The former Olympic organizers are still charged with a count of conspiracy and 10 counts of defrauding the Salt Lake City bid and organizing committees by mailing and wiring money to International Olympic Committee members and their families in their successful effort to win votes for Salt Lake City, which will be host of the Winter Games in February. The four counts rejected by the judge yesterday charged Welch and Johnson with violating the federal Travel Act by traveling between states and overseas while violating the state law.
In a hearing last week, the judge questioned why federal prosecutors were making the Olympic bribery scandal a federal case, observing that they had brought felony charges based on a Utah law that makes it a misdemeanor to offer or take bribes or kickbacks in business affairs.
"Why not let the state prosecutors determine that?" the judge said. State prosecutors had declined to bring a case under Utah law. Utah's attorney general, Jan Graham, told The Associated Press in February that her office did not find evidence that Welch and Johnson had committed a crime.
The Salt Lake Tribune expressed its hope in an editorial that the judge's questions and comments "are a signal that the curtain is coming down on this legal circus." The editorial contended that "Utah's commercial bribery statute is a misdemeanor, and to use it as a base for 11 federal felony counts is the kind of stretch that the tyrants of England once achieved with the rack." Welch, 56, was president of the Salt Lake City bid committee. Johnson, 42, was its vice president. A federal grand jury indicted them last July on charges of conspiring to bribe members of the I.O.C., which selects the host cities for the Winter and Summer Games, with $1 million in cash, scholarships, travel, gifts and medical care. Both men have rejected plea deals.
In a statement issued yesterday, Welch and Johnson said that they believed the court's ruling "confirms what we have said from the beginning: we committed no crime." The statement went on: "The Salt Lake bid committee conducted its bid consistently with the advice we were given and the conduct of other successful bid cities."
William W. Taylor, the Washington lawyer who represents Welch, said yesterday that he hoped the charges of conspiracy and fraud would also be thrown out, contending that the bribery charges that were dismissed were "the heart of the Olympics bribery case."
Taylor said: "The conspiracy and fraud charges are that these men made illegal payments and then covered them up. If the conduct is not illegal, these are not bribes. The theory that they made illegal payments and covered them up does not hold up."
Max D. Wheeler, the Salt Lake City lawyer who represents Johnson, said: "The whole purpose of the bid committee and these defendants was to influence the votes of I.O.C. members to get Salt Lake City awarded the Winter Games. That is what they accomplished. We find it strange the government would accuse them of fraud for accomplishing the goals they set out to accomplish."
Welch and Johnson were the fourth and fifth people to be prosecuted in the Salt Lake City scandal. David Simmons, a Salt Lake City businessman, pleaded guilty to tax offenses related to a sham telecommunications job provided to Kim Jung Hoon, the son of Kim Un Yong, a powerful I.O.C. delegate from South Korea who yesterday finished second in voting for the I.O.C. presidency. The son, known as John Kim, was also indicted. He surrendered his green card, returned to South Korea, and has denied any wrongdoing.
Alfredo La Mont, formerly in charge of international relations for the United States Olympic Committee, pleaded guilty to tax charges related to payments he secretly received from the Salt Lake City bid committee for his effort as a consultant to help secure the 2002 Games.
Salt Lake City had tried and failed for 30 years to get the Winter Olympics as part of a broad economic development plan to build a winter tourism industry. After losing the 1998 Games to Nagano, Japan, by four votes, the campaigners in Salt Lake City said they changed strategies and decided to court the I.O.C. with attention, personal favors and money -- anything to get the Games.
The series of disclosures in late 1998 and early 1999 about Salt Lake City's plan to win votes through lavish spending and gift giving to I.O.C. delegates severely damaged the Olympic movement and the credibility of the committee. Ten delegates either resigned or were forced out in the wake of the scandal. Since then, it has been disclosed that similar practices occurred in Atlanta, which secured the 1996 Summer Olympics; in Nagano, Japan, which was host to the 1998 Winter Games; and in Sydney, Australia, which won the 2000 Summer Games.
About 30 of the I.O.C.'s 114 delegates were linked to improprieties in bidding processes for those Games. The I.O.C. subsequently instituted a policy that prohibits most of the members from visiting cities seeking to stage the Olympic Games.

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL; 
Umpires Might Unite On Strike-Zone Issue

BYLINE:  By Murray Chass 

 BODY:
Major league umpires do not have to be told that in unity there is strength; they learned that fact of labor life long ago. They have also learned from their experience of the past couple of years what the absence of unity can mean. Their problem is they don't know how to regain the unity they had before the Richie Phillips war.
 It has been two years since the umpires' strong labor position began decaying. On the day after the All-Star Game in 1999, Phillips, their labor leader, convened the umpires at a meeting in Philadelphia and proposed a strategy that he said was designed to get Major League Baseball negotiators to the bargaining table sooner rather than later. 
 But no sooner had the umpires left the room, leaving signed letters of resignation behind, than the strategy began unraveling. A fight for control of the union ensued, the insurgents won, Phillips was ousted and a new union was in place.
The new union, however, has not attracted all 67 umpires. Its membership roll lists 46 umpires; 21 remain aloof, still bitter over the actions of the group led by John Hirschbeck, the president of the new union. Not that the 21 are not welcome to join the World Umpires Association.
"I hope all the time that a day will come when we can all get back together," Hirschbeck said yesterday. "I constantly tell my members to reach out to those guys."
Their reach, however, has not overcome the grasp the 21 umpires continue to have on the memories of 1999. 
"The group unanimously voted for the job action," an umpire said yesterday. "We all agreed. When we broke from that room, guys went in different directions."
Although the bitter feelings remain, the umpires have found one issue on which they agree. Across faction lines, they appear to be unified in their reaction to the pitch-count caper. 
Sandy Alderson, the official in the commissioner's office who initiated the return to the rule-book strike zone, says the umpires are wrong if they believe they have been asked to manipulate the number of pitches thrown in games, but the umpires, right or wrong, have expressed outrage at recent instructions to call more strikes." I know this issue is something umpires are unanimous about," Hirschbeck said.
If they are, they could use it to become unanimous again in their labor relationship. It would be no easy feat to pull off, but pitch counts could trigger a return to the unified strength umpires used to have.
The umpire who recalled the 1999 debacle was highly skeptical that it could happen.
"Trust becomes a big factor," he said. "We all trusted each other that day that we were together. In previous years, when we were on the street, we trusted each other and stuck together. In '99 we didn't. It's a mess. The biggest problem with this whole thing is trust. How do you get that trust back?"
The umpires need a conciliator, a wise man who could bring the two factions together. One man stands out. His name is Fay Vincent, the former baseball commissioner, a man who has always championed the umpires.
Whether or not his position had anything to do with the fact that his father was a football referee, among other things, Vincent treated the umpires better than any other baseball official before or since. He worked to improve the economic standing of minor league umpires, too. In retirement, he laments the plight of the umpires and how baseball has allowed the position to fall into disrepute. "Like good players, good umpires make a difference," Vincent has said.
A veteran umpire recently said that umpires' morale was at a low. In leading the campaign to oust Phillips, Hirschbeck thought there could be a better way of negotiating with baseball management. But having nothing to do with pitch counts, the new constructive relationship Hirschbeck envisioned has not developed.
"They don't play fair," one umpire said. 
As long as the umpires remain divided into factions, they will never have the strength to induce baseball to play fair. Both factions recognize that reality, but they seem to be powerless to do anything to change the status quo. 
Jerry Crawford, the last president of the old union, has been busy in recent months trying to help negotiate a settlement that would end the plight of the umpires whose resignations were accepted in 1999. 
"They've come close a couple times, but they're nowhere now," one official said.
Crawford declined an interview request yesterday, so he could not be asked if he would be willing to use the pitch-count crisis as a possible way of crossing the gap and at least talking to the other side, with Vincent, or someone else, in the room. 
"If you have a group that is divided on a lot of things and something happens which reminds them of their common interest," a lawyer involved in sports labor said, "that could overcome their division."
Pitch counts and Fay Vincent might make a winning combination.

HEADLINE: All Languages, All the Time, And All Over the Suburban Dial 

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
At daybreak in central New Jersey, Indian professionals wake up to live Hindi prayers on the radio. At midday on Long Island, lonely Chinese immigrants confide in the host of a popular radio program called "Happy Family." At dusk in the Hudson Valley, Polish-Americans absorb the latest news from Warsaw on Rockland County's only talk-radio station, which is all Polish, all the time.
 Though most radio stations that cater to specific ethnic groups attract just a smidgen of the audiences who tune in to, say, Howard Stern, they are increasingly popping up in the far corners of the New York metropolitan area, reflecting both the growing diversity of suburbia and changes in the radio business. 
 Ethnic broadcasters are settling in the suburbs in part because a New York City station can cost more than 10 times as much as a suburban one. Moreover, they can tap into an expanding pool of suburban immigrants, while occasionally reaching the city's ethnic enclaves. 
Guided by local hosts who function as cultural bridges, these stations are also slaking immigrants' thirst for round-the-clock news, interaction and entertainment from their native lands at a time when immigrants, in city and suburb, are transforming the New York region. 
"Ethnic is big, and there's been an explosion of ethnic radio in New York in the last few years," said Zev J. Brenner, president of Talkline Communications Network, a Jewish television and radio network in Manhattan that has helped several ethnic groups lease or buy radio and television stations. "If you're flicking around in the suburbs, you can probably hear more ethnic radio than you can in Manhattan or Brooklyn or Queens."
New York's changing radio landscape mirrors the trends in Chicago, Los Angeles, Washington and other diverse cities, where listeners can stumble upon stations broadcasting in Arabic, Vietnamese or Korean. And this does not even include the many Spanish stations, which have become mainstream powerhouses, and West Indian and other ethnic English-language programming.
Such variety is a far cry from what used to constitute ethnic programming: renting an Italian hour here, a German hour there, on a weekend afternoon, on someone else's station.
These days, of course, listeners can find plenty of Spanish programming on major stations, like WSKQ-FM (97.9), known as Mega, which has the seventh-highest Arbitron ratings in New York City. WPAT-AM (930), once the epitome of easy listening, is now a multiethnic smorgasbord of Russian, Spanish and Caribbean programming. And many stations still reserve weekend slots for foreign-language programs.
But in recent years, ethnic broadcasters have begun to lease or buy their own tiny stations in the suburbs. Just in the last few months, a Korean company has agreed to buy WGSM-AM (740), a station in Huntington, N.Y., that plays Sinatra and his contemporaries.
Shifting demographics have contributed to the interest in ethnic broadcasting, said Tom Taylor, editor of M Street Daily, a radio newsletter. According to the 2000 census, some suburban counties had percentage increases in minority populations that exceeded even those registered in Queens. In New Jersey, the fastest-growing group was the Asian population, which rose by 77 percent.
Economics has been another important reason, particularly after the 1996 overhaul of the nation's communications laws allowed corporations to own multiple stations in a single market. Corporate consolidation has led to skyrocketing prices for radio stations in major markets. So while a weak-signal suburban station may cost $2 million these days, a station barely covering New York City may cost $30 million, said Gary Stevens, a radio station broker in Connecticut.
As a result, more than a dozen ethnic stations have emerged in the last decade or so in the suburbs, attracting audiences of 10,000 to 20,000 people, on average, with thousands more tuned in via the Internet, Mr. Taylor said.
The stations usually fall into three categories: AM and FM stations; subcarrier stations that share a frequency with a major station but require a special radio or subscription; and pirate stations, which sneak in some very local programming on empty frequencies and are more prevalent in Brooklyn and Queens.
In Elizabeth, N.J., Radio Restoration, WJDM-AM (1530), has been operating for seven years, and just two months ago expanded its religiously tinged Spanish programming to include weekends. With a small 5,000-watt signal that reaches from Trenton to the Bronx, the station, which originates from a church called Ministerio Puerta de Paz, sometimes broadcasts Sunday services.
"Prisoners call from the Union County Jail," said Alicia Reynoso, the station's coordinator. "They are very lonely sometimes. They say: 'Can you contact my wife? Can you teach me about the Bible?' "
Another religious station is Radio Bonne Nouvelle in Asbury Park, N.J., WYGG-FM (88.1). Reaching perhaps 20,000 people in a 20-mile radius, the Haitian-American station, which began in 1991, offers tips in Creole on immigration, Social Security and community events. "In the city, people don't have to travel far to get what they need," said Hermann Larose, the station's administrator. "In the suburbs, it's different."
In Metuchen, N.J., EBC Radio, WCNJ-FM (89.3), which began three years ago, now segues from morning prayers to daytime quiz shows and nighttime song dedication programs. The disc jockeys often banter in a mix of English and Indian languages, said Kulraaj Anand, the station's director.
At a recent live broadcast outside Andhra Bhavan, a new restaurant in Iselin, N.J., Mr. Anand and other radio personalities handed out prizes, danced to the latest Indian pop hits and promoted an Indian concert in Plainfield, N.J. One passer-by, Avi Kulkarni, said he called the station recently to dedicate a song to his wife. "I love it," said Mr. Kulkarni, a software engineer who lives in Edison, N.J. "I listen to it every day."
On Long Island, the Chinese Radio Network bought WGBB-AM (1240) in Freeport in late 1999, replacing a varied format of popular standards and multiethnic talk and music. Before that, the Chinese broadcasters had been based in Queens and delivering Mandarin programming over a subcarrier signal.
The station's regular lineup includes news programs on China and Taiwan, radio soap operas and call-in shows dominated by issues of health and the elderly. And though the station can reach Queens, Brooklyn and Staten Island, it wants to lease or buy another small station, probably in central or South Jersey, said Josephine Chain, the station's owner and general manager.
"Obviously, we want the largest station to cover the city and the suburbs," said Ms. Chain, a former D.J. in Taiwan. "But now, the big stations are very, very expensive."
In Patchogue, N.Y., WLIM-AM (1580), a longtime haven for popular standards, was bought in May by Polnet, a Chicago company that also operates WRKL-AM (910) in the Rockland County village of Pomona. As a result, Polnet now broadcasts its all-Polish programs to both northern New Jersey and the Hudson Valley, as well as eastern Long Island and southern Connecticut, said Kent D. Gustafson, the company's vice president and chief executive.
On a recent day at WRKL, the station's program director, Agnieszka Kaczkowska, was interviewing a group of high school students from Gdansk who had just won an international scholastic competition in College Park, Md. Just before the students arrived, the station broadcast its daily "Vatican Report" live from Rome. Inside the studio, one of the clocks was set to Warsaw time.
The only reminder of WRKL's previous incarnation as an English-only station three years ago was an indigo mug holder that read: "Rockland News, Rockland Talk."
Actually, WRKL and WLIM are not the only local radio stations in Polish. There is also a Polish subcarrier station in Fort Lee, N.J. In fact, there are more subcarriers than commercial stations broadcasting in foreign languages throughout the region, said Ralph Sorbara, president of Sound City Electronic Corporation in Bayonne, N.J., which makes the specialized radios necessary to capture the subcarrier signal.
In recent years, Mr. Sorbara has manufactured radios for more than a dozen ethnic broadcasters, including an Iranian subcarrier in Port Washington, N.Y., a Russian one in Fort Lee and three Colombian ones in Queens.
"Many of these people, they have little command of the English language, said Jouhard Nicolas, the founder of Radio Verite, a Haitian subcarrier in South Orange, N.J. "They need to adjust to the American way of life; that's why they're tuned to their radio 24/7."
The immigrants are not the only ones who are paying attention. Bret D. Schundler, the Republican candidate for New Jersey governor, has chatted on Radio Pinoy USA, WRMN-FM (88.3), a Filipino subcarrier station in Bloomfield, N.J., that emphasizes news and talk. And the Democratic candidate, James E. McGreevey, has called to schedule an appearance, too, said Lino Celle, the station's owner.
So far, ethnic stations have not elicited criticism from residents unhappy with losing their old stations, although a few Rockland residents initially protested WRKL's switch. And eventually, more ethnic stations may introduce bilingual programming to appeal to children and grandchildren of immigrants.
But for now, the stations are enjoying their new niche.
"At the beginning, I was afraid that no one would listen," said Jola Naklicka, whose bubbly morning show on WRKL began two months ago. "Then you realize there are so many people getting up. And people tell me it's so great that there's a Polish station. They miss their language, their country, everything."

HEADLINE: From N.B.A. Courts to the Halls of Politics; 
A Life That Started in Caribbean Poverty Turns Toward Albany Lobbying

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 16 

 BODY:
In 1990, Adonal Foyle saw his future and dreaded it. With an eighth-grade education, living on a tiny Caribbean island that had neither electricity nor running water, his likeliest fate was to become a fisherman.
 His life since then has been made of stuff that, if written as fiction, would be rejected as absurd. Introduced to basketball at age 15, Mr. Foyle became, in order, athlete, immigrant, star, scholar, National Basketball Association player, labor activist and, soon, United States citizen. 
 Now, add another improbable activity to the list: crusader for campaign finance reform. 
With the help of the American college professors who are his surrogate parents, Mr. Foyle has created Democracy Matters, a group dedicated to limiting the influence of money in politics, backing it up with some fraction -- he will not say how much -- of his N.B.A. millions. Focusing on recruiting college students to the cause, the group has created chapters on 16 campuses, most of them in New York, and has hopes of adding many more, with the help of Mr. Foyle's visits.
On Tuesday, he is scheduled to make his first lobbying trip, to the state Capitol, where he will meet with lawmakers and hold a news conference with Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver and others in support of campaign finance legislation. The visit is meant to draw attention rather than make real news; it is not every day that a 6-foot-10-inch professional athlete surfaces with a cause in Albany. But he is deadly serious about his subject.
"It's the one issue that connects all the other issues," said Mr. Foyle, 26, asserting that environmental, labor and other causes would benefit from limits on campaign contributions and spending. "This is fundamental to our democracy."
Like most of the extraordinary events in his life, he shares credit for his new venture with Joan and Jay Mandle, the decidedly left-of-center academics who brought him to the United States and became his legal guardians. After years of taking part in their politically charged dinner-table debates, he recently expressed an interest in campaign finance.
"They immediately sent several books and a bunch of articles for me to read, so I'm going around the N.B.A., from plane to plane, with a computer and all these books in my hands," he said. "The players are looking at me like I'm certifiably nuts."
So far, Mr. Foyle said, he has discussed his interest in politics with just one or two members of his team, the Golden State Warriors. But he is determined to get other players to share his concerns, and envisions Democracy Matters sponsoring television and radio ads featuring professional players urging fans to register and vote.
His elders often say that young people are apathetic, but Mr. Foyle decided that they simply lacked a cause. So he set out to give them one. "If you organize students," he said, "you organize the future."
Democracy Matters took several of its newly designated campus coordinators last weekend to a conference at a hotel in Alexandria, Va., held by Public Campaign, an advocacy group devoted to public financing of campaigns, in hopes of inspiring them and teaching them organizing techniques.
"Incumbents can and do use their position to extract money from wealthy individuals who want legislative favors," Mr. Foyle said in an address to the conference. "We should not be surprised, only alarmed, when people refuse to participate in what they believe to be a rigged system."
Despite the grim words, his manner is disarming. He laughs frequently, mostly at himself; dispenses hugs readily; and cries easily. When chairs were in short supply for a workshop with student organizers at last weekend's conference, he plopped himself on the carpet.
Mr. Foyle is not the typical professional athlete, to say the least. When he talks of fighting discrimination, he cites, along with racial minorities, the rights of women and gays. He writes poetry (which he will not show to reporters). Despite turning professional after his junior year, he graduated magna cum laude from Colgate University with a degree in history, and he is working toward a master's degree at John F. Kennedy University, which, like his team, is based in the San Francisco Bay Area. An enthusiastic fan of the theater, he made an improbable Stanley Kowalski in a college production of "A Streetcar Named Desire."
His Golden State Warriors teammates sometimes hint that they see him as a bit of an oddball, but they have also made him their representative to the players' union, a sign of respect.
Mr. Foyle was born on Canouan, a speck of an island in the Caribbean nation of St. Vincent and the Grenadines. His father abandoned the family when he was 6, and then his mother left Canouan to find work. Adonal, his two sisters and his brother stayed on Canouan, population 500, with their grandmother.
At 15, it dawned on him that his only choices were to pass the entrance exam for secondary school or, like most of his peers, get a job.
"That was the real hurdle, the real turning point of my life," he said. "Then I start truly studying under the kerosene lamp and with candles, and my grandmother screaming about how expensive candles are. I just knew that this was my last chance."
He passed the test, and moved to Union Island for secondary school. He had never seen basketball played, but was soon recruited to play for both his school and a local club team. A few months later, he was playing in a tournament in Dominica, another island nation, where he met Jay Mandle, who was refereeing, and Joan Mandle, who was keeping score. Mr. Mandle, an economist, and Mrs. Mandle, a sociologist-anthropologist, had spent years studying and fostering the spread of basketball in the Caribbean.
"He was not the best player on the team, and the team was not the best in the tournament," Jay Mandle said.
"No, they were the worst," said Joan Mandle.
"They won a game."
"Yeah, they beat Grenada, but Grenada had a one-eyed point guard."
Still, they saw in Mr. Foyle enough raw talent to believe that basketball could be a ticket to a college education.
Within a few weeks, the couple had sponsored Mr. Foyle for entry to the United States. A year later, he was living with them in Hamilton, a town of 4,000 people in upstate New York and home to Colgate, where they were teaching. (Mr. Mandle remains at Colgate, while Mrs. Mandle left teaching a few years ago, worked on several political campaigns, and now works full time for Democracy Matters as its executive director.)
Mr. Foyle enrolled at Colgate, and while he was on the basketball team, it played in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament for the first time. He was named both a second-team all-American and an academic all-American, and was the Warriors' first-round draft choice in 1997.
His professional career has been the only part of his adult life lacking a fairy-tale gloss. The Warriors are one of the league's weakest teams, he has been set back by injuries, and he remains a reserve, playing forward and center.
But such challenges, Mr. Foyle says, pale next to what he has been through.
"I'm different from other players in that I had different challenges, and I've had these great resources at home," he said. Asked if his colleagues were apolitical, he said: "I don't think so. I'm certainly going to test that theory."

HEADLINE: 2 Large Banks Beat Estimates For Earnings; Another Slips 

BYLINE:  By RIVA D. ATLAS 

 BODY:
Lower interest rates bolstered second-quarter results at Citigroup and Bank of America even as their businesses showed some weakness from the softer economy. But Bank of New York, which has comparatively little exposure to lending, surprised investors with lower-than-expected earnings.
 Citigroup reported earnings before nonrecurring charges and accounting changes of $3.79 billion, or 74 cents a share, a penny ahead of analysts' expectations. It had net income of $3.5 billion, or 69 cents a share, compared with $3.34 billion, or 65 cents a share in the second quarter last year. 
 Citigroup benefited from its continued focus on cost control, with expenses growing just 1 percent, even though revenues increased 8 percent. The bank also announced a $133 million after-tax charge "for severance and other costs in connection with staffing reductions," signaling further cost cuts to come.
"This management team knows how to manage costs when the situation calls for it," said David Berry, head of research at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, which specializes in the financial services industry.
Citigroup, based in New York, reported strong results in its consumer businesses, with earnings before nonrecurring charges up 19 percent from the period a year ago. The bank benefited from increases in mortgage financing and its credit card business. It is also ahead of schedule on integrating Associates First Capital, which it acquired last year. That helped lift earnings in Citigroup's consumer finance business nearly 40 percent.
Earnings at Citigroup's global corporate and investment banking division were $919 million, up just 2 percent from a year earlier. "Under the circumstances, investment banking results were reasonably strong," said Richard Strauss, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs. Citigroup's performance looks reasonably strong compared with some others on Wall Street, he said. Last month, Merrill Lynch warned that its net income would fall at least 25 cents a share short of what analysts had expected. 
Bank of America reported earnings of $2.02 billion, or $1.24 a diluted share, compared with $2.06 billion, or $1.23 a share in the period a year ago. This year's results were 6 cents ahead of analysts' expectations, according to Thomson Financial/First Call.
"The consumer side has been very strong," said James H. Hance Jr., chief financial officer of Bank of America, in an interview yesterday. "For banks without exposure to that business, it can be a problem. It helps cover costs on the corporate side."
The bank's lending business has been hurt in recent quarters by large increases in problem loans. Bank of America's nonperforming assets amounted to 1.6 percent of total loans in the second quarter, compared with 0.97 percent a year earlier. 
Still, the bank's asset quality held up better than expected in the latest quarter, said Judah Kraushaar, an analyst at Merrill Lynch. Bank of America's nonperforming assets increased by 5 percent from the first quarter, which is much better than the 15 percent to 20 percent increase he had forecast.
"A lot of people have been worried about credit quality at Bank of America," Mr. Kraushaar said. "For the short term, they are reassured." Still, given that the economy is still weak, "the jury is still out for the second half of the year," he said.
Bank of America has successfully capitalized on consumers' hunt for a safe haven from the stock market. The bank's average deposits increased by 3 percent, with money market savings account balances rising 19 percent.
A benefit of lower interest rates was an increase in mortgage financings, which rose 26 percent.
Bank of America also gained market share in the corporate bond market. Its share of high yield bond underwritings nearly doubled, according to Thomson Financial Securities Data. For the first half of the year, Bank of America moved to fifth place, with 9.4 percent of the market, compared with ninth place, with 5 percent of the market a year ago.
Investors were clearly relieved at the results at both banks. Shares of Bank of America, based in Charlotte, N.C., rose $1.13 yesterday, to $61.38 a share, while Citigroup's stock was up 29 cents, to $49.15 a share.
The story was different at Bank of New York, which derives most of its earnings from securities processing. The bank reported earnings of $385 million, or 52 cents a share, up 8 percent from the prior year, but a penny shy of analyst expectations, according to First Call. Investor disappointment led the bank's stock to fall $6.40, to $43 a share.

Russia and China Sign A 'Friendship' Accord
Russia and China signed a treaty of "friendship and cooperation," binding the two giants closer in the next 20 years and committing them to oppose jointly much of the framework for international security that the United States is seeking to erect after the cold war, like a missile shield. The treaty also places Russia more firmly behind China's claim of sovereignty over the island of Taiwan and strengthens military cooperation. A1

HEADLINE: A Floridian, Not a New Yorker, Will Be the Ambassador to Rome 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL J. WAKIN 

 BODY:
President Bush has decided to appoint a Florida developer and major Republican Party fund-raiser as ambassador to Italy, New York State and Republican officials said yesterday. It was a rebuff to Gov. George E. Pataki and Italian-Americans who had pushed for Mr. Pataki's economic adviser, Charles A. Gargano. 
 The ambassadorship in Rome, one of the government's plum patronage appointments, will go to Mel Sembler, who was finance chairman of the Republican National Committee during Mr. Bush's run for the presidency. Mr. Sembler, who became rich building shopping centers, has raised money for the Republicans for many years and was especially helpful in soliciting contributions for the two gubernatorial races of Jeb Bush of Florida. 
 Mr. Sembler and Mr. Gargano were both ambassadors under Mr. Bush's father, who appointed Mr. Sembler to Australia and Mr. Gargano to Trinidad and Tobago.
A Pataki spokesman, Michael McKeon, said White House officials told the governor last week that Mr. Sembler would get the post, The Associated Press reported. "We're disappointed," Mr. McKeon said. "We think Charlie Gargano would have been a great ambassador."
Bush administration officials declined to comment, but Republicans close to the administration said it appeared to be a done deal. And they said that the Bush administration ultimately favored Mr. Sembler because of his longstanding ties and service to the Bush family.
The Republicans said those factors were more important in securing Mr. Sembler the job than Mr. Gargano's past troubles. Mr. Gargano is chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, which was the subject of a two-year criminal investigation that ended without charges. As part of his bid for the Rome job, Mr. Gargano made sure that a letter from the Manhattan district attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, clearing him reached the White House.
The National Italian American Foundation put forth Mr. Gargano's name along with four others, saying an Italian-American should be ambassador in Rome. The previous ambassador to Rome, Thomas Foglietta, fit that bill, but other predecessors have not.
New York voted heavily against Mr. Bush last year, and is likely to do so again in 2004.
A more curious facet of the decision was the White House's willingness to ignore the pleas of Mr. Pataki, who at one point brought his case directly to Karl Rove, the president's top political adviser.

HEADLINE: A Panel Backed by Bush Urges Higher Fuel Efficiency for Cars 

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 16 

 BODY:
A federal panel that President Bush has said will help him decide whether and how much to increase fuel economy standards has recommended in a draft report that the government require automakers to improve the mileage of new vehicles.
 The draft report also says significant improvements can be made using new engine technologies inexpensive enough to pay for themselves through savings on gasoline over the typical life of a vehicle. 
 The 13-member panel, appointed by the National Academy of Sciences, consists mainly of engineers and consultants who have worked for the auto and oil industries, along with some economists and retired oil executives. It does not include anyone from the environmental movement. Indeed, environmental and consumer groups have in recent months criticized the panel, fearing it would be biased toward the auto industry. 
The government has not raised fuel economy standards significantly since 1984. Ford Motor, General Motors and DaimlerChrysler have all pledged to improve the mileage of their sport utility vehicles. And a House subcommittee voted last week for a small increase in fuel economy standards for sport utility vehicles, pickups and minivans. 
But the federal panel argues that considerably greater improvements can be made without penalizing drivers financially, if the savings on gasoline are counted. 
The report does not recommend specific improvements in miles per gallon. But it states among its findings that the fuel economy of new vehicles, especially sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks, could be raised by as much as 8 to 11 miles a gallon over the next 6 to 10 years, with the extra cost offset by the savings on gasoline over the typical 14-year life of the vehicle.
The report also takes aim at the way automakers have taken advantage of rules intended to encourage the use of ethanol. G.M., Ford and DaimlerChrysler are now producing close to a million vehicles that can burn either gasoline or nearly pure ethanol, so as to qualify for fuel-economy credits that allow these vehicles to count as though they achieved double or triple the fuel economy they actually produce.
Yet virtually none of these vehicles actually burn ethanol. Barely 1 in 1,000 service stations sell nearly pure ethanol and automakers have made little effort to tell consumers that they have bought vehicles that could burn nearly pure ethanol.
The report recommends that "credits for dual-fuel vehicles should be eliminated, with a long enough lead time to limit adverse financial impacts on the automotive industry."
A copy of the report's lengthy executive summary, 14 findings and six recommendations was provided to The New York Times by a person who wanted to make sure that the report received wide attention. The panel, headed by Paul R. Portney, an economist who is the president of a nonprofit research firm, has kept secret the entire draft report.
Claire Buchan, deputy White House press secretary, said that the White House did not have a copy of the report but that the president had said Transportation Secretary Norman Y. Mineta would advise him on whether and how to change fuel economy standards, after giving due consideration not only to the report but also to passenger safety, economic effects and the American auto industry's competitiveness. 
Chet Lunner, a spokesman for the Transportation Department, which administers fuel-economy rules, declined to comment, saying the panel had not briefed the agency.
Gloria Bergquist, a spokeswoman for the Alliance of Automobile Manufacturers, declined to comment on the report, saying that automakers had been unable to obtain a copy. But automakers are generally worried that while it might be technologically possible to build higher-mileage vehicles, consumer demand for such vehicles has been weak, she said.
The auto industry has also argued that making vehicles more fuel-efficient will make them less safe because they might have to be lighter.
But the panel's report is optimistic that new engine technologies can produce fuel-efficiency savings without compromising safety, and notes that safety may actually be improved if automakers are forced to reduce the bulk of the largest sport utilities and pickups, which are especially deadly to other motorists. "Significant fuel economy gains in all vehicles can be achieved with minimal or no weight reduction and therefore minimal negative safety implications," the draft report said.
The report mentions that rapid increases in fuel economy standards for cars in the early 1980's may have contributed to thousands of additional deaths, as automakers sharply reduced the size and weight of vehicles instead of improving their engines. But making large sport utilities lighter may make roads safer by reducing the death rate of other motorists, federal research has found.
The report says that improved fuel economy is possible through the widespread introduction of engine technologies like variable valve timing, which offers greater precision in the combustion of gasoline, and integrated starter-generators, which electrically assist a gasoline engine. Many of these new technologies are now available on sports cars, and Ford has committed itself to introducing integrated starter-generators on Explorer sport utilities as part of the automaker's plan to increase the average fuel economy of its sport utilities by 5 miles a gallon by 2005.
But the report cautions that the large gains in fuel economy that the panel foresees will occur only if all the efficiency provided by these innovations is used to improve gas mileage. Automakers improved engines in the 1990's, but used the improvements to manufacture ever larger and heavier vehicles, notably sport utilities, and to improve acceleration. So instead of improving, the average fuel economy of vehicles sold in the United States has actually been falling for more than a decade.
The draft report says regulation would be the most effective way to achieve gains, while stopping short of recommending fuel-economy targets. "Selection of a new fuel economy target will require uncertain and difficult trade-offs among environmental benefits, safety, costs, oil import dependence, and consumer preferences, trade-offs the committee believes rightfully reside with elected officials," the report said.
Regulation is needed in part because vehicles with poor fuel economy contribute disproportionately to global warming and the nation's reliance on imported oil, yet these problems affect all Americans, not just those buying the inefficient vehicles, the report says. 
The draft report also recommends an overhaul of the current system of fuel-economy regulation, which requires each automaker to produce cars with an average fuel economy of 27.5 miles a gallon and light trucks with an average fuel economy of 20.7 miles a gallon. The report says that this system could be made more efficient by allowing automakers to trade fuel-economy credits, with automakers that don't meet the standards paying those that do. This idea, favored by many economists, is similar to a system that already allows electric utilities to trade air-pollution credits.
More lenient fuel economy standards for light trucks date back to the 1970's, when these vehicles were mostly pickups used by farmers and small businesses. One of the report's findings criticizes automakers for marketing sport utilities and minivans as substitutes for cars, while designing them so as to continue to qualify as light trucks for fuel-economy purposes.
"The car/truck distinction has been stretched well beyond the original purpose," the report says.

HEADLINE: Bush Forgoes Trying to Bar Cuba Deals By Foreigners 

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER MARQUIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 16 

 BODY:
In a setback for the Cuban exile lobby and its Congressional allies, President Bush said today that he would not activate the harshest sanction of a law that seeks to punish foreigners for investing in property in Cuba that was confiscated by the Havana government.
 The sanction, Title III of the Helms-Burton Act of 1996, would allow American corporations and citizens to sue foreign companies that use the expropriated properties for profit. 
 Mr. Bush said in a statement that his decision was "necessary for the national interest of the United States and will expedite the transition to democracy in Cuba." It appears to be aimed in part at avoiding a battle with European countries, which are critical of his policies on missile defense and global warming and see Helms-Burton as the United States legislating beyond its borders. 
President Clinton waived the Title III provision throughout his second term.
Mr. Bush's decision raises the likelihood that the full force of Helms-Burton will never take effect, Cuba experts said.
"If Clinton never imposed it, and this Republican president isn't going to, it's basically a dead letter," said Philip Peters, vice president of the Lexington Institute, a research organization that promotes market ideology.
Hard-line critics of the Cuban president, Fidel Castro, expressed dismay at the suspension, but they were quick to say Mr. Bush's approach to Cuba was preferable to Mr. Clinton's more conciliatory stance.
"Certainly before anybody jumps on the president for this six-month suspension, it would be wise to consider the other salutary initiatives that the president is putting into force," said Senator Jesse Helms, a chief sponsor of the bill and the ranking Republican on the Foreign Relations Committee. "The president is, in fact, taking a very tough line, which is certain to make Fidel Castro squirm."
Mr. Bush on Friday announced plans to strengthen the trade embargo by enforcing limits on cash payments that Cuban-Americans may send their relatives on the island and preventing American tourists from going there. He ordered officials to "use all available means" to overcome Havana's jamming of United States government broadcasts and promised additional support for human rights activists and dissidents.
Commenting on the Title III suspension, Dennis Hays, vice president of the Cuban-American National Foundation, the largest exile lobby, said, "We understand that the president has a bigger picture in mind, and we're prepared to accept his judgment that now is not the time."
Still, Democratic critics of Helms-Burton appeared to relish Mr. Bush's predicament. He is determined to pay back Cuban-American supporters, they said, but is worried about stirring an international furor that could haunt him in other policy arenas.

HEADLINE: Hughes Posts Wider Loss For Quarter 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: EL SEGUNDO, Calif., July 16 

 BODY:
Hughes Electronics, which runs the satellite service DirecTV, lost $156.5 million in the second quarter, more than twice as much as last year despite an 8.1 percent rise in revenue, the company said today.
 Hughes also lowered its 2001 revenue projections for the second time in less than two months. Five weeks ago, it warned that sales for the year would be lower than expected because of a sluggish economy. 
 The company now expects revenue for the year of $8.3 billion, down from an earlier projection of $8.7 billion, analysts said.
In a conference call with analysts, Jack Shaw, the chief executive, said only that the earlier estimate did not "fully reflect the issues and market conditions facing our business."
The earnings report comes as a potential suitor for Hughes, EchoStar Communications, has reportedly withdrawn from the bidding.
Hughes's controlling shareowner, General Motors, would like to sell Hughes and concentrate on its core auto-making business.
Hughes shares were down $1.59, to $18.86.
Hughes loss of $156.5 million for the second quarter was larger than its loss of $69.1 million in the corresponding period a year earlier.
The bigger loss was attributed partly to higher expenses related to the growth in customer leased set-top boxes in Latin America and the United States and a larger satellite fleet.
Revenue for the quarter was $1.99 billion, up from $1.84 billion.
The company's DirecTV service is the leading provider of satellite television services, with 9.5 million subscribers. DirecTV also provides high-speed Internet access.
But EchoStar, based in Littleton, Colo., has been doing a better job of marketing and signing up new customers for months, said Matthew Harrigan of Janco Partners in Denver.
The Wall Street Journal reported today that EchoStar was was planning to abandon its bid to acquire Hughes. EchoStar is the No. 2 satellite communications provider with five million customers.
G. M. said today that it was moving forward in talks with the News Corporation to sell Hughes.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; 
Blurring Borders in the New World

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. OSHINSKY; David M. Oshinsky is a professor of history at Rutgers University.

 BODY:
HERE
A Biography of
the New American Continent
By Anthony DePalma
375 pages. PublicAffairs. $26
 Americans seem indifferent to the phenomenon of globalization. Living within secure borders, sheltered by their country's immense military, economic and cultural power, they show little interest in exploring the connections between other societies and their own. Most Americans see no need to learn a second language, obtain a passport or focus on international events. They are detached from the world, it appears, because they don't believe anything foreign can seriously touch their lives. 
 And that applies to North America as well. In the United States, writes Anthony DePalma in "Here: A Biography of the New American Continent," people "rarely are conscious that they share this continent with anyone." Americans tend to view Mexico as a nation of banditos and mariachi bands, a giant banana republic connected to Latin America by culture and blood. Canada fares a little better, appearing, to American eyes, as a vast, frozen appendage of the United States -- scenic, friendly and dull. Its dubious claim to nationhood is nicely captured in a popular survey of American colleges, which praises the University of Notre Dame for recruiting students "from 50 states, 40 foreign countries, and Canada." Sometimes the unintended insult says the most.
It would be hard to find a surer guide to the new American continent than Mr. DePalma, who was a correspondent for The New York Times in Mexico and then in Canada from 1993 to 1999. Both countries came alive in these years, shedding their image as journalistic backwaters. In Mexico, Mr. DePalma reported on the violent drug wars, the ballooning debt crisis, the assassination of a leading presidential candidate and the armed revolt in Chiapas, the poorest state in the country. In Canada, he arrived in time to see the nation confront its fragile identity over the referendum on Quebec's secession.
Yet no event, Mr. DePalma says, was more significant than passage of the North American Free Trade Agreement in 1993. Blending a rich history of the continent with a sharp eye for cultural observation, he shows how the leaders of Mexico, Canada and the United States overcame generations of prejudice and exploitation to devise a common economic strategy based on free trade, open borders and mutual respect. Many were alarmed by the agreement, of course. Nafta "caused tremors in each country," Mr. DePalma writes, "but the fears each nation felt were something different."
Mexico presented the greatest challenge. The tremendous poverty, political corruption, class consciousness and religious orthodoxy made economic reform a chore. Foreign business executives complained about a culture in which time was viewed as fluid, not fixed, and deadlines were treated as guidelines. Mexico appeared to be caught between two identities: one looking to the complex modern world, the other yearning for a romantic agrarian past.
Its economy was in disarray. As an oil-producing nation, Mexico experienced the boom of the 1970's and the bust of the 1980's, which led it to default on its debts. Foreign investors shied away. Mexican industry, protected for decades by high tariffs, churned out shoddy goods. The leading export from Mexico seemed to be its own people crossing the northern border in a desperate search for jobs. Campaigning for Nafta, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari confronted American officials with the obvious question: "Where do you want Mexicans to work, in Mexico or in the United States?"
Canada faced different concerns, Mr. DePalma says, and culture played the central role. Unlike the United States, where individual rights take precedence over community norms, Canada cherishes order, civility and the public good. The United Nation's quality-of-life rankings -- which include such things as health care, literacy rates and life expectancy -- place Canada at the top. Yet these benefits did not come cheaply. In seeking consensus and social comfort, Mr. DePalma notes, Canadians sacrificed the opportunities for personal advancement and creativity that are hallmarks of American-style competition. As a result free trade was long viewed as an alien concept in Canada, where people grew up believing in the virtues of collectivism and government protection.
It was not simply their economy that seemed vulnerable. What Canada feared most about Nafta was the likelihood of a cultural meltdown, with Canadian radio, television, film and music forced to compete in an open market. Some Canadians demanded that Nafta include "cultural exemptions" to limit American media competition, as if that were possible in the age of the Internet and satellite television.
Others held conferences to bemoan the crisis of Canadian identity, with Yankees carefully excluded. The problem, Mr. DePalma says, is that the participants, mostly academics, spent their time scrutinizing the differences between Canada and the United States, thereby defining Canadian culture in terms of "what it is not rather than what it is." Canadians, he adds, can be masters at turning "self-flagellation into a national pastime."
Largely absent from "Here" is the view from inside the United States. We are reminded that President Clinton's successful bailout of the Mexican economy faced ferocious Congressional opposition and that the major domestic worry about Nafta -- famously described by Ross Perot as "a giant sucking sound" of American jobs draining into Mexico -- proved groundless. Unfortunately, Mr. DePalma does not examine the impact of free trade and open borders on American culture with the same care he gives to developments in Mexico and Canada. And he largely ignores the effect of recent immigration in broadening or perhaps hardening American attitudes toward globalization.
Mr. DePalma ends his elegant journey on an optimistic note. The economies of Mexico and Canada are stronger than before. Mr. DePalma contends that the openness required by free trade has lessened corruption in Mexico and increased the pressure for democratic reforms. In Canada, he writes, "corporations were forced to streamline," and the government followed suit, providing the first balanced budget in nearly 30 years. For Mexicans the major issue today is the creation of high-wage jobs; for Canadians it is the ability to stay competitive while retaining their generous welfare safety net. And for North Americans, Mr. DePalma concludes, it is the willingness to become "a community of shared interest, common dreams and coordinated responses to problems that have no regard for borders."
