HEADLINE: Minimum Wage Can Be Bumped Above Minimal 

BYLINE:  By DAVID KOEPPEL 

 BODY:
Another exhausting eight-hour shift had ended for Mussie Habetezion, a garage attendant, but his workday was far from over. He still had to endure an eight-hour overnight shift at the local 7-Eleven. On the days he didn't work at the 7-Eleven, he held a third job at a CVS Pharmacy.
 When a customer spotted Mr. Habetezion at all three jobs in a single week, she was flabbergasted. "She saw me at the garage, the CVS and the 7-Eleven and said, 'Oh my Lord, don't you ever sleep?' " he said. "I said that's all I have time to do." 
 The 28-year old Mr. Habetezion came to Alexandria, Va., from the eastern African nation of Eritrea four years ago, hoping to go to college. But he spoke little English and was nearly broke, so he gravitated to low-paying jobs, first at the convenience store and then at the parking garage.
Earning the federal minimum wage of $5.15 an hour, he struggled to pay the rent, maintain insurance on his 1978 Oldsmobile and save for his education. Like millions of other Americans, he was compelled to take additional low-paying jobs to make ends meet, and the American dream seemed to be fading.
Then, last October, Mr. Habetezion's life took a turn for the better. An ordinance had recently been passed in Alexandria that required all contractors providing services on city property to pay their employees a minimum $9.84 an hour. (The rate has since been raised to $10.21.) As a result, his salary at the garage nearly doubled, allowing him to quit one of his part-time jobs, buy a computer and begin taking a word-processing class at a local college. He hopes the work will lead him to a better job.
For his change in fortunes, he has a nascent crusade known as the living-wage movement to thank. Baltimore passed the first living-wage ordinance in 1994, an initiative that has grown into a grass-roots campaign to raise the minimum wage to a level that can actually pay for life's necessities. By the Federal Government's own figuring, the breadwinner in a family of four would have to earn $17,650, or $8.49 an hour, to escape poverty, and a living wage of around $10 or so would add a small cushion.
So far, more than 60 municipalities and counties in the United States have passed living-wage ordinances and about 75 others are contemplating them, according to Jen Kern, the director of the Living Wage Resource Center of the Association of Community Organization for Reform Now in Washington, known as Acorn, an important force in the movement. The laws generally cover workers at businesses that have contracted with a city or county government.
To be sure, 60 is a tiny fraction of the local governments in America, but proponents say the movement is gaining momentum, especially after a nationally publicized sit-in at Harvard in April by students demanding a living wage for university workers.
The movement has its critics, who warn it could lead to job losses for unskilled workers, saddle businesses with higher costs and worsen inflation. "When these laws are broad enough, there will be harmful effects on business," said Richard Toikka, the chief economist for the Employment Policies Institute in Washington, a nonprofit research organization. "It would hurt people going from welfare to work who really have no track record to get hired." Instead, the institute supports the earned-income tax credit, which he said "targets the families most in need."
In the workplace trenches, however, a pay increase that might be small change for most white-collar workers is bringing hope to impoverished Americans. "There's a big difference, but it's not all in terms of dollars and cents," said Makonen Hastemarian, 68, another parking-lot attendant in Alexandria whose hourly wage has risen to $10.21 from $7. "Now I'm only working one job, and the main thing is I get to have time with my wife and my children. Sometimes I go to the theater or a concert. These things give some meaning to life."
Mr. Hastemarian came to the United States eight years ago from Ethiopia, where he had been a grade-school teacher. His recent pay increase won't permit him to retire anytime soon, or pay much toward the cost of sending his two daughters to Virginia Tech. But it does give him time to pursue his ambition of writing his autobiography.
And what of the great majority of unskilled workers in America who don't fall under a living-wage law? Most would probably agree on one thing: It is impossible to get by on $5.15 an hour or even a dollar or two more.
Consider Charlsetta Cowan, 42, and her 20-year-old daughter Llanicia in Little Rock, Ark., where a living-wage ordinance is being debated. Llanicia Cowan, a single mother who earns $6.50 an hour doing clerical work for the city's parks department, says she can barely afford to buy Pampers for her baby daughter, much less clothing for herself.
Charlsetta Cowan, meantime, quit a $6-an-hour job as a motel clerk in May because of high blood pressure that her doctor warned could trigger a stroke. She recently returned to work as a medical-records agent at a local hospital that pays $6.79 an hour. 
She has no savings, and is trying to support three of her eight children (not including Llanicia) in a residential hotel that charges her $133 a week for a one-bedroom apartment. In recent months, she's been accepting handouts from friends and family and relying on her church pantry to provide many of her family's meals.
"This is my lowest point," Ms. Cowan said. "There's no way to save anything. You can't run a household on $6 an hour. I'm basically concerned with today. I'm hoping and praying tomorrow will be better."
Or consider Jerome Eiledge, 36, a divorced father of two in Houston. Mr. Eiledge earns the minimum wage cleaning office buildings on weekends and takes care of his daughters during the week. After a tropical storm destroyed the trailer park where they lived, the family took refuge at a friend's apartment.
Now and then, Mr. Eiledge lands construction jobs that pay well, but he has never been able to set aside enough money to travel with his daughters to visit family members in Illinois and Utah. Instead, he settles on trips to a McDonald's playground.
Even so, he tries to strike an optimistic note. "I look around," he said. "There are a lot of people in worse shape."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The pay of Makonen Hastemarian, a parking-lot attendant in Alexandria, Va., has risen more than $3 a hour under the living wage. (Linda Spillers for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Royal Philips Plans to Cut 4,000 Jobs 

BYLINE:  By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON, July 17 

 BODY:
In a further sign of the slowdown cascading over Europe from the United States, Royal Philips Electronics of the Netherlands, the Continent's leading electronics manufacturer, said today that it would shed a further 4,000 jobs, bringing its total for the year to more than 10,000.
 The chief executive, Gerard Kleisterlee, made the announcement as the company reported a second-quarter loss, excluding one-time items, of 348 million euros ($298 million), in contrast to a profit of 699 million euros in the period last year. 
 Including special charges and one-time gains, the figures showed an even more alarming slump from a second-quarter profit last year of 3.6 billion euros, when the company benefited from disposals, to a net loss of 770 million euros. 
One month ago, the company said it expected a significant loss in the second quarter, but the figure was higher than some analysts' forecasts and Philips shares dropped as much as 5.7 percent. The shares are down 27 percent so far this year. The fall weighed on European stock markets that were bracing to see whether Intel would add to the gloom in technology when it released its earnings report later today. 
Philips is suffering as economic growth stalls in most of its markets around the globe, particularly in Europe, forcing clients to cut back on purchases of computers, mobile phones, televisions and other consumer electronics products using semiconductors. It said its consumer electronics sales fell 18 percent in the second quarter while chip sales were down 19 percent and components fell 40 percent.
The company has already signaled its desire to reduce its money-losing mobile phone business, contributing to an earlier 7,000 job cuts in the divisions that make cell phones and television screens. Including the layoffs announced today, the job losses account for about 5 percent of the work force.
While the semiconductor business is seen as prone to up-and-down cycles, "the trough we are looking at is further down than in previous times," said Navdeep Sheera of Schroder Salomon Smith Barney.
The latest cuts will affect workers in Philips's semiconductor business and will cost the company about $255 million in the second half, adding to other layoff costs expected to total around $850 million for the year, even as earnings continue to fall.
"We remain very cautious about the economic development for the rest of the year," Philips said in a statement that echoed most analysts' assessments. "For semiconductors our current expectation is that the industry will not see a recovery before 2002."
According to Jan Hommen, Philips's chief financial officer, third-quarter losses will be about the same, or slightly larger, than in the second quarter. That could lead to the company's first full-year loss in nine years. Philips said it would break even or incur a small loss for the year.

HEADLINE: In Japan, A Steak Secret To Rival Kobe 

BYLINE:  By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: MATSUZAKA, Japan 

 BODY:
I WASN'T sure whether to be insulted or impressed when, seconds after I had stepped out of his barn here, Mikichi Kubo took out a dustpan and broom and swept up after me. The barn is home to six large black cows. Shouldn't I be scraping my shoes instead?
 But the cows housed in Mr. Kubo's barn are not just any old cows. They are Matsuzaka cattle, destined to become what some consider to be the finest beef in Japan. 
 No, this isn't Kobe beef, which in the minds of many Americans is the best in Japan. Cattle from Kobe, Americans have heard, are carefully bred, raised on special feed, even given massages; Kobe steaks are sold for astonishing prices. But here in Japan, Kobe has a rival: Matsuzaka beef, one of this country's best-kept secrets. 
Farmers like Mr. Kubo raise their highly prized cattle in this tiny town, just inland from one of the more spectacular wrinkles in Japan's glorious Pacific coastline, under conditions that a Park Avenue Pekingese might envy. And the meat, densely marbled and butter-tender, is difficult to come by, even in Tokyo, because only 2,500 Matsuzaka cows are slaughtered each year. It commands prices as high as Kobe's -- up to $60 a pound in a meat market, if you can find it. Don't look for Matsuzaka in the United States, where Japanese beef has been banned since March 2000, after an outbreak of hoof-and-mouth disease in southern Japan. 
There is something distinctively different about this beef from coddled virgin cows, its fans say, though myth and mystique may be just as important to how it is regarded as how it tastes. Matsuzaka cows are slaughtered when they are 3 years old, an unusually long life for cows bred for beef. "They are alive longer than any other beef cattle, and that makes a difference in the taste and texture of their meat," said Shizuo Kashiwagi, the owner of a meat market not far from Matsuzaka. "And in the fat." 
For Japanese beef eaters, choosing between Kobe and Matsuzaka beef "is like choosing between Alaska king crab and Maryland crab," said Elizabeth Andoh, an American journalist and the director of a culinary arts center in Tokyo. "It's very much a matter of personal taste, and how you intend to cook it." 
In the few restaurants where it is served in Japan, diners pay dearly. Okahan, an elegant restaurant in Tokyo, serves Matsuzaka beef as part of a sukiyaki or shabu shabu course which includes hors d'oeuvres and side dishes, for 16,000 yen, or $128. A grilled steak costs about $144. Ginza Sato, also in Tokyo, offers fillets grilled over charcoal for $48 and $64. Several other restaurants in Tokyo serve the beef only through orders placed in advance.
"Eating Kobe is like eating foie gras, where Matsuzaka is more like eating beef," recalled Tadashi Ono, the chef and an owner of Sono in Manhattan, who first tasted Matsuzaka beef years ago and found it similar to Kobe beef in taste. He said he might prefer the Matsuzaka, which is very fatty, for cooking because it had a beefier flavor.
In the beef-mystique war, Kobe may have gained the upper hand through an accident of geography. "Kobe is a port city," said Takeo Matsuda, whose family raises 1,800 Matsuzaka cows on its farms here and has a restaurant, Wadakin, that is probably the most famous purveyor of Matsuzaka beef. "Ships stopping to pick up food and water soon learned that there were good beef cattle on the outskirts of the city, and they carried the news with them."
There is no port in Matsuzaka, which may be why its beef has remained a secret, known perhaps to global gourmands but few others outside Japan. Mr. Matsuda's great-great-grandfather produced the first of what has come to be called Matsuzaka beef and if a cow isn't raised here, it cannot lay claim to the pedigree. 
At the height of Japan's economic bubble in 1989, the championship cow in the annual Matsuzaka competition sold for about $392,000 at current exchange rates. 
"Anyplace in the world would consider that to be a high price," said Chuck Lambert, chief economist of the National Cattlemen's Beef Association in Washington.
The best cows still command prices that impress beef cattle producers everywhere. Last year, when Japan was sliding into yet another recession, the champion sold for $81,600.
But putting a finger on what distinguishes Matsuzaka from Kobe and other top-quality beef "brands" like Maeda and Omi, is tricky. Other top-quality beef cattle also get massages from time to time and may drink beer.
Matsuzaka's stature is built largely on its excellent quality but is also enhanced and reinforced by myth. For instance, before I arrived in Japan four years ago, I had heard that Matsuzaka cows not only received massages and tippled beer, but also listened to Mozart piped into their barns. The music turned out to be a tall tale, but one that continues to circulate nevertheless.
Mr. Kubo, the farmer, says the secret is largely genetic. Matsuzaka, Kobe and other fine beef cattle come from breeders in the Tajima Valley, some 150 kilometers from Matsuzaka. Tajima is the home of Japanese wagyu, or beef cattle, which, legend has it, journeyed to Japan from the Korean peninsula in the company of Ame-no-Hiboko, a local divinity, in the fifth century B.C. Elsewhere in Japan, the four breeds of wagyu -- black, red, no-horn and shorthorn -- have been bred with cattle imported from Europe and the United States. But the lineage of Tajima cows is carefully protected. Each of Mr. Kubo's cows has papers, stamped with a nose print, that trace its bloodlines back several generations. 
Mr. Kubo, however, cannot comment on the beef's taste because he does not eat it -- he becomes too attached to his cows. "They are domestic animals, I know, and they are raised to be eaten," Mr. Kubo said. "But the thought gives me a very bad feeling."
Mr. Matsuda said he thought the difference between Matsuzaka and other beef was "climate and water -- that's all." Indeed, many say that Matsuzaka's reputation is built on little more than mystique.
"There is not a huge difference between Matsuzaka and Kobe beef," said Asako Kishi of Tokyo, a well-known food critic and writer. "Both are high-quality meats, with lots of very evenly distributed marbling." She said that if anything distinguishes Matsuzaka, it is that even though the meat is riddled with fat, one tastes the flavor and feels the texture of the meat only.
Mr. Kashiwagi, the founder and owner of Asahiya, a big, bustling, old-fashioned meat market just north of here in Tsu, insists that the virginity of the cows is a deciding factor in Matsuzaka's supremacy. Kobe and other fine beef comes from steers, as well as cows whose virginity is not so carefully guarded. 'It's the virginity," he said. "That, and their age."
But it is difficult for a visitor to see the nurturing the cows receive and not think it contributes something to their distinction. Before entering one of the barns where the Matsuda family's cows reside, I had to take off my shoes, put on a pair of pristine white rubber boots, walk through disinfectant and wash my hands. "Hoof-and-mouth," the manager explained.
At Mr. Kubo's farm, electric fans were running in the barns but not in his house, which has no air-conditioning. The brilliant sunshine pounded down on the rice paddies and fields, but the cows were all inside the barns. "Too hot," he explained. "They're black, you see."
Exercise is not encouraged. "The most important thing is, at an early stage the cow must eat a lot of high-fiber foods like hay, wheat bran, corn and soybean byproducts," he said. "That stretches the stomach and makes it big."
To encourage his cows to eat even more, Mr. Kubo, like other Matsuzaka cow owners, sees that they guzzle beer every week. Some cows develop a taste for it, others have to be force-fed.
Each of his cows has her own stall of roughly 17 square feet. The rails that form the stalls are made of wood and wooden pegs, and the water troughs are plastic, not metal. "They might scratch themselves on metal," Mr. Kubo explained.
All this pampering is expensive, so Mr. Kubo supplements his income by trimming the hooves and horns of other farmers' animals. This sideline is a necessity: his income swings wildly, depending on whether he produces a championship cow. Matsuzaka cows that are not among the final 50 contestants in the annual competition sell for about $9,600. "It's gambling," Mr. Kubo said.
Each fall, he and his wife travel to Tajima and select five or six heifers that are about 8 months old to raise, or rather, spoil rotten in Matsuzaka. For the next few years, they are treated to "massages," rubdowns with a stiff brush, every other day or so, a practice said to enhance the even distribution of fat throughout their bodies.
Matsuzaka cows become so accustomed to human attention and affection -- Mr. Kubo's cows stick their heads through the slats of their stalls and all but ask to be petted -- that they are led quite easily to the slaughterhouse, a trip that other, less coddled cattle vigorously resist.
The Cadillac treatment is expensive, and raising Matsuzaka cows is to some degree a labor of love, even for large producers like the Matsuda family. They make money because they sell virtually all of their stock through their restaurant.
The calves Mr. Kubo buys in Tajima cost between $6,400 and $6,800, and he figures he spends $3,200 to $4,000 on each one over her lifetime. Unless he produces potential champions, he cannot make a profit. No wonder, then, that most farmers raise only a couple of heifers at a time.
The annual November competition is the event of the year here. Getting into the final round is very often the difference between make or break for farmers like Mr. Kubo: finalists will fetch around $24,000 apiece.
Many of the finalists end up behind the counter at Asahiya, Mr. Kashiwagi's shop. Between 1990 and 2000, Mr. Kashiwagi purchased nine of the last 10 Matsuzaka champions, paying a total of $858,000 at current exchange rates. "I don't make money on these cows, that's not why I spend like this to get the champion," he said. "I try to drive prices up to encourage the producers to keep producing great beef cows. It's not such easy work, raising a Matsuzaka cow."
The day before I visited his shop, he had purchased a side of Matsuzaka beef, and he had his workers pull it out of the cold storage room. They sawed it open to reveal the thickly marbled meat, surrounded by layers of fat so white it could have been coconut. "Look," Mr. Kashiwagi urged. "Have you ever seen anything like it?"
He figured that the side would produce about 220 pieces of meat and that all of it would be sold before noon the next day. The most lucrative part of the cow will be the innards, or offal. Brains, in particular, are the source of much of the concern outside Japan about bovine spongiform encephalopathy, or mad cow disease.
"We don't have worries about that here," Mr. Kashiwagi said. "People like the offal because it provides the best indication of the health of the cow it came from."
I tried four different kinds of Matsuzaka steak at Wadakin and found it very, very good, even though I prefer my meat lean. You do not taste or feel the fat when you chew; it's very flavorful. My one complaint is that you can't eat a lot if it; it's too rich.
Mr. Matsuda of Wadakin believes, however, that standards for beef are slipping in Japan, as more and more regional beef comes onto the market and cheaper, imported meat is more readily available. "Even in Japan, people don't really know what's good beef any more," he said. 
"They think anything soft is prime beef, but that's just one criterion. The fat must be sweet, and the red meat must have the power to retain the juices."
His cows eat a custom-blended diet of wheat, soybean byproducts, hay and corn. "The basic ingredients are the same everywhere," Mr. Matsuda said. "The difference is in how they are blended, and that's our special and secret formula." 
But there is no such formula for blending the top-secret feeds, beer, massages and tender-loving care that go into the raising of Matsuzaka cows. "The bottom line," said Mr. Kubo, "is that you just don't know if a champion's a champion until you slaughter it."

HEADLINE: Colorado Sues Payday Lender Over Rates 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: DENVER, July 17 

 BODY:
The State of Colorado has sued a check-cashing chain, accusing it of violating state law and charging steep interest rates for payday loans to mostly poor clients.
 The lawsuit also accused the company, ACE Cash Express Inc., of operating in Colorado without a license. 
The company, based in Irving, Tex., has 50 stores in the state. 
 Eric Norrington, a vice president at ACE, declined to comment until he had read the lawsuit. 
With payday lending, a client might collect a loan of up to $500 in exchange for a personal postdated check for that amount, plus a 20 percent, or $100, surcharge. The lender will not redeem the check until the client's next payday, or up to 14 days. 
ACE and other payday lenders say they are doing nothing wrong and are providing a valuable service to low-income workers. Fees and surcharges can amount to a 442 percent annual rate. 
Colorado requires such lenders to be licensed and caps loans at $500. They cannot charge more than 20 percent for the first $300 and 7.5 percent for the next $200. 
For a 14-day $500 loan, that means a $75 fee, the equivalent of a 391 percent annual rate.

HEADLINE: Political Climate Complicates Food Shortage in Zimbabwe 

BYLINE:  By HENRI E. CAUVIN 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, July 17 

 BODY:
Zimbabwe faces a food shortage in the coming months, and while such shortages are not unknown in the country, this time the reasons behind it -- and the ways out of it -- are especially complex, aid officials say.
 Other shortages, such as the one in 1998 when Zimbabwe needed to import about 400,000 metric tons of corn, have not crippled the country, and typically, this year's projected shortfall of 447,000 tons would not have been cause for too much alarm either, officials say. 
 Zimbabwe, however, is hardly the same place it was even a few years ago. With its economy a wreck, the country is in no position to help itself. With its president, Robert Mugabe, the object of scorn in Western capitals because of his suppression of the political opposition and his support of farm seizures, Zimbabwe is isolated from the very countries that would be expected to come to its aid. 
"In normal circumstances, this should be manageable, but I don't think we're talking of normal circumstances," Elliot Vhurumuku of the Famine Early Warning System Network said in a telephone interview from the capital, Harare.
The shortfall is one result of a confluence of factors: some parts of the country were still struggling this year to recover from major flooding in early 2000, and many, especially in the south and east, endured erratic rainfall patterns. The planting of corn, the country's staple food, has fallen, driven down by the widespread farm invasions sanctioned by the government and further hurt by the crop's declining price. 
Meanwhile, hard currency, which would ordinarily buy Zimbabwe out of such a poor harvest, is scarce, a result of a big drop-off in tourism and falling production of the country's key exports, tobacco and gold. 
Last week, after months of doing little publicly about the problem, Mr. Mugabe assembled a cabinet task force to oversee the Grain Marketing Board, which controls the import and export of corn.
While encouraged by the government's acknowledgment of the problem, some international aid officials worry that with presidential elections scheduled for early next year, Zimbabwean political leaders will press too hard to keep the price of corn down and end up doing grave damage to agriculture. 
Already, some farmers have been switching to more lucrative crops like soybeans and the pepper plant, from which paprika is derived. If the price of corn is held down too much, many more will abandon it, setting up much bigger shortages next year, the officials say.
Donor nations, including the United States, are monitoring the situation, and while aid officials do not expect the West to withhold aid, the political tension is making communication more complicated.
The United Nations Development Program, which has been charged with coordinating international efforts in Zimbabwe, is serving as a bridge between Mr. Mugabe's government and the West. It is a delicate task; in declining to be interviewed, United Nations officials explained that the working relationships are simply too fragile to put at risk.
Zimbabwe was one of Africa's more stable countries until last year, when its struggling economy went into a free fall as political turmoil grew. But it is still a long way from the food crises that have struck in Angola, Congo and Sudan.
George Heymell, a program adviser for the United Nations World Food Program, said in a telephone interview from regional headquarters in Maputo, Mozambique, "We are not at the point where W.F.P. would have to move in with emergency assistance, and I don't know if we're ever going to get to that point." Still, the agency is not taking chances and is sending in one or two food specialists to help lay the groundwork for any relief effort that might be needed.
Last October, people rioted for three days in the capital and other cities after food prices surged. The country has remained restless. 
Last week the price of bread was doubled for the second time in two months. With the harvest down from last year, and with the foreign currency needed to import food and other essential goods like fuel in short supply, hunger and frustration could become more widespread. 
According to two recent reports, one by the Famine Early Warning System and the other by the World Food Program and the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization, Zimbabwe needs between 200,000 and 600,000 tons of corn and other grains, depending on how deeply the country dips into its reserves. 
Such quantities of food cannot be imported overnight, and that is why, aid officials say, the effort must begin now. "If the moves are taken now," Mr. Vhurumuku said, "there is time to counteract the problem."

HEADLINE: Industrial Output Declined 0.7% in June 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 17 

 BODY:
Production at factories, mines and utilities posted the worst showing since January, falling 0.7 percent last month on top of a 0.5 percent drop in May, the Federal Reserve reported today.
 The latest snapshot of industrial activity was weaker than many analysts were expecting. They were predicting manufacturing activity would decline 0.5 percent in June. 
 "These numbers don't provide any evidence that the bottom has indeed been hit in the factory sector," said Lynn Reaser, chief economist at Banc of America Capital Management.
Operating capacity sank to its lowest point in nearly 18 years as companies throttled back production in the face of sagging demand. The industrial sector operated at 77 percent of capacity in June, compared with 77.6 percent in May.
Many economists say the industrial sector, hardest hit by the slumping economy, has been pulled into a recession of its own. To cope, manufacturers have sharply cut production and shed thousands of workers.
"It's clear that the downturn in manufacturing that began last September has been nearly as severe as the 1990-91 recession," said Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers.
At factories, output fell 0.8 percent in June, after a 0.5 percent decline. The weakness was widespread, with production declining for, among other things, cars and trucks, home electronics and appliances, industrial machinery, semiconductors and metal products. Output of computers and office equipment was flat.
"The manufacturing sector is languishing in pain," said Stan Shipley, an economist at Merrill Lynch.
The Fed report also said that mining production fell 0.4 percent in June, after a 0.1 percent decline. But output at gas and electric utilities rose 0.9 percent, after a 1.7 percent drop in May.
To stave off recession, the Federal Reserve has cut interest rates six times this year, totaling 2.75 percentage points. The rate reductions lower borrowing costs and are aimed at generating consumer spending and business investment, which would rejuvenate economic growth.
Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, will provide Congress with his twice-a-year report on the economy on Wednesday. Many analysts say they think he will deliver a cautiously optimistic assessment and that he may signal that the Fed's latest credit-easing campaign may be coming to a close.
For the second quarter, total industrial output fell at an annual rate of 5.6 percent, after a 6.8 percent rate of decline registered in the first quarter.

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate; 
A Former Hotel Is Being Reborn as Small Offices

BYLINE:  By SANA SIWOLOP 

 BODY:
The owner of the 15-story former Knickerbocker Hotel in Times Square is thinking small: it wants to turn the top seven floors into office space for small tenants.
 One goal is to attract the many service companies that the owner, S. L. Green Realty Corporation, thinks will want to move to Times Square to serve the larger companies that are settling there. 
 Opened in 1906, the Knickerbocker Hotel, at 42nd Street and Broadway, saw its business suffer during Prohibition, and it was converted into office space in 1921.
In 1999, S. L. Green began trying to market the property, which now houses a Gap store, several small retailers and showrooms for some 200 women's sportswear manufacturers, through Lehman Brothers. 
It had hoped to return the building to its onetime role as a hotel. But Steven Durels, a senior vice president of leasing, said the building, at 1466 Broadway, was taken off the market just a few months later. The market had not matured, he said. While large companies like Reuters and Arthur Andersen had made commitments to the neighborhood, they had not yet moved in.
Now, S. L. Green wants to refit a total of 120,000 square feet on the upper floors of the building as office space, while keeping floors three through seven available for showrooms. According to Mr. Durels, the property now houses tenants that lease 500 to 15,000 square feet, but the goal on each of the office floors is to have just three or four tenants, with each renting 2,500 to 7,500 square feet. 
S. L. Green has already cleared Floors 8 through 10. It intends to convert the upper four floors into offices as space becomes available. (There is no 13th floor.)
In the meantime, the company is overhauling the building to include new plumbing, electrical wiring, common areas, central air-conditioning and broadband wiring. 
A new metal and glass canopy has been designed for the Broadway entrance, and the building's lobby is under construction. There, the goal is to do away with the lobby's illuminated plastic ceiling, which Mr. Durels described as vintage 70's, so that it can be replaced with a new barrel-vaulted ceiling similar to the building's original lobby, which was too deteriorated to be restored.
The scaffolding that has shrouded the building for more than two years will come down after the copper mansard roof and the limestone and brick exterior are restored.
Eventually, S. L. Green hopes to reconfigure the retail space. The Gap, which now takes up the ground floor, second floor and basement, recently reopened after expanding to 35,000 square feet, from 15,000 square feet. As for the three or four other small retailers that call the building home, Mr. Durels said that his firm hoped to combine their spaces over the next 18 months, once leases expire, into one 7,000-square-foot unit. 
Mr. Durels said his firm wanted to pursue tenants that prefer to be in the Times Square neighborhood, like small media companies. 
Peter Turchin, a managing director at Insignia/ESG, the real estate services company that is now marketing 1466 Broadway, said: "Times Square has become the area of the haves and the have-nots. The haves are the large tenants which have found new space, but small tenants are looking at properties that haven't been updated."
Mr. Durels said that his company was spending $10 million on the renovations, and would additionally spend about $60 a square foot building office space there. He expects space to become available by mid-September, adding that asking rents will be in the "low $50" range per square foot annually.
That compares favorably with asking rents in Times Square that are now about $60 to $65 a square foot a year, said Hiroshi Nagata, a managing director at Sumitomo Real Estate Sales.
Even so, Mr. Nagata said that S. L. Green might have trouble finding tenants, both because of the softening economy and because of the roughly two million square feet of commercial space that is expected to come onto the market in Times Square during the next two years. Asking prices for top buildings in Times Square have already come down 5 to 10 percent since a year ago, Mr. Nagata said.

HEADLINE: A Bet on Bulgaria Pays Dividends; 
Plants Like American Standard's Bolster the Economy

BYLINE:  By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: SEVLIEVO, Bulgaria 

 BODY:
Much like a Martian spacecraft, a huge new factory that makes porcelain bathroom fixtures is a startling sight on the farmland outside this worn-down city of 25,000 in a remote corner of the Balkans.
 Downtown, an old factory has been refurbished with the latest machines to make chromium-plated brass faucets and other plumbing fixtures. 
 In a village a half-hour drive across pastureland, a third factory -- spanking new, low-slung and painted blue and white -- turns out faucets, door handles and knobs.
All this is a result of the investment of more than $100 million by the American Standard Companies, the conglomerate based in Piscataway, N.J., that makes air-conditioners and auto parts as well as bathroom fixtures.
The business here has made Bulgaria -- a country of slightly more than eight million people that is not often mistaken for an economic powerhouse -- a leading supplier of bathroom fixtures to much of Europe and the Middle East, with brands like Ideal Standard and Jade. 
Such investments are providing the seeds for improvement around the country, which got a fitful start in its shift to an open market economy and is still well behind most other former Soviet bloc countries, like Poland and Hungary. 
But in addition to ranking among the largest foreign investments in Bulgaria, the American Standard presence is one of the few to take development into areas far from the center of government in the capital, Sofia, or the trade and tourism center in Varna, Bulgaria's Black Sea port.
It has certainly been a boon for this struggling region, providing employment as well as galvanizing efforts to transform the local economy. Jobs at the plants are so plentiful that workers have to be bused in by the company from towns as far as 35 miles away, a significant journey for the average Bulgarian.
For American Standard, the factories also represent the company's longest step into the formerly Communist and now rapidly growing Eastern Europe.
"It is definitely among the very successful foreign investments in Bulgaria," said Jean-Marc Peterschmitt, an economist based in Bulgaria for the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development.
Of course, experts say, operating in the Balkans poses many challenges and risks. American Standard must still rely heavily on Western suppliers, for lack of competitive local businesses. And there have been hitches because of the Balkan region's unstable politics.
When war erupted in nearby Kosovo in 1999, disrupting highways through Serbia that American Standard uses to deliver products to Western Europe, alternative routes through Romania and Greece added days to delivery times and increased transportation costs. And the recent fighting in neighboring Macedonia has done little to enhance investment in the region.
Still, the investment has given the company a pool of skilled and inexpensive labor reasonably close to crucial markets in Western Europe and the Middle East, and increasingly elsewhere in Eastern Europe.
The success in Bulgaria is in part attributable to the fact that American Standard bought in gradually, Mr. Peterschmitt said, beginning in 1992 with a joint venture in Sevlievo.
The venture involved American Standard's German unit, Ideal Standard, and the original downtown company -- called Vidima, for a local river -- that had been making bathroom faucets and valves since the 1930's. Nationalized by the Communists after World War II, the shabby Vidima factory was seized after the collapse of Communism in 1989 by a group of young managers, who cast about for investors. They were able to interest American Standard, whose products and managers they knew from trade fairs.
The Vidima plant, which had several dozen workers right after the war, had expanded to about 1,000 employees producing $9 million in revenue by 1992.
Five years later, American Standard had taken full control through several increases in investments, part of the millions it has sunk over the years into refurbishing the old Vidima factory and building the two new ones, the second of which opened in May. The business now provides employment directly for about 3,350 Bulgarians and indirectly for maybe five times that many people, including truck drivers and construction workers. Revenue this year is expected to total $63 million, from a much expanded product line.
"I wanted this job -- it's more in line with what I studied," said Ivailo Kanev, 30, who buffs and polishes brass faucet parts.
Mr. Kanev had gone to a local technical school, but then found work only at a textile factory rinsing newly woven fabric. With overtime, he now earns the equivalent of $175 to $220 a month, compared with $65 to $90 at the textile factory and the country's average wage of $100. This, he said, allows him to provide nicer clothes for his wife and their young daughter, and even take an occasional holiday away from Sevlievo.
Such wages may be a windfall for Mr. Kanev, but they are still a bargain to American Standard. Labor costs here are only about one-tenth of those at the company's factories in Western Europe.
American Standard says it is not just the inexpensive labor that makes Bulgaria attractive. "Geographically it is a good place to be, and the quality of what they make is world class," said Frederic M. Poses, the company's chief executive. "You have people who want to work, who want to be better, who care about their work."
Roughly one-fourth of American Standard's annual revenue of $7.6 billion, or $1.8 billion, comes from bathroom fixtures, and sales in Europe make up about half that amount. The Bulgarian factories are expected to account for around 7 percent of the company's European sales this year.
The return on investment has been rapid and substantial. The $43 million porcelain factory, which opened in 1997, paid itself off in four years, said Vasil Kanev (no relation to Ivailo Kanev), one of the young post-Communist era managers who was recently named chief executive of Eastern Europe operations.
American Standard's business here is very much in line with the policies of the government that took office in 1997 pledging to move the country toward a Western-style market economy. Those policies are expected to be continued by the cabinet that will be formed when the newly elected Parliament assembles next week.
Foreign direct investment in Bulgaria was roughly $1 billion last year, compared with $800 million a year earlier and $537 million in 1998, according to the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. Since the collapse of Communism in 1989, foreign investment per person has reached $407 in Bulgaria, compared with $751 in Poland, Eastern Europe's economic powerhouse, and $303 in neighboring Romania.
Experts like Mr. Peterschmitt of the European Bank agree that projects like the factories here spur local efforts that are helping to transform the overall economy.
And company executives stress their commitment to that process as they also seek to fill American Standard's needs. American Standard helped pay for the extension of gas lines and fiber optic cables to Sevlievo. Two years ago, it opened the city's first hotel, the 40-room Sevlievo Plaza. It is also attracting local talent back to Bulgaria, some of them refugees from the Communist era while others left after the collapse of the Soviet system as the economy stumbled.
Among them is Radoslav Tzankov, 39, who defected to the former West Germany in 1988, a year before the Berlin Wall came down, then made his way to the United States where he worked for a health care company in Provo, Utah. He returned to Bulgaria in 1993, drawn by an offer for a marketing job from American Standard.
"The town has done well on this issue," Mr. Tzankov, now head of logistics, said of American Standard's local investments. Two years ago, he added, Sevlievo even got its own customs office, mainly to handle the company's shipments.
Vasil Kanev, the chief of Eastern Europe operations, said American Standard was focusing on a companywide effort to reduce accidents and breakage rates. According to Tom Thornton, the manager of the Bulgarian porcelain plant, the portion of sinks and toilets that must be smashed as rejects has already dropped, to about 10 percent -- one of the best rates among the company's 47 plumbing factories in 25 countries -- from 36.5 percent last year.
The company has also been trying to draw suppliers to Bulgaria, an effort that is intended to cut costs but that will also benefit the local economy. One major supplier, Gruppo Minerali of Italy, which provides some of the 600 tons of raw materials -- clays, sand and the like -- that the porcelain factory consumes every week, is building a processing plant here. Four other important suppliers, from Germany, Spain and Austria, are expected to establish themselves in Bulgaria this year.
American Standard's stock has remained strong, rising nearly 23 percent so far this year. And analysts generally applaud the company's efforts. "I think they are raising the quality of the total work force, and that has a significant impact on costs as well as quality," said Daniel Noll, who follows the company for Balis Lewittes & Coleman in New York.
The company is not, however, impervious to bumps in the global road. When announcing that first-quarter revenue from bathroom products slipped 1 percent, to $455 million, Mr. Poses attributed the results to deteriorating economic conditions in North America and Europe, where 90 percent of its products are sold. And American Standard wants to increase sales in Eastern Europe, a natural market for the Bulgarian factories, but where the company has yet to make significant headway against local manufacturers or inexpensive Italian competitors.
Still, as Eastern Europe restores housing neglected by decades of Communism and builds new homes for its expanding middle class, the potential is huge. And Mr. Poses stresses that American Standard is in the region for the long haul.
"We started with the understanding that there's a small fixture factory there," Mr. Poses said. "We went, liked what we saw, and believed that with a little help we could make it into a world-class factory. From that beginning, we've had a good start."

HEADLINE: Revenues Rise And Legislators Debate Impact 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 17 

 BODY:
State revenues were strong in the first quarter of the fiscal year, but that was mostly an echo of last year's still-booming economy, officials said today, as all sides said that the new data supported their positions in the state budget fight.
 Over all, the state took in $495 million more than Gov. George E. Pataki had projected for the three months ended June 30, according to his budget office. But all of that was due to personal income tax payments for the year 2000, when the economy grew rapidly. 
 Factoring out last year's income tax payments, revenues for the quarter were above the previous year's, but were actually $210 million below the governor's projections, said Kevin Quinn, a spokesman for the budget office.
"Virtually every indicator of economic activity slowed, and personal income tax withholding for the quarter, estimated tax payments for the quarter and sales tax collections for the quarter were all below projections," he said.
The Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, a Democrat, said the higher-than-expected overall revenues showed that the Republican governor was wrong in trying to restrain state spending this year. Aides to Mr. Pataki and the Republican majority leader of the Senate, Joseph L. Bruno, said the numbers supported their more cautious approach.
The governor, citing the slowing economy, has insisted on staying close to the modest growth in spending reflected in his $86 billion budget proposal. The Assembly Democrats want to spend at least $2 billion more than Mr. Pataki does, including $1.3 billion more on aid to schools. The Republican-controlled Senate has taken a position between the two but closer to the governor's.
New York's budget is already three and a half months overdue. The Senate and Assembly today passed the latest in a series of emergency spending bills intended to keep state government running, this one to last for a week. 

CORRECTION-DATE: July 19, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about New York State's revenues for the three months ended on June 30 misstated the amount by which total revenues exceeded Gov. George E. Pataki's projection. The excess was $285 million, according to the governor's budget office; $495 million was the amount by which just one source of revenue, personal income tax collections, exceeded the projection.

HEADLINE: Panel Says U.S. Spending On Energy Is Paying Off 

BYLINE:  By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 17 

 BODY:
Money that the federal government has put into research and development for energy efficiency and fossil fuel production during the last 22 years has generally been well spent, a National Academy of Sciences committee said today.
 But the study also found that the government had sometimes used inconsistent accounting to keep track of the costs and benefits of that spending. 
 The committee tracked 17 programs on which the Energy Department had spent $13 billion. It found that the programs had produced about $40 billion in benefits, some of which went to individual companies, but others that accrued to society as a whole. For example, technologies that reduced pollution beyond the levels required by law did not increase profits for industry, but saved the public from environmental damage, the report said. 
Other programs produced benefits by demonstrating technologies that were not yet economic but would become useful options should the price of fuel or electricity rise. Others simply expanded knowledge of technology in ways likely to be helpful later, the report said.
"Most people focus on the realized economic benefits," said Jack S. Siegel, who led the group's subcommittee on fossil fuels energy. "We're trying to point out that there are a variety of other benefits, the environmental benefit, the security benefit, and the options benefits, technologies that may sit on the shelf for a while until market conditions change."
While the study said that the Energy Department had not applied uniform methods to track costs and benefits, it found that federal spending was effective in "fragmented" sectors of the economy, in which individual companies could not afford the research investments.
An example the group cited was low-emissivity glass, which keeps infrared energy from passing through and thus helps winter heating and summer cooling. 
Another example it described was refrigerators. Electricity consumption in refrigerators, the largest users of energy in houses that do not have central air conditioning, is down by two-thirds since 1974, though refrigerators have gotten bigger. By providing research and development money, the government could set consumption standards and cut electricity use -- while saving consumers money, the report said.

HEADLINE: Anxiety Rises After Attacks In West Bank And Israel 

BYLINE:  By CLYDE HABERMAN 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, July 17 

 BODY:
The month-old cease-fire between Israel and the Palestinians, more a concept than a reality from the start, seemed shakier than ever today with new violence that included the first Palestinian mortar attack against a Jewish neighborhood on Jerusalem's southern rim.
 For its part, Israel continued its policy of targeted killings when an army helicopter fired missiles on a farmhouse in the West Bank town of Bethlehem, killing four men, two of them described as senior figures in the militant Islamic group Hamas. Late tonight the Israeli Army sent infantry and armored reinforcements to the West Bank. 
 Palestinians called the Bethlehem killings an assassination. Israeli officials characterized them as an "interception," saying the Hamas men had been planning a major terrorist attack soon in nearby Jerusalem. 
Either way, the point is that nothing taking place here has enabled a truce brokered by the United States in mid-June to take root. If anything, the two sides have been sliding backward in the last couple of days.
That was forcefully driven home for Israelis on Monday by a suicide bombing that killed two young soldiers and wounded nine others near a train station in a northern Israeli town, Binyamina. Another militant group, Islamic Holy War, claimed responsibility.
With a mixture of dread and gloom, many Israelis say they feel trapped in a new "war of attrition." That term was used in the late 1960's to describe relentless, almost daily, fighting across the Suez Canal between Israel and Egypt, a decade before they signed a peace treaty.
Only this time, the war hits Israelis right at home, not hundreds of miles away in the Sinai Desert. The Binyamina attack happened to succeed. But the army has reported a series of would-be suicide bombers in recent days, leaving many Israelis sensing that their lives depend for now on the vigilance of their security forces, incompetence by the terrorists and maybe a bit of dumb luck.
And Palestinians are hardly any happier with their lot, which has them trapped by Israeli soldiers in enclaves of the West Bank and Gaza Strip, with little prospect for quick improvement in their shattered economy and their unrealized nationalist hopes.
"A war of attrition is exactly what we're in," said Mark Heller, a senior researcher at the Jaffee Center for Strategic Studies at Tel Aviv University.
"The atmosphere for the last month or so," Mr. Heller said, "has been one of waiting for another shoe to drop. The question is what will it be, and how big a bomb does it take to pull that trigger?"
Few here were surprised that some triggers were clicked today, and then some, in the wake of the Binyamina bombing.
Israel struck first, hitting the Hamas men in Bethlehem. Hours later, a mortar fired from the West Bank landed in Gilo, an area that Israel considers part of Jerusalem. Because it sits on land captured by the Israelis in the 1967 Middle East war, Palestinians deem it a West Bank settlement.
No one was hurt by the mortar round. It landed in the yard of a building that was under construction.
But the important thing was that it had been fired in the first place. Mortar attacks on Israeli towns by Palestinians in the Gaza Strip may have become common in recent months, but this was believed to be the first launched from the West Bank.
It certainly was the first to touch Jerusalem, and it led to long exchanges of fire tonight between Israeli soldiers and Palestinian gunmen in Beit Jala, a town just south of Gilo.
"The mortar attack on Gilo is a clear barrier that has been broken," said Dore Gold, an adviser to Prime Minister Ariel Sharon. An army spokesman called it "a very grave attack," but he declined to say if it meant that yet sterner Israeli reprisals were in store.
Mr. Sharon says he still accepts the cease-fire and is simply waiting for a week of calm to begin a cooling-off period that would be a prelude to real negotiations with Yasir Arafat and his Palestinian Authority. But the Israeli leader is also under pressure from politicians on his right to strike a decisive blow against the Palestinians instead of maintaining the present trend of tit-for-tat reprisals.
Realizing the gravity of the situation, Mr. Arafat reportedly warned Palestinian groups that he wanted no more attacks within Israel's pre-1967 borders. Implicit in that statement was a suggestion that the Palestinian leader looked differently on assaults against Israelis living in West Bank and Gaza settlements.
That is not a distinction shared by Mr. Sharon, nor, polls say, by a strong majority of Israelis.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
INTERNATIONAL PAPER HAS LOSS OF $313 MILLION

BYLINE:  AP 

 BODY:
 The International Paper Company lost $313 million in the second quarter, citing a weak economy, the strong dollar and costs related to closings and a merger. The company, based in Stamford, Conn., reported a loss of 65 cents a share for the April-through-June quarter. 
It had a profit of $270 million, or 64 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Before special and extraordinary items, earnings were $64 million, or 13 cents a share. Analysts estimated a profit of 5 cents a share. Second-quarter sales were $6.7 billion, down from $6.8 billion a year ago. The company has announced 4,000 job cuts since April. Special items included charges for closing installations, $465 million before taxes for severance and $32 million in pretax costs for the acquisition of Champion International in Stamford. The shares rose 77 cents, to $39.

HEADLINE: Metro Business Briefing Apartment Costs Rise; Sales Fall 

BYLINE:  By Terry Pristin (NYT) 

 BODY:
 Despite the softening economy, the average selling price of a Manhattan apartment in the past three months was a record $894,617, an increase of 2 percent over the previous quarter, according to the latest Douglas Elliman Manhattan market overview. In a more striking change, the number of sales declined by 19 percent -- from 2,257 apartments during the second quarter of last year to 1,829 last quarter. 
"The market was surprisingly stable," said Jonathan J. Miller, the president of Miller Samuel, an appraisal company, which prepared the report. "The only cause for concern is the decline in volume." He said sales were down because fewer apartments were on the market and many people were waiting to see what happens to the economy. Terry Pristin (NYT)

HEADLINE: Metro Business Briefing Unemployment, Back In Line 

BYLINE:  AP 

 BODY:
 New Jersey's unemployment rate rose 0.2 percent in June, drawing even with the national rate, state officials said yesterday. 
The June rate was 4.5 percent, compared with 4.3 percent in May, according to statistics released by the State Department of Labor. The national rate in June was also 4.5 percent. In December 1999, New Jersey and the nation both had unemployment rates of 4.1 percent. New Jersey's rate had been lower ever since. The decline was primarily in the goods-producing sector, which includes construction and manufacturing.

HEADLINE: RESTAURANTS; 
A Spirited Cafe Reaches for the Next Decade

BYLINE:  By William Grimes 

 BODY:
AT the upper end of the market, popular Manhattan restaurants tend to live through three stages. At the outset, they make their mark with innovative, high-quality cooking. They bask in the warm glow of flattering reviews. The chef becomes famous. The crowds line up.
 After the first flush of excitement, the restaurant goes about the business of being in business. It does what it does, night after night, and if the kitchen and management are dedicated enough, the energy level and commitment to quality outlive the reviews, even after the founding chef moves on. 
 Eventually, most restaurants enter their third and final stage. The performance begins to sag. The food that seemed innovative now feels a little old hat. The money is still there, so the staff shows up and goes through the motions. It's like "Cats" after the first decade. 
Park Avenue Cafe, which opened to great fanfare in January 1992, is deep into the second phase and showing some signs of crossing the threshold into the third. It's still a good restaurant. When the kitchen is on, it evokes memories of the heady days when David Burke, its chef, made American flavors speak with a new fluency and energy. But after a decade, the restaurant feels a little past its prime.
This does not seem to bother the Upper East Siders who treat it as a beloved neighborhood fixture, a cafe in spirit as well as name, where they can plop down on a banquette, relax in a fully realized J. Crew environment and eat sanely reinterpreted, high-spirited American food. 
Mr. Burke, a distinguished graduate of the River Cafe whose classmates included Charlie Palmer and Larry Forgione, now serves as corporate chef for the Smith & Wollensky Restaurant Group, which owns the restaurant. The menu is his, but his place in the kitchen has been taken by Neil Murphy, formerly of Aureole.
The spirit of the place remains unchanged. The signature "swordchop," one of Mr. Burke's early attention-getters, still holds its place on the menu, a mighty slab of swordfish attached to the collarbone, and it still comes with a numbered tag. The restaurant has served more than 50,000 of them.
A Mediterranean accent now inflects the cooking, a reminder that globalization is creating a borderless free-trade culinary economy in which pasta, to take a prime example, seems as much American or French as it does Italian. The American flag still waves proudly, but fitfully. Two plump quail, surrounded by a bright red slick of chili-fired barbecue sauce and set on a johnnycake, has a Fourth of July picnic feel to it. But it competes with appetizers like artichoke ravioli with arugula, roasted tomatoes and figs wrapped in prosciutto and cavatelli with wild mushrooms and white truffle oil. Both pastas are among the best dishes on the menu. The artichoke filling is suavely creamy, the ravioli casing firm to the bite. The concentrated sugar and salt of the fig and prosciutto work their way into the flavors with a pleasurable insistence.
The cavatelli and mushrooms would easily rate as the most sinfully indulgent experience on the menu if it were not for the formidable terrine of foie gras, served folksy style in a glass jar with fig jam smeared on the hinged lid. This is the whole hog, so to speak. The jar is filled to the brim with pink, chunky, dangerous-looking liver, sealed in place with a nice layer of yellow fat. Only one to a customer, please.
Gazpacho with avocado, with a fierce vinegar burn to it, comes with a crisp roll billed as a shrimp quesadilla, but more like a fried spring roll. It is delicious. A shrimp tail sticks out from each end, making it look like a stylized bull head, which supports the Spanish theme of the dish. Sauteed sweetbreads, not very flavorful and decidedly tough, share plate space with preserved peaches, a tomato-onion salad and an odd truffle-bacon vinaigrette. Many competing flavors add up to one big mess. 
The famous swordchop is still juicy and big-flavored, served with tomato ditalini and lemon broth. It has been joined by a second gimmick dish, Duck, Duck, Duck!, which quick-witted diners will realize is duck prepared three ways, two of them suspect. The roasted breast comes through in fine fashion, but duck meatloaf is obnoxiously herbed with sage and rosemary, and a tall cake of cornmeal wrapped around foie gras mousse has an off-putting richness. 
Richard Leach, the mad scientist whose desserts bristling with sugar antennas and Gehry-esque curved planes put him on the far edge of the architectural school, is still at work. But the productions seem dated now. The pendulum has swung back, and pastry chefs are more likely to aim for the perfect, pared-down apple tart. They taste good, though, especially the cherry tart with almonds and vanilla mascarpone, and the beautifully realized chocolate cube, a thin wall of chocolate containing a solid espresso mousse that you want to move your fork through in slow motion, just for the sensation. 
The restaurant's signature dessert, the admittedly ridiculous Park Avenue Park Bench, really does succeed as theater. With its chocolate slatted bench and leaning lamppost topped by a white chocolate globe, it exudes a strange, twilight melancholy. You almost expect a four-inch Frank Sinatra to stroll over, take a seat and start crooning.
It's a subversive dessert, at odds with the prevailing mood of the restaurant, which looks like a Cracker Barrel made over by Martha Stewart. Fun American folk art enlivens the interior; green checkerboard upholstery and napkins send a wholesome message; and the hapless waiters wear silly ties with a hideous American flag pattern. It's an impressive display of nerdsmanship. While the rest of Manhattan sweats day and night honing its hip edge, the Park Avenue Cafe sails on, like Wrongway Peachfuzz, in the opposite direction. It does what it does, and well enough, to prosper. But the sassy, amusing restaurant of a decade ago is a bit of a plodder now.

HEADLINE: News Corp. Intends to Shed Its Magazine Unit 

BYLINE:  By ALEX KUCZYNSKI 

 BODY:
The downturn in the magazine industry has beaten back one of the giants of worldwide media.
 Two years after financing a magazine intended to test the viability of starting a magazine division, the News Corporation is getting out of the magazine business entirely. Yesterday, Lachlan Murdoch, the company's deputy chief operating officer and the executive in charge of developing the magazine unit, told members of the senior editorial staff at Maximum Golf, the company's one title in the United States, that the magazine was for sale. 
 The decision to sell Maximum Golf comes at a time when the magazine industry is being blitzed with economic stink bombs from all angles, including depressed advertising, increased postal rates, rising paper costs and sinking newsstand sales. A News Corporation executive said that in the current environment the company did not believe it was worth maintaining a magazine publishing infrastructure to publish only one magazine. 
Advertising revenue across American magazines is down 8.2 percent for the month of June, compared with a year ago, according to the Publishers Information Bureau. Leading advertising categories like automotive, technology, media and advertising, finance, real estate, insurance and retail are all down, compared with a year ago. 
The specific depletion of technology advertising -- down by 36 percent in the last year, according to the bureau -- has caused layoffs at almost all the technology and Internet magazines. 
The Industry Standard, published by Standard Media International, plans to announce a third major round of layoffs, possibly before the end of this week, a Standard executive said. Salaries for remaining workers may be reduced as much as 15 percent, the executive said. 
The Industry Standard's advertising pages have dropped 80 percent, to 141 pages for the six months ended in June, from 711 for the period in 2000, according to the Publishers Information Bureau. Revenue is down 72 percent, to $4.2 million from $14.8 million. 
Jonathan Weber, the Industry Standard's editor in chief, said the magazine was in crisis, but not dead. 
"The market continues to be weak, and we are looking at a variety of additional cost-saving measures, but no final decisions have been made," he wrote in an e-mail message yesterday.
Publishing executives across the industry expect advertising revenue to sink through the rest of the year. Newsstand and subscription sales are also down. 
Maximum Golf, which recently raised its guaranteed circulation and had a relatively steady group of endemic advertisers, has two possible buyers. Both AOL Time Warner, whose Time Inc. group publishes over 60 consumer titles, including Golf magazine, and Dennis Publishing, publishers of Maxim, are considering making bids for the magazine in the next two weeks, according to executives at the News Corporation and AOL Time Warner.
Maximum Golf recently raised its rate base to 360,000 from 300,000, and, at a year old, has just filed for its first audit report from the Audit Bureau of Circulations.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 25, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day last Wednesday about the News Corporation's decision to sell Maximum Golf referred incorrectly to the effect on the company's magazine operations. The company will remain in the business through its ownership of The Weekly Standard; it will not leave the business.

HEADLINE: G.M. Registers 73% Decline In Net Income For Quarter 

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation posted a sharp decline in profits yesterday because of rising competition from Asian carmakers, cooling demand for cars in the United States and disappointing sales in Europe.
 Including problems with its Isuzu Motors affiliate in Japan, General Motors said net income for the second quarter slid 73 percent from the period a year earlier. 
 "The quarter was better than our low expectations," said John Casesa, an automotive analyst at Merrill Lynch. "The main reason is that while the consumer is more cautious, he hasn't gone on strike yet and is still buying big trucks." 
For the three months ended June 30 General Motors earned $477 million, or $1.03 a diluted share, compared with earnings of $1.75 billion, or $2.93 a diluted share. 
The results include a one-time charge of $133 million, or 23 cents a share, for Isuzu. General Motors said it would no longer feel the effect of Isuzu's operating losses, having now written down its 49 percent stake in the Japanese company to zero.
Excluding the charge, General Motors earned $610 million, or $1.26 a share. The consensus estimate among analysts had been $1.14 a share. 
General Motors shares, which have risen 32 percent this year, fell $1.05 each on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, closing at $65.99. 
Revenue for the three months fell 5.3 percent, to $46.1 billion, down from $48.7 billion in last year's second quarter. 
In a conference call with analysts and reporters, John Devine, the company's chief financial officer and vice chairman, said that "over all, it was a pretty good quarter." He added, "It wasn't great from an earnings standpoint, but relative to the reduction in output, it was pretty good." 
To deal with bloated dealer inventories, General Motors cut North American production by 13 percent, to 1.36 million cars and light trucks. Those cuts followed a 20 percent reduction in output during the first quarter. Analysts said production was likely to fall a bit further in the current quarter. 
Wendy Needham, a stock analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston, estimates overall automotive output will decline about 6 percent in the third quarter, traditionally Detroit's slowest period. 
"Things are getting better in Detroit," Ms. Needham said, "but they are still down."
David Healy, a stock analyst at Burnham Securities, said that "unless the rest of the economy goes off the end of a cliff, the inventory recession in the auto business is over." 
Ms. Needham and other analysts said they were pleasantly surprised with General Motors' performance in Latin America, Africa and the Middle East, where the company recorded a profit of $31 million. Net income for those regions during the second quarter of last year was just $1 million. 
And GMAC, the company's finance arm, earned a record $449 million, an increase of more than 13 percent from $395 million in the second quarter of 2000.
But the company's European operations continued to be troubled. General Motors lost $154 million in Europe, a sharp deterioration from the $166 million in earnings reported a year earlier. The company cited fierce price competition and an unfavorable product mix.
"We set a metric to improve in Europe in the second half," Mr. Devine said. "We are not at all pleased with our results there." 
He declined to predict when the European operations would return to profitability. 
North American operations, which provide the bulk of General Motors' profits, earned $521 million in the second quarter, compared with $1.4 billion a year earlier. 
Sales in North America fell 12 percent, and net prices were down about 0.8 percent. Intense competition from Asian carmakers, especially the Japanese, is putting downward pressure on prices, Mr. Devine said. 
"In the last six months the yen has weakened 9 percent against the dollar," he said. "We don't want to be crybabies, because we will compete in the marketplace. But this is hurting us." 
To mitigate the price advantage of the Japanese, American automakers have been offering cash incentives of as much as $3,000, crimping profit margins. 
Mr. Casesa said Japan's success had more to do with its products than with the sagging value of the yen. 
"The Japanese story is 80 percent product and 20 percent currency," he said. "They have had an enormous revival."
General Motors' Hughes Electronics unit was another drag on overall performance. Hughes lost $156 million in the second quarter, much greater than the $64 million loss a year earlier. 
Hefty marketing and subscriber-acquisition costs are hindering the satellite unit of Hughes, known as DirecTV, which is up for sale. The largest home satellite television provider in the United States, DirecTV has once again lowered its estimate of net new subscribers for this year. 
General Motors is in negotiations to sell Hughes to the News Corporation. Mr. Devine declined to comment on the status of the discussions.

HEADLINE: Free Trade Has to Be Managed 

BYLINE:  By Jeffrey E. Garten; Jeffrey E. Garten is the dean of the Yale School of Management and author of "The Mind of the C.E.O."

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN 

 BODY:
As the presidents and prime ministers of the seven industrialized nations prepare to gather later this week in Genoa, Italy, the global economy has come to resemble a balloon rapidly losing air. The world's three largest economies -- in the United States, the European Union and Japan -- are slumping, and the financial and trading connections among them are reinforcing the downward spiral. Emerging markets from Argentina to Turkey to Indonesia have serious financial problems, too, all of which are made worse by the slowing of the world's major economies. Corporate profits everywhere are evaporating, and stock markets are weakening.
 The G-7 meeting will be a crucial test for President Bush. Until now, he has said little about the global economy, much less offered any strategy on globalization other than rhetorical support for free trade. This will have to change. The forces that have increased flows of money, goods, services and information around the globe and helped create growth are now working to make the economic downturn deeper and more widespread. 
 Few mechanisms now exist to manage globalization. Cooperation among governments is increasing, but it is still uneven. We live in a world economy, but we lack institutions that could stabilize and regulate this economy. For example, stocks and bonds are traded around the world and around the clock, but there is nothing like a world Securities and Exchange Commission to oversee regulation. Food and pharmaceuticals are traded freely, but there is no global entity to ensure safety standards.
President Bush and the other G-7 leaders have to decide whether they have the foresight to construct new systems that can regulate commerce across borders as well as act to moderate a worldwide recession.
If they fail to build such systems, they face two risks. First, because of the connection of markets and financial systems, if problems in one part of the world are not successfully addressed, they will spread to other parts. In 1998 a currency crisis in Thailand created a financial debacle that engulfed Asia and Latin America and even threatened American banking. Today, the retrenchment of American technology companies has created another kind of contagion. As companies like Cisco, Lucent and Motorola contract their businesses, they cut back on purchases from abroad. That has contributed to a slowdown in the Asian economies, which are heavily dependent on exporting electronic components to the United States. Conversely, because American firms rely heavily on Asia to buy their products, contraction in countries like Singapore, Taiwan and South Korea will make it more difficult for our economy to resume its growth.
The second risk of failing to manage globalization is political. Unfettered market forces can lead to job losses and financial problems that could create a backlash against foreign investment and result in protectionism and overregulation. These developments would hurt our own recovery.
The Bush administration has shown little interest in grappling with these issues. It has demonstrated skepticism about intervening to help developing countries in financial difficulty. It has seemed critical of the attention that previous administrations gave to economic relations with Japan. Faced with rising steel imports, the president has taken steps likely to result in higher tariffs or quotas. 
But in light of the slowing world economy, Mr. Bush will not be able to avoid engaging the issues of globalization for long. He will have no choice but to lead the movement for new global trade negotiations, which will require expending enormous political capital to push Congress to give the administration authority to negotiate trade agreements.
Mr. Bush will also have to work closely with other G-7 leaders to avoid the prospect of a global recession. At minimum, they need to make sure that their policies toward interest rates, currencies, and banking and labor issues will collectively produce enough economic stimulus. They also need to consider how to forestall economic collapse in Argentina.
The recent E.U. veto of the proposed merger between General Electric and Honeywell shows that the administration should push for more coordinated global rules for antitrust policy. It should make aggressive efforts to build a better global system for intellectual property rights.
Finally, the administration and the G-7 nations will have to address the widening divide between rich and poor nations. This means providing more debt relief and increasing humanitarian aid to combat diseases like AIDS, as well as helping to build basic health systems in poor countries. 
This may seem like an ambitious agenda for President Bush, given his administration's reticence about international engagement. But since the end of World War II, every administration has eventually faced up to its international economic responsibilities. Some started early; some were dragged into the fray by events. In view of the precarious economic situation today, the Bush administration cannot wait too long. Genoa would be a good place to make the leap.
