HEADLINE: Senator Says Most Americans Want Controls on Light Arms 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, July 17 

 BODY:
Senator Dianne Feinstein said today that a majority of Americans would not approve of efforts by the United States to derail the talks here on an international agreement to tighten controls on light weapons. 
 Senator Feinstein, a California Democrat, is part of an American delegation to a conference on small arms here. She also said in a telephone interview from Washington that the American gun lobby was presenting other nations with a distorted view of American opinion on gun control. 
 The United States, with both a large gun industry and sound gun-registration laws, should be leading the way in demanding better marking and tracing of weapons worldwide, not trying to block such moves, she said. 
Many of the 189 member nations represented here want an agreement that would make tracking small arms -- from pistols to grenades and light missiles -- easier and more reliable. They would also like at least an admonition against the unrestricted sales of weapons to civilians. 
In a Senate speech on Monday and in the interview today, Senator Feinstein took strong exception to the perception created by Bush administration officials and their supporters here that Americans fear that the United Nations is threatening their right to own guns.
On Monday, Representative Bob Barr, a Georgia Republican and member of the National Rifle Association board, said the United Nations should limit itself to stopping the flow of illegal guns into areas of conflict, or it would risk alienating Congress and would put future payments in jeopardy. 
Congress still owes $582 million it agreed to pay the United Nations to pay part of the back dues the United States owes. By United Nations calculations, the United States now owes the organization more than $1.9 billion. 
"I do not believe that Mr. Barr speaks for a majority of the American people," Ms. Feinstein said today. "I believe he speaks from the National Rifle Association perspective. He certainly doesn't speak for California. It's now well established that Californians want controls on weapons. California has 34 million people -- this isn't a peanut of a state." 
She said that she, and her constituents, would support a treaty that called for international tracing of weapons and openness in gun sales. "So much of the legal sales appear to go into the black market that this transparency becomes extraordinarily important," she said. "There have been too many people killed by these arms."
In her Senate speech on Monday, Ms. Feinstein questioned the Bush administration's position opposing international agreements on the grounds that they could constrain legal American arms sales, which are well policed.
"There is good evidence of an increased incidence of U.S.-manufactured weapons, legally manufactured and legally traded or transferred, flowing into the international black market," she said. 
In 1999, the United States licensed more than $470 million in light weapons for export. The United Nations estimates that there are about 500 million illegally acquired guns and light weapons of other kinds in circulation around the world. 
Ms. Feinstein said that last year and so far this year, the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms had received more than 19,000 requests from foreign countries to trace guns used in crimes; 8,000 of them had originally been sold legally in the United States. 
She also challenged the frequently repeated assertions by American officials here that the Second Amendment to the Constitution guaranteed individuals the right to own guns. "Mr. Bolton's position on the Second Amendment is in direct contradiction to decades of Supreme Court precedent," she said. "Not one single gun-control law has ever been overturned by the court on Second Amendment grounds."
Ms. Feinstein said that the last attempt to claim constitutional protection for carrying a gun was in 1939, when a man arrested for taking a sawed-off shotgun across state lines lost his request to have the case dismissed by the Supreme Court. 
"If a sawed-off shotgun is not protected by the Second Amendment," she said in the Senate, "why does the administration seem to be taking the position that the Second Amendment protects the international trafficking of shoulder-launched missiles?" 

CORRECTION-DATE: July 19, 2001

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a United Nations conference that seeks to tighten international controls on light weapons omitted the given name and title of an American official who addressed the conference earlier. He is John R. Bolton, under secretary of state for arms control.

HEADLINE: Not All Lost In the Talks Between India And Pakistan 

BYLINE:  By CELIA W. DUGGER 

DATELINE: AGRA, India, July 17 

 BODY:
India and Pakistan, foes from way back, did not emerge from an intensive two days of talks here with even a jointly issued, garden-variety press release to show for it. Yet ministers from both countries said today in separate news conferences that the summit had not failed, but helped them better understand each other.
 Pakistan's foreign minister, Abdul Sattar, went further. He said the leaders of the two nations had a meeting of the minds and came "very close" to a deal that would have made possible substantive talks on Kashmir, the main source of their decades-old conflict, as well as nuclear-risk reduction, trade and terrorism. 
 "Both sides are keen to use the progress that has been made as a foundation for further discussion, hopefully leading to full agreement," Mr. Sattar told a roomful of journalists in Islamabad this afternoon, just a day after the negotiations broke down. 
Mr. Sattar and his Indian counterpart, Jaswant Singh, the minister of external affairs, reaffirmed that India's prime minister, Atal Behari Vajpayee, and Pakistan's president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, plan to keep talking. 
"I don't see this as the end of the exercise," Mr. Singh said this morning here in Agra. "Our commitment to peace and amity remains." 
Mr. Vajpayee's acceptance of an invitation from the general to visit Pakistan still stands, both ministers said. And Mr. Sattar said the leaders are likely to meet before that in New York when the United Nations General Assembly convenes in September.
The promise that these two adversaries, both declared nuclear powers, will keep their lines of communication open is not to be taken for granted. 
Until this weekend, it had been two and a half years since their leaders had met, an estrangement that was especially worrisome since India and Pakistan have been locked in a vicious conflict over Kashmir, which both claim, and waged a small, high-altitude war there in the summer of 1999. 
Nor was the temperate, optimistic tenor taken by the two ministers today a foregone conclusion. Last night, it seemed that the mood had soured on both sides. Senior Pakistani officials close to General Musharraf made comments to Pakistani journalists that painted India as an obstructionist on the road to peace. 
Here, there were fears that Pakistan would blame India for aborted talks, inflaming Pakistani public opinion against its long-time enemy. But Mr. Sattar, who often zings India with barbed comments, chose instead to be understated and diplomatic today -- an approach that analysts say may have also been intended to reassure the developed countries and international lenders whose help Pakistan needs if it is to rebuild its troubled economy.
The restrained tone was not matched by some of the militant Islamic groups that are battling against India in Kashmir. Today they seized on the breakdown at the summit meeting as evidence that holy war against Indian rule of majority-Muslim Kashmir is now the only path. 
And their comments have raised fears that there may be a spurt of violence in Kashmir. Hafiz Muhammad Saeed, who heads Lashkar-e-Toiba, a hard-line group based in Islamic Pakistan, told reporters in Lahore today that the group would now intensify its holy war. 
When it comes to India and Pakistan, Kashmir is the inescapable issue. 
Neither minister fully spelled out today what had derailed the talks this weekend, but each said disagreement about the wording of sections on Kashmir in what would have been a joint declaration was at the heart of the problem. 
Mr. Sattar said the two sides could not agree on what he called "the residual paragraph" that dealt with "the relationship between the settlement of the Kashmir problem and the progress on normalization." General Musharraf has taken the position that until Kashmir is recognized as the central dispute and addressed, India and Pakistan cannot seriously talk about solutions on any other major issues. 
That snag was a major one for the Indians. For decades, India has argued that Kashmir is just one of many important issues to be discussed and that the two countries should tackle some easier-to-solve disagreements first. 
"We do not believe bilateral negotiations between India and Pakistan can be held hostage by a single issue," Mr. Singh said.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
DeVito/Verdi, on its 10th anniversary, makes some changes.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
A NEW YORK agency that flourished during tough times is hoping history can repeat itself.
 The agency is DeVito/Verdi, known for a brash, sassy creative approach typically described as smart aleck -- or another word beginning the same way that cannot be repeated here. Its best-known output includes campaigns for New York magazine ("Possibly the only good thing in New York Rudy hasn't taken credit for"); Solgar ("It's a tough town. You need a tough vitamin"); the Pro-Choice Public Education Project ("Seventy-seven percent of anti-abortion leaders are men. One hundred percent of them will never be pregnant"); Empire Kosher Poultry ("It takes an even tougher man to make a kosher chicken"); and eCampus.com ("Textbooks and stuff. Cheap"). 
 DeVito/Verdi, which also produced ads for Hillary Clinton's Senate race last year, is making a series of operating changes that coincide with a celebration of the 10th anniversary of the collaboration between Sal DeVito, partner and creative director, and Ellis J. Verdi, partner and president. The anniversary events include a retrospective of the agency's work at the prestigious One Club for Art and Copy.
The changes include the naming of two executives as partners, the formation of a division to specialize in public relations and a search for a top creative executive who would work with Mr. DeVito.
"It was a tough time then," Mr. DeVito, 53, said of the days when a recession gripped Madison Avenue, "but we didn't seem to feel it."
"Recession, depression or boom, I don't see any difference in the kind of advertising I would do," he added. "We didn't start out to be outrageous; we started out to be heard."
Mr. DeVito, originally an award-winning art director, described his goal as to create ads that are "smart, focused, with a voice, getting noticed, but with a selling message," rather than to produce campaigns that are "outrageous for the sake of outrage," an opinion often expressed about the DeVito/Verdi oeuvre. "I really try to sell the product, believe it or not," Mr. DeVito said.
The agency was opened in 1989 as Follis & Verdi by Mr. Verdi and John Follis, partner and creative director. In 1991, Mr. DeVito joined as a second partner and creative director and the agency was renamed Follis DeVito Verdi. When Mr. Follis left in July 1993, citing "philosophical differences," to open his own New York agency, now known as Follis Advertising, Follis DeVito Verdi became DeVito/Verdi, minus a name but plus a slash.
"When people ask 'How do you survive these times?' I say, 10 years ago the agency went through this and thrived," Mr. Verdi, 45, said.
"Like any agency, you get tagged for your most visible work," he added, "but I don't mind it because every one of those ads" derided as gratuitously provocative "makes a clear, concise statement."
"We have to be interruptive because we can't afford not to be," Mr. Verdi said. "It's a fine line in some people's minds, but it's a very important line we try to delineate in client meetings."
The newest client of DeVito/Verdi, The Sporting News, the weekly sports newspaper owned by Vulcan Ventures, praises the agency's approach.
"In this day and age, if you want to be heard, you have to be -- I hate to use the cliche -- a little out of the box," said Stuart Marvin, vice president for marketing at The Sporting News in New York.
"DeVito/Verdi's work is a little more intrusive, not for the sake of being so but grounded in strategy," he added. "I'm quite frankly surprised the agency isn't larger and more successful than it already is."
For The Sporting News, a trade campaign introduced last week by DeVito/Verdi carries this cheeky headline that seeks to differentiate the sports publication from its many competitors: "Music, fashion and sports without all the damn music and fashion."
Mary Warlick, executive director at the One Club, said that the DeVito/ Verdi genre of "in-your-face advertising broke ground 10 years ago, and they're still doing it."
She said she was particularly pleased to mount the retrospective, which continues through Aug. 23, because agencies based in New York have "taken their share of hits, economically and creatively."
"It's nice to salute a New York agency," she added, laughing, "because how many of them are there left?"
As for the changes at DeVito/Verdi -- which now has 64 employees and estimates its billings at $134 million from clients including the American Civil Liberties Union, Canon USA, Daffy's, 8 O'Clock Coffee, the For Eyes optical chain and The Sporting News -- the two new partners are Andy Brief, 41, who heads account management, and Chris Tinkham, 45, who heads media planning and buying and promotions.
The new division, DeVito/Verdi Public Relations, is being headed by Nathana Josephs, 42, as director; she previously had her own public relations business. The division is working for For Eyes and the Pro-Choice Education Project.
As for hiring another creative director, Mr. Verdi said, Mr. DeVito "is talking to some people," adding: "Sal will always be in control, but there is a need at this point, due to growth, for a high-level creative person whose title would include 'partner.' I am not sure how or if Sal's title would then change; it's to be determined."

HEADLINE: Earnings at Apple Beat Expectations; Sales Miss Target 

BYLINE:  By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
Apple Computer Inc. reported quarterly earnings yesterday that exceeded Wall Street's expectations, but its sales were slightly below analysts' estimates. 
 The quarterly results suggest that Apple is managing its business efficiently during a difficult period for the personal computer business and the economy. But the soft revenue figures, analysts say, also indicate that the main issue surrounding Apple -- whether it can expand beyond its base of dedicated users and increase its share of the PC market -- remains unresolved. 
 Apple reported profits for its fiscal third quarter, ended in June, of $61 million, or 17 cents a share, 3 cents above the consensus estimate on Wall Street. Yet reflecting the sharp slowdown in the industry, profits were well below the same quarter last year, when Apple earned $200 million, or 55 cents a share.
Sales for the quarter were $1.48 billion. The Wall Street consensus estimate for revenue was $1.55 billion. But Fred D. Anderson, the chief financial officer of Apple, said in a conference call with analysts that part of the shortfall in the comparison was explained by the company's program of further reducing inventory in its distribution channels. After adjusting for lower inventory levels, Mr. Anderson said the "implied revenue" figure for the quarter was $1.53 billion.
For the current quarter, which ends in September, Mr. Anderson said that Apple expected revenues and sales to be "up slightly" from the June quarter, and that he did not foresee an imminent recovery.
In after-hours trading, Apple shares -- after rising $1.14 to $25.10 during the day -- fell to $22.75. Analysts attributed the selling to Mr. Anderson's cautious assessment of the outlook and the slight shortfall in the revenue figures for the quarter. 
Still, gross profit margins for Apple were 29.4 percent, well ahead of analysts' expectations, and it has $4.2 billion in cash and short-term securities -- an impressive nest egg for a company whose survival was in doubt a few years ago.
Apple is also introducing products that are having an impact. The company shipped more than 182,000 of its new iBook notebook machines intended for the consumer and education markets. Recent market research surveys show that it has regained the lead in the kindergarten-through-high school market from Dell Computer. And at the MacWorld conference in New York today, Steven P. Jobs, the Apple chairman, is expected to introduce new versions of its popular iMac desktop computers.
And Apple has achieved a respectable financial performance in difficult times without laying off workers, a tactic used by most personal computer makers. "I'm pretty pleased with these results," Mr. Jobs said in an interview. "Our strategy is to innovate our way through this difficult period. We're going to leverage our innovative people instead of laying them off."
Apple's strategy includes introducing machines with striking looks, its new Mac OS X operating system for an improved user experience and multimedia software like iMovie and iTunes, adding new uses to personal computing. In addition, Apple is opening its own retail stores, with the first two in May, and 25 expected to be open by year-end.
The stores are considered strategically important for Apple as venues for showing its wares, especially in persuading other PC users to switch to Apple's Macintosh technology. "For Apple to grow, it has to get new users, and they have to get switchers to make this story work," Charles R. Wolf, an analyst at Needham & Company, said.

HEADLINE: Reckonings; 
Other People's Money

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN 

 BODY:
It wasn't true when Richard Nixon said it, but it is true today: We are all Keynesians now -- at least when we look at our own economy. We give anti-Keynesian advice only to other countries.
 When it comes to the U.S. economy, everyone -- including people who imagine that they have rejected Keynesianism in favor of some doctrine more congenial to the free-market faithful -- in practice views the current slowdown in terms of the intellectual framework John Maynard Keynes created 65 years ago. In particular, everyone thinks that during a slump what we need is more spending. 
 Before Keynes, the general view was quite the opposite: economic slumps were supposed to be the invisible hand's way of punishing excesses, and the best cure was supposed to be a good dose of austerity, public and private. Only as a result of the Keynesian revolution did it become obvious to everyone -- so obvious that people take it for granted -- that the problem during a slump is too little spending, not too much, and that recovery depends on persuading the public to start spending again. 
So every time you read an article worrying that declining consumer confidence may tip us into recession, or that interest rate cuts will soon spark a recovery, or even that this time interest rate reductions may not do the trick, you are reading Keynesian economics. Like the man who was unaware that he had been writing prose all his life, these writers may not know that they are Keynesians -- but they are.
And you would have to search far and wide to find anyone who thinks that the U.S. government should slash spending and raise taxes to offset the budget impact of this year's downturn, or who thinks that the Fed is wrong to cut interest rates in the face of a slump. (There are some people who think that the Fed has overdone it -- but they aren't opposed to the policy in principle.) 
But we -- by which I mean both policy makers in Washington and bankers in New York -- often seem to prescribe for other countries the kind of root-canal economics that we would never tolerate here in the U.S.A.
Yesterday former Senator Howard Baker, our new ambassador to Japan, told reporters he did not expect to see that country drive down the value of the yen. Aside from being inappropriate -- exchange rate policy is a highly sensitive subject, about which even the secretary of the Treasury needs to be highly circumspect -- this comment was part of a pattern of hints from U.S. officials that we would not like to see Japan weaken its currency. Since it is very difficult to imagine a recovery strategy for Japan that does not involve at least the possibility of a much weaker yen, this amounts to telling the Japanese that they cannot do what we do routinely, that is, print however much money it takes to get the economy moving again.
And then, of course, there's Argentina. What's shocking about the political and economic crisis there is not so much its severity -- though it is amazing to see the punishment now being inflicted on a country that just three years ago was the toast of Wall Street -- as how gratuitous it is. We're talking about a government whose debt really isn't very large compared with the size of its national economy, and whose fairly modest budget deficit is entirely the product of an economic slump, forced into drastic spending cuts that will further worsen that slump. It wouldn't be tolerated here -- but the bankers in New York tell the Argentines that they have no alternative. And Washington -- not the Bush administration, which has been eerily silent as Argentina melts down, but the conservative think tanks that helped the country bind itself in a monetary straitjacket -- agrees.
Does it have to be this way? Is Keynesianism good only for the U.S. and selected other Western countries, but out of bounds for everyone else? Maybe. But I suspect that the core of the problem is that small countries, and even big countries like Japan that have lost their self-confidence, are too easily bullied by men in suits who give them advice dictated by a hard-line ideology they would never try to impose back home. 
My advice would be to stop listening to those men in suits, and do as we do, not as we say.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
A Strong Rally in Stocks On Positive Profit Reports
A handful of positive earnings reports set off a broad-based rally on Wall Street, sending the Dow Jones industrial average up 1.3 percent as investors grew more confident about companies' prospects in the months ahead.
 The Dow rose 134.27 points, to 10,606.39. Broader stock indicators also advanced. The Nasdaq composite index rose 1.9 percent, gaining 38.20 points, to 2,067.32, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index increased 11.99 points, or 1 percent, to 1,214.44. Page C12. 

Layoffs for Coca-Cola Enterprises
Coca-Cola Enterprises, the bottling company responsible for about 80 percent of Coca-Cola's soft-drink sales in North America, will cut 2,000 jobs, or 3 percent of its work force. It reported a 6.6 percent drop in net income, to $114 million, or 27 cents a share, 2 cents below forecasts. Shares of Coca-Cola Enterprises fell $2.68, to $15.05. C6.

Broadcasters Seek Looser Rules
As federal regulators prepare to loosen or eliminate the rules that have restricted broadcasters from growing bigger and owning newspapers, senior executives from Viacom and Tribune asked the Senate to let regulators proceed without intervention. C4.

Argentine Plan to Erase Deficits
The Argentine government negotiated an agreement with 14 opposition governors to unite behind the plan of the economic minister, Domingo Cavallo, to erase budget deficits of national and provincial governments. A12.

Apple Earnings Beat Expectations
Apple Computer reported earnings that exceeded Wall Street's expectations, but its sales were below analysts' estimates. C10.

News Corp. to End Magazine Venture
The News Corporation is quitting the magazine business entirely by putting its lone American title, Maximum Golf, up for sale. C4.

Taking Charge in the Huddle
William R. Johnson, chief executive of H. J. Heinz, said he was imbued with competitive spirit and energy growing up in a sports family. His father was a player and coach in the N.F.L. for 40-plus years. "It's helped me succeed," he said. As a child, though, "I used to get so emotionally involved," he said, "that I'd get sick before games." The Boss. C8.

Bristol-Myers to Invest in Exelixis
Bristol-Myers Squibb will pay $20 million for a small stake in Exelixis, a genomics concern, the two are expected to announce today. C8.

Additional Job Cuts at Royal Philips
Royal Philips Electronics of the Netherlands, Europe's leading electronics manufacturer, said it would shed 4,000 additional jobs, bringing its total for the year to more than 10,000. World Business, Section W.

House Committee Endorses Drilling
House Republicans moved swiftly to transform President Bush's energy plan into legislation as a committee for the first time endorsed the White House plan to drill for oil in an arctic wildlife refuge. A19.

Robust Corporate Airplane Market
Flight delays and increased waiting times in the commercial airline system have helped the corporate jet market bloom, a study has found. Joe Sharkey: Business Travel. C6.

HEADLINE: Protesters at Bay, Rich Nations' Chiefs to Meet in Genoa 

BYLINE:  By ALESSANDRA STANLEY with WARREN HOGE 

DATELINE: GENOA, Italy, July 17 

 BODY:
Multiple checkpoints, bomb-sniffing dogs and 13-foot iron gratings put up across cobbled alleys to seal off secure zones have given the medieval port city of Genoa the look of pre-1989 East Berlin. 
 On Friday, a summit meeting for the world's major industrial nations will begin here and is expected to draw more than 100,000 antiglobalization protesters. Tension and security fears are already high. 
 The meeting will bring together the leaders of the United States, Britain, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, Canada and Russia. A few radical groups have pledged to break through the police lines. 
As many as 60 bomb scares, all of them false alarms, were reported across the city today. On Monday, a police officer was injured when a mail bomb went off in a police station. The explosion puts more pressure on an already tense security force of 16,000 police officers and military men armed with riot sticks, water cannons and tear gas to secure the city for the meeting, which will last through Sunday.
Tonight, the police arrested one would-be demonstrator, a 25-year-old woman from Germany who was suspected of smuggling into Genoa rocks and other objects that could be handy in a riot. 
The rigid security restrictions being set up to prevent the kind of violence that disrupted previous international meetings -- from Seattle in 1999 to Goteborg, Sweden, last month -- seem to be straining the patience of some of the world leaders who will meet here to discuss world trade and third world debt reduction.
In London, Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain said today that people have been "far too apologetic" toward the demonstrators who disrupt gatherings of world leaders, and he urged the public to turn its back on them.
"These guys don't represent anyone," Mr. Blair told a group of reporters on the eve of a two-day visit to London by President Bush. 
"If the public knew their views," he said, "they'd disagree with them. I just think we've got to be a lot more robust about this." 
Mr. Bush echoed his remarks today while delivering a speech at the World Bank. "I respect the right to peaceful expression," he said, "but make no mistake -- those who protest free trade are no friends of the poor. Those who protest free trade seek to deny them their best hope for escaping poverty."
Mr. Bush and Mr. Blair both seemed to be reacting at least in part to the more conciliatory approach toward the antiglobalization movement on the continent, and particularly in Italy, which is the host for the summit meeting. 
The meeting is a major test for the newly elected conservative prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi. His government has kept open a dialogue with the more moderate protest organizers, and made soothing, sympathetic statements while insisting that Italy will not condone violence.
Italy is planning to shut down the Genoa airport, harbor, highways and train stations, though special trains carrying demonstrators from Germany and France have been given permission to enter the city before the meeting begins. Two protest marches, one on Thursday and the other on Saturday, have been approved by the meeting's organizers as long as the protesters stay clear of the six-mile secure red zone around the meeting's site. 
Mr. Berlusconi, Foreign Minister Renato Ruggiero and other officials have argued that Italy shares the loftier aims of many antiglobalization protesters and will champion such issues as third world debt reduction at the meeting. Italy is holding a cocktail party and dinner so the meeting's leaders can mingle with the United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, as well as the presidents of South Africa, Nigeria and Bangladesh. 
As hundreds of antiglobalization protesters began pouring into the city by airplane, train, car and bicycle, the police began emptying two jails in the city. 
Officials estimate that as many as 600 people might end up behind bars if the demonstrations turn violent. Weeks ago, city officials put aside 200 coffins, just in case. 
Antiglobalization demonstrators, and especially the Genoa Global Forum, a well-organized umbrella group that represents more than 700 groups, have already succeeded in reshaping the summit meeting before it begins. 
Because of the security concerns, leaders' wives will not have their own event in Genoa. While her husband confers with his counterparts, Laura Bush will visit the American Air Force base in Aviano. 
Foreign ministers, who had planned to meet before the meeting in the nearby resort town of Portofino, instead will gather in Rome on the Wednesday and Thursday. 
Except for Mr. Bush, who will stay at the Jolly Hotel Marina on the waterfront, other leaders will stay on the European Vision, a cruise ship with swimming pools, gyms, saunas, beauty salons and a casino. The port itself is being protected by frogmen and warships. 
"I don't want to be cosseted," Mr. Blair complained today. "I would prefer to be out there in the street with the people. These guys won't let us."

HEADLINE: Levy Warns Budget Cuts May Threaten Bilingual Plan 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy warned members of the Board of Education yesterday that their recently approved overhaul of bilingual education programs might have to be postponed because City Hall has not allocated enough money to pay for the changes.
 The warning is the latest round of a bitter battle of words between Mr. Levy and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani over the city's education budget. Mr. Levy says the current budget leaves the school system with $120 million less, after accounting for inflation and mandated spending increases, for the coming year than it had in the year that just ended. 
 Mr. Giuliani, who this month offered to have his budget staff help the Board of Education find potential cuts in its administrative ranks, responded that he found it "amazing" that the Board of Education cannot find enough money for its programs in a $12 billion budget. 
Just last week, Mr. Levy told district superintendents to prepare contingency plans for $120 million in budget cuts but said that administrative costs should be cut before classroom programs. 
Yesterday, Mr. Levy expanded his warning to classroom programs, including the $75 million bilingual reform approved unanimously by the board in February. The new program would expand dual-language programs, require more new teachers, increase teacher training and give parents more control over what programs their children take.
In a memorandum to the seven board members, released by his office yesterday, Mr. Levy said, "Until funding for these programs is secured -- the current budget does not include any additional support for English Language Learners -- we cannot be certain we can implement the program as proposed."
Also at risk are recently recommended changes in mathematics instruction, Mr. Levy said, which "will be limited by the absence of incremental resources."
Mr. Levy also said that he has told his staff to study the way federal Title I money is allocated to city schools, a system which he said drives money out of the schools that need it most. He would like his staff to see whether they can direct more money to those needy schools. Because of peculiarities of the poverty estimates on which those allocations are based, schools in the Bronx with the highest numbers of poor students will receive $552 per student in federal Title I money in the coming year, down from $597 per student last year. To contrast, schools in Staten Island with high concentrations of poor students will receive $1,710 per student in the coming year, up from $1,270 last year.

HEADLINE: BUSH URGES SHIFT TO DIRECT GRANTS FOR POOR NATIONS 

BYLINE:  By FRANK BRUNI with DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 17 

 BODY:
President Bush called today for a major change in the way rich nations help poorer countries, proposing that up to 50 percent of aid to those countries from the World Bank and similar institutions be given as direct grants rather than loans for needs like education and health.
 Mr. Bush, calling these grants a way to help alleviate the debt that burdens developing economies, said they should be used increasingly as substitutes for heavily discounted loans that the World Bank provides now. He promoted the approach in a speech at the World Bank headquarters here to state his commitment to fighting world poverty. Excerpts, Page A10. 
 "This is compassionate conservatism at an international level, and it's the responsibility that comes with freedom and prosperity," Mr. Bush said in remarks intended to set the stage for a European trip later this week.
"The needs are many and undeniable," Mr. Bush said. "And they are a challenge to our conscience and to complacency. A world where some live in comfort and plenty, while half of the human race lives on less than $2 a day, is neither just, nor stable."
During Mr. Bush's last trip to Europe he confronted and in many ways stoked the apprehensions of European leaders who felt that he was putting the United States' interests above its international obligations. With his speech today, he seemed to be trying to dispel that perception abroad while also showing a more moderate side to voters at home. 
But Mr. Bush's remarks today did not take into account nor delineate how expensive such a change in the way the World Bank operates would be. Nor did the president say how -- or whether -- the United States and other wealthy nations that give the bank its primary financial support would pay for the added cost.
Currently, the United States contributes $803 million annually to the World Bank. This money, with contributions from other nations, allows the World Bank to make loans totaling $15 billion each year -- $6 billion of that to poor countries as heavily discounted loans. The World Bank has estimated that in the next decade the United States would need to double its contribution just to maintain the current level of aid.
The president's vision for the World Bank carried a different emphasis than the one that the organization's president, James Wolfensohn, struck in comments he made on Monday. Mr. Wolfensohn said the most important step that rich countries could take was not giving loans and grants but opening their markets more fully to exports from poorer countries.
"We must recognize that it is simply hypocritical to give debt relief with one hand and then deny poor countries the ability to export their way out of poverty with the other," Mr. Wolfensohn said. 
These issues are likely to be discussed this weekend at a summit meeting in Genoa, Italy, where the president will meet with the leaders of the other largest industrial economies during a time of economic slowdown in Europe and the United States and recession in Japan.
But the focus of much of the Genoa discussions will be on restoring growth in the economies of the world's wealthiest nations, it is unclear how much attention or support Mr. Bush's ideas for the World Bank will receive.
But it was his remarks about the World Bank today that drew the most attention, and critics focused on the financial implications for the organization. They noted that because the World Bank depends on repayments of existing loans to have money for new loans or for the grants, it would encounter a shortfall and have less money to use under Mr. Bush's proposal.
Condoleezza Rice, Mr. Bush's national security adviser, said that would not be a factor in the short term. "It will be 10 years before this makes a difference," she said. "But we understand that this will require some greater commitments."
She also noted that, like Mr. Wolfensohn, "The president said it's important to open markets." But she acknowledged a longstanding tension, which the administration had yet to resolve, between that goal and its belief that "it's also important to protect American farmers."
Mr. Bush's speech comes as the administration is rethinking how the United States should deal with the World Bank, which fights poverty, and the International Monetary Fund, its sister organization, which deals with financial crises.
Last month, Treasury Secretary Paul O'Neill called for an overhaul of the World Bank. His concept was to focus the bank's programs on increasing a country's productivity and aiding its development of a self-sufficient economy.
Mr. Bush echoed that theme today, saying that the bank and similar organizations "should focus on raising productivity in developing nations, especially through investments in education."
World Bank officials, with some exasperation in their voices, say they have been doing exactly that for the past few years. As Mr. Wolfensohn has moved the institution away from grand projects like building hydroelectric dams and toward education programs and credit assistance to people starting small businesses.
But the bank's programs often go awry because of local corruption or the conflict between the bank's plans and those of local and national leaders. It is unclear how, according to Mr. Bush's vision, that problem would be surmounted.
Mr. Bush's remarks today dwelled more on his broad vision for the United States' role in helping developing countries than on specific prescriptions. They were delivered with an eye toward where he would be traveling, whom he would be seeing and how he wanted them to see him.
"We have, today, the opportunity to include all the world's poor in an expanding circle of development, throughout all of the Americas, all of Asia and all of Africa," Mr. Bush said. "This is a great moral challenge, what Pope John Paul II called placing the freedom of the market in the service of human freedom in its totality."
During his trip, Mr. Bush will meet the pope, a visit closely watched by many Catholics. Bush administration officials have been assiduously courting Catholic voters and know that Mr. Bush risks angering some of them if he decides, in coming weeks, to permit federal support for embryonic stem cell research.
As on his last trip to Europe, Mr. Bush is expected to encounter protests, many by groups opposed to globalization. But Mr. Bush said today that less restricted trade was one of the best ways to help developing countries.
"Those who protest free trade are no friends of the poor," he said. "Those who protest free trade seek to deny them their best hope for escaping poverty."

HEADLINE: Triangular Diplomacy 

 BODY:
The new treaty of "friendship and cooperation" between Russia and China, signed Monday by Presidents Vladimir Putin and Jiang Zemin, does not signal a return to cold-war tensions with the United States. But it does represent an effort by the Russians and Chinese to strengthen their hands in future diplomatic dealings with Washington. Triangular diplomacy is back, in a new form and with diminished strategic significance. 
 In the cold war, America and Russia were the two superpowers, but China was a pivotal factor in their relations. That three-sided strategic geometry explained the informal alliance between Washington and Beijing that began during the Nixon administration. The two countries were drawn together by shared fears over Soviet military strength and the Kremlin's aggressive diplomacy. But even as Washington cultivated Beijing, it pursued improved relations with Moscow. 
 Today the United States is the world's only military and economic superpower. Russia and China, both under pressure to deliver greater prosperity to their people through market-based growth, vitally depend on continued access to American trade and development. Neither is in any position to challenge Washington's conventional military power. But both are uneasy about the global sweep of American foreign policy, and with this agreement are establishing at least a symbolic barrier to unhindered American domination.
The new treaty commits Russia and China to resolve their own disputes peacefully, consult with each other about emerging threats and oppose any attempts by other countries to interfere in the sovereign affairs of any state. Though the treaty text is full of challenges to American policies, neither of its signatories intends to shun further diplomacy with Washington. 
China will continue its efforts to join the World Trade Organization and increase economic ties with the United States. Russia, as Mr. Putin made plain after his first meeting with President Bush in Slovenia last month, will continue to negotiate with Washington about missile defense, nuclear arms reductions and other mutually important issues. 
But Washington's record of military intervention in Iraq and the Balkans, its promotion of NATO expansion toward Russia's borders and its talk of building a missile shield have helped nudge Russia and China closer together.
Americans see missile defense as a way of protecting themselves against nuclear threats from unpredictable countries like North Korea, Iraq and Iran. Russia and China fear that permitting the development of new defensive technologies could one day undermine their own long-range missile forces. They also worry that with a missile shield in place, Washington might feel freer to intervene militarily in areas where they too have interests, like the Persian Gulf and the Korean Peninsula. 
Moscow and Beijing were unsettled by NATO's 1999 intervention in Kosovo, undertaken to protect ethnic Albanians from persecution by their Serbian rulers. They fear that similar arguments could one day be invoked against Chinese policies in Tibet or Russian actions in Chechnya. 
Though neither Russia nor China is a superpower, both are important. When American policies affect their interests, as is the case with missile defense and, for Russia, NATO expansion, Washington should consult with them carefully and not simply proceed according to its own preferences and timetable. Failure to take Russia and China into account will fan dangerous resentments and drive them away from Washington and toward each other.

HEADLINE: Bush's Words: 'To Build This Better World' 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 17 

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Bush's remarks today to the World Bank, as provided by the White House press office: 
 To build this better world, we must be guided by three great goals. First, America and her friends and allies must pursue policies to keep the peace and promote prosperity. The United States and her allies will pursue a balance of world power that favors human freedom. 
 This requires a new strategic framework that moves beyond cold war doctrines and addresses the threats of a new century such as cyberterrorism, weapons of mass destruction, missiles in the hands of those for whom terror and blackmail are a very way of life. These threats have the potential to destabilize freedom and progress, and we will not permit it. . . . 
Our second goal is to ignite a new era of global economic growth through a world trading system that is dramatically more open and more free. One of the most important objectives of my meetings with other G-7 leaders in Italy will be to secure their strong endorsement for a launch of a new round of global trade negotiations later this year. . . . Our third goal must be to work in true partnership with developing countries to remove the huge obstacles to development, to help them fight illiteracy, disease, unsustainable debt. . . . 
Already, 23 of the world's poorest nations are benefiting from efforts to relieve them of the crippling burden of massive debt. These nations have committed themselves to economic reform and to channeling the savings from debt relieve into health and education.
The United States has been, and will continue to be, a world leader on responsible debt relief. The developed nations must also increase our commitment to help educate people throughout the world. . . . 
For its part, the World Bank and the other development banks must, as Secretary O'Neill has noted, focus on raising productivity in developing nations, especially through investments in education.
Yet only about 7 percent of World Bank resources are devoted to education. Moreover, these funds are provided as loans that must be repaid and often times aren't. Today I call on all multilateral development banks to increase the share of their funding devoted to education and to tie support more directly to clear and measurable results. I also propose the World Bank and other development banks dramatically increase the share of their funding provided as grants rather than loans to the poorest countries. Specifically, I propose that up to 50 percent of the funds provided by the development banks to the poorest countries be provided as grants for education, health, nutrition, water supply, sanitation and other human needs, which will be a major step forward. Debt relief is really a short-term fix. The proposal today doesn't merely drop the debt. It helps stop the debt.

HEADLINE: House Committee Approves Bush's Plan for Drilling in Alaskan Refuge 

BYLINE:  By LIZETTE ALVAREZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 17 

 BODY:
House Republicans moved swiftly today to transform President Bush's energy plan into legislation as a committee for the first time endorsed the White House plan to drill for oil in an Arctic wildlife refuge.
 After a heated debate over the drilling provision the House Resources Committee voted 29 to 19 to kill a Democratic amendment to ban exploration in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. 
 Five Democrats joined 24 Republicans in defeating the ban on Alaskan drilling, effectively endorsing the drilling plan.
The oil-drilling provision is now expected to move to the full House as part of a larger energy package in the coming weeks. But it faces a tough road there and an even tougher one in the Senate, where many Democrats and moderate Republicans oppose opening the refuge for oil exploration and have expressed resistance to expanded oil drilling on other federal lands. 
Indeed, today's approval of oil drilling in the Arctic refuge sets the stage for a battle over Mr. Bush's energy plan on the House floor.
"I don't think we will drill in A.N.W.R," Representative Sherwood Boehlert, Republican of New York, said, using the abbreviation for the Arctic refuge. "It's much talked about but it isn't going to happen."
In an effort to bolster the Alaska oil-drilling provisions, Republican leaders have enlisted the support of trade unions to battle the environmental groups and try to persuade Democrats and moderate Republicans to support the bill.
The strategy splits two traditionally Democratic constituencies. Many unions support the drilling bill because it would create jobs for their workers.
"We are putting everything into it we can, along with many other members of organized labor," said Jerry Hood, principal officer for Teamsters Local 959 in Alaska. "By the end of September, we will be planning for the environmentally responsible opening of A.N.W.R. because it is going to pass."
The White House has worked behind the scenes with union leaders to try to push the bill in Congress. Last week, James P. Hoffa, the general president of the teamsters, appeared at a news conference with Representative Don Young, an Alaska Republican, and Interior Secretary Gale A. Norton.
"I think the votes are there on A.N.W.R.," said Representative Joe Barton, a Texas Republican, who helped write parts of the energy legislation. "We have to work it."
Also today, the Energy and Commerce Committee, hoping to lace the overall package with less contentious, more popular proposals, took up a bill to reward energy conservation and strengthen fuel efficiency standards for light trucks and sport utility vehicles, among other things.
Republicans plan to move other elements of the energy package to the full House later this week, including one that provides tax incentives for energy-efficient cars and solar energy devices.
But that measure is also running into opposition from Democrats, who said they supported the tax breaks but feared they would take too large a bite out of the budget surplus.
The committee has also postponed action on more complex energy bills dealing with electricity deregulation, the overhaul of electricity grids and the renewal of liability insurance for nuclear power plants.
Representative Billy Tauzin, the Louisiana Republican who is the committee's chairman, said it would take up those issues in the coming weeks.
The Republican push to move energy legislation comes as the public's concerns about energy appear to be waning. Gasoline prices have dipped and California has not yet suffered the rolling summer blackouts that had been feared.
Hoping to promote the White House plan, Mr. Bush, Vice President Dick Cheney and five cabinet secretaries traveled around the country to emphasize the need for a national energy policy.
House Republicans are moving swiftly on major elements of Mr. Bush's plan. But they are also trying to avoid following the exact tack taken by Mr. Bush and Mr. Cheney, who have been criticized for focusing too much on oil and too little on conservation and other environmentally friendly policies.
By making conservation one of the first major elements of the package, Republicans are trying to undo some of the political damage.
Democrats today, though, castigated Republicans for doing too little to reduce energy use and said that the committee's measure to toughen fuel efficiency standards could do more harm than good.
"This bill is a lost opportunity," said Representative Henry A. Waxman, a California Democrat. 
The efficiency provision was the product of a compromise between Mr. Tauzin and Representative John D. Dingell of Michigan, the committee's ranking Democrat.
It would require the Transportation Department to raise fuel economy standards for sport utility vehicles and minivans high enough to save five billion gallons of gasoline from 2004 to 2010.
The White House has not endorsed any increases in fuel economy standards.
In light of a draft report by the National Academy of Sciences that calls for even greater increases in fuel economy standards, Democrats on the committee said that the measure did not go far enough.
"It will reduce consumption by one-tenth of one percent but, due to loopholes, it will actually worsen motor vehicle fuel economy standards," Mr. Waxman said.
Other provisions in the two energy bills include tax breaks for cleaner coal-burning technology, and more money to help low-income households winterize their homes and pay their energy bills.
One of several oil-related provisions would encourage oil production on federal lands; another would allow companies to pay royalties in gas or oil instead of cash.
The Resources Committee legislation, to which the arctic drilling measure was attached, was passed by the full committee tonight.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The House Resources Committee bustled with activity yesterday as it debated the first elements of the Bush energy plan to make it into legislation. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Bonkers for Music, Cheer and Glory; 
For Britons, It's Time for the Proms, That Exhilarating Feast

BYLINE:  By WARREN HOGE 

DATELINE: LONDON, July 18 

 BODY:
You never know from the weather if summer has arrived in Britain, but you have no doubt it's here once music starts pouring nightly over throngs in the Royal Albert Hall and out to millions more on the radio. 
 Opening night of the BBC Proms, the two-month feast of sound that invites no quarrel calling itself "the greatest music festival in the world," is as exhilarating a seasonal moment for Britons as the opening-day crack of bat and ball is for Americans. 
 "Invite me to a party, a wedding, a tea dance or an orgy during those lyrical eight weeks," Richard Morrison of The Times of London wrote last year at this time. " 'Sorry,' will come my reply. 'Rattle conducting Wagner that night. Unmissable. Start the orgy without me.' " 
Friday night will be the first of 73 consecutive concerts this year in what is the 107th season of the Proms. More than half will sell out the 6,000-capacity Victorian domed hall on the edge of Hyde Park, and all will be broadcast live on BBC Radio 3, the network's classical music station. Grand orchestras, chamber groups, famous soloists and marquee singers will pass through the rotunda-shaped pile over the next two months, with it all coming to a giddy end on Sept. 15 with the marathon Last Night at the Proms, in which the audience with their flags and party hats and Union Jack umbrellas and sing-along scores of Britain's most unabashedly patriotic anthems are as much a show as the serious music-making. 
Both Friday's opening and the Last Night will be Webcast this year over www.bbc.co.uk/radio3.
Going to a Promenade Concert is a communal experience, a gathering of people in a vast wraparound space that makes for neighborly seating patterns. "It's not people sitting in serried rows with everyone staring at a proscenium arch as in the theater," said Nicholas Kenyon, a former music critic in London and New York who joined the BBC in 1992 and became Proms director in 1996.
They are dressed informally (the Royal Albert Hall is famously not air-conditioned), some standing, some stretched out on the arena floor, some snuggling but everyone paying keen attention. It is an audience that musicians love to play for, Mr. Kenyon said. 
"One of the reasons performers are prepared to come back year after year and swelter in the heat of the Albert Hall and get paid too little by the BBC is because of what they get from the audience," he said. "It's not in the economic interests of the Boston Symphony or the Chicago Symphony to come to the Proms. They come because they will never have a more alert audience."
Up to 1,000 standing places are available for each concert in the gallery and the arena at $4.25 each, and 500 of them go on sale only 30 minutes before showtime, so even sell-outs are accessible to people with time, a good book and some staying power.
The stand-up regulars who crowd around the lip of the stage have developed traditions of their own. They bob in place to particularly lilting melodies and chant ribald phrases of greeting to visiting orchestras in their own languages. They'll chide chamber groups for playing too quietly by crying out in unison: "This concert can be heard on BBC Radio 3." The lifting of a piano lid onstage always gets a shouted "heave" from the arena and a responsive "ho" from the gallery.
While live music is struggling to build a faithful public, attendance at the Proms last year averaged 88.9 percent of capacity. The annual Proms guide, a 150-page listing of concerts with artist profiles, background notes and essays, sold 70,000 copies, making it the best-selling book on classical music in Britain.
The Proms formula is as simple as it is successful. "People say you can do high-quality, elitist things that few people come to, or you can do popular, dumbed-down things that lots of people go to and nobody values," Mr. Kenyon said. "What we are saying with the Proms is it is possible to do high-quality classical music of the widest possible repertory and get an audience who don't necessarily know every detail of what they're coming to but are prepared to respond. They are the most open-minded audience I've ever encountered in the world."
In a typically broad mix, this year's season includes more than a dozen visiting orchestras, among them Boston, Chicago, the Kirov, Leipzig Gewandhaus and Czech Philharmonic; artists like Vladimir Ashkenazy, Emanuel Ax, Daniel Barenboim, Alfred Brendel, Renee Fleming, Valery Gergiev, Bernard Haitink, Antonio Pappano, Sir Simon Rattle and Frederica von Stade; little-known finalists and winners of the BBC Young Performers contests; 10 newly commissioned pieces and many more old favorites like Vivaldi's "Four Seasons" and Beethoven's "Pastoral" Symphony; and 11 premieres of new works by composers including Sir John Tavener and Sir Harrison Birtwistle.
Friday night is the debut of the American Leonard Slatkin as chief conductor of the BBC Symphony Orchestra. A Californian who was the longtime music director of the St. Louis Symphony and since 1996 has been at the helm of the National Symphony Orchestra in Washington, he will be only the second non-Briton to lead the bizarre Last Night nationalistic sendup. The first, the Australian Sir Charles Mackerras, was a lot less foreign since he had been based in Britain for more than 30 years when he took on the assignment. 
Friday night will also witness the annual installation at the back of the orchestra of the illuminated bust of Sir Henry Wood, the originator of Promenade Concerts in 1895 that became the BBC Proms in 1927. He conducted almost every concert himself for nearly 50 years and has presided in stony silence over all the ones since. The concerts originated in Queen's Hall (another barnlike London space with an arena in the middle), which was destroyed by bombs in 1941. 
For all the nights of quiet enchantment and hearty good cheer, there have been moments of unplanned drama. During a performance of "Carmina Burana" in 1974, the baritone, Thomas Allen, fainted from the heat, and a student singer who knew the score, Patrick McCarthy, leaped onstage and took over the part. 
Mstislav Rostropovich was playing Dvorak's Cello Concerto with the U.S.S.R. Symphony Orchestra the night in August 1968 that Soviet tanks rolled into Prague. Anti-Soviet demonstrators protested outside the hall. Mr. Rostropovich, who was soon to defect, played a Bach solo as an encore and dedicated it to the Czech people. 
In 1967 Sir Malcolm Sargent, a conductor beloved of Promgoers, was too ill to attend the full Last Night concert, but he went over to the hall from his apartment in the Royal Albert Mansions next door, and Sir Colin Davis brought him on stage to address his cheering fans. He told them that "God Willing" he would be back the following year. He died a month later.
The first weeks of September 1997 were a particularly charged period for the Proms. The death of Diana, Princess of Wales, brought millions of mourners to London, and many of them filled the meadows of Hyde Park outside. Mr. Kenyon remembers deciding to proceed with the concert schedule because, he reasoned, that is what she would have wished. Then he went through the programs to make sure there was nothing inappropriate. The one work he felt he had to drop was John Adams's "Short Ride in a Fast Machine." (It is part of this year's Last Night program.) 
Then a week after Diana's death, Sir Georg Solti died. He had been scheduled to conduct the Last Night performance of the Verdi Requiem a week later. Sir Colin Davis led the work instead, and it was dedicated to both the conductor and the Princess.

HEADLINE: Continent's Inflation Rate Eases 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: LONDON, July 18 

 BODY:
Europe's inflation rate fell in June, and the decline, the first in five months, should pave the way for the European Central Bank to lower interest rates in the months ahead.
 Consumer prices rose 3 percent in June, compared with June 2000 and 3.4 percent against May, the European Union's statistics office said. 
 The central bank is under growing pressure to spur the economy in the face of broad slowdowns in the United States and Japan. The European Union last week warned that growth in the 12 countries in the euro zone would fall below 2.5 percent in 2001, compared with a decade high of 3.4 percent last year.
In anticipation of potential rate cuts, the euro rose to a two-month high against the dollar. In New York today, the euro settled at 87.06 against the dollar, up from 85.91 on Tuesday.
Even so, policy makers, who are scheduled to meet on Thursday, are likely to wait for more evidence that inflation is under control before trimming rates, analysts said. That is because they have largely missed their goal of keeping inflation below a predetermined target of 2 percent the last 13 months.
The central bank last cut its benchmark rate on May 10, after seven rate increases within a year.
Recent reports from Germany, Europe's largest economy, supported evidence that inflation was being held at bay. A report today, for instance, said German producer prices rose 4.6 percent compared with a year ago -- less than the 4.7 percent that analysts had expected.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene; 
There are fewer summer jobs for teenagers, but that might not hurt long term.

BYLINE:  By Alan B. Krueger; This column appears here every Thursday. Alan B. Krueger is the Bendheim Professor of Economics and Public Affairs at Princeton University and editor of The Journal of Economic Perspectives. E-mail: akrueger@princeton.edu.

 BODY:
SUMMERTIME and the living is supposed to be easy. But for many teenagers looking for work, this summer is shaping up as a disappointment. As Ira Gershwin might have put it: the fish are not jumping and the cotton is not quite so high.
 Every summer millions of teenagers swarm into the labor market like ants around a picnic basket, only to retreat in the fall when school resumes. Last year, the number of 16- to 19-year-olds employed increased from a low of 6.7 million in January to a high of 8.6 million in July, a 28 percent increase. The number fell to less than seven million in October. As of the middle of last month -- the latest data available -- the number of teenagers working bounced back to only 7.8 million, 6 percent below where it was at the same time last summer. Only 48.5 percent of teenagers worked last month, compared with 51.6 percent a year ago. 
 Teenage workers are usually the first to feel the pinch of an economic slowdown because they frequently move in and out of jobs. The current slowdown is no exception. The unemployment rate for teenagers has increased 2.2 percentage points since June 2000, considerably more than the 0.5 percentage point increase for all workers. The continued slowdown portends tougher times ahead for young workers.
What impact will reduced employment this summer have on teenagers? A draft study by Public-Private Ventures, a nonprofit research organization based in Philadelphia, suggests that summer employment has measurable short-term benefits for youth, but negligible longer-term benefits.
The study evaluates the experiences of 1,708 youths who applied to the Summer Career Exploration Program in 1999. Since 1983 this program, created by the William Penn Foundation as an alternative to government-sponsored programs, has assisted high school students in the Philadelphia area to find summer jobs in the private sector and provided academic mentors for the students it places.
The program pays employers 80 percent of their wage costs for employing a participating student at the minimum wage for six weeks, and recruits employers to participate. Students are placed in jobs related to their career interests, including positions in law firms, hospitals and computer service companies. College students meet with participants about twice a week as mentors on career and academic opportunities and to encourage them to do well in school and pursue a college education. 
To conduct the study, 1,157 first-time applicants were randomly selected and provided summer job placement assistance, while another 551 were randomly selected for a control group. Most applicants were B or C students; 72 percent were blacks. They all came from families with incomes that were no more than 150 percent of the poverty level. Because random assignment was used to allocate applicants, any systematic difference in outcomes between the program group and control group could reasonably be attributed to the summer job program, rather than extraneous influences.
The study found that 92 percent of those who were provided assistance worked in a summer job in 1999, compared with only 62 percent of those in the control group. The fact that students participating in the program were nearly 50 percent more likely to work during the summer of 1999 -- one of the hottest job markets on record -- suggests that many teenage workers have difficulty finding employment even in the best of times.
The average student provided summer job assistance earned $250 more than the average member of the control group, including nonworkers in both cases. The average hourly wage rate was $5.30 for program participants and $5.69 for control group members who found work. 
The main benefit of working in a summer job measured by the study is that it gives students more money to spend or save for college. The average student who found employment earned about $900 over the summer. In addition, summer jobs keep teenagers from being idle during the summer, which may reduce criminal behavior, but such information has not yet been collected. In Pennsylvania, criminal activity, for both youths and adults, tends to rise in the summer.
The Summer Career Employment Program costs around $1,000 a participant to operate, and raises the earnings of participants by only around $250. Thus it is an inefficient way to transfer money to young people unless there are other lasting benefits. 
The study found little reason to expect that summer employment has a lasting effect on students beyond the summer they are employed. 
Students who were selected to participate in the summer job program, for example, did not have a higher likelihood of working during the following school year than did control group members. Three-fifths of those in both the program and control group worked during the 1999-2000 school year. Moreover, their average hourly wage and total hours worked during that school year were almost identical. 
Even more disheartening, being placed in a summer job did not appear to improve significantly the students' academic outcomes or educational aspirations. One year later, about equal percentages of program and control group members said they planned to attend college, had sufficient information about college, and had taken or planned to take the SAT or ACT exam. Based on these results, there is little reason to suspect that holding an ordinary summer job, which excludes a college mentoring component, would meaningfully influence a student's academic achievement either. 
Wendy S. McClanahan, the study's co-author, said one should not expect a six-week summer job to have a major impact on adolescents' attitudes and behaviors because they are undergoing tremendous changes in their lives and are subject to numerous influences. 
To generate lasting benefits for adolescents, a more intensive program is required. For example, a randomized evaluation of the Job Corps program released by Mathematica Policy Research earlier this week found that participants' earnings were 12 percent higher and welfare use was lower four years after participating in the federal government's most intensive youth training program. This program costs $16,500 per participant but generates $33,000 each in benefits for society, according to Mathematica.
On the positive side, the findings of the summer jobs study suggest that the joblessness experienced by many youths this summer will probably cause only a short-term blemish on their economic and academic prospects, not a long-term scar.

HEADLINE: Dredge the Hudson 

BYLINE:  By Gary S. Guzy; Gary S. Guzy served as general counsel of the Environmental Protection Agency under Bill Clinton.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
The Bush administration is facing a critical public health and environmental choice about the future of the Hudson River. It must decide whether to embrace the proposal made by the Environmental Protection Agency in December 2000 -- after 11 years of study -- to get polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCB's, out of the river by dredging and removing contaminated sediments from the upper Hudson.
 From the 1940's through the 1970's, General Electric discharged more than one million pounds of PCB's into the Hudson from two now-abandoned plants. PCB's have been banned in this country since 1979; the E.P.A. classifies them as carcinogens in animals and potentially in people. They persist in the environment and accumulate in the food chain, so that eating fish caught in the Hudson may cause harm. As a result, 200 miles of the Hudson River have been declared a federal Superfund hazardous waste site. Fish consumption bans are in place in a 40-mile stretch of the upper Hudson from Hudson Falls to Troy. The E.P.A. has found that a cleanup would greatly reduce the health risks of consuming upper Hudson River fish. 
 Under the Superfund law, G.E. could bear the financial responsibility for this cleanup, which may cost nearly $500 million. The E.P.A.'s decision-making has reflected both the magnitude of the public health and environmental issues and the potential expense. Before proposing limited dredging of toxic hot spots, the agency undertook years of study, publishing several detailed reports assessing the behavior of pollutants in the river and their effects on people and wildlife. There were five independent peer reviews of the research.
The E.P.A.'s scientists found that PCB's in the river would not change chemical composition and become benign, nor would they be covered up by river sediments. The sediments are constantly shifting and exposing new areas of contaminated river bottom, and capping toxic hot spots is not feasible given the river's turbulence. 
Although fish tissue contamination has declined since PCB's were banned in the late 1970's, and as a result of G.E.'s efforts to limit PCB leakage from its former factories, the government's data show that contamination in the fish cannot reach safe levels for generations without removal of PCB's from the river bottom. Although G.E. argues that dredging will do harm, modern dredging technologies can capture pollutants from contaminated sediments and avoid disrupting the ecology of the river.
The opponents of dredging also say questions about dredging's effects have not been thoroughly answered. But the environmental laws do not require absolute certainty before action to address a clear problem.
The Hudson cleanup is not one that will happen overnight; it will require time and perhaps even revision along the way. Gov. George Pataki's office has supported the plan proposed by the Clinton administration. So much time has been devoted to studying this issue that the Bush administration should move ahead with a responsible cleanup.
America's modern environmental movement has demonstrated over the last 30 years that public health and environmental protections can be achieved without weakening the economy. This was true in the cleanup of polluted waterfronts across the country, from Baltimore's Inner Harbor to Chicago's lakefront. The same will be true of the Hudson. The cleaner the Hudson, the greater the possibility that tourism, recreation and appropriate real estate development along its reaches will thrive.

HEADLINE: Times Co. Operating Profit Fell 73% in Second Quarter 

BYLINE:  By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
The New York Times Company reported yesterday that operating profit fell 73 percent in the second quarter, as declines in advertising sales more than offset increases in circulation revenue and reductions in expenses.
 The company said that operating profit totaled $48.2 million, down from $176.3 million in the second quarter of last year. Revenue fell 11 percent, to $760.3 million, from $857.5 million in the period a year earlier. 
 John M. O'Brien, the chief financial officer, noted in a conference call with analysts that economists said the economy was not in a recession. But, he added, "it sure feels like one." 
Russell T. Lewis, the president and chief executive, said the company hoped that the sharp decline in advertising would end soon and that by the fourth quarter that market would "show signs of improvement."
But there was no sign of improvement in June advertising results. The company said that advertising revenues for the month were down 16.3 percent from a year earlier -- and that they were off more at the company's most important properties. Ad revenues declined 17.8 percent at The New York Times, and 22.8 percent at the New England Newspaper Group, which comprises The Boston Globe and The Worcester Telegram & Gazette. The companywide figures exclude some regional newspapers that were sold during the year.
While operating earnings were down, net income was up sharply because the company recorded a $241.3 million pretax profit on the sale of its magazine group, including Golf Digest and Golf World. Over all, net income came to $265.5 million, or $1.64 a diluted share, up from $101.7 million, or 59 cents a diluted share.
The Times Company said the earnings number it preferred to focus on -- which excluded special items like the magazine group sale and a $79.1 million charge for costs related to work force reductions in the second quarter -- came to $70.5 million, or 44 cents a diluted share, down from $101.7 million, or 59 cents a diluted share, a year earlier. Mr. Lewis said that was slightly above the consensus Wall Street expectation.
The company said its operating expenses -- excluding the costs of the work force reductions -- were down 5.4 percent from a year earlier, largely because of lower compensation and promotion expenses. The decline came despite a 2.8 percent increase in spending on newsprint.
Shares of the Times Company ended the day yesterday at $45.85, unchanged, in New York Stock Exchange trading.
A 3.6 percent increase in circulation revenue at the company largely reflected price increases imposed by The New York Times and The Boston Globe. The company said that the impact of higher prices on the number of copies sold had been smaller than expected, but that The Times expected to report lower circulation for both its daily and Sunday papers in the next audited figures, for the six months through September, while The Globe was expected to show a Sunday decline but might show a small increase for the daily.
An impressive area of strength in advertising revenue came from real estate, which was up 13 percent for the newspaper group, including gains of 12 percent at The Times and 21 percent for the New England Newspaper Group.
The sharpest falloff was in help-wanted advertising. "It was almost unprecedented," Mr. O'Brien said. For The Times, help-wanted revenue fell 42 percent in the second quarter from its level a year ago, after declining 24 percent in the first quarter. The decline was even worse for the New England group, down 52 percent in the second quarter after dropping 23 percent in the first quarter. 
"We view this as a cyclical phenomenon," Mr. Lewis told analysts, "not as a secular trend" reflecting the rise of Internet help-wanted advertising. He noted that online help-wanted advertising revenue had also fallen.
At New York Times Digital, the online part of the company, revenue fell 12.3 percent, to $15.3 million, but costs fell even faster. The company said that in the quarter the division had positive cash flow -- earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization -- for the first time in its history.
At the broadcast group, revenue fell 6.4 percent, to $38.7 million, and operating profit dropped 12.3 percent, to $12 million. The company said advertising for autos and packaged goods was particularly weak.

HEADLINE: Prices in June Increased 0.2% For Consumers 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 18 

 BODY:
Food, housing and health care costs ate into consumers' wallets last month, but lower energy prices helped to moderate inflation.
 The government's inflation gauge, the Consumer Price Index, increased 0.2 percent in June, the Labor Department said today. The index was up 3.8 percent for the year. 
 The core rate of inflation, which excludes volatile energy and food prices, rose 0.3 percent in June compared with 0.1 percent in May.
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, told a House committee today that the slowdown was continuing and might require another interest rate reduction to turn around. "Uncertainties surrounding the current economic situation are considerable," he said.
The Federal Reserve has cut rates six times this year to ward off recession. The next meeting is Aug. 21.
One sector of the economy that has held up well is housing, and a separate report by the Commerce Department today indicated that it remained strong.
Housing construction rose 3 percent in June to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.66 million. That came after a revised decline of 1 percent in May.
Consumer energy prices dropped 0.9 percent last month, though they were still up 11.3 percent for the year.
The cost of electricity jumped 3.8 percent last month -- the largest increase on record. But natural gas prices were 5.6 percent less, the largest decline on record. The cost of gasoline also dropped 2.6 percent, the best showing since March, when prices dropped 3.8 percent.
Motorists this summer have been getting a break at the pump after world crude oil prices eased and refiners rushed to fill shortages that developed during the spring.
Gasoline prices have dropped nearly 13 cents the last three weeks as supplies rose. The average price of gasoline, including all grades and taxes, was $1.51 a gallon Friday -- down 12.8 cents since June 22, according to the Lundberg survey of about 8,000 gasoline stations. 
But prices increased in other areas. Airline fares surged 5 percent last month, the biggest increase since October 1999, when prices jumped 5.3 percent.
Food prices were up 0.4 percent in June and up 3.7 percent for the year. Housing prices rose 0.4 percent after the same showing in May. Medical care also jumped 0.4 percent.
