HEADLINE: In U.S. Unions, Mexico Finds Unlikely Ally on Immigration 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 18 

 BODY:
It is rare for foreign officials to address labor conventions, much less raise their fist in solidarity with the union members.
 But when Mexico's foreign minister, Jorge Castaneda, did so on Tuesday night, saying at the hotel workers' convention here that illegal Mexican immigrants should be given legal status to prevent their exploitation, he got a rousing ovation. 
 For years, Mexico and the American labor movement were at loggerheads, with unions denouncing the North American Free Trade Agreement for dragging down American workers' wages and job conditions. But now Mexico's government and American unions are making common cause on an issue that long divided them, immigration. 
Both are urging the Bush administration to grant legal status to millions of illegal Mexican immigrants. 
After decades of hostility toward immigrants, arguing that they push down wages, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. has changed course and concluded that the best way to prevent immigrants from undercutting American wages is to grant them legal status and unionize them. American union leaders also recognize that allying with Mexico on the issue will help unions attract immigrants to their ranks by improving the image of unions in the eyes of immigrants.
Mr. Castaneda has spearheaded Mexico's effort to improve ties with American unions because he recognizes that organized labor is one of the strongest voices to advance President Vicente Fox's goal of winning legal status for Mexican illegal immigrants in the United States.
Mr. Castaneda spoke at the convention of the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees International Union as President Bush and President Fox are negotiating changes in American immigrant policy to reduce the dangers of crossing the border and to improve the lives of Mexican immigrants.
"Their lack of legal status makes them vulnerable to employers who undercut the competition by exploiting these immigrants," Mr. Castaneda told a crowd of 400 union delegates who gave him four standing ovations.
Raul Hinajosa, a researcher at the University of California at Los Angeles, who serves as a consultant to the Fox administration on immigration, said, "If they want to move this issue forward in the United States, they know U.S. labor can play a make-or-break role on an issue Mexicans care about."
Noting that President Fox has met with several American labor leaders, Mr. Castaneda said the Mexican government was eager to strengthen ties with American labor after labor's bitter fight against the North American Free Trade agreement soured relations with Mexico.
The Mexican government and organized labor are pushing to give legal status to illegal immigrants as the Bush administration has faced intense opposition from conservative Republicans not to agree to such a step. 
Organized labor is looking to Mexico to advance its call for amnesty for the more than five million illegal immigrants, a position that the A.F.L.-C.I.O. adopted last year after decades of hostility to illegal immigrants. But unions are now reaching out to immigrants, seeing them as a source of growth and energy, rather than a threat.
"Immigrants are in every workplace in the United States, and they're not leaving," said John Wilhelm, the president of the hotel employees' union and the chairman of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s task force on immigration policy. "We have to make it clear to immigrant workers that we're on their side."
Labor leaders support granting legal status to illegal workers because that in theory makes them less vulnerable to exploitation since it enables them to make workplace demands and assert their rights without fear of deportation. In demanding legalization, the labor movement also gains favor with not just illegal immigrants -- who are allowed to join unions -- but also legal immigrants who want legal status for relatives or for friends from their hometowns who are here illegally.
Eager to reverse its membership slide, organized labor is focusing increasingly on recruiting immigrant workers, especially low-wage ones, and has had some of its greatest recent success unionizing Mexican immigrants who work as janitors, hotel maids, hospital aides and farm workers. Many Mexican immigrants, reared to idolize Cesar Chavez, the legendary Mexican-American farm workers' leader, see unions as the best way to climb the American economic ladder and secure better wages and fairer treatment on the job.
The American labor movement and the Fox administration have worked intensely to improve ties, partly because they share an interest in improving the lives of Mexican immigrants. In January, Mr. Fox met with John Sweeney, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., and on Monday he met in Detroit with James P. Hoffa, the Teamsters president, and Stephen Yokich, president of the United Auto Workers. 
Last month, Mr. Wilhelm and the presidents of the service employees, farm workers and laborers unions went to Mexico to meet with Mr. Castaneda to discuss legalization of illegal immigrants and labor's concerns about the business community's push to expand the guest worker program.
"I frankly think the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s new position in immigration has had a big impact on having people think that fundamental reform will be possible," Mr. Wilhelm said.
In a half-hour speech, Mr. Castaneda said the Mexican government would not agree to the Bush administration's business-backed proposal to allow in far more guest workers each year unless there was also some agreement on granting legal status to illegal Mexican immigrants.
Mr. Castaneda said Mexico also wanted the United States to agree on ways to promote economic growth in Mexico and on a higher annual quota for permanent legal immigrants from his country.
"It's either the whole enchilada or nothing," Mr. Castaneda said.
To add momentum to the push for legalization, the hotel workers' union voted today to establish what it called an Immigrants Freedom Ride, modeled after the freedom rides of the 1960's civil rights movement. Under the union's proposal, buses carrying illegal immigrants would drive from California and other states to Washington, D.C., daring immigration authorities to arrest them while publicizing the legal limbo and job difficulties faced by these immigrants.
Mr. Wilhelm said, "The reason I think there is an opportunity for significant immigration reform is both parties, but most especially the Republicans, who I think are smarter on this than the Democrats, are figuring out that the new citizens' vote is likely to be the determining factor in what will probably be a close set of elections in 2002 and 2004."

HEADLINE: Treasury Chief: Tax Evasion Is on the Rise 

BYLINE:  By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 18 

 BODY:
Tax evasion by Americans using offshore accounts is rising and will increase, Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill testified today as he tried to persuade a skeptical Democratic senator that he was committed to vigorously pursuing tax cheats.
 Mr. O'Neill said that decades of efforts to catch money launderers and other tax criminals using offshore accounts had not worked. But he dismissed as meaningless a document, based on government data, presented by the senator, Carl Levin, a Michigan Democrat, indicating that fewer than 6,000 of more than 1.1 million offshore accounts and businesses were properly disclosed and therefore legal. Pressed by Senator Levin about whether the disparity between reported offshore accounts and their actual numbers was significant, Mr. O'Neill replied: "I find it amusing." 
 His testimony, to the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, came before Robert M. Morgenthau, the district attorney in Manhattan, described a scale of bank deposits in tax havens far greater than most experts suspected. Citing previously secret Federal Reserve Bank data, Mr. Morgenthau said that more than $800 billion of American money is on deposit in just one tax haven, the Cayman Islands. 
That sum, equal to one-fifth of all the bank deposits in the United States, he said, is so large that it cannot be solely, or even primarily, the fruits of criminal activity like drug dealing. Rather, Mr. Morgenthau said, these funds must be the product of huge and growing tax evasion by wealthy Americans who have little, if any, fear of prosecution. 
He said his office's efforts to pursue tax cheats had often been stymied not just by foreign governments, but by the federal government, especially the Justice and State Departments and the intelligence agencies.
The hearing was prompted by Mr. O'Neill's balking in April at a plan by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development to pressure the Cayman Islands and other tax havens into cooperating with criminal investigations of tax evasion and money laundering. That plan was thrown into disarray after Mr. O'Neill declared that the project was too broad and "not in line with this administration's priorities."
Mr. O'Neill repeatedly insisted that his remarks had been misconstrued by reporters to suggest laxity. "We ought to pursue every tax cheat to the ends of the earth," Mr. O'Neill testified. He cautioned, however, that "we should not presume to interfere with the internal tax policies of sovereign nations."
Mr. O'Neill promised to return, within a year, with treaties in hand from half, as he put it, of the five biggest offshore tax havens, that will help prosecutors in the United States make cases.
He said the Treasury's inability to estimate reliably how much the government spends investigating money laundering has made him skeptical about existing efforts. He vowed to find more efficient and effective ways to combat money laundering and tax fraud.
Mr. O'Neill and Senator Levin agreed on little except that tax fraud and money laundering were significant issues and a growing problem. Senator Levin said that "for years now, offshore tax havens have damaged U.S. interests by facilitating crime, money laundering and tax evasion."
He said the United States loses $70 billion in taxes annually from such evasion -- "a figure so huge that if even half that amount were collected it would pay for a Medicare prescription drug program without raising anyone's taxes or cutting anyone's budget."
Doubting that Senator Levin's attacks would result in improved enforcement, Mr. O'Neill told him, "You are acting like you are going to do something without really accomplishing anything."
Seven former Internal Revenue Service Commissioners sent Mr. O'Neill a letter in June questioning his stance on the O.E.C.D. effort to make foreign tax havens cooperate with investigations of tax crimes. Mr. O'Neill said today that he was "frankly thunderstruck when I got the letter; they responded to misinterpretations in the press."
The letter came in response to an article, in the May 10 Washington Times, which appeared under Mr. O'Neill's own byline.

HEADLINE: Ailing Statue: Symbol of Industry or Pork Barrel? 

BYLINE:  By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 16 

 BODY:
With his body sliced into pieces and spread ignominiously over an asphalt parking lot, Vulcan looks as if he has already been laid low by Senator John McCain's flashing, budget-cutting sword.
 His 11,000-pound head, frozen in an iron grimace, appears to be maintaining a desperate grip on dignity, averting his eyes from his naked posterior a few yards away that was his best-known feature. The raised arm that once inspired a city to steel-making greatness now lies pockmarked and withered on the ground, awaiting the collection of a mere $12.5 million to point skyward again. 
 The beloved old statue that loomed over Birmingham for 61 years fell apart fairly naturally, given its age and the strain of eternally holding aloft a torch on top of Red Mountain. Originally built for the 1904 World's Fair in St. Louis, Vulcan was set on a pedestal above Birmingham in 1938 as an icon of the then-booming steel industry in the valley below. 
But it is the use of tax dollars to help put him back together that has infuriated Mr. McCain, who has spent the last week laboring to transform Vulcan, the Roman god of fire, from a symbol of industry into a symbol of pork-barrel spending, to the bewilderment and anger of the statue's many admirers here.
Birmingham's leaders have been trying to raise the money to restore Vulcan since he was dismantled in 1999 for safety reasons, after city officials began to have nightmares of his limbs falling off and rolling down the mountain into downtown. While about 80 percent of the money will come from private sources, the nonprofit Vulcan Park Foundation asked the federal government to help with about $3 million in restoration money. The money would not only restore the 56-foot statue, but would also return the surrounding park to the rustic look of the Works Progress Administration era.
Like thousands of other small projects in the federal budget, the grant to the statue was championed by local lobbyists and members of Congress, and seemed on its way to a quiet passage until Mr. McCain, the Arizona Republican better known for his support of a campaign finance overhaul, decided to make an example out of the project and butt heads with Vulcan.
"While the federal surplus is rapidly dwindling, why should federal dollars pay for a face lift of a statue of a Roman god in Alabama?" Mr. McCain asked on the Senate floor last Thursday, introducing an amendment that would block federal money for the project.
"Not one more federal dollar should be spent on this kind of foolishness," he said. "I ask my colleagues to extinguish this Roman god of fire and strike a victory for taxpayers -- and Metis, the goddess of prudence -- by throttling down our insatiable appetite for pork-barrel spending, starting today."
Mr. McCain said he knew that his amendment would never pass, and indeed, after passionate speeches in defense of Vulcan by Alabama's two senators, the full Senate approved the money for the statue on a vote of 87 to 12. But after Mr. McCain brought it up again on Sunday in an appearance on the NBC program "Meet the Press" and issued a news release calling for an end to federal subsidies to pagans, many Birmingham residents began to get annoyed.
As every elected official knows, what is pork to 90 percent of the country is a vital or treasured project at home, particularly when covered with a scanty iron loincloth.
"The senator is a little misinformed," said the Rev. Stephen Jones, pastor of Southside Baptist Church, which used to be in the statue's shadow. "No one thinks of it as a pagan symbol. It's the symbol of our city, and with the economy the way it is, we need our symbol back."
Steve Yoder, chairman of the Vulcan Park Foundation, said Vulcan was no less a regional landmark than the Gateway Arch in St. Louis, or the Liberty Bell or -- pointedly -- the Grand Canyon.
"O.K., maybe the Grand Canyon isn't a fair comparison," Mr. Yoder said, "but there are certain symbols and destinations in this country that rise above simply local interests, and deserve a place in the federal budget.
"The Vulcan statue represents the economic transformation of the South, and it's every bit as deserving as any other project."
Local residents interviewed here said they resented the characterization of their symbol as pork and had no trouble describing the statue's importance in their lives, although few of them cited the economic transformation of the South.
"It's where I had my first kiss," said Laura Hardy, a waitress at Jim and Nick's Barbecue, citing a common reason for idolatry at the park.
"I had to stare at it every day in math class," said Ellen Bellsnyder, a colleague at the restaurant, whose high school was near the park. "Now it's just an empty pedestal, and I miss it."
Granted, some of the city's affection for Vulcan was rooted in its slightly silly grandiosity, as it lacks the timeless grace of, say, the Statue of Liberty or Michelangelo's David. But there have been worse reasons for spending federal money. As The Birmingham News wrote a few years ago:
"Sure, he's a green, scantily clad pagan. But at least he's our green, scantily clad pagan."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Decline on Bleak Earnings Reports

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DAY 

 BODY:
Stock prices fell yesterday as investors digested another round of bleak corporate earnings reports along with downbeat comments from Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve's chairman, about the economy's continuing weakness.
 Mr. Greenspan told the House Financial Services Committee that the Fed's six interest rate reductions should help bolster the sluggish American economy later this year. 
 But, he said, "we are not yet free of the risk that economic weakness will be greater than currently anticipated and require further policy response."
Analysts said Mr. Greenspan's comments further frustrated investors, many of whom already said they believed that an economic recovery was still far off. 
"For now, the good news is that the Fed does realize that at least another rate cut is in order, but that does not indicate when capital spending is likely to improve," said Alan Ackerman, a market strategist at Fahnestock & Company. 
The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index fell 51.15 points, or 2.5 percent, to close at 2,016.17. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 36.56 points, or 0.3 percent, to 10,569.83. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 6.73 points, or 0.6 percent, to 1,207.71.
After a broad market rally on Tuesday, in which investors looked past negative earnings reports and focused on forecasts, stocks fell sharply yesterday morning in the wake of disappointing earnings reports.
Shares of Intel, the computer chip maker, fell $1.01, to $28.89, after the company reported Tuesday that its profits dropped 76 percent.
EMC lost $2.34, to $18.05 after the company, a data storage provider, posted a 75 percent decline in its earnings and warned that its financial outlook for the third quarter was worse than it had been for the second quarter.
Veritas Software fell $13.34, to $37.08 , after the company lowered its revenue growth rate for the next quarter because of the decline in corporate technology spending.
The disappointing news from Veritas, which sells data storage software, cast a pall over other software companies, especially those with which it competes. Computer Associates International lost $1.35, to $33.40, and Legato Systems fell $1.52, to $11.99.
Siebel Systems, another software maker, lost $5.91, to $37.64, in regular trading. Late yesterday, the company reported earnings that exceeded Wall Street's estimates but its software sales were weaker than analysts expected. In after-hours trading, Siebel's stock fell $2.77, to $34.87.
Shares of AOL Time Warner fell $4.80, to $44.65 after the company reported revenue that failed to meet expectations. Although AOL's revenue rose 3 percent, to $9.2 billion, analysts predicted it would report revenue of $9.74 billion.
 --------------------

Treasury Prices Up
 (By Reuters) -- Treasury bond prices rallied yesterday, pushing long-term yields to three-month lows, after Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said more interest rate cuts might be needed to help revive the sluggish economy.
The 10-year Treasury note rose 25/32, to a price of 99 10/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.09 percent from 5.20 percent on Tuesday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 12/32, to 97 30/32. The bond's yield fell to 5.52 percent from 5.59 percent on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; 
Sweetness and Light at a Brothel? It Still Sounds Pretty Grim

BYLINE:  By MICHIKO KAKUTANI 

 BODY:
BROTHEL
Mustang Ranch and Its Women
By Alexa Albert
271 pages. Random House. $24.95.
 When the federal government closed the Mustang Ranch in Nevada in August 1999 after fraud and racketeering verdicts were returned against its owners, the brothel was the oldest and most famous in the state. Prostitution was legal in Storey County, and the bordello had been the county's third largest employer, after the Kal Kan pet-food factory and the school district. It supplied some $500,000 a year in tax revenues, one-eighth of the county's $4 million budget. 
 In her new book, Alexa Albert, a Harvard Medical School graduate, gives readers a guided tour through the hermetic subculture of Mustang Ranch. The book, which grew out of a public-health survey and spans several years in the 90's, provides an often intriguing look at the economics and emotional dynamics of the brothel but is seriously undermined by the author's lack of reportorial skills, her failure to back up her anecdotal material with supporting information and her penchant for gross generalizations.
Ms. Albert starts her work with a dogmatic preconception: "I had long believed that prostitution represented 'badness' on multiple levels," she writes. "Practically, it disturbed me because of the dangers to the women who practiced it. Politically, I thought prostitution degraded all women."
After multiple visits to Mustang Ranch, she reaches an equally sweeping and dubious conclusion. She not only ratifies the reasoning of proponents of legalized prostitution -- that "it's naive to believe that prostitution can ever be eliminated" and "only when we recognize and validate the work of professional prostitutes can we expect them to practice their trade safely and responsibly" -- but she also celebrates "the humanity that's at the core of this complex and timeless profession."
"The brothel had provided an income as well as friendship, compassion, trust and hope for countless women and men," she writes. "In many ways, Mustang Ranch picked up where society had dropped the ball. It had provided a safe, nonjudgmental, economically sound work environment and a fair way for a community of several dozen women and their families to meet their most basic needs." In the book's acknowledgments, Ms. Albert adds that she owes an unpayable debt to George Flint, executive director of the Nevada Brothel Association, an unabashed lobbyist for the prostitution business, "for trusting me and for opening the doors to this exotic world."
Though this volume attests to friendships among some members of the Mustang Ranch, though it profiles several hard-working women who chose to become prostitutes to support their families, this concluding paean to the brothel business flies in the face of the indignities and unfairnesses Ms. Albert chronicles in earlier chapters of her book.
Early on she observes that "the brothel residents actually lived like animals in a zoo": the prostitutes "were required to remain on the premises and were let out for fresh-air breaks only in the enclosed front and back yards." To go into town on an errand, they were required to hire "a runner or escort" at their own expense, and they were prohibited from making phone calls on weekends. Each woman's room was equipped with a hidden intercom system that enabled management to eavesdrop on their negotiations with clients, and unannounced room searches were frequently conducted as well.
Although Ms. Albert notes that most of the Mustang women "possessed a profound sense of personal responsibility and an unwavering commitment to their families that ultimately drove them to do this 'immoral' work" many had ended up at the ranch because their boyfriends or husbands had pressured them into the business to make money. "Knowing that so many of these women had been manipulated by men they loved," Ms. Albert writes at one point, "cast them in a new, more tragic light."
As for female solidarity at Mustang -- where the women are required to split their earnings 50-50 with the house and receive no employee benefits -- it is intermittent at best. For all the talk about the brothel being a family, there is fierce competition among the women and occasional incidents of intimidation. (A new prostitute named Heather, for instance, discovers that someone has put Nair in her shampoo.) "When I asked the women why they hadn't organized to form a union or joined together to purchase a brothel themselves," Ms. Albert writes, "most of the prostitutes rolled their eyes and said they could never trust 'another ho.' "
Those passages in which Ms. Albert stops editorializing and simply describes the facts of life at Mustang Ranch are considerably more compelling. She tells us that the women work 12-hour shifts, and average six customers a day. They negotiate with customers over a price, which ranges from $150 to $500, "depending on the time of day, the day of the week, the customer's attitude and how drunk or high he was." Baby, one of the ranch's most successful women, services 70 to 80 customers a week, generating some $300,000 worth of revenue for the brothel in seven months of work.
Whereas Baby says she takes real pride in her work, arguing that prostitution is "a very intimate, service-oriented, people-oriented profession," other women cited in this book are decidedly less upbeat. Donna recounts how her 42-year-old husband, who claimed he was unable to find a job himself, sent her off to Mustang Ranch despite her tears, and gave her a $4,000 monthly quota. Daisy, who later retired from the profession, asserts that the "first words that come to mind" about her work as a prostitute are "degraded, dehumanized, used, victim, ashamed, humiliated, embarrassed, insulted, slave, rape, violated."
In playing down or completely ignoring such comments in her summation, Ms. Albert reveals herself to be an inept reporter and the author of a deeply flawed book.

HEADLINE: Profit Soars at German Software Giant 

BYLINE:  By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON, July 19 

 BODY:
Europe's biggest software maker, SAP of Germany, outpaced rivals and broke ranks with the Continent's gloom-laden technology business today, beating analysts' forecasts with a report of a 78 percent rise in second-quarter profit and offering a bullish forecast for the full year.
 SAP's shares rose more than 11 percent in Frankfurt, outperforming leading technology and blue-chip indexes. Its American shares climbed almost 12 percent. 
 The results suggested that SAP is ahead of American rivals like Oracle, i2 Technologies and Siebel Systems, which compete to supply back-office computer applications enabling businesses to manage an array of operations from inventory control to accounting, increasingly over the Internet.
Both i2 Technologies and Siebel Systems made far less hopeful forecasts on Wednesday.
Analysts ascribed SAP's performance to a broader geographic spread than many of its rivals and its strong position in Europe, despite problems last year with its mySAP.com e-business software.
Across Europe, moreover, customers have slowed purchases of high-technology products, from semiconductors to mobile phones, as they wait out an economic slowdown that has spread from the United States. But, because SAP has some 14,000 existing customers using its products, it is able to sell them updated Internet software, analysts said.
As companies spend less, "it's clear that the big fish will do better," Hasso Plattner, the co-chief executive, told a news conference in New York.
SAP said net income in the second quarter ended June 30 rose to 206 million euros ($179 million), from 116 million euros in the period last year. Sales were up 24 percent, to 1.85 billion euros ($1.6 billion). Excluding the cost of a stock option program and a flurry of acquisitions, margins increased to 23 percent from 16 percent a year earlier.
The second quarter brought major contracts with companies including Compaq in the United States, and major European concerns like AstraZeneca, Nokia and Siemens, the company said.
SAP has said it expects sales growth for the first nine months to outpace last year's 23 percent, and it said today that it expected full-year revenue in 2001 to grow by more than 20 percent. That could imply tougher conditions in the fourth quarter, where many big technology companies are shying from forecasts, said Daud Khan, an analyst with Merrill Lynch.

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

Museums

"A CENTURY OF DESIGN, PART 4: 1975-2000," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 81st Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Jan. 6). The tangle of design trends in the last quarter-century is seen in the tables, chairs, lamps, architectural projects, fabrics, dining implements, a windup lantern, a lemon squeezer and a wristwatch that furnish this internationally minded show. What remains of the function-loving Modernist style appears in Mario Botta's sleek 1982 armchair, whose skeletal frame of matte-finished steel is enhanced only by a gridded black bottom and two back-supporting rolls of polyurethane. Postmodernism, with its backward look to neo-classical forms and materials, has a heavy presence, prominent in a rendering of Ricardo Bofill's stretch Greek temple design for an enormous apartment house in Versailles, France. The green movement, with its socially responsive environmental conscience, and the incorporation of scientific concepts in everyday objects are two other areas represented here. Some of the work is very playful, notably a wildly confused but lovable table by the Italian designer Ettore Sottsass. From this show you could get the idea that the last quarter of the 20th century was not the weightiest era in design history. And you would not be wrong. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $5 for students and 65+ (Grace Glueck).

* "AFRICAN FORMS," Museum for African Art, 593 Broadway, near Houston Street, SoHo, (212) 966-1313 (through Aug. 8). This show forgoes the figurative sculptures and masks that made African art a foundation of Western modernism to concentrate on supposedly humbler stuff, objects of physical adornment and daily use. With some 400 objects created by 156 ethnic groups, it proceeds in clusters of related carved wood neck rests, stools and boxes; ivory hairpins and snuff bottles; all kinds of jewelry; baskets and ceramic vessels; and spoons, weapons and musical instruments. The show is pervaded by an elegance, an economy of form and a sensitivity to materials that is both intensely spiritual and protomodern. Figurative sculpture and masks may be the "high art" of Africa, but there is no low. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $2.50 for students and 65+ (Roberta Smith).

* AFRICAN GALLERIES, Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (on long-term view). The museum has one of the oldest and most important collections of African art in the country. Just a few years ago, 250 objects from the permanent collection were installed in revamped first-floor galleries; now two dozen pieces have been added and the space has been redesigned again, this time with multicolored walls, mural-size color photographs, documentary films and ambient sound. Added works expand the definition of African to include both Morocco and ancient Nubia. And the overall selection, from familiar friends to treasures recently acquired, is thrilling. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (to 11 p.m. the first Saturday of each month). Admission: $4; $2 for students and 62+ (Holland Cotter)

* "AFRICAN, OCEANIC AND ANCIENT AMERICAN ART: RECENT ACQUISITIONS," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Oct. 28). One of the best new group shows in the city is sitting smack in the middle of the Michael C. Rockefeller Wing at the Met, and you've probably never seen the likes of much of what's in it. The 70 pieces all arrived at the Met as gifts or purchases over the last five years. They take many forms, from devotional icons to notebook drawings to Sunday-best hats, and they span centuries and continents, from a tiny Mexican ceramic mask made around the ninth century B.C. to a hummingbird-colored silk mantle woven in Madagascar in 1998. A bottom line to such diversity? Almost everything here was meant to have some contact with the human body: to be worn, carried, caressed. This is art with the velvet ropes down. Hours and admission: See above (Cotter).

"AZTLAN TODAY: THE CHICANO POSTNATION," Bronx Museum of the Arts, 1040 Grand Concourse, at 165th Street, (718) 681-6000 (through Sept. 9). Removed in time from the intensely political art of the Chicano civil rights era, almost everything in this show of recent work takes the form of conceptually based photography and video. The tone is low-key; the polish is high. A stance of rooted historical witness has been replaced by ambiguity. Ethnic identity is treated alternately with shrewd comic flair, tender theatricality or autobiographical intimacy. The work is strong; of particular interest is the way it suggests subtle changes in the nature of political art through the 1990's. Hours: Wednesdays noon to 9 p.m.; Thursdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $3; $2 for students and 65+ (Cotter)

* "BEAUTY, HONOR AND TRADITION: THE LEGACY OF PLAINS INDIAN SHIRTS," National Museum of the American Indian, at the United States Custom House, 1 Bowling Green, Lower Manhattan, (212) 514-3700 (through Nov. 4). To Plains Indians of the 18th and 19th centuries, magnificently decorated hide shirts were symbols of bravery earned in battle by only the most courageous. Obsessively fringed and embellished with porcupine quills, paint, ribbon, hair and later, tight patterns of colored glass beads, the shirts took on the spirits of their owners and even today are made for wearing at powwows and in recognition of other accomplishments. Celebrating the power of this glory gear, almost 50 dazzlers in the museum's collection are on view, dating from about 1820 to the 1990's. Among the more fascinating examples are a brilliantly painted Crow shirt (1890) with beadwork in geometric patterns and frizzy fringes of dyed magenta and yellow hair and a Lakota shirt, circa 1890, that carries United States Army insignia, the American flag and stepped tepees topped by crosses, all worked in porcupine quills and metal beads. Hours: 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. daily; Thursdays to 8 p.m. Free. (Glueck).

"BEYOND THE EASEL: DECORATIVE PAINTING BY BONNARD, VUILLARD, DENIS AND ROUSSEL, 1890-1930," Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1000 Fifth Avenue, at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Sept. 9.) The themes of the 80 or so French paintings in this show, created for bourgeois homes by artists who called themselves the Nabis, couldn't be more lightweight: city parks and country gardens, gift-wrapped tots and fusspot nannies, with the occasional nymph thrown in for tone. Yet the results, with their clotted textures and mildewy palettes of puce, mauve and brown, often look leaden and suffocating, trapped in nostalgia. Bonnard and Vuillard, unsurprisingly, come off best; Maurice Denis and Ker Xavier Roussel less well. Works that haven't been seen together for a century have been gathered for the occasion. Of most interest, though, is the concept of decoration that the Nabis promoted, one that was at once radical and reactionary. Hours and admissions: see above (Cotter).

"MARC CHAGALL: EARLY WORKS FROM RUSSIAN COLLECTIONS," Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92nd Street, (212) 423-3200 (through Oct. 14). When Chagall returned to Russia in 1914 after four years in Paris, he intended to marry his beloved fiancee, Bella Rosenfeld, and hurry back to the French capital. Instead World War I and the Russian Revolution kept him in his homeland for eight years, during which he did some of his greatest work. The 60 artworks here, most being exhibited in the West for the first time, form a series of intense Chagallian doses rather than a comprehensive overview. They are accompanied by nine paintings by Chagall's first teacher, the sensitive realist Yehuda Pen. The show culminates in the seven large, deliriously inventive murals Chagall made for the Jewish State Chamber Theater in Moscow during three feverish months in 1920. Hours: Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Tuesdays, 11 a.m. to 9 p.m.; Mondays, Wednesdays, Thursdays, 11 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays, 11 a.m. to 3 p.m. Admission: $8; $5.50 for students and 65+ ($2 surcharge for "Chagall") (Smith).

* JACQUES AND NATASHA GELMAN GALLERIES, Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 879-5000 (continuing). These glorious new galleries display 50 French modern works, almost all paintings, drawn from the Gelmans' collection. In addition to the paintings here, the collection includes five sculptures, more than 30 drawings and a major work on paper: a Matisse cutout, the Met's first, which will be shown in a subsequent hanging. The standouts installed here include Matisse's Fauve masterpiece "The Young Sailor II"; a matched set of small, classic Cubist paintings, one by Picasso, one by Braque, both from 1911, arguably the high point of their collaboration; and a fantastically refined, sexually fraught 1929 Dali, "Accommodations of Desires." It is a selection that is not only consistent in its high quality but also, for all the big names and visual firepower, surprisingly personal. It makes the museum a modern art destination in a way that it has never quite been before. Hours and admission: See above (Smith).

* WILLIAM KENTRIDGE, New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 219-1222 (through Sept. 16). By way of drawings and film animations, Mr. Kentridge uses searing images to address South Africa and its racial problems, along with the longings and frustrations of bourgeois lives played out in the country's deeply dysfunctional setting. The exhibition begins with his jarring "Shadow Procession" (1999), a ragtag parade of silhouetted moving images projected on a big screen, which evokes the displaced and dispossessed who haunt not only South Africa but also the history of the world. At the heart of the show are his drawings and the short animated films he makes of them, in which the process shares importance with the content. Many of the films contrast the lives of two antiheroes, one a crude rapacious businessman, the other a sensitive artist, in compelling medleys of images that touch on the personal and the political. Departing from this format is "Ubu Tells the Truth" (1997), a highly charged satire based on the hearings of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission, set up in 1995 to investigate human rights abuses in the apartheid era. It's not often that good art is shaped from such raw angry material, but Mr. Kentridge's powers of invention are equal to the challenge. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Thursdays to 8 p.m. Admission: $6; $3 for students, artists and 65+ (Glueck).

* "MASTER DRAWINGS FROM THE CLEVELAND MUSEUM OF ART," Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street, (212) 685-0610 (through Aug. 19). From Michelangelo to Louise Bourgeois, from Rembrandt to Franz Kline, this cornucopia of drawings from one of the most important collections in the United States bristles with the work of stellar talents. A standout is a double-sided drawing in red chalk by Michelangelo, probably done around 1510-11. One side reveals the trouble he had sketching a foot that fits the position of a youthful male nude on the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel; the other shows the headless nude. A rare compositional drawing by Fra Filippo Lippi, a subtly toned landscape by Claude Lorrain, a scene of battling horses by Gericault, a stately portrait by Ingres, one of Seurat's brilliant black crayon drawings of a French vaudeville scene, and works by Degas and Toulouse-Lautrec are among the highlights. The 20th-century American group is something of a disappointment, but there are enough great things from other eras to make this a masterpiece of a show. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, 10:30 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays, 10:30 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $8; $6 for students and 65+ (Glueck).

"MASTER DRAWINGS FROM THE SMITH COLLEGE MUSEUM OF ART," Frick Collection, 1 East 70th Street, (212) 288-0700 (through Aug. 12). This selection of drawings spanning six centuries has compelling works on paper by some of the more resonant names in Western art history, names like Tiepolo, Boucher, Ingres, Gericault, Beardsley, van Gogh, Mondrian and others. There are works of only academic proficiency, but in far more cases the drawing sings: in the 15th-century Italian Rosso Fiorentino's near-orgiastic vision of a double martyrdom made with urgent sensuousness in red chalk, for example, or Seurat's studies for "La Grande Jatte," in which broad, deft swipes of a black crayon evoke the silhouettes of women who seem almost dissolved by watery light (Ken Johnson).

*"MIGRATIONS: HUMANITY IN TRANSITION," photographs by Sebastiao Salgado, International Center of Photography, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43rd Street, (212) 860-1777 (through Sept. 9). The show (there are two accompanying books) is the product of seven years in more than 35 countries documenting what Mr. Salgado calls "the reorganization of the human family," partly because of the shift from "majority rural to majority urban." His subjects are refugees, exiles, orphans, landless peasants, homeless families, boat people, internees and others. This is a sprawling, frequently gruesome story -- the scale and the gravity of it should speak for themselves -- and if the suffering doesn't prompt guilt, indifference to it will. That's how emotional blackmail and effective moral photojournalism work. Mr. Salgado practices both as well as anyone does these days. Of course the pictures are also explotaitive, but that's also a feature of photojournalism. We respond despite the voyeurism and the manipulation because of the formal beauty. The good photographs are so stupendously gorgeous that, for better and worse, they can make you forget everything else while you are looking at them. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $8; $6 for students and 65+ (Michael Kimmelman).

* WAYNE THIEBAUD: A PAINTINGS RETROSPECTIVE," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3600 (through Sept. 23). The world not being a perfect place, this show will be around only through the summer, so consider yourself forewarned. At the Whitney, as in life, happiness is fleeting. Meanwhile, you are free to bask in these pumpkin pies, meat and cheese deli counters, lipsticks, hot dogs and gum-ball machines, which, as Mr. Thiebaud has painted them for the last 40 years, have the aura of loves lost and too fondly recalled. Joy yielding to melancholy then yields to the less jolting but more durable satisfaction of being in the presence of pictures so lovingly and wittily made. These pictures provoke happiness if for no other reason than that they are content to be what they are, which is enough, this being the same message they convey about the modest objects and people they depict. (A smaller show of recent work by Mr. Thiebaud is at Allan Stone Gallery, 113 East 90th Street, through today; information: 212-987-4997.) Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $8 for students and 62+ (Kimmelman).

Galleries: Uptown

LOCKWOOD DE FOREST, Richard York, 21 East 65th Street, (212) 772-9155 (through July 27). By no means a name to reckon with in the pantheon of American view makers, de Forest (1850-1932) specialized in unpretentious small sketches meant to convey the feeling of a place rather than dwell on its physical attributes. His work, until recently kept mostly in family hands, was a visual diary of his many wanderings. In contrast to the taste of the time, he regarded his sketches as finished works, focusing, even in exotic locations like Egypt, India, Syria, Greece and Mexico, on village life, stretches of dunes, desert rocks, tree-lined shores and distant mountains bathed in fog. For those who like their countrysides relaxed and uninvasive, this show will appeal (Glueck).

"MINIMAL," Zwirner & Wirth, 32 East 69th Street, (212) 517-8677 (through Aug. 10; reopens Aug. 27 to 31). This elegant show includes works of classic Minimalism like a box made of stainless steel and fluorescent red Plexiglas by Donald Judd; an iconic arrangement of red, pink and yellow fluorescent lights by Dan Flavin; and a gorgeous, glossy red, thick plank shape by John McCracken. It also embraces more Conceptually motivated works, like words on the wall by Lawrence Weiner that say "Around the bend"; a square of typewritten concrete poetry by Carl Andre; and photographs of framework houses by Bernd and Hilla Becher (Johnson).

* "POP ART: THE JOHN AND KIMIKO POWERS COLLECTION," Gagosian Gallery, 980 Madison Avenue, at 77th Street, (212) 744-2313 (through Aug. 31). With his Japanese-born wife, Kimiko, John Powers (1916-1999), a former president of the Prentice-Hall publishing company, gathered a big-bang collection of Pop Art by the movement's stars. The 26 objects shown here, including works by Robert Rauschenberg, Jasper Johns, Claes Oldenburg, Roy Lichtenstein, Andy Warhol and James Rosenquist, are mostly from the 1960's, and they bring a whole era back into vivid focus. Among the signature works are Warhol's serial extravaganza, "200 Soup Cans" (1962); Mr. Rauschenberg's "Broadcast" (1959), a combine painting with a working radio attached; and Mr. Oldenburg's soft "Drum Set" (1967), a bodylike sendup of a professional drummer's instruments in vinyl and canvas that droops on a platform in a metaphor for its own spent energy. Collectors' collectors, the Powerses made the pursuit of art into an art of their own (Glueck).

"VOYAGES: A SMITHSONIAN LIBRARIES EXHIBITION," Grolier Club, 47 East 60th Street, (212) 838-6690 (through Aug. 4). Mostly a selection of mostly rare books with some curious objects also, "Voyages" offers a miniature cross section of the vast holdings of the Smithsonian Institution Libraries. Contents range from remarkable antiquities like "Mundus Subterraneus" by the 17th-century Dutch scholar Athanasius Kircher, thought to be the earliest printed study of geophysics and vulcanology, to a copy of Neil Armstrong's "Stroll on the Moon," which is signed by the author and the fellow astronauts Buzz Aldrin and Michael Collins. (Johnson).

PAUL WEINGARTEN; ADOLFO BARNATAN, Salander-O'Reilly, 20 East 79th Street, (212) 879-6606 (through July 27). The thickly painted, acid-hued still lifes of lobsters and fish, fruits and vegetables, and homey kitchenware by Paul Weingarten of Montclair, N.J., have a hectic, expressionistic energy that calls to mind Chaim Soutine, though without his melting sensuousness. The Madrid-based Mr. Baratan's smooth, simplified sculptures in stone include ancient Egyptian-style heads arranged in a Modernist grid and flat, near-Minimalist discs that evoke the sun and the moon (Johnson).

Galleries: 57th Street

ADA GILMORE: "THE SUMMER OF 1915: WATERCOLORS FROM PROVINCETOWN," Mary Ryan, 24 West 57th Street, (212) 397-0669 (through July 31). All 22 paintings in this modestly radiant exhibition were made on the backs of official United States Postal Service postcards during the year after World War I drove this American Modernist from Paris to Provincetown. Gilmore's sunny, Impressionistic pictures of women gardening or doing laundry or views of houses among trees become more absorbing the more you look. Like her most obvious influence, Vuillard, she worked a fine balance between vibrantly patterned surface and evocative domestic space (Johnson).

MORRIS GRAVES, "Still Life," Schmidt Bingham, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 888-1122 (through Aug. 17). This small retrospective honors a great American original who died in May at 90. Ranging from vigorously palette-knifed paintings of drinking fountains from the 1930's to exquisitely delicate pictures of flowers in transparent bottles from the 90's, the show gives a fine taste of Graves's craftsmanlike versatility and his modest yet intense poetic sensibility (Johnson).

ALEXANDER LIBERMAN, "Maquettes for Monuments," Ameringer/Howard, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 935-1110 (through Aug. 10). In the late 1960's, this Modernist sculptor and Conde Nast editorial director produced gigantic abstractions using old, unearthed gas pipes. On view here are sleek little copies of those monumental works, compositions of standing, leaning or tumbling cylinders finished in glossy red or matte rust-colored patina. Though not deeply consequential, they are appealingly precious (Johnson).

"SIGNS OF LIFE," Ramis Barquet, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 644-9090 (through July 27). This disjunctive but interesting six-artist show includes lively, comically erotic semi-abstract pink paintings by Fernanda Brunet; tires with treads recarved into traditional decorative motifs by Betsabee Romero; strangely clinical photographs of a man in his underwear by Ernesto Pujol; small, iconic realist paintings by Marco Arce; a droopy shaped painting by Leda Catunda; and a funny video by Ximena Cuevas in which she breathlessly practices introducing herself to the video curator John Hanhardt (Johnson).

Galleries: Chelsea

JOHN BALDESSARI, JEFF KOONS, TOM WESSELMANN, Sonnabend, 536 West 22nd Street, (212) 627-1018 (through July 27). The big surprise is how shockingly uninteresting one finds Mr. Koons's dry, anonymously painted, Rosenquist-style montages. Mr. Baldessari's new photo-constructions offer the familiar conceptual impenetrability and visual enervation that have always characterized his least interesting works. But the unassuming hedonism of Mr. Wesselmann's three cutout steel works -- a rippling abstraction, a still life and a cartoon landscape -- is delightfully if not deeply seductive (Johnson).

"BEING THERE," Derek Eller, 526-30 West 25th Street, (212) 206-6411 (through July 27). Highlights of this lively eight-artist show include Carl D'Alvia's bionic monkey and child; Jeff Sonhouses' masklike face finely painted in watercolor with an Afro of real burned matches; Tricia Keightly's neo-Art Nouveau abstract painting; a comical, quirkily detailed landscape painted by Johan Nobell; and, by Jennifer Sirey, a wobbly, pyramidal tower of glass boxes with moldy interiors (Johnson).

JACQUELINE BOOTIER, "Basic Training," Lombard/Freid, 531 West 26th Street, (212) 967-8040 (through July 27). This promising show of exuberantly painterly pictures based on old family snapshots is Ms. Bootier's first solo. The L.A.-based artist trowels swathes of thick paint this way and that, creating vibrant, fractured spaces around lumpy, gnarly figures. In "Potty Training" a sad little girl with her pants down seems overwhelmed by the inexplicable and chaotic pressures of her young life (Johnson).

"CAMERA WORKS: THE PHOTOGRAPHIC IMPULSE IN CONTEMPORARY ART," Marianne Boesky Gallery, 535 West 22nd Street, (212) 680-9889 (through Aug. 11). Despite the encompassing title, this show focuses almost exclusively on photographs by 31 established artists, mostly in their 30's and 40's, who are not known primarily, if at all, for working with the camera. Usual suspects are in the majority, from Ross Bleckner to Lisa Yuskavage, with Peter Doig, Jessica Stockholder, Rachel Whiteread and Gregor Schneider in between. But there are still plenty of surprises and revelations, especially when you find yourself thinking that some of the assembled should stick to photography (Smith).

JASON DUVAL, Marcello Marvelli, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 627-3363 (through Aug. 5). The small, blocky abstractions in this young painter's first solo exhibition have a painterly touch that veers from graceful to brusque and a finely tuned sense of color. At best, in two larger, more finished works that call to mind the paintings of Thomas Nozkowski, the circulating line, semi-transparent glazes and vibrating play of reds or greens reward extended contemplation (Johnson).

ENEAS, "Thriller," Esso, 211 West 28th Street, (212) 560-9728, (through Aug. 16). Every canvas in this empty but archly sophisticated display of insider gamesmanship has the name Michael Jackson stenciled across the top above a skillful simulation of gesture or drip painting by Jackson Pollock, who shares a name with the mercurial pop star. These works so closely resemble George Condo's jazz album cover paintings you can't help but suspect the sly Condo might have invented Eneas. (Johnson).

NEIL FARBER: NEW DRAWINGS, Clementine Gallery, 526 West 26th Street,(212) 243-5937 (through July 27). Children, cats, the Devil and hell are recurrent themes for this young Canadian artist, whose cartoony, vaguely "Peanuts"-like whimsies seem to proliferate like rabbits on the gallery walls. In his artfully artless drawings, sometimes mordant, sometimes terminally cute, animals morph into more unaccustomed creatures; children drink poison and descend to the netherworld; a pair of swallowed birds preen in the stomach of a smug cat. His free flow of the pen could use, if not quenching, a little editing (Glueck).

"FOUR ABSTRACT CLASSICISTS," Gary Snyder, 601 West 29th Street, (212) 871-1077 (through Aug. 25). This punchy time capsule of a show features works from the 1950's and 60's by four West Coast painters of hard-edged abstraction -- Karl Benjamin, Lorser Feitelson, Frederick Hammersley and John McLaughlin. The exhibition recalls a generational shift away from Abstract Expressionism toward the cooler aesthetics of the 1960's. Its title invites reflection on the paradoxical tension in reductive abstraction between historical avant-gardism and timeless formalism (Johnson).

RICHARD HAMILTON, "Prints, 1968-1998," Charles Cowles Gallery, 537 West 24th Street, (212) 925-3500 (through Aug. 17). James Joyce's "Ulysses" and tabloid subjects like Mick Jagger's arrest for drug possession are part of the huge print repertory of the English painter Richard Hamilton. Mr. Hamilton is wide-ranging not only in subject matter but also in print technique; while not dispensing with venerable practices like etching and engraving, he sets no limits on technical possibilities, fooling around with contemporary techniques from silk-screening to computer manipulation of digital images, sometimes using several in the same print. This wonderfully animated show illustrates his belief that images will always be more important than the manner of their execution. But it also reveals the role that technical innovation plays in the impact of his graphic work (Glueck).

"HEAT," Margaret Thatcher, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 675-0222 (through July 27). This intentionally dissonant and overcrowded exhibition has some interesting things in it, like Patrick Wilson's smooth, dark red monochrome painting; a drippy, candy-colored stripe painting by Markus Linnenbrink; odd, slightly comical, smoothly carved lumps of marble by Venske and Spanle; and a radiating, psychedelic, computer-generated print by Daren Kendall (Johnson).

"SUPERIMPOSITION," Caren Golden Fine Art, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 727-8304 (through July 27). This smart group show by mostly young American artists, organized by the critic David Hunt, focuses on art based on stacking, layering, volume or the illusion of depth. One sculpture is made from vertically arranged reels of film, another from painstakingly assembled stones. A painting is composed from layers of drizzled paint; a fabric relief from a free-associational network of words. The deep space of science fiction gets some play in a Minimalist wall piece that doubles as a star ship control panel. And a digital work weaves together personal references, abstract forms and music (Cotter).

"THE WEDDING SHOW," Casey Kaplan, 416 West 14th Street, (212) 645-7335 (through July 31). The best piece in this miscellaneous roundup of gallery artists (titled in honor of Mr. Kaplan's recent nuptials) is Carsten Holler's reclining, hairless orangutan: with a life-size body of fleshy rubber, expressive glass eyes and bony toe- and fingernails, it has a winsome, almost human presence. Also noteworthy are Karen Yasinsky's drawing of Girl Scouts in the woods; Anna Gaskell's mysterious photographic narrative about nurses; and John Chilver's painterly play of abstraction around a primitive man and his campfire (Johnson).

Galleries: SoHo

AIDAS BAREIKIS, "Silence Before the Curve," Leo Koenig, 359 Broadway, near Grand Street, (212) 334-9255 (through July 28). Mr. Bareikis produces aggressively messy yet artfully color-coordinated installations of found objects, paint, wax, foam, plastic, scrapwood and many other materials. The main event is an epic spill of mostly silvery or transparent plastic materials, including helmets, tools, toys, human legs in motorcycle gear, a motorcycle partly dismantled and partly rebuilt out of found junk, and wax-drenched zombie-like figures struggling to rise from the wreckage (Johnson).

* LOUISE BOURGEOIS AND YAYOI KUSAMA, Peter Blum, 99 Wooster Street, (212) 343-0441 (through July 28; reopens Aug. 21 to Sept. 15). Bringing Ms. Bourgeois and Ms. Kusama together for the first time in this illuminating drawing show was an inspired idea. Both have found inspiration in the wilder parts of consciousness, and both have long practiced repetitive mark-making. In a recent drawing by Ms. Bourgeois, nested ovals made in a scratchy red line create a primitivistic, enigmatically iconic image. Ms. Kusama's dot fields and all-over linear networks produce, at their best, eye-buzzing opticality and cosmic transcendentalism (Johnson).

TEUN HOCKS, P.P.O.W., 476 Broome Street, (212) 941-8642 (through Aug. 10). For his large, funny and mysterious photographs, this Dutch artist constructs and paints his own sets, and, like Buster Keaton or Magritte's bowler-hatted Everyman, performs actions that prompt philosophical meditation on reality and illusion. The image of the artist concentrating on a burning candle in his hand while the sun blazes behind him might be a metaphor about the human limits of spiritual perception (Johnson).

JUDI WERTHEIN AND LEANDRO ERLICH, "Turismo," Kent Gallery, 67 Prince Street, (212) 966-4500, (through Aug. 2). This photo-installation piece by two Argentine artists, a hit at the seventh Havana Biennial last fall, revolves around big color Polaroids of ordinary Cubans posing as they please in a loonily unlikely setting: a sparkling winter wonderland incorporating a bright Alpine backdrop, fake snow underfoot and props including skis, a sled and Styrofoam snowballs. The original snow-scene set is also here -- pristine, carefully lighted and inviting. Cultural and climatic contrasts abound, and the images point up the paradox that although Cuba is economically dependent upon tourism, its citizens are not free to travel. But these beautiful, joyful, ineluctably poignant images transcend such didacticism. They exemplify the best kind of site-specific, political art, one that makes its points effortlessly and travels well (Smith).

"WET!" Luise Ross Gallery, 568 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 343-2161 (through July 27). Some summer group shows just want to have fun, and this one accomplishes the goal with admirable flair and ecumenicism. The slippery subject helps. Wetness is surveyed with a thoroughness that includes geography, food, sport and sex. The artists range from Sigmar Polke to Bill Traylor to Patty Chang and Nicole Eisenman, and the styles are just as various (Smith).

Other Galleries

TONY CRAGG, "Turbo-Ferryman," Doris C. Freedman Plaza, Fifth Avenue and 60th Street, (212) 980-4575 (through October). This year's Public Art Fund installation here consists of two bulbous bronze sculptures by a consistently interesting British sculptor. One is a perforated, biomorphic bottlelike form with wiggly arms going in and out of its body; the other is a big, asymmetrical shape, like a toy top with odd lumpy places. In a gallery either would be fine; outdoors they look too small. If one or the other were five times larger, it would be terrific (Johnson).

"FACES AND FIGURES: CONTEMPORARY PHOTOGRAPHY IN SCANDINAVIA," Scandinavia House, 58 Park Avenue, near 38th Street, (212) 779-3587 (through July 29). Nordic photography makes a good showing here with a mix of established and lesser- known talents using a range of approaches, from documentary to personal diary. The aim is to dispel stereotypes about "coolness, control and psychic remoteness" in the words of Ann Sass, chief curator. And the show succeeds, with a humanscape of transvestite haunts in Paris, high jinks in Swedish suburbs, hunting and farming in Iceland, plain folk at home in Sweden, Christmas in Finland, prostitutes plying their trade in Denmark and children frolicking in Norway (Glueck).

Last Chance

* "ABCD: A COLLECTION OF ART BRUT," Museum of American Folk Art, 2 Lincoln Square, Columbus Avenue at 66th Street, (212) 977-7170 (through Sunday). Memorably vivid and widely abused, the phrase Art Brut (meaning raw or rough art) was coined in the 1940's by the French artist Jean Dubuffet. This exhibition, drawn from the holdings of a Paris-based foundation, tries to reinstate his original meaning, revisiting the amazing pantheon of artists who inspired it and proposing some additions. Its many highlights include works by acknowledged greats like Adolf Wolfli, Aloise Corbaz, Henry Darger and Augustin Lesage, but the show also introduces many equally riveting artists unfamiliar to American audiences. Hours: Today through Sunday, 11:30 a.m. to 7:30 p.m. Free (Smith).

* "BETWEEN STREET AND MIRROR: THE DRAWINGS OF JAMES ENSOR," Drawing Center, 35 Wooster Street, SoHo, (212) 219-2166 (through tomorrow). The show's pleasure partly involves serendipity. This feels like the perfect moment for an oddball like Ensor, but maybe any time would feel like the right time for somebody whose work, whether it is appalling or fantastic (and it can be both simultaneously), looks eternally modern. The drawings are from the 1880's and 90's. Some started out as ordinary sketches of household objects to which faces and monsters were added, like Rorschachs of the artist's imagination. They somehow become more luminous and translucent the more densely they are drawn, an extraordinary paradox. On the other hand, when the drawings aren't dense, they can be vaporous like Turners, with an effect akin to looking back on a dream: you can't quite place what you are seeing. But the emotion the images provoke is stronger precisely because of the frustration attached to it. Ensor is one of those artists Americans tend to forget or never really knew properly. A hero in Europe, he is vastly deserving of reappraisal here (Kimmelman).

RACHEL LEE HOVNANIAN, "Isolation Beauty," David Beitzel, 102 Prince Street, SoHo,(212) 219-2863 (through today). In a simplifying style indebted in part to Alex Katz, Ms. Hovnanian paints the people, places and things of a comfortably privileged life. At her best, she conjures up a mysterious state of lonely suspension (Johnson).

HEADLINE: 8 Months Later, Talks on Climate Treaty Restart, Now in Bonn 

BYLINE:  By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

DATELINE: BONN, July 19 

 BODY:
Nearly eight months after formal talks over a proposed climate treaty fell apart in The Hague, negotiations resumed here today in nearly as tangled and troubled a state.
 Informal talks started on Monday, and today environment ministers and other senior diplomats who represented 178 nations took their seats. Jan Pronk, chairman of the talks since last year, admonished them to find consensus, albeit without the United States, the largest emitter of heat-trapping gases. The United States has rejected the treaty. 
 "We did a good job in Kyoto," Mr. Pronk, of the Netherlands, said, defending the document negotiated in 1997 in Japan. "It is the only game in town. It is the best we have." 
The accord, now called the Kyoto Protocol, would be the first treaty to require industrialized countries to cut emissions of carbon dioxide and other gases linked to a potentially disruptive warming trend. Because it could have just as many effects on economies as on the environment, negotiations have proved extraordinarily complex and contentious. 
In talks today, wealthy countries still disagreed over rules to measure cuts and punish those that failed to meet targets. Poor countries insisted that wealthy ones help pay for damage from changing temperatures and rising sea levels, and they want control over spending that money.
Although President Bush rejected the treaty months ago, the United States, even from the sidelines, threw a long shadow over the officials, corporate lobbyists and environmentalists who milled in the halls of the Maritim Hotel. American negotiators, ending their routine of nightly news conferences last year, remained deeply immersed in talks on points that they said could harm the country's interests. At least one point could imperil the effort to close out the talks and allow countries to seek ratification. That point is a proposal for a $1 billion-a-year fund to help developing countries.
Under a negotiating text used as a guide for the talks, some of that money would be paid by all countries that have signed an existing climate treaty, including the United States. That is a structure that some developing countries prefer, because it guarantees that they will receive the money even if the Kyoto Protocol never takes effect. But it could also theoretically mean that the United States would have to pay for parts of the Kyoto pact even though Mr. Bush has rejected it. 
At a news session this evening, Mr. Pronk appeared to side with Washington on that point. "If you are not becoming a party to the protocol," he said, "it would not be fair to be expected to have implicitly or indirectly similar obligations as those countries who become a party." 
That could become a sticking point at the conference if the developing countries, 134 of which act as a bloc, insist that the proposed payment structure follow the current plan.
Other disputes simmered unrelated to United States interests. Europe, Japan and Canada once again debated the merits of forests as a means of absorbing carbon dioxide. 
Generally, however, the tone was more subdued at this meeting than the one that was suspended last fall, when cream pies were thrown at American negotiators and protesters climbed to the rafters of the Dutch conference center.
"At The Hague, there was a sense of urgency," said Glenn Kelly, executive director of the Global Climate Coalition, a lobby in Washington that has fought the protocol through contributions from industry. "Here it's more like being at the wake for a not-so-well-liked second cousin."

HEADLINE: What the Protesters in Genoa Want 

BYLINE:  By Michael Hardt and Antonio Negri; Michael Hardt and Antonio Negri are the authors of "Empire."

 BODY:
Genoa, that Renaissance city known for both openness and shrewd political sophistication, is in crisis this weekend. It should have thrown its gates wide for the celebration of this summit of the world's most powerful leaders. But instead Genoa has been transformed into a medieval fortress of barricades with high-tech controls. The ruling ideology about the present form of globalization is that there is no alternative. And strangely, this restricts both the rulers and the ruled.
 Leaders of the Group of Eight have no choice but to attempt a show of political shrewdness. They try to appear charitable and transparent in their goals. They promise to aid the world's poor, and they genuflect to Pope John Paul II and his interests. But the real agenda is to renegotiate relations among the powerful, on issues like the construction of missile defense systems. 
 The leaders, however, seem detached somehow from the transformations around them, as though they were following the stage directions from a dated play. We can see the photo already, though it has not yet been taken: President George W. Bush as an unlikely king, bolstered by lesser monarchs. This is not quite an image of the future. It resembles more an archival photo, pre-1914, of superannuated royal potentates.
Those demonstrating against the summit in Genoa, however, are not distracted by these old-fashioned symbols of power. They know that a fundamentally new global system is being formed. The world can no longer be understood in terms of British, French, Russian or even American imperialism.
The many protests that have led up to Genoa were based on the recognition that no national power is in control of the present global order. Consequently, protests must be directed at international and supranational organizations like the G-8, the World Trade Organization, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. The movements are not anti-American, as they often appear, but are aimed at a different, larger power structure.
If it is not national but supranational powers that rule today's globalization, however, we must recognize that this new order has no democratic institutional mechanisms for representation, as nation-states do: no elections, no public forum for debate.
The rulers are effectively blind and deaf to the ruled. The protesters take to the streets because this is the form of expression available to them. The lack of other venues and social mechanisms is not their creation.
Antiglobalization is not an adequate characterization of the protesters in Genoa (or Goteborg, Quebec, Prague, or Seattle). The globalization debate will remain hopelessly confused, in fact, unless we insist on qualifying the term globalization. The protesters are indeed united against the present form of capitalist globalization, but the vast majority of them are not against globalizing currents and forces as such; they are not isolationist, separatist or even nationalist.
The protests themselves have become global movements, and one of their clearest objectives is the democratization of globalizing processes. This should not be called an antiglobalization movement. It is pro-globalization, or rather it is an alternative globalization movement -- one that seeks to eliminate inequalities between rich and poor and between the powerful and the powerless, and to expand the possibilities of self-determination.
If we understand one thing from the multitude of voices in Genoa this weekend, it should be that a different and better future is possible. When one recognizes the tremendous power of the international and supranational forces that support our present form of globalization, one could conclude that resistance is futile.
But those in the streets today are foolish enough to believe that alternatives are possible -- that "inevitability" should not be the last word in politics. A new species of political activist has been born with a spirit that is reminiscent of the paradoxical idealism of the 1960's -- the realistic course of action today is to demand what is seemingly impossible, that is, something new.
Protest movements are an integral part of a democratic society, and for this reason alone we should all thank those in the streets in Genoa, whether we agree with them or not. Protest movements, however, do not provide a practical blueprint for how to solve problems, and we should not expect that of them. They seek rather to transform the public agenda by creating political desires for a better future.
We see seeds of that future already in the sea of faces that stretches from the streets of Seattle to those of Genoa. One of the most remarkable characteristics of these movements is their diversity: trade unionists together with ecologists together with priests and communists. We are beginning to see a multitude emerge that is not defined by any single identity, but can discover commonality in its multiplicity.
These movements are what link Genoa this weekend most clearly to the openness -- toward new kinds of exchange and new ideas -- of its Renaissance past.

HEADLINE: Apartment Buyouts 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "$25,000? I'm Leaving Today," by John Tierney (Big City column, July 17): 
 Most affordable rent-stabilized apartments are held by those who live and work in the city and are not looking to cash in and move to the suburbs. 
Their jobs, families and roots are here, and they are at the limit of what they can afford, so moving makes no sense socially, geographically or economically.
Low-income tenants looking for a buyout do so because they have no other option. They may lack the resources to challenge an eviction proceeding. Inadequately insured, they might face huge medical bills and need a quick infusion of cash. They won't be moving up in the housing food chain to make room for others at a low-rent level. Instead, they compete for even cheaper housing. 
This buyout scheme based on myth cannot result in a glut of vacant apartments driving down prices when there is already an exponential supply-and-demand disparity.

CRAIG ACORN
New York, July 18, 2001

The writer is staff attorney, Urban Justice Center.

HEADLINE: New York Needs a Place to Live 

BYLINE:  By Roland Lewis; Roland Lewis is executive director of Habitat for Humanity-New York City.

 BODY:
Times are still good in New York City, after a long boom coupled with the benefits of a drop in crime. The next mayor, rightly, is expected to focus on fixing the schools. But another slow-motion crisis threatens to undermine the city's progress.
 The growing shortage of affordable housing is threatening to make the city once again unlivable. A year from now, we can expect the housing crisis to be at the center of New York's politics. Consider it the sleeper issue. 
 The mayoral candidates seem aware of the brewing problem. At candidate forums and in position papers, they have begun to address the housing issue, recognizing that the way the winner deals with it is likely to determine his legacy.
This focus on housing for all New Yorkers can't come soon enough, because the problems in finding a decent place to live have never been more severe for New Yorkers. During the last decade, New York City added 456,000 new residents but built only 82,000 new units of housing. The rental vacancy rate in the city has dropped sharply, to just over 3 percent -- its lowest point in a decade.
There are now 150,000 doubled-up renter households in the five boroughs. Half a million New Yorkers now spend more than 50 percent of their incomes on housing. There is an eight-year waiting list to live in New York City public housing. And there are still 27,000 New Yorkers who will live in shelters on any given night.
This housing crunch affects us all in ways we sometimes don't even see. A recent public opinion poll found that 45 percent of New Yorkers had "seriously considered moving out of the city" because of its high housing costs. The high price of housing is one reason new teachers have been so hard to recruit and retain in city schools. If we do not find a way to provide decent, affordable housing, efforts to improve education, health and law enforcement could be undermined.
But just as we found ways to bring down crime and expand economic development in distressed communities, we can build and keep affordable housing if government acts in tandem with the private sector. The new mayor should double the level of current city spending, now at about $500 million a year. Additional city subsidies could induce new private investors to create below-market-rate housing. Religious and civic groups can do much to help guide this kind of development, but a substantial government investment will be crucial.
Government has acted successfully before. The city housing program begun under Mayor Ed Koch built tens of thousands of homes and revitalized whole neighborhoods. The program created under New York State's Mitchell-Lama legislation produced 125,000 middle-income apartments from the 1950's to the 1970's. The new mayor must persuade the state and federal governments to increase their share of housing costs, and he must convince New York City's business community that an expanded investment in housing is economically smart as well as morally right.
The good news is that there is tremendous expertise in our city to build the needed homes; neighborhood-based community development corporations, government agencies and private developers all have the right experience. These groups and many others from the business, religious and nonprofit worlds -- more than 150 organizations -- have come together to form a new coalition called Housing First! This coalition is seeking a $10 billion investment in housing in New York City over the next 10 years that would create 100,000 new homes and preserve an additional 85,000 homes.
Each of the four major Democratic mayoral candidates -- Fernando Ferrer, Mark Green, Alan Hevesi and Peter Vallone -- has proposed his own multiyear, multibillion-dollar housing program. The Republican Michael Bloomberg, the political newcomer in the race, has also discussed housing as a central issue.
For candidates, talking about the need is easy. But voters will have to press them for answers to hard questions: Where will the housing go? How much city-owned land will be dedicated to housing? What types of housing and what services should be provided to the homeless? How should zoning laws be changed to encourage more housing development?
The legacy of the next mayor is likely to depend on how well he focuses on these issues. The housing crisis will drive the city's future and will have an increasing impact on education, crime and poverty. But if the next mayor acts aggressively and imaginatively, it is possible for New York to achieve real gains in housing, just as it has against crime.
