HEADLINE: Forecasting Index Registers Third Consecutive Increase 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 19 

 BODY:
The index of leading economic indicators rose for a third month in June, a private research firm said today, suggesting growth may accelerate by the end of the year.
 A gain in consumer confidence last month helped push the Conference Board's gauge up 0.3 percent after a 0.4 percent increase in May. 
 The rise reinforces the view "that the news is no longer unrelentingly negative," said David Orr, chief economist at First Union in Char lotte, N.C. "An 'all clear' for the economy isn't guaranteed, but it adds to the tentative evidence of a recovery." 
In noting the improvement, the New York-based research group also said the economic outlook "remains fragile." Reports on trade, initial jobless claims and Philadelphia-area manufacturing confirm what Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, told Congress on Wednesday: stronger growth is more likely, not a given.
The trade deficit narrowed 11.4 percent in May, to a 16-month low of $28.3 billion, as imports of consumer goods and business equipment sank, the Commerce Department reported today. While that suggests falling demand, it also means that foreign producers rather than American factories have absorbed some effects of the decline. Exports rose, led by pharmaceuticals and other consumer goods.
First-time claims for unemployment insurance fell 35,000 last week, to 414,000, as automakers recalled workers from seasonal shutdowns. At the same time, the number of workers continuing to receive jobless benefits climbed to 3.11 million in the first full week of July, the most since October 1992.
The Philadelphia Fed's index of manufacturing in Delaware, eastern Pennsylvania and southern New Jersey declined more than expected this month, dropping to minus 12.2 from minus 3.7 in June. Measures of new orders and employment nonetheless improved.
The trade report also suggests second-quarter growth may look stronger than previously forecast. Because of the way the government calculates gross domestic product, the drop in imports also means G.D.P. probably rose during the second quarter at a 1 percent annual rate, rather than the 0.5 percent pace predicted in earlier forecasts, analysts said.
The economy had slowed to a 1.2 percent rate in the first quarter, compared with 5 percent growth in all of 2000.
The indicators that make up the Conference Board's leading index were mixed as well, with 5 of 10 pointing to strength, including an increase in the supply of money in the economy and slower delivery times, which suggests companies have more orders to fill. Declining stock prices and falling orders for business equipment held down the index.
"There appears to be enough economic demand to end the slide in industrial production, though no strong rebound appears in sight," said Ken Goldstein, an economist at the Conference Board.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Two Bright Spots in Technology Give Lift to Share Prices

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DAY 

 BODY:
Stock prices rose modestly yesterday, led by the technology sector, after Nokia reported better-than-expected earnings and Dell Computer stood by its profit forecast.
 A surge in Microsoft provided part of the gains in the three leading indexes, as investors anticipated a favorable earnings report. But after the stock market closed, Microsoft warned that its sales and profits in its next quarter would be lower than previous forecasts. 
 "It continues to be an earnings-driven environment," said David Sowerby, a market strategist at Loomis, Sayles & Company. "The only analogy I can give is when you're in the middle of a profit recession, it's very similar to the market suffering from a bad case of indigestion and some days your gut has no appetite for the market. At least today, the market ulcer is on hold."
The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index rose 30.42 points, or 1.5 percent, to close at 2,046.59. The Dow Jones industrial average increased 40.17 points, or 0.4 percent, to 10,610. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was up 7.31 points, or 0.6 percent, to 1,215.02.
Nokia rose $2.51, to $19.51, after the cell phone maker reported second-quarter earnings of 15 cents a share; analysts had expected 13 cents. Nokia, based in Finland, said its third-quarter results would be weaker and declined to offer guidance on the fourth quarter, but it said the industry should rebound next year. 
Other telecommunications equipment companies also rose. Ericsson gained 11 cents, to $4.71; Motorola rose $1.56, to $19.14; and Qualcomm jumped $3.15, to $65.70.
Dell rose $1.18, to $28.38, after the computer maker reaffirmed its previous forecast for second-quarter revenue of $7.6 billion and earnings of about 16 cents a share. Dell expects to take a $700 million charge in the second quarter for job cuts and other items.
Microsoft gained $2, to $72.57. After regular trading ended, the company reported revenue that met Wall Street's expectations for the current quarter. But it also projected earnings of 39 to 40 cents a share in its next quarter and revenue of $6 billion to $6.2 billion; analysts had been projecting earnings of 45 cents a share and revenue of $6.27 billion. Microsoft fell as low as $69.50 in after-hours trading.
Semiconductor stocks were among the day's notable gainers, with the Philadelphia Stock Exchange's semiconductor index rising 27.42 points, or 4.9 percent, to 590.19. Broadcom rose $3.40, to $42.40, after the maker of chips for communications equipment, projected a possible rebound toward the end of the year, although it posted a loss that was in line with analysts' estimates.Cypress Semiconductor, a computer chip maker, rose $2.24, to $23.85, after saying it would cut 650 jobs, or 19 percent of its work force. It also posted a second-quarter loss. --------------------

Treasury Prices Fall
By Bloomberg News
Treasury bond prices declined yesterday on concern that stronger economic growth will limit the number of Federal Reserve interest rate cuts in coming months.
The 10-year Treasury note fell 3/32, to a price of 99 7/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.10 percent from 5.09 percent on Wednesday. The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 4/32, to 97 26/32. The bond's yield rose to 5.53 percent from 5.52 percent on Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Genoa's Protesters March Peacefully, but Vow Stronger Action 

BYLINE:  By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: GENOA, Italy, July 19 

 BODY:
On the eve of a meeting of leaders of the industrialized nations, tens of thousands of people marched peacefully today through Genoa to protest the meeting as a symbol of globalization, capitalist exploitation, environmental insensitivity and a host of contemporary ills.
 Earlier in the day, leaders of the more radical protest groups announced that they had chosen Friday to tear down the "red zone," a high-security area in the city center where the leaders will meet, and "all red zones that limit our lives." The statement was tantamount to a declaration of war on the many police units that have blanketed the city in preparation for the meeting, which begins on Friday. 
 Various political, social and religious organizations had announced that they would convene in Genoa to use the occasion of a three-day summit meeting to voice their protest. 
In a snaking procession resembling at times a carnival parade, crowds of people -- young and old, neatly and outrageously dressed or hardly clad at all -- marched through the streets, dancing and singing to the accompaniment of bands, loudspeaker trucks and marchers with musical instruments.
It was the usual mixed group that has taken to protesting whenever leaders of governments or financial institutions like the International Monetary Fund come together. The first such demonstration was two years ago in Seattle. Today, the Genoa protesters were closely kept in line by hundreds of riot policemen and armored vans.
"We're here because we don't like the present model of development," said Anna Lazarotti, a Genoa homemaker and mother of one, who came with about 40 members of her women's club, the Baghdad Cafe. "It does not respect the rights of individuals, but the rights of money."
Mrs. Lazarotti's group, dressed as for a shopping trip, was surrounded by elderly trade unionists, environmentalists from Green parties in various European countries, unemployed workers from France, fundamentalist Catholic groups, and anarchists from across Europe with colorfully died hair, metal studs in their bodies and uniform black dress.
Many plainclothes police officers, some disguised as photojournalists, others wearing red arm bands and Kurd independence T-shirts, mingled in the march, and kept a close eye on protesters.
Students from Genoa University held aloft a washline fluttering with men's and women's underwear to protest an appeal to the Genoese by the recently elected Italian prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi, to refrain from hanging wash across the city's narrow lanes, a venerable local custom, to avoid esthetic offense. A banner beneath the undergarments read, "Silvio -- How Do You Like the Drawers?"
The leaders of the industrialized nations -- Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan and the United States -- meet on Friday. They will be joined by President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Saturday.
A general playfulness reigned along with the kind of mocking of modern homogenization that has come to characterize such protests. The organizers said that about 50,000 had marched; the police estimated the crowds at 30,000.
The streets were lined with onlookers, though not everyone agreed with the marchers.
Piero Lanzetta, 44, a building superintendent, said: "Globalization is neither good nor bad. It's like a river that can be dangerous or useful depending on how people control and use it."
The police have been particularly nervous because of the explosion this week in northern Italy of several letter bombs in which postal officials and others suffered minor injuries. In Ancona, on Italy's Adriatic coast, the Italian police blocked 150 Greek youths who had arrived by boat from entering the country. The Italian authorities said that about 850 people have been refused entry in recent days. 
This morning, the red zone was declared the symbolic goal of demonstrators who announced an unauthorized march for Friday that the police say could turn violent. Francesco Caruso, the spokesman for an organization called Network No-Global, said that at least 10,000 marchers were expected on Friday, "seeking to smash down the wall of shame," a reference to the steel mesh gates that block streets to the red zone.
The police officials closed Genoa airport today for the duration of the meeting. Mr. Berlusconi arrived from Rome tonight and met with trade union leaders in Genoa on the wharf where staff members and media will work. Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi of Japan was also expected tonight, while other leaders arrive on Friday.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Tens of thousands of demonstrators marched yesterday in Genoa. The Italian government is sending in more than 10,000 extra security personnel. (Agence France-Presse); Shipping containers set up in "red zone" in Genoa to thwart stone throwing. Some groups announced plans to dismantle the security zone. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Panel Argues for Changing Social Security 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 19 

 BODY:
A commission appointed by the Bush administration set out a rationale today for overhauling Social Security, describing the current system as plagued by financial problems and a crisis of confidence.
 Stating that the program, which was established 66 years ago in the New Deal, "has itself reached retirement age," the commission's staff and its co-chairmen said demographic and economic pressures left no choice but to reshape Social Security to allow workers to invest in stocks and bonds -- the sooner the better. 
 The commission was established by President Bush to develop a detailed plan for enacting his campaign promise to add private investment accounts to Social Security.
Today's report was intended not to make specific proposals -- it referred only obliquely to private accounts -- but rather to make a case for why one of the most popular and successful government programs should undergo the most sweeping changes in its history. 
Democrats dismissed the document as alarmist, and said they intended to step up efforts to show that Mr. Bush's approach would create more problems than it would solve and would ultimately leave many older people less well off.
The report reviewed statistics and projections showing that, if no changes are made, Social Security would run short of money needed to pay promised benefits within the next few decades. 
It sought to show that doing nothing would inevitably lead to big tax increases, deep benefit cuts, a sharp rise in the national debt or some combination of all those things. 
It characterized the current system as often unfair to members of minorities, who because of shorter lifespans tend to receive less in benefits, and to women, who tend to spend less time in the work force than men but live longer.
And the report laid out a vague but positive vision of modernizing Social Security for a world in which people are comfortable with investing and eager for the assurance that would come with controlling and owning a piece of their government-sponsored retirement benefit.
"Though the demographic changes since 1935 will soon strain our retirement system, other changes offer the opportunity to improve it," said the draft report, which will be discussed and possibly amended by the full commission when it meets on Tuesday. 
"We better understand the power of markets than Americans did during the shock of the Great Depression," it said. "We feel more urgently the importance of extending the benefits of personal asset ownership. And we are more strongly committed to equitable treatment of all our nation's people, regardless of race, income or gender."
Democrats in Congress and other opponents of Mr. Bush's approach said the report overstated the threat to Social Security and ignored the drawbacks of private accounts.
"The only purpose of this report is to frighten the American public and to have the public think the system is about to fall apart," said Representative Robert T. Matsui, Democrat of California. "It's intended to make younger people think they're not going to get their benefits, so they should keep their money and invest it in a private account."
John Rother, legislative director of AARP, the advocacy group for older people, said the report portrayed the situation "in the most alarmist way possible." It will further polarize the political debate over how to shore up the system, Mr. Rother said.
"This may actually move us further away from a solution rather than toward a solution because it will be perceived as extremist," he said.
The commission is expected to spend the summer and fall developing detailed recommendations for Mr. Bush about private accounts as well as possible benefit cuts that might be needed to restore the retirement system's long-term health. The president has signaled that he would like Congress to begin serious work on the issue next year.
Before doing so, however, the White House has made clear that it needs to convince voters of the urgency of addressing Social Security, an issue that has long carried extreme political peril, especially for Republicans. It is also facing reluctance from Republicans in Congress, who see little benefit in taking up the issue next year, during a mid-term election campaign.
"The system is broken," the commission's co-chairmen, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the former Democratic senator from New York, and Richard D. Parsons, the vice chairman of AOL Time Warner, wrote in a preface to the report. "Unless we move boldly and quickly, the promise of Social Security to retirees cannot be met without eventual resort to benefit cuts, tax increases or massive borrowing. The time to act is now."
The fate of Mr. Bush's plan is likely to hinge in the end on broad ideological differences, between those who see Social Security as a guaranteed government benefit against poverty in old age and those who see a greater role for market forces and individual responsibility in preparing for retirement.
But for now much of the argument revolves around technical issues, including the definition of when Social Security will first run into trouble.
The Bush commission's report said the key date was 2016. That is when payroll tax revenues flowing into Social Security from workers and employers will fall short of benefit payments for the first time. At that point, the system will begin relying in part on interest payments from its vast holdings of government bonds -- the Social Security trust fund.
But the bonds and the interest on them are nothing more than commitments by the government to help pay future benefits out of general tax revenues, meaning that Social Security will begin to impinge on the rest of the budget.
Opponents of Mr. Bush's approach said it was wrong to look at Social Security as starting to run into trouble in 2016. The government bonds held by the system, they said, are backed by the full faith and credit of the United States government, and are considered by investors to be the safest investment in the world.
The system will not have to begin redeeming bonds to pay benefits until 2025. Democrats said there was no reason to suggest that Social Security would be short of money before 2038, when the system will have redeemed all the bonds and will be able to pay only about 72 percent of promised benefits out of payroll tax revenue.

HEADLINE: Losses at Delta and Northwest; Southwest Has a Profit 

BYLINE:  By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
Hurt by a slump in business travel, Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines reported quarterly losses yesterday and joined other major carriers in announcing cutbacks.
 Southwest Airlines, meanwhile, the country's largest low-fare carrier, posted a solid profit yesterday and said that it planned to stick with its aggressive expansion plans. 
 Northwest went further than any of the major airlines by announcing plans to eliminate 1,500 jobs, including 500 layoffs; close two reservation centers and a flight attendant base; and cancel some international flights. The airline said the cuts would save it $135 million on top of $209 million worth of cuts, including 500 jobs, announced earlier this year. 
Delta said that it planned to save $425 million this year by retiring nine Boeing 737 jets and replacing larger aircraft with regional jets on some routes. But like United Airlines and American Airlines, its two larger competitors, Delta said that it still expected to lose money this quarter and had imposed a hiring freeze rather than announcing layoffs.
In addition to the steep decline in last-minute business travel this year, which has cut into revenues, costs for the major airlines have risen from higher fuel prices and new, more expensive labor contracts. As a result, the industry posted a loss during the second quarter, traditionally its strongest, for only the third time in the last 30 years, said Samuel C. Buttrick, an airline analyst with UBS Warburg in New York.
Still, the losses at Northwest and Delta were smaller than analysts had expected. Northwest lost $55 million, or 65 cents a share. That was in contrast to a profit of $115 million, or 1.26 a share, in the year-earlier period. Revenue fell 5.9 percent, to $2.72 billion from $2.89 billion a year earlier. The average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call was for a loss of 74 cents a share.
A new management team took over at Northwest earlier this year, which may explain why it is cutting more aggressively than its larger competitors, analysts said. The airline said that it would close reservations centers in Garden City, N.Y., and in Hawaii. The 300 employees will be offered jobs at one of Northwest's seven other centers.
Northwest also said that it would close a flight attendant base in Chicago and eliminate flights linking Osaka, Japan, and Seattle; Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia; Los Angeles; and Manila. Nonstop flights between Detroit and Rome will be suspended over the winter.
Delta lost $90 million, or 76 cents a share, during the quarter. That was in contrast to a profit of $460 million, or $3.51 a share, during the period last year. Revenue declined 16 percent, to $3.78 billion from $4.47 billion a year earlier. Excluding several one-time items, Delta's loss was $123 million, or $1.03 a share, less than it had predicted last month and less than most analysts had expected.
Leo F. Mullin, the chief executive of Delta, told analysts that a threatened strike by its pilots and the 89-day strike at Comair, one of its regional airlines, were responsible for two-thirds of its decline in revenue, while the weak economy was responsible for the remainder. Without the Comair strike, which cost about $195 million during the quarter, Delta would have been profitable, he said.
Southwest continued to show why it has a market value larger than that of American, United and Delta combined. It matched Wall Street's expectations, earning $175.6 million, or 22 cents a share, compared with a record profit of $190.6 million, or 24 cents a share, in the second quarter of 2000. Revenue rose 6.4 percent, to $1.55 billion from $1.46 billion.
Rather than retrenching like the major carriers, Southwest, which offers direct service between cities instead of transferring passengers at hub airports, is adding aircraft, employees and new routes. It expects to be solidly profitable this quarter, according to Gary C. Kelly, its chief financial officer.
Mr. Kelly added that Southwest had experienced only a slight softening in corporate travel. "Business travelers are cutting out the $3,000 fares," he said. "They are much more likely to pay $79 to travel on Southwest Airlines."

HEADLINE: The Big City; 
Why People Love to Hate Publicists

BYLINE:  By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
THE Mayans had their ways of dealing with publicists, as you may have seen in an ancient illustration published on Tuesday in these pages. It showed a flack, once the powerful issuer of royal press releases but now obviously out of favor, who was in the process of having his fingernails torn off. 
 Are there any lessons here for the Lizzie Grubman case? 
 I'm not suggesting we adopt that specific punishment for publicists to the stars. I realize that the warm wax wrap manicure with fruit peel costs $70 at Bliss spa. Nor am I specifically advocating the other punishments listed in a new scholarly paper on the fate of Mayan scribes who fell into the hands of an enemy king. 
Those Mayan former spokesmen, who had inscribed monuments celebrating the accomplishments of their royal client, were singled out for humiliation as part of a rival king's public relations campaign. The ceremony was like the launch party for a new movie or restaurant, the kind that Ms. Grubman threw, with several important differences.
The publicists were stripped and bound, then presented prostrate and half nude before their conquerors. In front of the era's gossip columnists and paparazzi, the conquerors proceeded to break the scribes' fingers, slice their skin, cut off their heads and extract their hearts.
That's a bit extreme for even the most arrogant celebrity handler today, although the symbolism of the broken writing fingers might be adapted. Perhaps the "send" button could be disabled on the cell phone of a publicist who announces that she "did not intentionally leave the scene of the accident." We might want to close down the Web site of a party planner who runs into 16 people with her S.U.V. and then asks the press to "please respect my family's privacy."
But those would be paltry penalties compared with the criminal charges, lawsuits and media frenzy faced by Ms. Grubman. The furor has been set off by her behavior and by suspicion that she got special treatment from the police, but the public anger has been exacerbated because of who she is. There's something about publicists that inspires extra animosity.
Why do they get so much abuse on the front pages of the tabloids and the walls of Mayan palaces? Why do professional image-makers today have the same dismal image as their colleagues 1,300 years ago? You could theorize that publicists, like journalists, are doomed to perpetual disdain, but there's a more interesting explanation.
Mayan society shared a quality with modern America. Mayan rulers, like the rulers of New York's business and cultural worlds, did not have the political power to coerce the provinces into submission. "Kings lacked coercive military and economic authority," writes Kevin J. Johnston in the current issue of the journal Antiquity, in an article titled "Broken Fingers: Classic Maya Scribe Capture and Polity Consolidation."
DR. JOHNSTON, an archaeologist at Ohio State University, notes that Mayan kings had to compete against nearby rivals because the Mayans lived in a loosely organized society consisting of about 50 decentralized political units. To build public loyalty to his brand, a ruler employed publicists to herald his achievements and links to ancient kings and deities -- the equivalent of getting celebrities to show up at the launch party.
"Kings exercised authorities primarily through ritual display rather than administrative domination," Dr. Johnston writes. "A king's loss of capacity to produce public monuments because of scribe capture was a blow to his persuasive power, authority and presence." It was like a company no longer able to afford an advertising campaign, or a celebrity no longer being able to afford a contract with Howard J. Rubenstein.
It is probably safe to assume that Mayan kings hated paying their scribes as much as today's celebrities resent the bills they get. Why was a flack necessary? Why couldn't the public simply appreciate the wonderful qualities of the enlightened king? A Mayan ruler must have sounded like today's whiny movie stars and authors when the scribes asked him to promote a new monument in the hinterland.
The chattering classes of the Mayan era probably dismissed the monument-opening party as a pointless exercise even as they fought for invitations and stood outside watching. Like their ruler, they professed disdain for publicists and insisted that hype didn't matter. But it did, and that was what really bothered everyone.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Sun Posts Quarterly Loss For First Time in 12 Years

BYLINE:  By CHRIS GAITHER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, July 19 

 BODY:
Sun Microsystems posted its first quarterly loss in more than a decade yesterday, as orders from customers in Europe and Japan continued to dwindle.
 Sun, a computer and software maker, reported a loss of $88 million, or 3 cents a share, for its fourth quarter, ended June 30. Michael E. Lehman, the chief financial officer, said the loss was Sun's first since its fourth quarter in 1989. 
 Still, Sun beat Wall Street's lowered expectations by a penny a share. With special items like acquisition expenses excluded, Sun said it earned a profit of $134 million, or 4 cents a share. Earnings declined sharply from the period last year, when Sun earned $720 million, or 21 cents a share.
Revenue in the United States, where Sun sells nearly half of its products, rose 14 percent in the quarter, the first growth this year. Analysts said Sun's American market typically improved 20 percent between the third and fourth quarters. Sales in Europe and Japan fell 17 percent and 27 percent, respectively.
Over all, revenue was $4 billion, down 2 percent from the previous quarter and 20 percent from the year-earlier period, when Sun earned $5 billion.
Although they were pressed by analysts during a conference call, Sun's executives would not say whether they expected the economy or the company's business to recover soon. In an unusual move, the company declined to offer a detailed forecast for the current quarter. "We don't draw conclusions," said Scott G. McNealy, Sun's chairman and chief executive. "We ship computers."
Mr. Lehman said he expected Sun to earn at least $3.7 billion, or enough to break even, for its first quarter. Revenue of $3.7 billion would represent a 7.5 percent decline from the fourth quarter, common for Sun at this time of year.
Sun, a maker of servers, equipment and software for computer networking and storage systems, has tough numbers to live up to. The company reported unusually rapid growth in the first half of the fiscal year that just ended, increasing revenue 60 percent year over year in the first quarter alone, largely on the strength of deals with telecommunications and Internet service providers. Those customers have since cut back sharply on spending as the markets turned down.
"They portrayed a cautious, uncertain tone, but they didn't portray a negative tone," said Toni Sacconaghi, an analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, after the conference call with Sun. "Investors will probably shrug and say we need to wait and see to get a more definitive perspective from Sun."
Sun said its transition to its new UltraSparc III line of servers had improved after failing to meet demand earlier in the year. The company said it expected to release a high-end model in the late summer or early fall.
"That's what we're focused on, the things we can control," Mr. Lehman said in an interview.
Sun will increase its investment in research and development 17 percent this year, a decision Mr. McNealy said he expected to pay off in several years.
"We've taken a haircut on earnings, no question about that," Mr. McNealy said. "But we are protecting what we think to the long-term shareholders is what matters, and that is the long-term assets." 

CORRECTION-DATE: July 21, 2001

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about financial results at Sun Microsystems misstated the company's earnings for the quarter ended June 2000. Excluding special items, the figure was $717 million, not $720 million.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
U.S. Agency Asks Firestone To Recall Additional Tires
The Transportation Department said it had asked Bridgestone/Firestone to recall additional tires but the company insisted that its tires were safe and that it would state its case at a public hearing and in court.
 As a result, the government said it would begin a proceeding to start a mandatory recall, only the 10th time since 1966 that it has done so. Page C4. 

Austerity Plan Provokes Strikes
Several labor confederations began a crippling 24-hour nationwide strike to protest the Argentine government's new austerity plan, which cuts public wages and pensions up to 13 percent to avert a default on foreign debt payments. It was the sixth labor action since President Fernando de la Rua took office in December 1999, and appeared to be one of the most effective. A8.

Music-Swapping Services Thrive
Figures to be released today show that a precipitous drop in Napster's traffic the last several weeks has been paralleled by explosive growth in the less centralized music-swapping services welcoming millions of Napster refugees. The new generation of services are more numerous and harder for the record industry to police. A1.

Mounting Job Losses in New York
New York State's economy, which had been bucking the national economic slump, has slammed into a brick wall, losing jobs in the private sector in May and June, the first such back-to-back job declines since 1995. Employment also fell in New York City. A1.

F.A.A. Seeks to Fine American
The Federal Aviation Administration said it would seek to fine American Airlines $285,000 for violating regulations mandating how many hours pilots can work without rest. American has 30 days to negotiate a compromise, seek arbitration or take legal action. C4.

Panel Finds Social Security Faults
A commission appointed by the Bush administration set out a rationale for overhauling Social Security, describing the current system as plagued by financial problems and a crisis of confidence. It said demographic and economic pressures left no choice but to reshape Social Security to allow workers to invest in stocks and bonds, the sooner the better. A14.

Trade Deficit Narrowed 11% in May
The trade deficit narrowed 11 percent in May, to a 16-month low of $28.3 billion, as imports of consumer goods and business equipment sank, to $116.1 billion, the Commerce Department reported. While that suggests falling demand, it also means that foreign producers rather than American factories have absorbed some effects of the decline. Exports rose to $87.7 billion, led by pharmaceuticals and other consumer goods. C4.

Ad Agency Companies Are in Deals
Havas Advertising offered to acquire the Tempus Group, one of the few remaining independent media agency companies, for $:425 million ($603 million). But the deal may be challenged by the WPP Group, which has been slowly increasing its minority stake in Tempus. Separately, the Publicis Groupe agreed with the Cordiant Communications Group to form a joint venture media agency company. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C5.

Technology Lifts Stocks Modestly
Nokia and Dell Computer were among the technology companies that helped lift stocks higher. The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index rose 30.42 points, or 1.5 percent, to close at 2,046.59. The Dow Jones industrial average increased 40.17 points, or 0.4 percent, to 10,610. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed 7.31 points, or 0.6 percent, to 1,215.02. C6.

Beck Brewery Is Up for Sale
More than 125 years after their family began brewing beer, the owners of Beck's, Germany's top-selling export brew, said the company was for sale. World Business, Section W.

HEADLINE: EchoStar Earns $2.25 Million 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: LITTLETON, Colo., July 19 

 BODY:
EchoStar Communications, the television satellite broadcaster, said today that it had an unexpected second-quarter profit, though it also warned that it might add fewer subscribers this year than previously forecast. 
 EchoStar earned $2.25 million, or less than a penny a share, in contrast to a loss of $132.9 million, or 28 cents, a year earlier. 
Sales rose 50 percent, to $966.3 million from $646.1 million. The quarterly profit was the company's first since going public in 1995. 
 Analysts had expected a loss of 10 cents a share for the quarter.
The company also said that it had ended talks about a possible merger with its rival DirecTV, which is owned by the Hughes Electronics unit of General Motors. 
The company added 350,000 customers for its Dish satellite service in the quarter, twice as many as DirecTV, which reduced its subscriber growth forecasts on Monday. EchoStar said it would sign up as many as 1.75 million customers this year, fewer than earlier forecasts for as many as 2 million. Charles W. Ergen, the chief executive of EchoStar, cited the slowing economy.
EchoStar had 6.07 million customers as of June 30, 41 percent more than at the same time last year. Hughes has 10 million customers. 
EchoStar had a second-quarter profit because some expenses declined when the company started leasing satellite dishes to customers instead of giving them away, analysts and investors said. 
Matthew Harrigan, an analyst at Janco Partners in Denver, said: "They've done an exemplary job of growing in a difficult economic environment. In the quarter, they captured 66 percent of new satellite customers." 
Shares of EchoStar fell 99 cents, to $28.98.

HEADLINE: INDUSTRIAL NATIONS CALL FOR MONITORS FOR MIDEAST TRUCE 

BYLINE:  By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: ROME, July 19 

 BODY:
Responding to the increasing fury of violence in the Middle East, the foreign ministers of the major industrialized countries told the Israelis and Palestinians today that they should agree to "third party" monitors as the most assured way of halting the deteriorating situation. 
 In a fresh outburst of violence in the Middle East today, Israeli gunmen near Hebron were reported to have shot and killed three members of a Palestinian family, including an infant, and to have wounded several other people. Page A3. 
 Given Israel's frequent objections to any plan for outside monitors, the decision by the ministers, including Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, was seen as reflecting frustration with the disintegrating cease-fire as well as an effort to take a more active role in encouraging peace.
Bush administration policy on peace in the Middle East has evolved significantly in the president's six months in office, moving from a hands-off approach to limited involvement, to brokering the current cease-fire five weeks ago. Just over two weeks ago, on a trip to Jerusalem, Secretary Powell pushed to the next step, saying observers would be needed to monitor a cease-fire between Israelis and Palestinians, if the two sides would agree to them, and setting a schedule for moving toward political talks. 
The wording of the foreign ministers' statement on the monitors, which was attached as an appendix to their official communique, was checked by the American delegation with the State Department's senior Middle East experts in Washington, apparently in an effort to ensure that it did not transgress the policies of the Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon. 
After a news conference at which the communique was discussed, a senior administration official said the United States was satisfied with the Middle East statement because a reference to "third party" did not imply that either the United Nations or the European Union would provide the monitors.
Israel has consistently objected to "international" monitors but has expressed more willingness to entertain "third party" monitors, the official said. The third-party monitors that Israel would feel most comfortable with would be from the United States, the official added. 
But Israeli officials rejected the suggestion, saying that creating a monitoring team would be pointless and even dangerous in the absence of a working cease-fire.
"We strongly believe that what we need is not observers but observance, meaning observance on the part of the Palestinians to observe the cease-fire," said Avi Pazner, a government spokesman.
Dore Gold, an adviser to Mr. Sharon, said the Palestinian Authority chairman, Yasir Arafat, would view an observer force as a victory. "There's a danger that Arafat will perceive that his policy of violence has been rewarded, and it will become more difficult to dissuade him from violence in the future," Mr. Gold said.
The Israelis were pleased that the Group of 8 ministers had said Israel and the Palestinians should both agree on this matter. Israel is not automatically opposed to observers, Mr. Pazner said, noting that there are monitors from several countries in Sinai, to help maintain the Egyptian-Israeli peace, and a United Nations force on the Golan Heights, observing a 28-year-old cease-fire between Israel and Syria.
But in a situation as volatile as the present one, "it is dangerous, and we think it will make matters worse," he said.
"It is obvious," Mr. Pazner said, "that in the present situation -- I stress, the present situation -- there is no agreement on the part of Israel to observers."
Nabil Shaath, the Palestinian Authority's minister of planning and international cooperation, welcomed the G-8 ministers' call, saying, "Any presence of a third party on the ground is a positive step."
"What is demanded now is that these countries should commit Israel to accept the presence of a third party," Mr. Shaath said. "This was a Palestinian demand for a long time. Now it's gaining international support."
Diplomats said the most spirited exchanges among the foreign ministers, who discussed issues from globalization to arms control, occurred over the Middle East. At the heart of the discussion was how far to go in instructing the two sides to accept monitors as a way to ensure the carrying out of the Mitchell Report, which maps a path to negotiation between Israelis and Palestinians.
While the call for monitors was quite strong, it was not as strong as some countries would have liked. "The trick is to persuade the Israelis that monitors are useful," a European diplomat said. 
All the foreign ministers, including Igor S. Ivanov of Russia, agreed that the report, written by the former Senator George Mitchell, must form the basis of trying to move the Israelis and Palestinians beyond violence and toward political talks. The plan calls for an end to the violence, followed by a period in which both sides would take steps to rebuild trust between them. The final phase would be a return to peace negotiations.
The ministers' meeting today touched on many of the themes that their leaders will discuss when they gather for their summit meeting in Genoa on Friday. In what amounted to a preview of the Genoa meeting, where President Bush will be making his G-8 debut, the ministers discussed arms control but sidestepped the specific issue of the Antiballistic Missile Treaty. They agreed instead in their communique to place "great importance on the existing regimes of multilateral treaties." 
The ABM treaty, which the Bush administration has said it may withdraw from, is a bilateral agreement between Russia and the United States. And by referring to "existing regimes," the ministers did not endorse the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty, a multilateral treaty that is not yet in existence because of the failure of the United States, among others, to ratify it. 
At today's session on arms control, diplomats said Canada was the only nations to speak out against the Bush administration's plans on missile defense. In response, Secretary Powell gave what several diplomats called an "encouraging" reply, reassuring the closed-door conference that Washington would continue to consult with its allies and Russia on its intentions about the ABM treaty. 
Over all, the meeting was a fairly low-key affair. In some respects, the Bush administration looked on the G-8 -- both the foreign ministers' meeting and the grander event in Genoa -- as one more diplomatic chore, a more onerous task than a useful thrashing-out of burning economic issues, the original agenda nearly three decades ago when the meetings began with a smaller group. Earlier this month, in the middle of its final preparation for the G-8, a member of the Bush foreign policy team said the administration was "scraping around" for issues to discuss.
In an effort to breathe new life into the summit meeting, the so-called Shadow Group of Eight, a collection of foreign policy luminaries, including Henry A. Kissinger and Paul A. Volcker, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve, called on the G-8 nations to include less-developed countries like China, Brazil and India in their meetings. Embracing those regional powers is seen as helping answer the concerns of protesters worried about the ill effects of globalization as well as promoting progress in fighting poverty and expanding trade. A Bush administration official said today that the United States was opposed to expanding the G-8 any further. 
The efforts to settle the conflict in Macedonia, which are being led by diplomats from the United States and the European Union in the capital, Skopje, were dealt with informally and without any conclusion before the official start of the foreign ministers' meeting. The discussion reflected the precarious negotiations in Skopje where the Macedonian government is balking at accepting a final political deal with Macedonian Albanians, diplomats said. 
On the one hand, the foreign ministers were eager to get a deal so that a planned NATO force could begin to disarm the Albanian insurgents, a European diplomat said. On the other hand, the ministers held back from imposing a settlement on the Macedonian government for fear of encouraging a takeover there by hard-liners.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate; 
Draw to Brighton Beach Is by the Sea, by the Sea

BYLINE:  By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
For buyers at the Oceana condominium development, which is taking shape on 15 acres once occupied by the Brighton Beach Baths, a major attraction is the same thing that once drew bathers -- the Atlantic Ocean.
 That is the case for Vsevolod and Natalie Maksin, who moved in March to a two-bedroom apartment, with water views, that they bought in 1999 after looking at blueprints. "Being able to see and feel the water was one of the most important considerations," said Mr. Maksin, a lawyer and an accountant at PricewaterhouseCoopers in Manhattan. 
 Five buildings with 272 two- to four-bedroom apartments, including penthouses, are now on the site of the bath complex, which closed in 1997. Ultimately, there will be 850 apartments in 15 5- to 12-story buildings in Oceana, a gated community separated from the ocean by the Boardwalk. 
The development, among the largest market-rate housing projects in the boroughs outside of Manhattan in decades, has been under construction for the last 16 months. Its recreational amenities, including a health club and indoor and outdoor pools, have opened. And with all but 30 of the initial units sold, sales will begin this month for 75 more units in the sixth building, said Joshua L. Muss. He is the president of the Muss Development Company, of Forest Hills, Queens, which is developing the $325 million project with the Carlyle Group of Washington. 
Construction on the latest structure will start in two months and is scheduled for completion in 13 months. The building will overlook Brighton Beach Avenue, with its rows of neighborhood stores, and Manhattan beyond. Its apartments are to have two and three bedrooms with 1,000 to 1,550 square feet, and cost $325,000 to $500,000, or $300 to $350 a square foot on average. When the complex opened, the average per square foot price was $250, said Jason A. Muss, Joshua Muss's son and a company vice president. 
Despite the cooling economy, "we have raised prices because as an oceanfront project it is somewhat insulated," Jason Muss said. "We are selling a lifestyle." 
Joshua Muss said the biggest issue "is having enough inventory." 
That is also the case in many Brooklyn neighborhoods, said Jeffrey J. Ferretti, president of National Brokerage in Mill Basin and past president of the Brooklyn Board of Realtors. "Nothing has cooled here," he said.
Howard M. Ginsburg, a sales agent at National Brokerage, said that in the last year prices have risen by an average of 20 percent for one- and two-family homes and by 10 percent for condominiums. He put the average sales price for condominiums at $200,000, and higher for those close to the water. 
"Houses are still selling," he said. "But only a scattered number of new ones are being built."
Mr. Maksin said he bought his Oceana apartment, which cost in the $300,000 range, because at one-third the price of a comparable size unit in Manhattan, "it is a great value," with the potential to appreciate over time.
Monthly maintenance charges range from $211 to $968 for the apartments, and higher for the penthouses. Real estate taxes at the complex will be kept low thanks to a 15-year abatement, with taxes fully abated for 11 years and rising after that by 20 percent a year. 
Despite sales that have been strong enough to support price increases, Joshua Muss said his company's development style was cautious. "We will still build one building at a time," he said. 
Three more structures with 50 to 70 apartments each are in various stages of approval by the New York State attorney general's office, and make up the next wave of construction at the development, he said. A one-acre public park at the entrance to the site along Brighton Avenue is also planned. 
The idea of reshaping the site for housing dates to 1986. From then through the early 1990's, Stephen Muss, Joshua Muss's cousin, tried unsuccessfully to develop 1,500 condominiums in four towers, rising as high as 32 stories. The project was put off in the mid-1990's because of the real-estate recession.
In 1999, Joshua Muss bought the property and reconfigured the project to its present scale and layout. The shorter buildings meet the height restrictions under the area's waterfront zoning, which also required that they not block the view of the water from Brighton Beach Avenue. 
All the buildings at Oceana are designed with gabled roofs and balconies to blend with their older neighbors. The new buildings are also clad in prefabricated stucco panels to better weather the elements that come with a beachfront location. Most of the units at the complex will have full or part ocean views. 

GRAPHIC: Photo: The outdoor pool is one of the recreational amenities at the Oceana condominiums, a gated community. The complex is expanding with the planned construction of a new building and more units to be offered for sale. (G. Paul Burnett/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: School Cost Overruns No Secret, Official Says 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
Members of the Board of Education howled in protest earlier this month when they learned that the cost of building new schools and repairing old ones was running far above estimates -- so far above that the school system now faces a $1.9 billion shortfall in its current $7 billion capital budget.
 But the president of the School Construction Authority said yesterday that the board members had not exactly been left in the dark about rising costs. 
 According to Milo E. Riverso, president of the construction authority, two computer terminals were set up three years ago on the 11th floor of the Board of Education's headquarters in Brooklyn specifically to allow the seven board members to track the construction authority's progress in building new schools. Board staff members were even trained in using the computers. 
The terminals have remained untouched, Mr. Riverso claimed, saying that the construction authority's computer system showed no evidence that the terminals were ever used to check the authority's financial records.
That was but one of the striking statements made yesterday during a three-and-a-half-hour City Council hearing into the Board of Education's process of building and repairing schools, a hearing prompted by the shortfall. 
Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy, who had been personally blamed by some board members for not keeping them informed, told Council members that the Board of Education had routinely failed to amend its capital plans over the last 12 years to take into account rising costs and shifting priorities, apparently in violation of state law. 
Mr. Riverso testified that the cost of completing projects that were scheduled to be finished as much as two years ago was running at more than 10 times the Board of Education's estimates. 
Some board members admitted that they had not been paying close attention to construction expenses. Ninfa Segarra, who took over as board president in April, said she was still trying to find one of the computer terminals. "If it was there, I'm not sure where it is now," she said.
Several City Council members seemed baffled by the dispute. Herbert E. Berman, chairman of the Finance Committee, said the Board of Education, the chancellor and the construction authority seemed to "function as players in a medieval intrigue, operating in shadows which blur accountability, and fearing that cooperation with, and reliance on, other players may erode their own powers."
All the parties appeared to agree on the basic causes of the budget gap. In an economy that, at least for the building trades, is still booming, construction costs have risen by more than a third in the last two years. That has laid waste to the board's 1999 estimates of the costs of building 34 new schools to serve nearly 24,000 students.
In addition, the board has found it difficult to find sites for new schools, and the sites that have been found often have extensive environmental problems or require streets, sewers and other basic infrastructure. In response to studies showing that students learn better in small classes and generally smaller schools, the board has changed projects along those lines -- but at a price.
No one was accusing the board or the construction authority of malfeasance yesterday, though previous inquiries into school construction have involved such charges. Nevertheless, school officials did not hesitate to deny the possibility. "There's been no corruption here," Mr. Levy said. In case the Council members did not understand his point, he added, "Nothing has come to my attention that would suggest any impropriety of that type."
But several Council members did wonder, sometimes loudly, why Mr. Levy or his staff members did not raise the issue of the cost overruns a few months ago when the finance and education committees held hearings on the education budget.
At the time, the chancellor and his staff campaigned very publicly against the mayor's operating budget recommendations, which they said would leave the school system vastly underfunded. Even after they worked out a deal with City Hall that would gain the school system additional money this year if they cut administrative spending, Mr. Levy and his deputies have complained that the board would have to cut more than $100 million from its budget by the time school begins in the fall.
The board's deputy chancellor for management and policy, Anthony Shorris, said those operating budget shortfalls were far more important and immediate than the discrepancies in the construction budget. "There was an extraordinary threat on the table that would have affected the kids right now," Mr. Shorris said. By comparison, he said, problems in the construction budget were "a long-term issue."
Mr. Levy, Mr. Riverso and Ms. Segarra each told the Council members that they were committed to working together to try to come up with more reasonable estimates of construction and repair costs in the three years remaining in the five-year capital plan. A plan to amend the capital plan to account for new estimates could be completed by the end of the summer, they said. 
The chairwoman of the Council's education committee, Priscilla A. Wooten, summed up the Council's response to that promise.
"It's very impressive to know what people can do after the fact," she said, sounding not at all impressed.

HEADLINE: U.S. and Caribbean Face Era Of More, and Big, Hurricanes 

BYLINE:  By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
The Atlantic Seaboard and the Caribbean face 10 to 40 years of stronger and more frequent hurricanes, a new analysis of weather data shows.
 As a result, crowded coastlines and islands are confronted with the greatest risk of devastation in a generation, said the scientists who conducted the study. 
 Many meteorologists said the new analysis provided the firmest evidence yet that cycles in ocean and atmospheric conditions that suppressed big storms from 1971 to 1994 had shifted into a storm-spawning state.
The number and power of storms first jumped in 1995, but only now have enough years passed to measure a significant trend, the researchers said. 
In a paper in today's issue of Science, they say the driving force is a periodic warming of the Atlantic north of the Equator and a simultaneous drop in wind shear, the difference between trade winds near the surface and winds at higher altitudes.
Tropical storms thrive on energy and moisture supplied by warmer water. In addition, the lack of clashing winds aloft allows the resulting cyclones to mushroom miles high, the researchers reported.
Conditions were similar from the 1920's through the 1960's, the study said. But coasts that were sparsely populated then are now dense with people, high-rise apartment buildings and summer homes, said Stanley B. Goldenberg, the lead author of the study and a meteorologist at the National Oceanographic and Atmospheric Administration's hurricane research center in Miami.
The greater frequency of stronger storms, combined with more people and buildings, spells a far greater risk of having a storm become a $100 billion disaster, Mr. Goldenberg said.
"It's like shooting arrows at a target," he said. "The more arrows you shoot, the more likely you are to get a bull's-eye. The problem now is there are not only more arrows, but there are more targets because of the coastal buildup."
In the Caribbean the biggest risk is of enormous loss of life. In the United States, it is enormous losses of property, Mr. Goldenberg said.
"It's not only the number of new buildings, but their heights," Mr. Goldenberg said. "Recent research here has shown that in strong storms, at around 300 to 500 feet you get tremendous peaks in winds" that can have twice the force of winds at the surface. Those potent gusts, he said, can easily rip the skin off a skyscraper.
In the study, the scientists said the return to cooler waters and more wind shear -- and thus less stormy times -- could happen in 10 years, but was likely to persist much longer. 
They said no one knew what drove the cycle of warming and cooling in the North Atlantic, and the relationship between the water temperature and wind shifts was being studied.
Other scientists injected a note of caution, saying the recent string of stormy years was still too short to constitute a clear trend.
In a separate analysis in Science, Dr. Lennart Bengtsson, a climatologist at the Max Planck Institute for Meteorology in Hamburg, Germany, said patterns of hurricane activity were nearly impossible to discern with only a few decades of data.
But he agreed that countries with vulnerable coasts could suffer huge economic losses if they did not prepare for the worst and the worst happened.
"A change to what was typical, say, for 1920 to 1960 would create a potentially serious situation requiring most urgent attention," he wrote in Science.
Dr. Bengtsson and the authors of the new study said the link between warmer seas and hurricane patterns did not necessarily mean that global warming would spawn more such storms. One reason given by Dr. Bengtsson was that, in a generally warmer world, the air above the ocean would warm as well as the water, reducing the contrast that drives the formation of storms.
The new study generated a picture of a tempestuous future by closely tracking sea temperature and wind shear measurements over the last century -- taken by ships and weather balloons -- and comparing patterns with the frequency, severity and tracks of hurricanes from the 1940's until now.
The team limited its full analysis to 1944 to 2000, a stretch with the best data.
Graphs of hurricane frequency meshed well with graphs of water temperature, particularly in the region west of the bulge of Saharan Africa, where most tropical storms begin.
Although the relationship between the shifts in water temperatures and wind shear are still not understood, the pattern is consistent and clear, said Dr. Christopher W. Landsea, a colleague of Mr. Goldenberg at the hurricane center and a co-author of the paper. "The atmosphere and ocean are talking to each other," Dr. Landsea said.
The research adds detail and new lines of evidence to earlier predictions of a stormier future by another of the co-authors, Dr. William M. Gray of Colorado State University, and to separate studies by Dr. James B. Elsner, a hurricane authority at Florida State University.
There is still plenty of variability year to year, with the recent quiet stretch including, for example, the devastating Hurricane Andrew in 1992. So there is no reason to think that the 2001 hurricane season or any particular coming year will be exceptionally catastrophic, the scientists said.
And plenty of other weather factors and changes influence hurricanes. Most notable is El Nino, a condition that develops in the Pacific once or twice a decade and suppresses hurricanes by shifting eastward-flowing winds.
But already, the researchers said, 1995 to 2000 had hurricanes form at a rate twice as great as seen in the preceding quiet period. Moreover, the frequency of strong storms, those with sustained winds of more than 110 miles per hour, is 2.5 times as high as it was.
They added that the recent stormy years have also seen a five-fold increase in hurricanes in the Caribbean, including Hurricane Mitch in October 1998, which killed more than 11,000 people.
The prospect of more exceptionally strong storms is particularly troubling because their destructive power rises enormously for even a small increase in wind speed. For example, Mr. Goldenberg said, winds of 130 m.p.h. have almost double the punch of winds of 100 m.p.h.
"The strong storms produce more than 80 percent of all hurricane damage even though they only account for one-fifth of the storms that make landfall," Dr. Landsea said.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 24, 2001

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article on Friday about the likelihood of stronger, more frequent hurricanes misstated part of the name of the agency that oversees the hurricane research center. It is the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, not Oceanographic.

HEADLINE: BUOYANT ECONOMY OF NEW YORK STATE SHOWS A REVERSAL 

BYLINE:  By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
New York State's economy, which had been bucking the national economic slump, has slammed into a wall, losing jobs in the private sector in May and June, the first such back-to-back job declines since 1995.
 Employment also fell in New York City, which has been the powerhouse of the state economy in the last couple of years, according to new data from the New York State Department of Labor and the City Comptroller's office. 
 Just a month ago, economists were still seeing signs of slow growth in both the city and the state. But yesterday, state officials revised May's gain in jobs to a loss of about 3,800, and reported that in June the number of jobs fell by about 9,500, adjusted for seasonal factors. 
The results were similar in New York City, said Alan G. Hevesi, the city comptroller, whose office computes seasonally adjusted job data for the city based on figures provided by the state. Instead of a gain of 1,900 private-sector jobs in May, the city lost 3,800 jobs and 700 more in June.
How could a relatively sunny economic picture suddenly look so cloudy? Some of the answer has to do with job data itself, said Thomas J. Spitznas, an economist in Mt. Vernon, N.Y.
Because of the way employers report job data, job losses are underestimated when bad times begin. "It's the most difficult thing in economics -- the turning point," he said.
Economists tend to look at job growth as the primary sign of an economy's health and focus on private-sector employment because government jobs fluctuate for noneconomic reasons. Last year, for example, many people were hired to work for the census; they are no longer employed by the government.
The new economic data comes as some of the biggest companies on Wall Street warned that they would slash even more jobs. American Express, Merrill Lynch, and J. P. Morgan Chase & Company all said this week that poor profits were forcing them to cut jobs, although it was not clear how many of those cuts would be in New York City. Wall Street employment in the city has fallen by about 4,100 since February, and the declines are accelerating, the comptroller's office said.
"We are not an island, and the whole nation is slowing down," said James P. Brown, an analyst for the state labor department. As corporate profits fall across the country, he said, so does employment not only on Wall Street, but also at advertising agencies, insurance companies and law firms.
Business services -- a catchall of temporary employment agencies, computer consultants and dot-coms -- have shed more than 15,000 jobs in the last two months after soaring during the city's boom. But other sectors gained jobs during that period.
A weak manufacturing industry has hurt northern and western New York State, particularly Buffalo and Rochester, which have suffered a net loss of private-sector jobs over the past 12 months.
The job market is still better in New York State than in much of the rest of the country. For example, the state's unemployment rate is 4.4 percent, which is just under the national average of 4.5 percent. And while the national rate has risen by half a point in the last year, New York's unemployment rate remains just under its level of a year ago.
During the 1990's, New York's jobless figures were higher than the national numbers, but recently the state's jobless rate has been lower than the national average.
Stephen Kagann, chief economist for Gov. George E. Pataki, said that over the last year, private jobs in the state rose by 1 percent, while nationally the increase was 0.4 percent.
Even in New York City, the job losses are modest compared with the situation in cities like Detroit, which has lost more than 10,000 jobs in the last year. And while the unemployment rate has edged up from 5.1 percent in March to 5.3 percent in June, the jobless rate in New York City remains well under the 5.6-percent rate recorded a year ago, when the economy was still booming.
"A pessimist would say New York is finally getting hit," said Jason Bram, an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. "An optimist would say New York is hanging in there pretty well."
Which camp is Mr. Bram in? "In the short-term, I'm pretty optimistic," he said. "But New York City is very prone to booms and busts."
Mr. Bram said he was watching two areas closely. One is the real estate market, where sales have slowed, but prices have not dropped. The other is Wall Street -- in particular, the volume of stocks being traded, which he said is an even better forecaster of Wall Street employment than stock prices. "Our research shows pretty conclusively that as goes the financial sector," he said, "so goes New York City."

HEADLINE: As the World Warms: More Debate 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "The New Laws of Nations," by Laura D. Tyson (Op-Ed, July 14): While it is the case that an increasingly global economy will require multinational solutions, what kind of international governance will we choose and whom it will benefit? 
 The Kyoto Protocol on climate change and other environmental treaties represent the type of approach we require to sustain the environment and improve social standards. 
In contrast are harmful multinational approaches like the investor-rights provisions in the North American Free Trade Agreement, which are being used by multinational investors to sue governments for enacting environmental and other public interest protections.
Although we must embrace multilateral solutions that raise environmental and social standards, we should also reject those that pull them downward.

DAVID WASKOW
Washington, July 15, 2001

The writer is trade and investment policy coordinator, Friends of the Earth.

HEADLINE: As the World Warms: More Debate 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "U.S. Set to Oppose International Plan for Cleaner Energy" (front page, July 14): 
 The Bush administration's opposition to the clean-energy initiative of the Group of Eight industrial nations is yet another twist of contradictions and international embarrassments. 
The administration wants the marketplace and not government to decide how quickly renewable resources will enter the marketplace. Yet economists agree that present energy prices are far from representing real costs of energy, particularly the damages done by fossil fuels, which do receive handsome subsidies in both the United States and, more important, in most of the developing world.
So the marketplace can't decide without government help. Worse, the Bush administration's own energy policy suggestions are precisely what the market will not bring forth to the United States -- significantly more oil and gas production and more nuclear power.

LEE SCHIPPER
Paris, July 15, 2001

The writer is an energy economist.

HEADLINE: Rate Proposal For Electricity In California 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, July 19 

 BODY:
A proposed agreement between state regulators and the agency that buys electricity for millions of Californians would allow the state to raise electric rates without outside review. 
 The California Public Utilities Commission issued the agreement on Wednesday and it will become effective after a period for public comment in August. 
 The proposal explains how the commission will work with the Department of Water Resources to ensure that the state is repaid for the billions of dollars it has spent buying electricity for customers of three financially ailing utilities. 
In the agreement, the commission vows to assess electric rates at least annually and adjust them so the department has enough money to pay for its power purchases and administrative costs.
Harvey Rosenfield, the president of the Foundation for Taxpayer and Consumer Rights, said on Wednesday that under the agreement the commission waived the right to deny a rate increase if it was deemed unfair to California ratepayers. Mr. Rosenfield said the agreement gave unelected officials "the unilateral right to order rate increases for the next 15 years." 
Geoff Dryvynsyde, a legal adviser at the Public Utilities Commission, said the commission would be "no longer in charge of determining what costs are reasonable before it changes rates."
The commission's agreement is a vital step toward California's efforts to issue $13 billion in bonds to recoup the more than $8 billion it has spent since January buying electricity. 
California wants to improve its credit rating to lower interest rates on the bonds and to assure Wall Street of a reliable stream of money rolling in from electric rates.
In May, the Public Utilities Commission issued a record rate increase that followed another January increase of roughly 10 percent.
The state has bought electricity for the customers of three companies since January, when the utilities warned the state that high power prices and the inability to recoup their costs through frozen electric rates were driving them into bankruptcy.

HEADLINE: Fire in Baltimore Snarls Internet Traffic, Too 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: BALTIMORE, July 19 

 BODY:
A fire that raged for a second day in a train tunnel under Baltimore cast smoke over downtown offices and burned fiber-optic cables today, slowing Internet traffic across the country.
 Several city blocks were closed above the tunnel, where a train carrying hazardous materials derailed on Wednesday afternoon. Extreme heat kept firefighters from reaching a 12,000-gallon tanker car that was leaking 10 gallons of hydrochloric acid a minute. Just 5 of the train's 60 cars had been removed from the tunnel by this afternoon. 
 Firefighters fed a hose through a manhole and doused the cars to cool them, a fire department spokesman, Hector Torres, said. Railroad workers then began vacuuming out the acid. 
"We're told some of the boxcars are actually glowing," Mr. Torres said. "You're talking about glowing metal. I'm guessing 1,000 or 1,500 degrees."
More than 100 firefighters battled the blaze. Two who suffered chest pains on Wednesday remained hospitalized today.
The train was carrying wood as well as hydrochloric acid and at least five other hazardous chemicals. But Mr. Torres said air quality tests showed that the smoke was coming mostly from burning wood.
He said there appeared to be no toxic substances in the smoke, "so that's a good sign." 
The fire caused major Internet slowdowns in the Middle Atlantic States, and delays rippled across the country as companies diverted Web traffic to other cables. Fiber-optic cable running through the tunnel was damaged by the fire, but the authorities said they had not assessed the extent of the damage.
Keynote Systems, which measures the performance of Web sites, said slowdowns in Atlanta, Seattle, Los Angeles and elsewhere were probably related to the burned cables. The company said the Internet delays were the worst it had seen.
Telecommunications companies including WorldCom, PSINet and AboveNet all reported problems. 
No homes or businesses were evacuated today, but health officials warned people in the area to stay inside, keep windows closed and turn off ventilation systems.
Robert Gould, a spokesman for CSX Transportation Inc., said the more than two dozen trains that travel through the city each day would have to be rerouted or rescheduled.
A National Transportation Safety Board team was investigating the the accident, which happened as the train was traveling from North Carolina to New Jersey.
