Summit Leaders Pledge Money to Fight Diseases
After protests in Genoa, Italy, leaders of the world's biggest economies sat down for the first time to discuss health, debt and the poor -- the topics that demonstrators have complained that rich countries ignore.
 The leaders announced that about $1.2 billion had been committed to a United Nations Global Health Fund that will fight AIDS, and other infectious diseases, following through on a commitment made at the summit last year in Okinawa, Japan. Page A7. 

F.C.C. Considers Chris-Craft Deal
The Federal Communications Commission has decided to approve the News Corporation's purchase of Chris-Craft Industries and waive rules that would have forced the combined company to sell either The New York Post, WYNW-TV or WWOR-TV, according to senior government officials. The commission's five members are in the process of finalizing an order that approves the merger with virtually no conditions, according to the officials. They said the decision is expected to be announced Monday after it is voted upon. B3.

Microsoft Warning Upsets Markets
Stock prices slipped under pressure from Microsoft, which led the major market indexes lower after it warned that sales and profits in the next quarter would be lower than previously forecast. The Nasdaq composite index dropped 17.22 points, or 0.8 percent, to close at 2,029.37. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 33.35 points, or 0.3 percent, to close at 10,576.65. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 4.17 points, or 0.3 percent, to close at 1,210.85. C3.

Insurer Stops Selling Credit Life
American General, seeking approval of its pending $23 billion purchase by American International Group, has decided to stop selling a type of life insurance that consumer activists say is merely a tool for stripping the equity out of poor people's homes. C3.

Merrill Lynch & Company has agreed to pay $400,000 to settle a claim by a former client that the brokerage company's Internet analyst recommended a stock without disclosing a conflict of interest. C4.

Philip Morris Report Stirs Outrage
A report Philip Morris presented to the Czech government that argues that smokers save the state millions of dollars by dying prematurely has done little to dampen public enthusiasm for smoking cigarettes. C2.

"Weak market conditions for our industry persisted in the second quarter," the chief executive, Kurt Hellstrom, said. "Many of our customers have delayed spending on network expansion and in some cases postponed contracted deliveries. We cannot predict how long this situation will prevail as we have yet to see signs of improvement." C2.

Samsung Profit Decreases
The semiconductor crisis caught up with Samsung Electronics in the second quarter of this year, though the company's success in other fields besides chips held off the kind of losses its competitors had. C2.

California Debates Utility's Future
California legislators were working late into the night to reach a compromise to aid the nearly bankrupt Southern California Edison. No deal was reached, however, to help the state's second-largest utility pay its debts. The utility's parent, Edison International, reported an 89 percent decline in second-quarter earnings, a bigger drop than expected. C2.

HEADLINE: Chrysler Loss Isn't as Deep As Expected 

BYLINE:  By MICHELINE MAYNARD 

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 20 

 BODY:
DaimlerChrysler said today that its Chrysler unit lost $125 million in the second quarter, a better performance than analysts had predicted because of stronger auto sales and gains from a turnaround plan. Chrysler earned $986 million in the period a year earlier.
 The second-quarter performance, which translated to 148 million euros, was markedly better than that of the first quarter, when Chrysler lost $1.2 billion. 
 In February, DaimlerChrysler officials said they expected a loss as high as $2 billion at Chrysler for 2001, with the company breaking even next year, and becoming profitable again in 2003. 
While the company has not yet revised its earnings projections, Dieter Zetsche, Chrysler's chief executive, told analysts this morning it was likely that Chrysler would beat its cost-cutting targets for 2001. "We are doing very well on the cost-reduction side," Mr. Zetsche said in a conference call. "We are committed to our forecast for year-end and confident we will deliver accordingly."
Seeking perhaps to damp expectations that the worst is over at Chrysler, company officials warned that the third quarter could be difficult. It is traditionally the weakest quarter of the year for auto companies, because plants are shut for vacations and for changing over to the new model year. This year, too, the United States industry is awash in incentives that have pushed up marketing costs.
"They're not out of the woods at all here," said Stephen Girsky, an auto analyst with Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.
Indeed, second-quarter net income at DaimlerChrysler fell 58 percent, to about $681 million, or 713 million euros, including a one-time gain from the sale of its Temic automotive electronics unit. But even that drop was better than forecasts, which had put DaimlerChrysler's net at just under $200 million.
Excluding the gain, DaimlerChrysler's second-quarter earnings fell to $453 million from $1.52 billion. Revenue dropped to $35.1 billion from $38 billion.
In February, DaimlerChrysler's chief executive, Jurgen Schrempp, embarked on a $3.9 billion three-year recovery plan that called for job cuts of 26,000 at Chrysler and another 9,000 at the Japanese automaker Mitsubishi Motors, where DaimlerChrysler owns 37.5 percent. The company is also trimming 9,000 jobs at the Freightliner Corporation, its troubled heavy-truck business.
Today, Mr. Schrempp said DaimlerChrysler was on track to post an operating profit for the year of $1 billion to $1.5 billion.
A main reason is the fledgling recovery at Chrysler. Compared with the first quarter, auto sales rose 160,000 vehicles, while inventories declined, as did marketing costs. In the second quarter, Chrysler's spending on advertising was 17 percent of revenue, compared with 21 percent the first quarter. Chrysler's cash on hand, which plummeted last fall, setting off its financial crisis, rose to $4.81 billion in the second quarter from $3.6 billion in the first quarter.
Mr. Girsky said that much of the second-quarter improvement stemmed from these factors, far more than cost-cutting. He said the impact of the Chrysler turnaround plan -- which includes price cuts on auto parts, reduced spending on new vehicles and slimmer payments to dealers, along with the job cuts -- had yet to flow to the bottom line.
"They'll get the savings, but spread out over a longer period," Mr. Girsky said. When questioned by analysts, Mr. Zetsche declined to define specific areas of improvement. "I don't think I'm in a position to split the development between volume and cost-reduction effects," he said.
Though cautioning against raised expectations for the current quarter, Mr. Zetsche said Chrysler's auto sales should be helped by the new version of the Dodge Ram pickup, due in September. Analysts say a strong start for the vehicle is critical, but are concerned because Ford Motor and General Motors have rolled out fat incentives on their pickups this summer -- in what Mr. Zetsche called "the truck wars."
Along with the Chrysler improvement, DaimlerChrysler's results were bolstered by a 10 percent increase in profits at its Mercedes-Benz unit, which earned about $700 million. Mercedes recently introduced a new version of its small C-Class sedan to good reviews and strong sales.
In commercial vehicles, including Freightliner, DaimlerChrysler's profits sank to $108 million from $353 million. Mr. Schrempp said the company was drafting a turnaround plan for Freightliner that would be rolled out this fall.
Shares of DaimlerChrysler rose 97 cents each, to $50.15.

HEADLINE: GENOA SUMMIT MEETING: THE FIRST LADY; 
Laura Bush Enjoys Globalization's Lighter Side

BYLINE:  By SUZANNE DALEY 

DATELINE: PISA, Italy, July 20 

 BODY:
Because her plane had to land in Pisa anyway, Laura Bush took a detour from her duties today to get a close look at the Leaning Tower of Pisa.
 A few yards away from the marble monument, which began tilting almost as soon as it was finished in the 14th century, she stopped in her tracks, stretched out her right arm and tilted her hand at an angle. 
 "Is this the spot where you stand if you want to help hold it up?" she asked, with a girlish giggle.
Seconds later, she was more serious. "It is beautiful," she said. "Very beautiful." 
Petite, tidy and capable of smiling through endless rounds of picture taking, the quiet librarian from Midland, Texas, struck out on her own today, able -- despite frequent questions about whether she likes her role as first lady -- to have a good time. 
By the end of the day, Mrs. Bush was laughing about her tour of the Pisa tower, a cumbersome affair with dozens of security people, tripping photographers and gawking tourists, many of whom had no idea who she was.
"It was new for me," she said. "It was the first time that I have been to a major tourist attraction in this role." 
Six months into her husband's presidency, Mrs. Bush remains one of the most low-key first ladies in recent history, in sharp contrast to her predecessor, Hillary Rodham Clinton, who was in the headlines almost daily during her first year, from stories about the cost of her hairdresser to her role in developing health care policy. 
But Mrs. Bush, who wears drugstore makeup and simple suits, seems determined to chart her own course. She has said that she will not speak out on an assortment of policy issues, only those she feels she knows.
As her husband attended a Group of 8 summit meeting in Genoa, she turned to her own passions, teaching and reading.
On the first leg of her trip from London, she visited the Aviano air base north of Venice to encourage United States military personnel to go into teaching when they retire. After her stops in Aviano and Pisa, she visited a reading program at a Florence hospital.
She seemed at ease in both places, shouldering into a cluster of eager young soldiers who wanted their picture taken with her or popping soap bubbles to entertain children in the hospital.
She said she was most struck by an Italian doctor's description of reading to children to help them with pain. "It is common sense when you think about it, that reading would be a distraction, but I had never heard of the idea." 
"You do get new ideas on these trips. It's a chance to learn."
Mrs. Bush said that she particularly liked the overseas travel that went with the job. For one thing, it gives her a chance to meet and talk with "a very small club" of people whose lives resemble her own. 
"What I have enjoyed most is meeting my counterparts," said Mrs. Bush, taking a break in the art room of the hospital. "We have so much in common. Everyone has children and everyone is trying to make sure that they are O.K. There is a lot to share."
She said she learned that in Poland, the concern for the safety of leaders' children extends to the point of not allowing them to be photographed. 
Mrs. Bush said that she and Cherie Booth, wife of the British prime minister, Tony Blair, have been discussing doing some work together because both have an interest in the issue of breast cancer awareness. 
She is planning to spend a private weekend in Florence with her daughter Barbara before rejoining Mr. Bush on Sunday in Rome. 
"We could shop," she said. "But I think we will be eating. That's the thing."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Laura Bush, posing in Pisa yesterday, became a tourist attraction herself. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: For Aspiring Americans, New Hope and Concern 

BYLINE:  By JIM YARDLEY 

DATELINE: SOCORRO, Tex., July 19 

 BODY:
The old military barracks in this farming town just across the Rio Grande from Mexico are empty except for a room where seven students are studying to become American citizens. The instructor, Vincent Ramirez, moves quickly from the War of 1812 to the Civil War before segueing to a familiar subject, immigration.
 Mr. Ramirez, 50, who became a United States citizen in 1972, asks his students about the possibility that the Bush administration would allow millions of illegal Mexican immigrants to earn legal status, and everyone seems pleased. Yet when Mr. Ramirez questions how such a policy would be carried out, how so many people could be processed in an orderly manner, his skepticism brings knowing nods. 
 "I do believe that Bush is trying to do something right," Mr. Ramirez said. "But he's just got to set his plan up right, something logical. We're talking about millions and millions of people who are going to be coming out of the closet." 
The non-word in vogue in Washington and Mexico City is "regularization," as in the need to bring clarity and coherence to immigration policy along the border. But even as there is hope along this stretch of the border near El Paso that President Bush, as a former Texas governor, will bring a unique understanding to the issue, people know too well that life here is rarely regular.
The complications and contradictions of immigration policy are on full display here. Families can often be divided between those who are legal and those who are not, and the same government that is now considering granting legal status to millions of illegal immigrants has also armed agents at the border to keep more from coming in.
The news that Mr. Bush is considering ways to help illegal Mexican immigrants thrills many people. But others express concern that there are not enough jobs, that any new promises of legalization will bring more chaos to the border, not less. 
In fact, the old barracks and the lives of the people who come here for help provide a history lesson in the failings of past efforts to grapple with Mexican immigration.
The barracks once served as a processing center for thousands of Mexican farm hands as part of the bracero guest worker program that ended amid charges of exploitation in 1964. And several of the students in Mr. Ramirez's citizenship class were among the millions affected by the last major initiative intended to stem illegal immigration on the border -- the amnesty program passed under President Ronald Reagan in 1986.
"It's one of those things that is always happening here, and we're just used to it," Mayor Raymond Caballero of El Paso said of the vagaries of immigration policy, while endorsing any plan that would allow illegal immigrants to earn legal status. 
In the El Paso area, across the Rio Grande from sprawling Ciudad Juarez in Mexico, a policy jolt came in 1993 with the crackdown by the United States Border Patrol known as Operation Hold the Line. Before then, people flowed back and forth across the Rio Grande with only mild interference; a bus even carried maids from Juarez to houses in El Paso. The lack of resistance also made it easy for criminals and smugglers.
But the huge buildup of border patrol officers stamped out much of the illegal foot traffic and, as a result, many Mexicans simply stayed illegally on the American side.
Maria de la Torre, then seven months pregnant, fled Mexico in the early 1990's and now finds herself in a fairly common tangle in the immigration process. She and her two oldest children are illegal residents; her two youngest children, born in the United States, are citizens.
Ms. de la Torre, who volunteers at a community center in the barracks complex, applied for citizenship in 1996 with her sister, a legal resident, as her sponsor. Five years later, she is saving money to pay for physical examinations with a doctor chosen by the Immigration and Naturalization Service. Meanwhile, she and her husband have separated, and she supports her children by working as a maid. She regarded the news that the Bush administration was looking for ways to legalize millions of Mexicans like herself as a godsend.
"I am hoping and praying that it will come true," she said, speaking through a translator. 
Another woman at the community center, who gave her name only as Maria, illustrated the potential complexities of any new immigration program. Her husband, a construction worker, became a legal resident as part of the 1986 law that created general amnesty for illegal immigrants who could prove residency for four years and offered special amnesty to farm workers. Maria sneaked across the river nine years ago with their children to join her husband.
But her own immigration efforts have been entangled. When her father became ill, she went to Mexico. When she tried to return after his death, she was detained twice, placing a violation on her record. She returned to El Paso on her third trip, but now she says she must fill out a form to clear her record -- at a cost of $175, a large sum for her -- to apply for citizenship. 
Maria said she took comfort in the fact that Mr. Bush had emphasized compassion, and she hoped a legalization program was instituted. "I believe that Bush believes that families should be together," she said.
Carlos Marendes, director of the Border Agricultural Workers Center, which offers support services for migrant farm workers, said that those considering any new policy should learn from failings in the past.
Perhaps the most famous immigration policy for Mexicans was the bracero program for farm workers that began in the labor shortages of World War II. This guest worker policy funneled Mexican field hands to American farms for limited periods. Ultimately, the program brought complaints of exploitation, low pay and poor working conditions. This year, a class-action lawsuit was filed in California seeking hundreds of millions of dollars on behalf of thousands of Mexican farm workers who claim they were bilked out of part of their earnings.
Mr. Marendes said much of the next generation of Mexican farm workers gained legal status under the 1986 amnesty program. But that policy's other goal -- reducing the tide of illegal immigration -- failed.
"If they want to solve the problem," he said, "they have to do an amnesty that is humane, that is flexible and that is fair."
The I.N.S. estimates that there are now 6.5 million to 7.5 million illegal immigrants in the country, including roughly 3 million Mexicans. There are no current figures, but a 1996 study showed that about 700,000 illegal immigrants lived in Texas. 
Peter Maldonado, 70, a native Mexican who became a United States citizen during the 1986 amnesty, worries that the number of illegal residents is even greater and that the promise of citizenship would bring waves more across the Rio Grande.
"If they get it right, it's O.K.," Mr. Maldonado said. "But is there an opportunity for them? Are there jobs?" 
Mr. Ramirez, the citizenship teacher, said he believed Mr. Bush was uniquely qualified to address the Mexican immigration problems, but he worried about the unintended consequences of any new policy.
He said unemployment was already acute in El Paso and along the border, where many legal residents live in ramshackle developments. He also questioned how a bureaucracy that takes 18 months to 3 years to complete the citizenship process could handle a sweeping legalization program. "And we're talking about three million people they are trying to get legalized?" he asked. "Come on. You've got to have some sort of plan set up. Like the braceros. They promised all those things and never got it."
One student, Yolanda Chairez, a legal resident, has a cousin in California who was detained, jailed and awaits deportation to Mexico. Ms. Chairez said a legalization plan would "help a lot of Mexicans who don't have their rights yet and would protect them from abuse."
But no one thinks it will be easy.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Maria de la Torre, right, in Vincent Ramirez's citizenship class in Texas, is "hoping and praying" for a plan to give residency to illegal immigrants. (Bruce Berman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: GENOA SUMMIT MEETING: THE OVERVIEW; 
ITALIAN PROTESTER IS KILLED BY POLICE AT GENOA MEETING

BYLINE:  By ALESSANDRA STANLEY and DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: GENOA, Italy, July 20 

 BODY:
A 23-year-old Italian protester was shot and killed today by a police officer during a riot less than two miles from a gathering of leaders of the world's largest industrialized nations, who were protected by a 13-foot fence that anti-globalization demonstrators had vowed to breach.
 The killing in Genoa, a medieval seaport converted into a 21st-century citadel, is the first death during an anti-globalization demonstration since the movement tempestuously surfaced at a World Trade Organization meeting in Seattle in 1999. Today's grim milestone deepened an already widespread feeling that these kinds of international conferences -- and the vast and often violent protests they inspire -- cannot go on unchanged any longer. 
 "One hundred thousand people don't get upset unless there is a problem in their hearts and spirits," President Jacques Chirac of France told reporters shortly before he was informed of the death. Italy's prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi, who is host for the summit meeting, began the morning session by suggesting that the venues for such high-level meetings be reconsidered. 
After hearing about the demonstrator's death, Mr. Berlusconi, his face ashen, appeared alongside President Carlo Azeglio Ciampi of Italy, letting him speak for both of them about their sorrow over the death. 
Vittorio Agnoletti, head of the Genoa Social Forum, an umbrella association of more than 700 anti-globalization groups gathered in Genoa to protest the summit meeting, called tonight for the immediate suspension of the sessions. Today for the first time, the Group of 8 leaders discussed health, debt and the poor -- exactly the topics that demonstrators have complained that rich countries ignore. Page A7. 
Today's several thousand protesters could multiply into tens of thousands on Saturday after calls today for demonstrators to show their anger over the death by marching through the city.
Mr. Agnoletti deplored the violence of a small group of protesters who undercut the main demonstration by looting, burning cars and battling the police and also condemned the use of firearms by the police to combat them.
Tonight, Italy's interior minister, Claudio Scajola, issued a terse statement confirming that Carlo Giuliani, 23, a Roman who lived in Genoa, was "hit by a shot from a gun," and saying it was fired "in self-defense by one of the police."
The policeman who shot him was hospitalized, police officials said, for injuries sustained in the fighting.
According to Dylan Martinez, a Reuters photographer who captured some of the scene on film, the victim was one of several young men who had surrounded a police van and were smashing it with rocks, metal rods and other weapons. He said the man had been shot by a policeman and then his body run over by the vehicle.
Italian television repeatedly showed grisly still shots of Mr. Giuliani, his face masked by a balaclava, hurling a fire extinguisher at a police van, then a close-up of a hand inside the van firing a pistol in return. A third photograph showed the man lying on the ground beneath the van, seemingly as if the police vehicle had run over his legs after he fell.
It was not clear today why the riot police were armed with live ammunition. The police in Seattle and in Quebec last spring had been equipped with air-guns that shot a powerful but nonlethal rubber pellet, the size of a large marble. In Genoa, the police used water cannons, riot sticks and tear gas today. 
Tonight, after scenes of burning cars and tear gas dominated television images broadcast from the summit meeting, the White House issued a terse statement saying President Bush had been informed of the situation. It quoted Mr. Bush as saying, "the death is tragic," and that the violence was "highly regrettable."
As in previous demonstrations -- from Seattle to Gotenberg, where a man was shot and badly wounded by the Swedish police -- a small number of more radical youths, bent on battling the police, instigated a form of violence that most demonstrators did not condone.
That rift was clearly evident in Genoa, where demonstrators, who range from Catholic Scouts to Turkish Communists, today fell into three groups, coded by their appetite for confrontation by color.
There were so-called pinks, pacifists who include gay groups, but also many Italian and foreign labor associations, church groups, and other anti-globalization associations. There were "whites," bound by their desire to fight the Group of 8 with "civil disobedience" that they define as defiance and self-defense. Lastly, there were "blacks", anarchists and other fringe rebel groups that have no patience for organized marching. Today, they wore black scarves and masks and broke windows, burned cars and fought with the riot police.
The police responded by chasing demonstrators into a neighborhood cafe where regular customers were waiting out the violence, then tossed a tear gas pellet into the bar area. A demonstrator who tripped when running away was kicked and hit repeatedly with riot sticks before being dragged away for arrest. At least 70 people were detained by the police.
More than 100 people were slightly wounded, including several dozen police officers. At least two people were seriously wounded: a young woman who is in a coma and a police officer who was operated on for an injured eye.
The day began with greater expectations. Late this morning, several thousand "whites" -- including groups that included an Italian association called White Overalls, as well as Greek Socialists, British members of the Socialist Workers Party, French Communist youth groups and others -- had gathered at a stadium-turned-camping ground, a few miles from the summit meeting area. They pulled on makeshift foam rubber shields, life jackets, bicycle helmets, goggles and soccer shin guards in anticipation of a scuffle with the more than 16,000 police officers deployed to prevent protesters from disrupting the summit meeting. Most had the phone number of a lawyer scratched in ink on one arm. 
"Our goal is pretty clear," Michael Probsting, 24, an Austrian, yelled gleefully into a megaphone to fellow members of the Revolutionary Communist International, "We want to stop the summit of the G-8."
The goal of anarchist protesters was different. Bank windows and storefronts were smashed and businesses looted. Two blocks from where Mr. Giuliani was killed, and a few hours earlier, a group of men broke into a car rental agency, smashing windows, scattering credit card forms and burning two cars.
"We disagree with those people who throw bricks and burn cars; we yelled at them to stop," said Manuel Morales, 31, a Spaniard from Grenada who was with a smaller groupbut left when anarchists began looting next to him. "It's terrible," he said. "They are helping the police. Now the police can say they had a pretext to attack."
Other marchers showed their dismay by turning on the violent demonstrators. When one young man, wearing a mask, kicked in a gas station window that had already been smashed, marchers screamed, "Provocateur!" and chased him into a nearby doorway.
Thousands of marchers who were headed for the so-called red zone -- a six-square-mile high-security area -- were pinned down and cornered a mile away by the riot police, shooting tear gas and banging riot sticks on their shields. Others fought the police in side streets, hurling stones and firebombs, weeping from tear gas. Asked what group he was with, one young protester about to throw a stone replied, almost indignantly: "I'm an anarchist. I'm not in any group."
But their actions upset organizers who had sought to keep a distance from violent groups.
"This is bad," Christophe Aguiton, a leader of the French anti-globalization group Attac, said as he ducked into a doorway to avoid tear gas. "There are people who want to use this movement to do their own thing, but they are borderline hooligans."
At the same time, around 4 p.m., other demonstrators at the Piazza Dante, about 300 yards from the Ducal Palace, the Renaissance building where the leaders met, shook the steel gates of the barricade sealing off the red zone so hard that they broke. One woman slipped into the red zone, where she was immediately grabbed by heavily armed policemen and carried away. Nearby, Mr. Bush's limousine, with flags and presidential seal, stood parked.
Today's protests were in line with the increasingly violent demonstrations that began at the Seattle trade summit meeting two years ago -- a meeting that failed less because of the demonstrators than because of a rebellion by developing nations that believed that another round of free trade negotiations would hurt their workers. With each summit meeting this year, the demonstrations have grown louder, and more violent, and in some ways more effective.
Even before the summit meeting began, both Mr. Bush and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain expressed irritation with demonstrators' views of Western capitalism. The agenda inside the Ducal Palace, which included a meeting with the leaders of Nigeria and Bangladesh, was clearly intended to demonstrate that the wealthiest nations were not fixated only on their own slow economic growth in the last year. 
But tonight, issues of third world debt and unfettered capitalism were not foremost on many protesters' minds. "I think tens of thousands of us are very angry," Mr. Probsting, the Austrian protester, said as he prepared for Saturday's march. "Tomorrow, we can't be naive and wait for the police to fire cannons of tear gas. We have to be better prepared to defend ourselves."

HEADLINE: States Steer Religious Charities Toward Aid 

BYLINE:  By LAURIE GOODSTEIN 

DATELINE: NEWPORT NEWS, Va. 

 BODY:
Despite the resistance that President Bush's religion-based initiative has encountered in Washington, the idea is already catching on in many states, where local officials are making unprecedented efforts to encourage religious charities to apply for government money.
 At least 15 states, including New York and New Jersey, have appointed government liaisons who are brokering new collaborations between clergy members and state social service departments -- two constituencies that previously enjoyed little contact or trust. 
 Even more states are holding conferences to introduce religious leaders to the arcane rules of government contracting, and judging by attendance, the interest is intense. More than 150 church and community leaders attended a daylong seminar here in southeastern Virginia on the pros and cons of seeking public money and how to go about it -- 1 of 10 forums that Virginia is offering this summer. 
The friendly talk in the states about a new era of partnership between government and religion seems a world removed from the constitutional questions and partisan wrangling in Washington, where the president's proposal has been a magnet for controversy over whether it threatens the separation of church and state. On Thursday, the House narrowly passed the initiative despite criticism that it would allow religious ministries that receive government money to practice employment discrimination. And yesterday, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman said he would work with President Bush in shaping a version of the bill that the Senate could support. Page A11. 
The states have not needed to wait for Congress to act in order to redirect money to religious social services. Since 1996, when the federal rules known as charitable choice were passed as part of the legislation overhauling welfare, states have been required to make it easier for religious groups to win contracts to run social service programs.
But until recently, states remained lukewarm to the idea. A report issued last year by the Center for Public Justice, a Christian policy group in Annapolis, found that most states had virtually ignored the charitable-choice laws. It was not until the presidential campaign, when both Mr. Bush and Vice President Al Gore said they favored expanding government support for religious charities, that the approach started to gain wider acceptance. Mr. Bush, one of few governors who actively directed state agencies to finance religious programs, made expanding charitable choice a priority. 
Now, after five years of hesitation, states are diving into new relationships with religious ministries, many with good intentions but little experience either as government contractors or as social workers. 
"The faith community in this country is no little bitty body of folk," said Anthony McClarn, the faith and families coordinator for the Department of Human Resources in Georgia, who like several state liaisons is also a minister. "And once this thing is moving -- and it is moving -- you can't say you're going to stop it." 
"You can go into any part of the country, and if there's not a conference for faith leaders going on, there's one scheduled," Mr. McClarn said.
"This is something new," said Stanley Carlson-Thies, who helped develop the charitable-choice provision and now works in the White House Office on Faith-Based and Community Initiatives. "States are asking, how do we enlist and empower these groups that haven't been part of the traditional mix of services that government sponsors?"
For years, the dominant charities affiliated with religious groups -- the Salvation Army, Catholic Charities USA, Lutheran Services in America and Jewish Family Services -- garnered the lion's share of public money that went to religious charities. That domination will most likely be challenged by the newcomers, state officials said. 
New religious coalitions and individual churches that never before applied for government financing are starting to do so, said state officials and university researchers who are monitoring the law.
These are not churches simply looking for government support for soup kitchens. They are seeking financing for job training, juvenile delinquency prevention, mentoring, abstinence and sexuality education, housing and economic development.
State officials say there is no way to quantify how many religious groups have recently applied for government money and how much they have received. They say the process is too decentralized -- the sources of financing too varied and often controlled at the county level -- and it is frequently hard to tell whether a program is linked to any religion. 
In addition to the 15 states that have appointed faith liaisons, in recent months, several governors have ordered state social service agencies to carry out the federal guidelines. Within these states, some counties have done more than others. For example, in Long Beach, Calif., there is now a bilingual child care program jointly sponsored by a church and a university; in El Paso County, Colo., headquarters to scores of national evangelical ministries, a coalition of about 100 churches received a government contract to act as mentors to former welfare recipients. 
In the cities, 121 mayors have appointed liaisons to religious groups, some of them recently, and 37 other mayors said they intended to appoint such liaisons soon, according to the United States Conference of Mayors.
One reason for the action now is that after five years of reducing the welfare rolls, states are finally able to turn their attention to the law's charitable choice provision.
Kevin R. Richards, Colorado Works director with the Department of Human Services, said: "Colorado's initial focus, like most other states, was reduction of caseload. Now we're in our Phase 2 approach, which is tending directly to charitable choice." 
So far, the debate reverberating in Washington has ensnared a few states. California is being sued for setting aside money expressly for religious social services. Texas was sued for financing a job training program that required students to study the Bible -- a program the state has since stopped financing. And Wisconsin is being sued for giving $750,000 to a Milwaukee program that says it brings homeless addicts to Christ.
Charitable choice guidelines say a "faith-based" program may offer religious teaching to clients but not require it. However, it may be difficult for state agencies to police the boundaries. In Philadelphia, several Muslim clients complained last year when a church-run job retention program financed by the state required them to read from the Bible. A supervisor from the state's welfare department was called in, and he made sure the Muslims could choose alternative readings from the Koran and National Geographic. 
At the seminar in Virginia, as a roomful of ministers and grant writers scribbled notes, Jane M. Brown, liaison for Virginia's Community and Faith-Based Initiative, set out to shatter what she called Myth No. 1 -- that the government has set aside a fat new pot of money for religious charities. Instead, religious groups will have to compete with other community agencies for the same limited funds, she told them. 
But in encouraging tones, she explained that under charitable-choice rules, the government would not require them to dilute their religious missions in order to receive money. They can share their faith with their clients, as long as they do not make it a requirement. They can use religious criteria in hiring, she said, as long as they do not discriminate on the basis of age, race or gender. 
A sobering note came from some religious leaders, who stood to warn colleagues that it was far more onerous to get money from the government than from a church board. The government can scrutinize your methodology, your staff's qualifications and your building for safety and health regulations, they warned.
"If your church is going to use government funds, you've got to play by their rules, and I'm proof of that," said the Rev. Alfred A. Terrell, whose Macedonia Baptist Church is receiving money from Virginia's education department to work with children suspended from schools. "Really do your homework before you jump into that soup, because it gets real, real hot real fast." 
In the past, word of mouth like this has discouraged religious leaders from government involvement. But many at this conference said they were prepared to jump through the hoops because the financing amounted to more than they could raise passing the plate. Most had already started programs and were looking to professionalize and expand. 
"I'm encouraged," said the Rev. Johnny L. Cook, pastor of Morning Star Baptist Church, who wants to develop a mentoring program for the impoverished children he got to know at his church's free Sunday breakfasts. "I'm going to get my paperwork in order to get some more help for my kids. Our church sure doesn't have the money to fund it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jane M. Brown is the Virginia liaison responsible for linking religious charities to government aid in her state. (Gary C. Knapp for The New York Times)(pg. A11)

HEADLINE: We're Not in Oz Anymore 

BYLINE:  By Diane Cardwell; Diane Cardwell is a reporter for The Times.

 BODY:
 INSIDE RIKERS
Stories From the World's Largest Penal Colony.
By Jennifer Wynn.
223 pp. New York:
St. Martin's Press. $24.95.
 Every day, it seems, we are bombarded with images of crisis from the nation's penal system. Stories about hellish conditions, draconian sentences, physical brutality and the neglect of rehabilitation saturate the news media. Even prime time television feeds the frenzy, with supposedly realistic dramas like "Law and Order," "100 Centre Street" and "Oz." 
Into this landscape comes "Inside Rikers: Stories From the World's Largest Penal Colony," by Jennifer Wynn, who is director of the Prison Visiting Project for the Correctional Association of New York and teaches writing at the jail; she also edits its inmate magazine. Wynn first made contact with a Rikers Island prisoner when she was a freelance journalist with a headful of middle-class preconceptions. Here, she sets out to humanize this dehumanized population and expose the jail's -- and by extension society's -- wrongheaded approach to men who break the law. 
Like Wynn herself, we first meet Angel, a charming, nonthreatening con artist who has had his share of difficulties, but with Wynn's assistance becomes one of her success stories. By book's end, he has transformed himself into a functioning member of society and is thrilled, on his 50th birthday, to have landed a steady $23,000-a-year job. In a chapter titled "Convicted at Birth," we meet Rico, a 19-year-old whose deeply unstable, economically disadvantaged upbringing practically ensured, in Wynn's telling, that he would land at Rikers. Then there is Mike, a talented storyteller and origami artist who, despite the privilege of being white and middle-class, cannot escape a ferocious crack habit that continues to buffet him from Rikers to homelessness and back again. 
Interwoven with these characters are discussions of the great divide between New York's ultrarich and ultrapoor, descriptions of how the prison population is overwhelmingly black and Latino, and discourses about the fact that many inmates come from single-parent homes in poor communities that lack basic social structures and services. None of these observations are revelatory, but seeing how socioeconomic inequality, the aftershocks of lingering racism and shortsighted corrections policies play out in these men's lives gives this book emotional power and political relevance, particularly at a time when the penal system is lurching ever more toward punitive warehousing at the expense of rehabilitation. 
Wynn points out, for example, that addicted inmates, rather than being put into a drug detoxification program, are funneled into methadone maintenance, which has the effect of sending them back into their communities, once they are released, still shackled to a drug dependency. As one inmate writes: "I could have used jail time to kick the habit and get a sober perspective on life, but I never got to the point where I was able to 'say no' to dope. It's far more difficult to make the decision to be drug-free if you haven't had a drug-free day in years."
Wynn illuminates many counterproductive practices, and, at its best, her book shows how economic deprivation, bad schools, absent parents, deteriorating neighborhoods and dissolving job prospects can grow into petty criminal activity or drug addiction and how that, inevitably, inexorably, leads to jail. Wynn demonstrates, time and again, how the taint of a jail term forever dooms these men to be defined by their "single worst deed" and to be sucked into a sadly preventable vortex of recidivism. 
Unfortunately, "Inside Rikers" is marred by the misguided inclusion of Wynn's own narrative of transformation from a naive, privileged outsider to a humble-yet-knowing social worker, a narrative that is as cliched as it is irritating. Visiting the South Bronx with a man who runs a program dedicated to helping teenage felons turn their lives around, Wynn is taken aback by how barren and racially segregated the housing projects are, and dismayed to see that even a pathetic, dusty patch of grass has a sign to keep off. Her first reaction is to think of her own comfortable upbringing. "In a high school of 800 students, there was one black," she writes with the kind of gee-whiz condescension that infects many of her observations. "And you can't buy a piece of property unless it's on five acres of grass, much less walk on it." 
At another point, she writes of Frank, an urban Robin Hood who rationalizes his thievery as justifiable payback for a society that has deprived him of the means for success: "I admire the Franks of this world, and as I travel home from Rikers Island, noticing how the city gets cleaner and whiter with each mile closer to Manhattan, I ask myself how they do it, how they live such wretched lives in the richest city on earth, mired in the underclass yet still finding it in their hearts to take care of little boys without fathers and bring flowers to their teachers, when most people -- certainly me, I know -- would have given up long ago, or been too embittered to care."
Far better simply to let Frank, who has spent a good part of his 39 years in and out of correctional facilities, speak for himself, as he does in a letter to the author. "I wonder again for the hundredth time why I continued with my criminal activities," he writes. "It certainly wasn't worth it. I had $300 in my pocket when I was arrested. I live simply, and I give away much of the proceeds from my hits. 'Wealth redistribution' is what I call it. But Jennifer, in answer to your question as to why I continued to steal . . . perhaps it was only to show that I could." Free from the cloying guilt of the newly empathetic do-gooder, the men's stories, like Frank's, stand as eloquent and damning testimonies to the cycle of jails and lives gone avoidably wrong and our inability to break it. 

Author's Query
For a memoir of growing up in Wainscott and other places on the South Fork of Long Island, I would appreciate hearing from residents of Quogue, Montauk or anywhere in between from the late 1950's to the early 70's.

Geoff Gehman
Arts Writer
The Morning Call
Box 1260
Allentown, Pa. 18105
Geoff.gehman@mcall.com

HEADLINE: Eyes Instead of Theories 

BYLINE:  By Sarah Kerr; Sarah Kerr, the film critic for Vogue, writes regularly about Latin America.

 BODY:
 LOOKING FOR HISTORY
Dispatches From Latin America.
By Alma Guillermoprieto.
303 pp. New York:
Pantheon Books. $25.
 It's not often that you want to thank a writer for the things she doesn't do, but such is the case with Alma Guillermoprieto. For over a decade now, first with her reporting in The New Yorker and later in The New York Review of Books, Guillermoprieto has set the standard for elegant writing in English on Latin America. In large part she has done so through an almost heroic avoidance of the bad habits that too often dog people who bring us the news from foreign parts. She is wonderfully lucid, for example, but without the airless certainty of someone writing for an audience of think tanks or insider colleagues. Though capable of exquisite, self-conscious prose, she doesn't treat her self-consciousness as a theme, and thus avoids sweeping into a country V. S. Naipaul-style, passing irritable judgment and dramatizing her despair at the mess she finds. Nor, though she possesses extraordinary empathy, does she wrap up chaotic Mexico City or troubled Bogota in a bow and try to sell it to you as if it were Tuscany or Provence. 
Above all Guillermoprieto is subtle: in fact, the task she sets for herself with "Looking for History," her second collection of essays (after "The Heart That Bleeds," and also after "Samba," her rich account of a year's immersion in the culture of Brazilian dance), is so subtle that you could almost call it radical. Guillermoprieto simply looks at various Latin American situations and describes what she sees, in reported pieces on Mexico's Zapatista rebels or the pope in Cuba, and in witty essays on iconic figures like Evita Peron and Che Guevara. Her goal, she writes in the introduction, is to "render visible to U.S. readers some of the more hidden and enigmatic aspects of Latin American history and conflict." 
Those accustomed to books with a catchall, high-concept thesis may wonder: Where's the Big Idea? Where have these countries been, and which way are they headed? But if Guillermoprieto fails to oblige on this score she does so deliberately, with a higher purpose in mind. Too many Big Ideas have hung around Latin America for decades -- fantasies, sprung from the minds of Latin demagogues and myopic United States policy makers alike. "Looking for History" wages understated battle against most of them, from old-style socialism to anti-Communism-at-any-cost to the war on drugs and the latest fashionable mantra declaring, with admirable intentions and reductive simplicity, that a clean election once every few years is the same thing as a healthy democracy. 
Elections are a necessary first step. But what exactly have they accomplished in Colombia, which advertises itself as Latin America's oldest democracy even as a deadly doubles match rages across the land, teaming drug cartels and guerrillas against the army and paramilitary vigilantes? Guillermoprieto's three reports from Colombia are easily the most important in this collection. No factor in the country's predicament, from its weird and trackless topography to its history as a base for smugglers of emeralds and pre-Columbian artifacts, escapes her attention. Actors on all sides of the conflict come in for devastating blame and a small dose of sympathy. Guillermoprieto considers Rosa, a leftist kidnapping victim who ends up like Patty Hearst, fighting passionately alongside her rightist paramilitary captors. Then there is the Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia (the FARC), the leading guerrilla group, whose headquarters Guillermoprieto once visited by trekking across an icy swamp high up in the Andes. She characterizes the FARC as uncharismatic and out of touch -- and also among the most ruthlessly effective insurgencies in the world. 
As for United States aid to Colombia, which increased under Bill Clinton and which George W. Bush has pledged to continue, Guillermoprieto is skeptical at best. Though the Pentagon insists that the money will go toward disabling the drug trade, common sense would indicate that Colombia's army might prefer to use it to wipe out the guerrillas. This might be effective in the short term, but Guillermoprieto can't help recalling the sorry denouement of similar episodes in the past in which a fragile peace was won "by use of force, leading to exclusions that lead to more violence." 
The Colombia pieces are dense reading, weighted with a kind of ethical thoroughness, as if Guillermoprieto wanted to create a lasting, essential primer. She basically succeeds, but elsewhere it's nice to hear her voice range more freely. In Cuba, to assess the impact of the pope's first visit, she notes odd details of injured pride and raw-nerved accommodation to scarcity. In one of the book's more inventive passages she reads the collective mind of the generation of Cubans who are the same age as Castro's reign -- just slightly younger than America's Baby Boomers but equally prone to imagine themselves protagonists of a grand history. She revisits their boundless pride in Fidel as children, their paranoid loyalty during the Mariel boatlift of 1980, their nervous deference in 1989 as Castro charged a leading hero of the Revolution with treason and had him killed. Landing in post-Soviet, increasingly isolated times, she finds the old cultish confidence replaced by a cultish despair. "This is a new adventure: Cuba, this beloved and fragile vessel, will ride out the ominous storm. With Fidel at the helm, there is no cause for fear, and yet you are, for the first time, unconsolably afraid." 
At such moments, Guillermoprieto gets at the truth the way a psychological novelist might. Indeed, she may be at her most authoritative when studying the emotional pressure points of Latin American politics -- the way machismo helped to corrupt Che Guevara, for instance, and the ease with which justifiable cynicism can turn into a "longing for false certainties" and then surrender to a would-be hero. 
This is not a comprehensive survey. Several marquee news stories, (Elian Gonzalez, the dramatic fall of President Alberto Fujimori and the Lori Berenson case in Peru, the arrest and threatened trial of Chile's Pinochet, to name a few) are not addressed here. But Guillermoprieto may be at her best away from headlines anyway. She does a fine job retracing the top-level assassinations that led the Mexican news throughout the 1990's, and she makes the now iconic trip through the Chiapas jungle to interview the Zapatista rebel leader Subcomandante Marcos. 
Shortly before last summer's presidential election Guillermoprieto sat down with the history-making eventual winner, Vicente Fox, who likes to wear cowboy boots and conducts politics like a business, "delegating tasks, making important decisions quickly and sticking to a schedule." Sound familiar? Her entertaining account reinforces some of the eerie similarities that have been pointed out between Fox and George W. Bush, but reading it one is confronted, too, with the profound difference: that even people who disagree with Fox ideologically can celebrate his victory as a step forward for Mexican democracy, whereas the circumstances of Bush's victory permit no such shared civic joy. 
Yet the tone in the dispatches from Mexico feels somewhat distant. Vivid as Guillermoprieto is on the assassinations and machinations, she is dealing necessarily in speculation. I sometimes wished she had skipped the political news and brought her precise, aware brand of wisdom to life away from the news. And much as I admire her subtlety, I found myself hoping she would be a little less evenhanded and say more straightforwardly what she thinks. 
The problem may be a matter of time: too much happening in Mexico too fast to digest it all. Whatever the case, when Guillermoprieto speaks her mind -- in a particularly strong essay, for instance, on Mario Vargas Llosa, the brilliant novelist who ran a disastrous campaign for the Peruvian presidency in 1990 -- she speaks with power. Vargas Llosa the politician lost, Guillermoprieto writes, because he ignored everything Vargas Llosa the novelist knew of his country. His rigid economic platform, promising "reforms that look orderly on paper but are not designed to deal with chaos," utterly failed to connect with Peru's poor. His arrogant faith in reason proved utterly irrational, and in his naivete he opened the door to the opportunistic demagoguery of the victor, Fujimori. 
Here, in distilled form, is the dare Guillermoprieto throws out to Latin America. (And to the extent that the United States has its hand in the pot, she issues the challenge to us as well.) Keeping out the demagogues will take more than mere elections, or the paying off of loans. It will take something like a realignment of consciousness: facing up to a deeply compromised reality and cultivating realistic hope.

HEADLINE: Gaul Divided 

BYLINE:  By Mark Mazower; Mark Mazower is a professor of history at Birkbeck College, London.

 BODY:
 FRANCE
The Dark Years, 1940-1944.
By Julian Jackson.
660 pp. New York:
Oxford University Press. $35.
 In 1939 there was only one France. Within a year, Julian Jackson notes, it had given way to no less than six distinct zones of occupation. Defeat by the German Army led to the country's territorial division and administrative disintegration. By 1943 at least three governments claimed to embody French sovereignty: Marshal Philippe Petain's Vichy, Gen. Charles de Gaulle's in London and Gen. Henri Giraud's in Algiers. Hardly surprising, then, that according to President Franklin D. Roosevelt, France had ceased to exist. In "France: The Dark Years, 1940-1944" Jackson, a professor of history at the University of Wales, Swansea, charts this story of the fragmentation and eventual reconstitution of the French nation-state, emphasizing the various political forces that emerged to speak for the country, the myths they spun and the visions of national well-being that held them in thrall. 
This book is an exhaustive synthesis of scholarly research, memoirs and diaries. It is difficult to imagine that anyone else will now feel the need to bring together in a single volume the mass of material that has been published over the past half-century on France's wartime experience. What makes Jackson's account particularly useful is that it traces both the prewar roots of wartime developments and the postwar reverberations -- the trials, purges, films and novels. Vichy and the resistance thus emerge clearly as part of the longer run of French history. 
For instance, the contempt for parliamentary democracy widely associated with Vichy turns out to have been shared by many within the resistance as well. On questions of population decline, immigration policy and the welfare state, continuities of ideas, and even personnel, were evident. Vichy itself was, in Jackson's words, "both legal and legitimate" in its birth, and in its frequent ministerial changes rather reminiscent of the system it claimed to have superseded. In fact, the prewar republic was never formally renounced by Marshal Petain; the "Marseillaise" continued to be played at official ceremonies (though not in the Occupied Zone). Premier Pierre Laval's policy of French-German collaboration, Jackson observes, owed not a little to his precursor, Aristide Briand, and anticipated, in turn, the postwar Schuman Plan.
The war years also saw the creation of a national police force, a nationalized film industry and a huge popular expansion of athletics -- all of which continued after liberation. Far from cutting modernist culture off at the knees (the notion that modernism fled during the war from a benighted Europe to a welcoming Manhattan is a myth), wartime France was a place where 
Le Corbusier entertained hopes of architectural renewal and where Picasso published luxury art books. Seeing the war in this way helps us understand how Francois Mitterrand, to take but one example among many, could move smoothly from being a junior civil servant in Vichy to a rising Socialist star of postwar French politics. 
Jackson is good at showing all this, but finds explanation harder. He stresses that many of these developments had little to do with Vichy itself, which had difficulty controlling even the institutions and organizations it deliberately set up. But because his approach is largely political, Jackson does not spend much time examining the social and economic forces that were also shaping the country. Consequently, this is mainly a book about politicians old and new, their ideas, activities and groupings, to a degree that may exhaust the reader who is not up to speed on the difference between Briand and Caillaux, or between Darnand, Doriot and Deat. These men were all important, but we are also introduced to a multitude of minor figures. Eventually, the accumulated prosopographical detail swamps truly important events, like the extraordinary exodus during the summer of 1940, which saw millions of people take to the roads to flee the German advance. This led "to a total disintegration of social structures," according to the author, but the consequences of this flight are not shown.
Jackson, like most of his predecessors in the field, has relatively little to say about the Germans, British and Americans. Their importance -- no, their determinative role -- is too obvious to deny. Yet for all the attention devoted to endless French minor players, major figures who are not French are kept firmly offstage. Between Goebbels's mischievous suggestion in 1940 that the Germans would turn France into "a greater Switzerland, a country of tourism . . . and fashion" and the Nazi atrocities carried out in 1944 is a story of France as seen and ordered around by its masters in Berlin. But historians of France remain as entranced by the mystique of France as the characters they describe. They write as if the resistance on the one hand and de Gaulle on the other really did embody France and hold her fate in their hands. Jackson is far too good a historian really to believe that, but the awful weakness of the country -- the true profundity of the national humiliation it endured in these years -- remains veiled by his concentration on what Frenchmen (and to a much lesser extent Frenchwomen) did. Often, in truth, it did not much matter.
Describing the liberation, the author eschews generalization for what he calls a series of microhistories, "departement to departement, valley to valley, village to village." The kind of approach that, one is told by experts, should be applied to wines and cheeses is here turned into historical method. With good reason, to be sure, since national fragmentation reached its apogee at this point in the war. Nevertheless, there is a striking contrast between the loving detail given to locale and region, and Jackson's unwillingness to set France in a broader context. When he does this, as in a comparison of France and Denmark that points out the peculiarities of the political settlement that embodied Vichy, the results are illuminating. Much of what France went through cannot be understood divorced from the larger picture. Patterns of collaboration and resistance, German military behavior, ideas about the future -- all of these ran across the borders of Hitler's New Order. 
This book bears impressive testimony to the depth of France's postwar conversation with itself about what it endured during the war, but it brings out as well the introverted, even provincial, character of that conversation. At the beginning of the 21st century, it is still hard for European historians to see themselves, and their subject, as part of something called Europe.

HEADLINE: Glory Road And Its Storied Past 

BYLINE:  By WAYNE CURTIS; WAYNE CURTIS, a freelancer, lives in Eastport, Me.

 BODY:
NOSTALGIA comes in dozens of forms, some subtle and some not. The least trustworthy kind is always shiny and bright -- think of those overly restored diners whose walls are adorned with 45 r.p.m. records, where sandwiches have names like "The Big Bopper." It's nostalgia as marketing tool, and when someone's trying to sell you something, the sense of place often dies in the sales pitch.
 So it was with a bit of trepidation that I recently set out to drive 260 miles of historic Route 66 across parts of Oklahoma and Texas, taking two days in one direction and doubling back on a third. No highway has been more thoroughly gift-wrapped in nostalgia. Blame it on John Steinbeck's "Grapes of Wrath" (he dubbed it the "mother road"), or on that inescapable Bobby Troup song -- the one about getting your kicks. Route 66, which this year is celebrating the 75th anniversary of its creation, has become an enduring American icon. 
 The highway lost its official U.S. route designation in 1985, but the road (two lanes for the most part, four lanes in some places) has persisted through inertia and the efforts of enthusiasts. Much of the surviving highway between Chicago and Santa Monica, Calif., has been given the quasi-official designation of Historic Route 66, marked with signs to help modern pilgrims trace large chunks of the old Mother Road. 
The tourist traffic has not gone unnoticed by the emergent Route 66 industry, which churns out decals, T-shirts and shot glasses for sale at themed restaurants and gift shops that crop up along much of the highway. That's not to say Route 66 is one long, linear gift shop -- happily, there are still vast, open expanses where the spirit of the original open road comes through.
One of those stretches is between Oklahoma City and Amarillo, Tex. This region of endless vistas and few services doesn't often top lists of vacation destinations, but that's part of the appeal. It's mostly devoid of touristy claptrap, and somewhere between the two cities you abruptly pass from an Eastern landscape to a Western one. It's as if the curtains have parted on a grand proscenium. And that exhilarating sense of arrival, it seems to me, is a large part of the highway's original spirit.
I started out in May in Oklahoma City, which sprawls across the open landscape, with each generation of development claiming another ring around the core. But rather than being annoying, I found the sprawl here oddly appealing.
Longtime residents will tell you that most of Oklahoma City's idiosyncratic roadside architecture has been lost to time and neglect. But in driving aimlessly -- sometimes following old Route 66 (it's marked on the AAA city map), and sometimes not -- I still found enough slam-on-the-brakes midcentury modern architecture to keep the ramble interesting.
Among the best was the 1962 State Capitol Bank (now an Arvest branch) on Lincoln Boulevard, which looks like a gathering of baby flying saucers awaiting the return of the mother ship. It was designed by the Oklahoma architect Robert B. Roloff, who told me that the bank president who commissioned it wanted it "more like a cocktail lounge than a bank." Mr. Roloff also designed the gold-domed Citizens State Bank (now a Bank One) in 1958, inspired by Buckminster Fuller's geodesics.
Off North May Avenue is a Bank of America branch made of modernistic arches, cables and parabolic concrete, a building utterly resistant to any attempt at classification. And nearby is the brilliant plumage of the exceedingly neoned Charcoal Oven, a drive-through hamburger stand that's been a city institution since 1958.
In contrast to the spirited outskirts, downtown Oklahoma City is more subdued and melancholy, in part because much of the economic energy has migrated outward, and in part because it's the site of the former Alfred P. Murrah building -- now a stark and dramatic memorial to those who died in the 1995 blast.
I set off westward on a blue and sunny afternoon, linking up with the old Route 66 near the city's outskirts. The road here is made of a pinkish pavement, but it's just as easy to recognize by listening: Route 66 has its own soundtrack, made by tires thunking over pavement seams.
Almost everyone describes the sound differently. One motel owner told me it was "fwocka . . . fwocka . . . fwocka." Some visiting Germans said it was "dob do . . . dob do . . . dob do." I actually heard "dot com . . . dot com . . . dot com." You be the judge. (Be forewarned: the 1946 Bobby Troup song "Get Your Kicks on Route 66" is all but impossible to stop singing when you're driving because the tune's rhythm closely mimics the actual sound of the road.)
Once outside city limits, finding traces of the original highway becomes something of a scavenger hunt. The old road has in large part been absorbed by I-40 (where you won't necessarily see signs for Route 66), which plunges westward with a humorless efficiency -- sides of hills blasted away, rivers spanned, small towns skirted as if they were tar pits threatening the march of progress. Original Route 66, where you find it, sits more lightly on the land, weaving around hillocks, and rolling gently right through the middle of the towns, like a welcoming carpet.
In western Oklahoma I found two relatively new museums devoted to the history and culture of Route 66. Just 26 miles apart, both were glossy and bright. As to why two largely similar museums ended up in such close proximity, I was told that the state passed over Elk City in favor of Clinton when it sought a museum site in the mid-1990's. In a minor fit of pique, Elk City opened its own.
Visitors to the Oklahoma Route 66 Museum in Clinton begin by perusing the "world's largest curio cabinet," then progress, decade by decade, through displays about the highway's history. It's a good outline of the road's rich heritage; each of the decades occupies a room, where visitors hear songs or see film clips and artifacts relating to that decade. (In the 60's room is a VW microbus, painted in psychedelic colors. According to a helpful placard, "The driver would flash the peace sign expecting a return of the same.")
The National Route 66 Museum in Elk City had less extensive displays, but featured a superb RV prototype (a converted 1929 Stewart truck) that succinctly captured the grand enterprise of road tripping before Interstates and motels.
My disappointment with both museums might be summed up by the phrase "pavement display." Both exhibited a cross section of pavement from the original highway, and I couldn't help but recall tales of fanciful beasts that perished upon being caged. These bits of pavement -- and all the other entombed curios -- seemed to suck the life out of this storied route. Where was the sense of adventure? Where was the comforting "dot com . . . dot com"? It was like trying to summon up the grandeur of Rome by putting a paving stone on a stand. I pressed on.
Fifteen miles west of Elk City is the town of Sayre, where the impressive Beckham County Courthouse may look dimly familiar -- it had a cameo in John Ford's "The Grapes of Wrath." Soon after, at the border of the Texas panhandle, I crossed the 100th meridian, a continental divide of climate, architecture and culture, the beginning of the Great American Desert. The arid West with its false-front towns and dun landscapes suddenly loomed ahead, and the green farm fields of the Midwest receded into the rear-view mirror.
Tying the two landscapes together are the fine ruins that quickly come into view up along the highway. Americans usually loathe ruins, of course -- they want to either fix them up or tear them down. But that attitude doesn't seem to apply along Route 66, where abandoned signs and buildings benefit from picturesque neglect. I found handsome ghost signs fronting enterprises long since demolished, and empty roadside stands that were every bit as evocative as Tintern Abbey.
I came upon disused and cobwebbed ice cream stands, restaurants, motels, movie theaters and gas stations. In Groom, Tex., there was the eerie and defunct 66 Courts motel, now in a state of advanced dishabille. In McLean I found an exception to the rule: a handsomely restored vintage Phillips 66 station -- the old kind with the steep gables -- with an antique pumper parked out front.
The most striking near-ruin was the U Drop Inn in Shamrock, Tex., a former gas station and cafe designed in a sort of Art Deco-ish, nationalist style one might associate with a Teutonic regime, complete with monumental spire. When this impressive edifice of brick and green glazed tile opened in 1936, the local paper called it the "swankest of swank eating places." It shut down in 1997, but a sign promises a future restoration.
About midway across the Texas Panhandle is the city of Amarillo. As in Oklahoma City, the downtown here is a bit gap-toothed -- it's largely a patchwork of parking lots interrupted by the occasional building -- but has some extraordinary Art Deco structures worth looking at, including the Kress Building (1932), the landmark Santa Fe Building (1929) and the late-Deco Greyhound bus terminal (built in 1949, it now also houses offices).
Historic Route 66 follows Amarillo's West Sixth Avenue, and between Georgia and Western Streets there's a strong sense of small town cordiality. A blue water tower even rises up over lowslung buildings (some in a brick Spanish colonial style), and former gas stations (some now shops) crowd in on the road.
Browsable antique shops cluster along here, and I spent a productive morning poking around. The Sixth Street Antique Mall has 25 dealers housed in the Nat (short for natatorium), an old indoor swimming pool that was converted to a dance hall and once played host to many of the big bands that motored along Route 66. Whispering Pines Antiques has rustic goods with a north-woods flavor, and Alex's Route 66 Antique Mall has a fine selection of vintage 20th-century goods. Having gotten in the 66 spirit myself, I ended up in possession of two vintage ice crushers, a handsome old suitcase and a passe set of shot glasses ringed with colorful stripes.
Historic Route 66 also offers some of Amarillo's most diverse dining. The Shack at Ocho Rios specializes in tropical barbecue and serves excellent jerk pork. And just down the block is the Golden Light Cafe, a Route 66 institution since 1946. The original plywood booths have been replaced, and the place is now festooned with Coors Lite signs, but it retains the smoky feel of a classic road joint. I elbowed up to the crowded counter and ordered a bowl of green chili stew.
The man next to me informed me that he sold leather motorcycle paraphernalia at biker rallies for a living. Upon learning that I was a writer, he told me in a way that left little room for negotiation that I was to write that this is the best green chili stew between Tulsa and Tucson.
So there you have it. I'm also pleased to report that for fans of Route 66, the cafe -- like much of the highway through the two states -- is also home to a comfortably frayed nostalgia, the kind you can trust.

Along the aging Mother Road

Lodging
The Renaissance Oklahoma City, 10 North Broadway, Oklahoma City, (405) 228-8000, fax (405) 228-8080, www.jqhhotels.com, has 311 modern rooms around a soaring atrium. The hotel is downtown within walking distance of Bricktown, a district of restaurants and nightclubs, and the Oklahoma City Memorial. Doubles from $79 through the end of the month.
Cactus Inn, Route 66 West, McLean, Tex., (806) 779-2346, fax (806) 779-2313, is a vintage motel just off the road that's been recently renovated by the owners, Gordon and Jane Sheplor. Nonsmoking rooms are available; doubles from $35.
The Ambassador Hotel, 3100 I-40 West, Amarillo, Tex., (800) 817-0521, fax (806) 358-9869, or on the Web at www.shanerhotels.com, is one of the city's better full-service hotels, situated off the Interstate south of downtown. Doubles from $99.

Architecture
Aficionados of mid-20th-century commercial architecture will find plenty to gawk at, both in the cities and along the roadside.
OKLAHOMA CITY: Arvest Bank (formerly State Capitol Bank), 3900 North Lincoln Boulevard (at Northeast 39th Street); Bank One (formerly Citizens State Bank), 1112 West 23rd Street (at Classen Boulevard); and Bank of America, 5613 North May Avenue (at United Founders Boulevard).
SHAMROCK, TEX.: the U Drop Inn, Historic Route 66 and Route 83.
AMARILLO: the Kress Building, Seventh Avenue and Polk; the Santa Fe Building, Ninth Avenue and Polk; and the Greyhound Bus Terminal, Seventh Avenue and Tyler.

Dining
Charcoal Oven, 2701 Northwest Expressway, Oklahoma City, (405) 842-8911, is a classic drive-through restaurant with terrific burgers. You can park under the awning after you pick up your order. Burgers, $2.89 to $4.99.
Golden Light Cafe, 2908 West Sixth Avenue, Amarillo, (806) 374-9237, serves sandwiches and various tasty chilis, priced from $2 to $5. It's open from 11 a.m. until 10 p.m. daily except Sunday.
The Shack at Ocho Rios, 3020 West Sixth Avenue, Amarillo, (806) 374-6522, specializes in Jamaican jerk dishes, but also serves fish, pasta and burgers. Lunch and dinner entrees from $7 to $18. Open for lunch and dinner Tuesday through Saturday.

Shopping
The largest concentration of antique shops is found on West Sixth Avenue in Amarillo, between Western and Georgia Streets: Sixth Street Antique Mall, at No. 2715, (806) 374-0459; Whispering Pines Antiques, at No. 2727, (806) 373-8131; and Alex's Route 66 Antique Mall, at No. 2912, (806) 376-1166.
