LENGTH: 1363 words

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey; 
In Newark Urban Desert, New Homes Begin to Rise

BYLINE:  By ANTOINETTE MARTIN 

DATELINE: NEWARK 

 BODY:
THE rundown blocks in the area off Route 78 near Newark Airport, splotched with boarded-up buildings and lacking such urban amenities as shopping and playgrounds, seem an unlikely nest for dreams of home ownership and community.
 Yet the place is proving to be a fertile incubator for visions of a better life. 
 Two model homes, each designed for two-family occupancy, stand like proud hatchlings at the corner of Hillside Avenue and Runyon Street amid the tired old denizens here -- a hulking abandoned warehouse, some empty weeded lots and dozens of two- to four-family apartment structures that have seen better days.
"Joe! Stop the car, Joe! That's the house I want," Mary Edmonds, who works for Verizon, remembers shouting at her husband, Joseph, who is a postal worker, as they happened to drive by the brand-new models one day last spring.
Mr. Edmonds pulled over. The couple took a look inside the brick-front colonials, available in two different styles, each with a three-bedroom, two-bath owner's unit on the second floor and a slightly less roomy tenant's apartment on the first floor, and they were sold. 
That was in May. The Edmondses close on their new home -- which is going up now, on property just behind the models -- in November.
Mrs. Edmonds's sister is all set to move in from Yonkers, find a job in Newark and occupy the first-floor apartment.
Mary Edmonds thought it was happenstance that she and her husband should be seriously thinking about buying for the first time, that they would instantly find the perfect house for sale, that it would be affordable with its own rental unit for income.
Actually, though, her excitement is taking flight entirely according to design. Mrs. Edmonds's classic American dream of owning a sparkling new home falls right in line with city planners' designs for Newark's future, not to mention the ambitions of the contractors who have been hired to create a whole new community in the South Ward.
"The lure of the American dream is alive," said Newark's mayor, Sharpe James, who grew up in a small rented house in the South Ward. "People want to own something. They want to own it."
Mayor James said that when he visits Southwyck Estates, as the development site has been christened, he always sees an interested buyer or two stop by. "And wherever I go, people come up to me," he added, "and they say, 'How can I get one?' "That kind of excitement is what's going to transform one of our oldest neighborhoods."
The developer for Southwyck concurs. "We're in it for the money, of course," said Peter Weissbrod, a principal in New Century Homes, who was smiling as he said it. "It's so great to get involved with a neighborhood, and a project with this size and scope."
Mr. Weissbrod said the battle over suburban sprawl in New Jersey is done -- and the results, for developers, have made urban areas more attractive. In the suburbs, "it takes years now to get anything through the planning boards," he said, "and it's just not worth it." 
But working with an urban center like Newark, which owns a huge inventory of vacant lots that it is seeking to turn into tax-paying properties, is a mammoth opportunity, Mr. Weissbrod said. He and his partners, who own and operate a number of affiliated and subsidiary companies, including Summit Real Estate Developers, which holds the contract in Newark, feel their own dreams revitalized, Mr. Weissbrod said -- "like we've found something to do for the next 20 or 30 years."
His company, based in Westfield, will build about 240 homes in the first phase of this program, by far the largest share of the 600 homes the city put out to bid last year, offering vacant lots at $1 a square foot. Newark is pursuing an ultimate goal of 1,500 new homes, which would double the owner-occupancy rate in the city to 50 percent. New Century will keep pursuing the contracts, Mr. Weissbrod said.
"This is a plan we can believe in," he said. "What's going to make it work is the two-family home."
Newark authorities are using a neighborhood stabilization program in Cleveland as a model. New Century looks to its own work in Plainfield, N.J., where it started building 200 to 300 two-family units a year ago.
T HE situation is somewhat different in Plainfield than in Newark," Mr. Weissbrod said. "There are only vacant lots in pockets, maybe two or three on a block -- and there are well-established neighborhoods, where here we need to create that. Some of the housing we're producing in Plainfield is subsidized in various ways, and buyers might need to meet income limits or other requirements.
"Here, the homes will all sell at market rate -- somewhere right around $200,000 -- and all buyers have to qualify for a mortgage." 
But the thrust is the same: attract working families to troubled areas by offering pride of ownership. At Southwyck Estates, this attraction is generating a powerful pull.
More than 100 people showed up at the first open house in March, and 10 contracts were signed that first week. A second open house in April drew several dozen more interested people. Drop-in visitors are lured by project billboards or, like Mary Edmonds, by sheer curb appeal.
What about the effect of the depressed area around Southwyck? The mayor promises that a new elementary school will be built soon and that commercial strips will be installed using a combination of federal block grant funds and other incentives to developers.
He notes that a new recreation center, the first to be built in Newark in 40 years, will go up near Southwyck Estates. Still, the present is not as prepossessing as the potential future.
"I turned up my nose at it at first," admitted Marcelle Beck, 52, whose husband, Ozzie, 56, insisted they tour the model homes before they were even advertised. He had spotted them on his way to work as a longshoreman at Port Newark.
However, Mr. Beck fell in love with the idea of the quick commute -- he intends to work quite a few more years -- and with the idea of owning brand-new property. 
The Becks have lived in an eight-room East Orange apartment for 15 years. "It's spacious," Mrs. Beck said, "but it's old, the owner is really old and it's becoming a problem."
The Becks have a music room with a white baby grand piano in their apartment. "Where are we going to put the piano?" Mrs. Beck said on the first tour of the Southwyck models. Mr. Beck immediately came up with an answer. His credit rating was found to be excellent when the financing counselors did a quick check at Southwyck. So the Becks decided to occupy both units in their new home and not take on a tenant. They have already inquired about customizing the house being built for them, to provide access between the units.
The developers have indicated they are willing to be flexible and to accommodate buyer preferences. New Century recently agreed to switch from modular construction, which was used in Plainfield, to "stick building," because Mayor James believed the more labor-intensive approach would mean more jobs at the site for city residents. 
FURTHERMORE, while the models were built with utility rooms, but no basements, New Century decided it would put basements in all of the homes because buyers generally say they prefer that.
The standard models offer buyers a number of choices. These include a choice between a traditional interior design, with a bay window, separate kitchen and dining area, or a more contemporary design, with a kitchen that opens into the living and dining area. Buyers may also decide between a pantry and utility closet, and they are given a choice of colors, carpeting, floor coverings, cabinets and fireplaces.
All of the homes are equipped with separate gas and electricity meters for the two units, as well as separate heat and central air-conditioning units. They have a single-car attached garage and two spaces on the paved driveway.
The city was very detailed in its specifications when putting the project out to bid, the mayor said. The handsome wrought-iron fences in front of the models were required in the contract, as was ceramic tile in the bathrooms.
"I love everything about it," said Mary Edmonds, about her new home.
"Then, she's my hero," said Mayor James.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Stuart Fuchsman, left, and Peter Weissbrod, principals of New Century Homes, in front of two model homes in the South Ward in Newark. (Dith Pran/The New York Times) Map of Newark, New Jersey highlighting the South Ward and site of new development.

HEADLINE: Growth Stock: Corporate Apartments 

BYLINE:  By NADINE BROZAN 

 BODY:
WHEN the economy soars and corporations bring phalanxes of executives, consultants, associates and trainees to New York, the corporate apartment market thrives. 
 But a dip in the economy does not necessarily bode ill for corporate apartment providers. Budget cutters trimming employee travel expenses may well be attracted by the fact that, no matter how luxurious the apartment may be, it will probably cost less than a comparable hotel room for the typical stay, which ranges from a month to a year. 
 Though occupancy rates have declined this year, firms that specialize in leasing blocks of apartments, furnishing them with all the amenities of home and rerenting them to corporations are expanding their toehold in New York.
Many are increasing the number of leases they hold, and ExecuStay by Marriott is going one step further by laying claim to almost an entire residential Midtown tower being built from the ground up specifically for corporate clients. 
Until last year, the city was not a leader in the field. "But now, it is turning into one of the strongest markets both in the growth of demand and the growth in average rents," said Mark Skinner, a partner in the Highland Group, a consulting and research firm based in Atlanta that specializes in extended-stay lodging. 
The author of a study titled "Corporate Apartment Industry Report: 2001," which will be issued next month, Mr. Skinner said preliminary findings show growth to be continuing but at a markedly slower pace than last year. 
"The number of corporate apartments rented in New York City in 2000 was more than 20 percent higher than it was in 1999, and over the same period, the average rent also increased more than 20 percent," Mr. Skinner said. "This year I foresee that you won't sustain that same pace of growth. It will probably be in the single digit range." 
Nationally, he predicted that the rate of growth would continue at last year's pace of 5 to 10 percent. There are 75,000 corporate units around the country, but in the summer, peak season for employee relocation and the arrival of trainees, that number temporarily escalates to 100,000. 
As Sean Hennessey, director of the hospitality consulting practice for PricewaterhouseCoopers, sees it, the market is going through a period of contradiction. 
"We are hearing from extended stay properties that they see conflicting signs," he said. "They are losing some business due to cutbacks in corporate travel, but they have picked up business from companies that would have put their travelers in full service hotels who are now looking closely at corporate apartments as a more economical alternative." 
Studios typically range from about $3,000 to $4,000 a month. One-bedroom apartments command $3,800 to $6,000 and two bedrooms about $6,500 to $8,100 a month, significantly less than the $300 plus that is the going rate in luxury hotels. 
Firms that lease blocks of apartments or, in some cases, entire buildings from developers and landlords and furnish them and equip them with everything from complete kitchens to high-speed Internet systems, are reporting more vacancies this year than last. But how much of that is due to the economic downturn and how much to an expanding supply of apartments in the city is not clear. 
"Summer is the busiest time of the year because that is when people are relocating and when all the training programs begin," said James Coniglario, director of corporate services for D. J. Knight & Company, a relocation firm. "Last year was really tough and it was a challenge for us to secure all the housing we needed for investment banks and consumer product firms. This year the demand is as high, but there is so much more product. It has been easier for me to secure housing and to be able to negotiate great prices for clients this year."
Oakwood Worldwide, a national company with headquarters in Los Angeles, has had a drop in occupancy here from 95 percent in 2000 to 85 percent this year. "But last year we had about 280 units in our portfolio, whereas this year we have about 500, so I think we are doing phenomenally well," said Noel Hernandez, Oakwood's senior district manager for New York. Still, he did note: "Last year, the pace was frenetic, especially with summer associates and interns. One financial company alone had close to 1,000 summer associates come here, and this year it went back to normal with closer to 600."
Furnished Quarters, a three-year-old local firm, is reporting a slight slippage in its occupancy rate from 97 percent last year to 95 percent this year. But, said Steven Brown, president of the company, "Last year we had 180 units. This year we have 350 and we are planning to add 150 more in the next few months. By the end of 2002, we will be up to 500 and we think we have only scratched the surface of the client base." 
THIRTY percent of his listings are in town houses the firm owns, where rents range from $2,600 for a studio to $6,200 for a three-bedroom duplex. "Prices are 25 to 30 percent less than they are in doorman buildings," Mr. Brown said. "A lot of people in the theater and Europeans like the town house experience." 
Though the business traveler is the main target consumer for corporate housing, Mr. Brown said, "we also get theater people; athletes who have been traded to teams here; people who are renovating their homes; unfortunately, people visiting hospitals; and a lot of divorces. That's a good market -- men who call and say, 'Help, my wife just kicked me out of the house.' " 
Some of the business is flowing out of the city. "Our Manhattan rentals are down about 10 percent so far this year, but our New Jersey rentals are up 15 percent," said Jason Eisenberg, corporate relocation director for Churchill Corporate Services, which operates in the tristate area. "Where Manhattan was the only option last year, now corporations are willing to place people 10 minutes away in Jersey City or Brooklyn Heights for savings of at least 10 to 15 percent a year." Churchill rents about 400 apartments in Manhattan and another 800 scattered through Westchester, New Jersey and Connecticut. Mr. Eisenberg was not yet ready to sound an alarm, but he conceded: "It's too early to tell what will happen. We're hoping to maintain where we are. We're not looking for growth this year. We just want to hold down the fort." 
Alternative Business Accommodations, a four-year-old company, entered the corporate housing market in 1997 and doubled its inventory from 30 to 60 apartments in its first year. "Since then we have gone up in number by 50 percent every year until this year," said Frank Laufer, the president. "Now we are not forecasting more than 10 percent growth."
In addition, he said: "We have noticed the clients are here for shorter stays. The 60-day average has dropped to 45 days. Some corporations are asking for smaller apartments, and some are looking to double up two people in two bedrooms. Clearly, cost consciousness is in the air."
One exception to the slack is the Phillips Club at 66th Street and Broadway, which opened as an extended-stay hotel in 1996 and later expanded into the former Chinese mission next door to include transient hotel accommodations and luxury time-share apartments. 
Though its apartments are at the high end -- with studios renting for $6,000 or more a month and two-bedrooms for $11,000 to $12,000 a month -- occupancy is up slightly over last year. The average stay is 100 days, according to Matthew Hall, the spokesman for Millennium Partners, the developer of the club. 
Shop talk in the industry is mostly focused these days on what companies are giving up some of their units as they stand empty, sending them back to the open market.
"As leases come up in the third andfourth quarters of the year, we will return some properties, so our inventory may go down somewhat," Mr. Hernandez of Oakwood said. "This business is very cyclical, so in the fourth quarter we always see a dip. We want to be prepared if the dip is even greater this year." 
ExecuStay, which was acquired by Marriott International in 1999, has been the target of much speculation on the part of its competitors that it had a bloated inventory and was being forced to relinquish some of its excess units. David Lorenzo, general manager of the New York, northern New Jersey and southern Connecticut market, denied that there was any downsizing in the works. 
"In a few cases, we have consolidated our inventory," he said. "For example, we recently gave up six units in a building in Battery Park City, returned the leases when they expired and took six units in a building across the street where we already had 40 units." The company manages an inventory of about 1,000 apartments scattered through some 100 buildings in the metropolitan area. 
"In New York, our goal is to concentrate 60 percent of our inventory," " Gary Abrahams, president and chief executive of ExecuStay, said. "There are efficiencies to be gained and we can offer a better level of service."
Had demand not fallen off since last year, he said he doubted that the company would relinquish any leases. "We couldn't find apartments then, but now things are cooling down." Nevertheless, the company is forging ahead with plans to expand. 
Last month, ground was broken at Third Avenue and 37th Street for a 30-story tower that will be almost entirely taken over by ExecuStay, and five months ago, it began filling a new 56-unit building on West 22nd Street in Chelsea. 
IT has also signed a 15-year lease on a 204-apartment building at 160 West 24th Street called the Chelsea that was recently bought by Townhouse Management and Pine Equity for $72 million. ExecuStay already has 29 units there in its portfolio and will add the remainder as leases expire. 
"This is still a very new business and in many markets, including New York, there is plenty of room for us to grow," Mr. Abrahams said.
Although ExecuStay apartments are filled for the summer, Mr. Lorenzo said it is offering reduced rates for people booking reservations now for the time between November and March, generally a slow period. "We haven't finalized plans yet, but it could be anywhere from 10 to 35 percent off current pricing," he said, adding, "That's simply good revenue management." 
The first building to be constructed from the ground up specifically for ExecuStay, the Third Avenue site, which is steps away from the Queens Midtown Tunnel, will be particularly convenient for travelers needing proximity to airports, like sports figures and United Nations diplomats.
There are distinct advantages to starting from scratch. "We are not constricted by the prior development of smaller units," Mr. Abrahams said. "Units can be constructed and designed for the specific needs of the business traveler with working areas, areas in which to relax and sleeping area."
Also a joint venture of Townhouse Management and Pine Equity, the residential tower will contain 145 apartments, 126 of them studios and one-bedrooms to be leased by ExecuStay. The remaining 19 apartments will be two-bedroom duplexes that will be sold to the public as condos. 
Clad in limestone, the building will have a 24-hour doorman, gym, conference center and storage space among its amenities. Ofer Resles, president and chief executive of Pine Equity, said he expected the average rent for a one-bedroom unit to be about $6,000 a month. 
From the developer's vantage point, Mitchel Maidman, chief executive of Townhouse Management, said: "It is less risky to build a 30-story building this way than to do it without a tenant. And it is apparently great for them because they will rent out the units for substantially more than they will pay us." 
Other companies are taking over entire buildings as well. Furnished Quarters, for example, assumed the leases on more than 40 units at 316 East 63rd Street last October. "It was a brand new building that was finished by M-1 Properties with us in mind," Mr. Brown said. "They will be building another building within the next year that we will occupy."
Mr. Hernandez of Oakwood said that his company, which had its start in the 1960's as the developer of garden style communities for singles in California, was considering putting up its own buildings but that it was premature to divulge details. "We have a few deals in the negotiating stages," he said. 
Despite its standing as the financial nerve center of the country, the city has always had a relatively modest supply of corporate accommodations.
"The available inventory has never been there," Mr. Lorenzo said, predicting, "Things will loosen up now because for the first time since corporate housing became popular there is inventory available. 
"Last year there was an overwhelming demand for traditional rentals in Manhattan and an insufficient supply," he continued. "In 2001 supply has caught up with demand because a number of buildings under construction have been completed. As demand has leveled off, developers are more willing to consider leasing blocks of apartments to corporate housing companies."
"In addition," he said, "all the myths about corporate housing -- about the wear and tear of people moving in and out -- are being dispelled. It has become accepted in high-end rental and condo buildings." 
CLEARLY, there is room for newcomers like BridgeStreet Corporate Housing Worldwide, which began filling its first outpost here, 85 John Street, a rental apartment house where it has taken 32 units, in May.
"Certainly it is easier to enter this business in a more robust market," said David McCaslin, president of MeriStar Hotels and Resorts, which acquired BridgeStreet for $60 million a year ago. "Business is down, and there is less relocation and less consulting work, but we did not go into the New York market for the short term. We currently have over 700 units in London and 500 in Toronto, and we think we can handle that many, if not more, in New York." All told, BridgeStreet has 3,700 units in 29 cities in this country, Canada and England. 
In addition to the monetary savings it offers, corporate housing has lifestyle appeal. "Hotel living can be great for a week, but living out of a suitcase gets boring," Mr. McCaslin said. "We have executives coming to town for projects lasting 30 to 90 days or so. A hotel room is too confining for that length of stay, but they don't want to go into unfurnished apartments and be bothered setting up a second home for a place where they won't live in the long term." 
Besides, he added, "No one wants to have to pay $3 for a can of Coke from the service bar or $4 for a bag of peanuts."

HEADLINE: RELIGION; 
A Man of the Cloth

BYLINE:  By DAVID KOEPPEL 

DATELINE: PASSAIC 

 BODY:
Ronald Coleman had just bought what he thought was the perfect Brooks Brothers suit, a black, single-breasted Italian pinstripe, marked down to about $800. Despite its apparent stylishness and superior tailoring, Mr. Coleman, a lawyer, suspected that the suit had one major flaw.
 He brought the garment to the laboratory of Rabbi Avrohom Aronovitch of Passaic, where his suspicions were confirmed. The garment contained shatnez around the lining of the jacket collar. 
 The prized suit couldn't be worn until the offending material was removed.
Little-known outside the Orthodox Jewish community, the law of shatnez prohibits the wearing of any garment that has a mixture of lamb's wool and linen. These days, the testing of clothes, rugs and even upholstery is on the rise as more people adopt the Torah's prescribed regulations.
"Some people refer to it as wearing kosher clothes," said Rabbi Aronovitch, 39, a professional tester whose home laboratory serves the shatnez needs of customers from northern New Jersey, Rockland County and parts of New York City. "People understand kosher food, so it's a way for them to understand without actually having to give an in-depth explanation."
Even the most learned of rabbinical scholars are uncertain about the underlying reason for the laws. Some trace their history back to the biblical story of Cain and Abel -- saying that joining these two opposing forces allow powers to exert destructive forces on the world -- while others contend that the wearing of shatnez has a generally negative spiritual effect, a sort of Jewish version of bad karma.
In his 1988 pamphlet "A Guide to Shatnez," Rabbi Dovid Loebenstein wrote: "There is a body of laws whose rationale the human mind can appreciate. On the other end of the spectrum, there is a smaller body of statutes not given to rational explanation."
While shatnez falls into the latter category, Rabbi Loebenstein emphasized that it was an important act of faith to observe the practice. That is where testers like Rabbi Aronovitch come in. 
The rabbi has been in the business of testing for shatnez for four years -- a second career that he performs part time when not teaching elementary school at a yeshiva in Queens -- filling a need in the burgeoning Orthodox Jewish communities of Passaic and Clifton.
His home office looks part retail showroom, part biology lab -- Brooks Brothers meets Louis Pasteur.
It is a successful sideline with little competition. Rabbi Joel Schocket, a shatnez tester at the Rabbinical Seminary in Lakewood, said that only a handful of people tested for shatnez throughout New Jersey.
North Jersey Shatnez, as Rabbi Aronovitch calls his business, is situated in a small room on the first floor of the two-story home he shares with his wife and seven children.
The office is filled with men's, women's and children's clothing waiting to be tested. On the bulletin board is his latest alert to customers: "Check J. Crew Hats for Shatnez."
On his desk sits the primary tool of his trade, a microscope, which is used to examine microfibers. Like an excitable child playing with a chemistry set, Rabbi Aronovitch placed a fiber from Mr. Coleman's collar on a slide, then squeezed a droplet of olive oil on the fabric to separate the threads. 
"Linen looks like bamboo," the rabbi said as he peered through his microscope. "Distinctive wool has a scaly appearance. Linen fibers are smoother than some others. Silk for example is shinier."
Four years of shatnez experience has made the rabbi savvy about the types of clothing most likely to contain shatnez. Suit collars, waistbands and shoulder pads are usually the most problematic areas. Clothing labels only provide the guidelines, he said, noting that at times an item labeled 100 percent wool will still have a shatnez problem.
With that, he brought out a woman's suit labeled 90 percent viscose, 6 percent wool and 4 percent other fibers. It was the "other fiber" label that sounded the alarm.
And despite what some people expect, the more expensive a garment, the more likely it is to contain shatnez. Indeed, many of the high-end suits use linen to reinforce the collars, something not done as frequently in cheaply made garments.
Once a garment is discovered to have shatnez, a tester cuts away the forbidden material and a local Clifton tailor, Stefan Gorzelany, replaces it with another fabric, usually cotton. The rabbi charges from $7 to $10 to routinely check each garment, and $15 to $40 for repairs. When the alterations are completed, the rabbi places his own shatnez-free label on the garment. 
He makes regular visits to Nordstrom's, Neiman Marcus and Bloomingdale's in Paramus, all stores with a large Orthodox clientele. Amy Jones, a spokeswoman for Nordstrom in Seattle, said that the demand for shatnez testing at the Paramus store had sharply increased in the past few years.
The rabbi examines both handmade European suits and less-expensive clothes straight off the discount rack. Initially skittish about cutting up pieces of $3,000 Armani and Brioni suits, experience has made him steadier with a pair of scissors.
"Rabbi Aronovitch is one of the best economic indicators in the Orthodox community," Mr. Coleman observed. "How much business and the quality of the garments he tests are indicative of how flush people are."
Before the arrival of Rabbi Aronovitch, Mr. Coleman recalled that most observant Jews from the North Jersey area took their clothes to Brooklyn or waited for the occasional visit of an elderly traveling tester from Munsey, N.Y.
At the Lakewood facility, Rabbi Joel Shochet and his partner do their own testing, train aspiring testers from around the world and promote the practice of shatnez.
It takes about six weeks of classes to become a tester, and Rabbi Shochet said he had found that the vocation's appeal was transcending just rabbinical scholars. For instance, he said that a computer programmer from Washington and a urologist from Phoenix had decided to pursue testing as a second career. 
Few can make a living exclusively from testing, though Rabbi Aronovitch said that money was only a small part of the equation. Customers usually do most of their testing before weddings, bar mitzvahs and holidays, so a tester becomes part of the community's most festive celebrations. 
It also seems to be a recession-proof business, said his client, Mr. Coleman.
"If you can afford a $1,200 suit," he said, "you're not going to be losing sleep about paying $50 for shatnez testing."

GRAPHIC: Photos: In his Passaic home, Rabbi Avrohom Aronovitch uses a microscope to analyze clothing. Wearing garments containing both wool and linen is prohibited in Orthodox law. (Norman Y. Lono for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS; 
Marcy Reher, Lance Spacek

 BODY:
Marcy Jill Reher and Lance Joseph Spacek were married on Friday by the Rev. John Laferrera at St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church in Caldwell, N.J. 
Mr. and Mrs. Spacek work at Salomon Smith Barney in Manhattan. She is an executive secretary in mergers and acquisitions, and he is a vice president for investment banking in technology.
 The bride, 27, is also a doctoral candidate in criminal justice at the City University of New York Graduate Center. She graduated from Manhattan College and received a master's degree in counseling psychology from New York University. She is a daughter of Sandra and Albert Reher of New Springville, Staten Island. Her father is a music teacher at Intermediate School 51 in the Port Richmond section. Until last month, her mother taught the eighth grade at the Immaculate Conception School, a parochial elementary school in the Stapleton section. 
 The bridegroom, 32, graduated from North Carolina State University and received an M.B.A. from the University of Pennsylvania. He is a son of Patricia and Thomas Spacek of Albuquerque. His mother retired as the director of management services at the Lehigh Valley Hospital and Health Network in Allentown, Pa. His father, also retired, oversaw economic analysis of telecommunications and Internet services at Telcordia Technologies, a software company in Morristown, N.J.

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Column 2; New Jersey Weekly Desk; Pg. 5

LENGTH: 779 words

HEADLINE: N.J. AND COMPANY; 
A Winery Changes Its Face

BYLINE:  By ROBERT STRAUSS 

DATELINE: EGG HARBOR CITY 

 BODY:
The joke about this village in the flat farmland of central Atlantic County is that there are few eggs, no harbor and not much of a city.
 Much of the area surrounding the small main street as well as the White Horse Pike -- overgrown with gas stations and convenience stores -- is sliced up into several-acre lots of developed about a hundred years ago. 
 Those developers sold the land mostly to first- or second-generation German families looking for a rural respite from Philadelphia. The roads are redolent with that heritage: Frankford, Vienna, Hamburg and, most prominently, Bremen. 
On Bremen Avenue, a couple of miles outside of town, lies the Renault Winery, the oldest continuous commercial winemaker in New Jersey, founded in 1864 and sprawling over 1,400 acres. Even during Prohibition, Renault stayed in business by producing sacramental wines and Renault Wine Tonic, a 22 percent alcohol brew sold in pharmacies for a variety of ailments.
In the last decade or so, though, the Milza family, which bought the winery in 1977, has cut back on wine distribution, saying that it is too hard to ship its product and compete against the larger wineries. Renault still makes wine -- mostly for sale in New Jersey -- but the Milzas felt they needed to do something more in their relatively remote South Jersey outpost.
Thousands of cars whiz past each week headed for Atlantic City, only 16 miles away. And though 16 miles can seem endless to people in South Jersey, it is just a short ride to Philadelphians and New Yorkers. Such reasoning gave birth to the Tuscany House, which opened in April with 50 rooms, a restaurant and banquet facilities. 
The land on which the Tuscany House -- sand-colored with Northern Italian accents -- was built on virtually untouched land adjacent to the winery and retained as a buffer from development.
For a while, promoters of Egg Harbor City thought a metropolis would sprout there, especially after the late 19th century resulted, when travelers heading south from Philadelphia had to switch trains in Egg Harbor. But a jetport in the pinelands -- proposed in the 1950's and 60's -- never came, and Egg Harbor never flowered.
Still, Renault has flourished, with busloads of tourists passing through; on some weekends as many as three wedding receptions a day are held in the old winery.
"We thought there had to be a way to convert some of those buses and weddings into overnight stays," said Lana Aylwin, the general manager of the Tuscany House. "And then we thought even bigger."
Undertaking a study, the owners found that several golf resorts had opened within 50 miles in recent years, including an extension of Blue Heron Pines and Pine Hill Golf Club. The Tuscany House now puts up several people at Blue Heron Pines, about eight miles away. But, more importantly, it has contracted Arthur Hill, a well-known golf course architect, to build an 18-hole course that is expected to be ready next summer.
"We have some issues with the trees and environmental permits, but that will only make it a more beautiful course," said Ms. Aylwin. "We prefer, though, not to say we're in the middle of nowhere, but in a great and unexpected rural setting." 
Prices are clearly not middle-of-nowhere. On summer weekends, the rooms -- small but quaint with free Internet access and ample bathrooms -- cost $150 to $190 a night, and at the casual northern Italian restaurant entrees are $12 to $24.
And as might be imagined, there is little to do except tour the winery, have dinner or stroll among the pines.
"Look, we're not going to get the person who wants to spend all night gambling in Atlantic City," said Ms. Aylwin. "But if you are coming down from New York and want a quiet night, maybe go into Atlantic City for a show and come back to the country, we're hoping we are it."
Or, as she put it, "Now you can have that extra glass of wine after the wedding and sleep it off here."
An owner of a smaller winery in South Jersey said he well understood Renault's experiment. "The wine business is tough, and they have decided to de-emphasize it," said the winery owner.
Bill Walker, the state Department of Agriculture liaison to the wine industry, concurs.
"Because of the economies of scale, it is hard even for bigger wineries like Renault to compete on a national scale," said Mr. Walker. "They have to make themselves into agritourism."
To be sure, said Ms. Aylwin, the winery is still the main draw.
"In fact, we feature the Renault wines at the new restaurant, and people tend to order them," she said. "I don't think we'll ever be a major international winery again, but it will always be a big part of the package for people who find us here."

HEADLINE: Paid Family Leave Would Protect Livelihoods 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 A report by New Jersey Policy Perspective, a nonpartisan, nonprofit organization that conducts research on state issues, shows a majority of people favor using disability or unemployment insurance surpluses to finance a paid family leave program in New Jersey. The report went on to say that working parents who put the needs of their families first sometimes have no choice but to quit their jobs, hoping that someday they will be able to find another comparable job. 
 If New Jersey were to establish a program that would require employers to allow employees to take time off to tend to ill family members or newborns -- parents would not feel compelled to choose between their families and their jobs.
I have sponsored legislation that would prevent parents from having to make such a difficult decision. If signed into law, my measure would make New Jersey the first state in the nation to establish a paid family leave program, enabling employees to take up to 12 weeks of paid leave to care for an ill family member or stay at home with a newborn or newly adopted child. The program would not cost taxpayers any additional money because it would be financed by the Unemployment Insurance Fund, which already has a $3 billion surplus.

ARLINE M. FRISCIA
Woodbridge

The writer is associate Assembly minority leader.

HEADLINE: BRIEFING: TAXES; 
HOMESTEAD REBATE INCREASE

BYLINE:  By Anne Ruderman 

 BODY:
 Acting Governor DiFrancesco last week signed legislation that will increase to $750 the maximum property tax rebate for elderly and disabled citizens. 
The payback, called the Homestead Rebate, had not increased from $500 since 1990. The increase will cost the state an extra $144 million a year. Starting next year, the maximum Homestead Rebate will automatically increase annually to match the rate of inflation. Anne Ruderman

HEADLINE: BRIEFING: ECONOMY; 
UNEMPLOYMENT

BYLINE:  By Anne Ruderman 

 BODY:
 Unemployment in New Jersey rose to 4.5 percent in June from 4.3 percent in May, as New Jersey lost 5,100 jobs, mostly in manufacturing. 
Although the state unemployment rate has been at or below the national rate for 19 months, it has increased steadily since the beginning of the year. The only June employment gains were in retail trade and the services industry. Mark Boyd, the state labor commissioner, attributed some of the increase in unemployment to auto industry layoffs and a strike at Pepsi. Anne Ruderman

HEADLINE: ON THE JOB; 
A Welcome Mat, or a Banana Peel?

BYLINE:  By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
Yes, a fresh chapter in life can be exciting. And when that new chapter involves new employment, the initiation can prove enlightening, whether it leads -- literally or figuratively -- to a bed of hot coals or a bed of roses.
 In 1986, Kevin Fox, now of Overland Park, Kan., began his first day as a junior engineer for an electric utility in the New York metropolitan area. He was told that he would have three consecutive meetings: the first one would be with the plant manager, the second with the chief engineer and the last with his direct supervisor, who was the maintenance engineer. 
 At the first meeting, the plant manager told Mr. Fox how he ran things in his plant -- and that the most important thing for Mr. Fox to remember was to inform him of anything the chief engineer told him to do.
At the second meeting, the chief engineer said that he ran the plant, and that the most important thing for Mr. Fox to remember was to tell him of anything the plant manager told him to do.
At the third meeting, Mr. Fox's immediate supervisor, the maintenance engineer, said -- you guessed it -- that he was the person who actually ran the plant, and that most important thing for Mr. Fox to remember was to inform him of anything that the other two managers told him to do.
"After working at the plant for a few months, I came to realize two important facts," Mr. Fox writes. "First, I had to keep everyone above me informed as to what I was working on, and second, that none of them was actually running the plant.
"That function was being performed by Dolly, the woman who worked as the secretary for all three managers."
"Several years ago, I accepted a position with a small, prestigious firm," writes Elise Lee of Carmel, N.Y. "I was told that the firm's policy was to serve a catered corporate lunch each day. And it was as described.
"You can imagine my utter surprise, however, when I was given a list of rotating kitchen detail. That is, each secretary was expected to do kitchen duty at least one day a week."
That included clearing dishes from each boardroom, rinsing them, loading the dishwasher and wiping down counters.
"It took us almost three years to leave the Paleolithic period behind us as we successfully evolved to an Age of Enlightenment," she said.
"A kitchen staffer is now a part-time member of our family."
On her first day on the job, Jackie Herskovitz was asked to walk on fire -- a 12-foot-long path of it.
"Yes, walk -- with bare feet -- on glowing orange coals that averaged 1,500 degrees Fahrenheit," writes Ms. Herskovitz, who lives in South Boston and is the marketing director at the Insight Development Group in Hopkinton, Mass.
She says her boss did not demand that she do the firewalk, "but since Insight Development Group provides experiential training and motivational seminars to managers and sales teams at large corporations across the country, I thought it would be wise for me to participate."
So, after sitting in on a two-hour development session for sales executives of a large data storage company, Ms. Herskovitz found herself walking away from her belongings and from the safety of the seminar room.
"Outside we gathered around what was the most violent, raging bonfire I'd ever seen," she says. "We stood in a circle, seeking comfort in the fire's warmth from the cold March night."
The boss, she says, "asked us to close our eyes and envision successfully walking across the path."
Then he shouted, "Let go of your fears!" Ms. Herskovitz and the others threw into the fire a paper upon which they had written their ultimate fear. Hers was fear of failure. The paper turned to ash.
"As simple as it seems, I knew, after throwing my paper into the flames, I would be able to achieve all that I desired," she writes. "Walking across a path of fiery coals was just the first step.
"And then I waited. Waited in a line of jittery people for my turn to approach the path. My bare feet were numb as I jumped on the cold pavement.
"Brand new coals, straight from the fire, were shoveled along the path before me."
As she took her last step -- onto a cool, wet pad of grass, she heard the cheers. "And that was my first day on the job," she says. "It's been exciting ever since."
"Despite the Internet-tech sector crash, remnants of the heyday of start-up mania are alive and well in 2001," writes Jonathan Dunn of Manhattan. Recently, he said, "in my first 48 hours at NYPR, a boutique public relations firm catering to technology clients, I had two free meals, a 15-minute massage, plus Corona beers and margaritas as a tribute to a co-worker relocating to Mexico. 
"I also worked with a client who was launching a business with cool technology and $28 million in funding in the bank," he added. "In 1999 this may not have been news, but during an economic downturn it made me do a double take."

PERSON: Anne Stevens 

HEADLINE: Private Sector; 
Comfortable With the Fast Track

BYLINE:  By MICHELINE MAYNARD 

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich. 

 BODY:
AS a 15-year-old racing fanatic, Anne Stevens longed to hang out with the mechanics in the pits at the stock car races near her home in Reading, Pa. But girls weren't allowed.
 So she borrowed a baggy shirt and trousers, tucked her hair under a cap and finagled her way in. "If you looked dirty, they didn't bother you," she recalled. 
 Now she is a major force in another arena where women once weren't welcome. On July 12, she was chosen as vice president for North American vehicle operations at the Ford Motor Company, where she is in charge of 29 assembly, stamping and tool-and-die plants. It was her second promotion in three months; she had been vice president for North American manufacturing.
Mrs. Stevens, 52, is easily the most powerful woman in American automotive manufacturing; factory management has always been a male domain. Friends say she has a clear view of what she wants to accomplish.
"Anne is impatient with the need for change and is certainly unrelenting in driving for change," said Joel Cutcher-Gershenfeld, director of the Engineering Systems Learning Center at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. But, in comparison with other executives, he said, "she truly expects it to be based on data and knowledge, not some out-of-the-blue event."
Mrs. Stevens said she would focus on two important goals: ensuring that all Ford plants adhere to its uniform productivity and quality standards, and that morale at Ford's plants remains high.
Her task will be difficult. Ford has suffered a series of blows to its reputation. It is embroiled in a $3 billion recall of Firestone tires on Ford Explorers. Its market share is falling. It ranked last among seven major car companies in J. D. Power & Associates' most recent survey of quality. And its factory productivity, long Detroit's best, fell in 2000, as measured by the annual Harbour Report, while General Motors gained ground.
In an interview at Ford headquarters here, Mrs. Stevens did not flinch from the criticism. "The customer votes," she said. "We've got a lot of work to do."
In fact, Mrs. Stevens said she was pleased to see G.M. improve its plants' performance. "It's great that American manufacturing isn't gone," she said. "I don't want to see jobs lost to competition" from foreign rivals.
Mrs. Stevens showed similar calm last August, when the Ford Escape, a small sport utility vehicle, was recalled five times in its first month on sale. The task of informing her of each new problem fell to Chuck Maitland, director of manufacturing operations, who reports to her.
"It was never about personalities; it was never about, 'who's the culprit,' " Mr. Maitland said. Instead, Mrs. Stevens wanted to make sure that Ford fixed the source of the defect.
Mrs. Stevens, who is married to Bill Stevens, a retired auto supplier manager, and has a grown son and daughter, has been interested in finding answers since her own inquisitive youth.
While keeping her invalid mother company, Mrs. Stevens said she used to make pencil holes in the dining-room wall behind her mother's chair, peering at the sawdust and wiring. In science class, she was fascinated by dissecting frogs.
She won a nursing-school scholarship but found she was not cut out for medicine. She switched, studying mechanical and materials engineering at Drexel University in Philadelphia. 
Drawn to Detroit by her love for cars, she spent a summer working in Ford's stamping operations in Dearborn. But she ultimately took a chemical engineering position at Exxon, choosing it over 11 other job offers she received upon graduation. For a time, she was based at Exxon's refinery in Linden, N.J., where she loved climbing the soaring towers for a view of Manhattan.
Three events in the late 1980's prompted a career shift. An animal lover who breeds pedigreed dogs and cats, Mrs. Stevens was shocked by the environmental damage from the Exxon Valdez oil spill in Alaska in 1989. "I would have been out there, cleaning the beach," she said. 
Then a friend's death in a car crash caused Mrs. Stevens to wonder about her own life's purpose. She decided to enroll in New York University's business school, where she encountered W. Edwards Deming, the quality expert who helped postwar Japan revive its factories.
Impressed by her persistent questions, Dr. Deming called her home one Saturday afternoon and invited her to study with him. She said he taught her important lessons: "You must listen to the people and the process. If you don't have the respect of your organization, you cannot be as effective as you could be." 
Her work with Dr. Deming eventually brought her back to Ford, where Dr. Deming had been a consultant a decade earlier. After starting in a marketing position in 1990, she moved to manufacturing in 1992 and in 1995 was appointed plant manager at Ford's electronics and plastic molding factory in Enfield, England. She was the first woman to be a Ford plant manager in Europe. 
Mrs. Stevens said her male colleagues went out of their way to introduce her to other professional women so she would feel at home.
One new friend was Sara Allen, the founder of Answers, a behavioral consulting firm based in London. Hearing that Mrs. Stevens had arrived, Mrs. Allen, who is from Johnstown, Pa., called her office and invited her to supper that evening.
With their husbands on assignment elsewhere, the two expatriate women became traveling companions and often discussed issues facing the business world.
Mrs. Stevens has great strength as a strategic thinker, Mrs. Allen said. "She has this wonderful sense of, "I need to do this, this and this in order to make this over here happen," she said.
In dealing with a problem, Mrs. Stevens first asks for data, then often goes directly to the assembly line for a closer view. She tries to visit at least one plant a week, she said, and communicates constantly by e-mail with plant managers, union leaders and other employees whom she called "my pen pals." 
Initially, said Mr. Maitland, who had never worked for a woman, "there might have been a tendency to underestimate her experience." 
Actually, Mrs. Stevens said, she encountered more resistance earlier in her career than she has at Ford, where she has assembled an informal network of 400 women in Ford's white-collar work force. One subordinate at Exxon refused to take a job working for a woman. "I said, 'I can do anything about the job description, but I can't doing anything about this,' " she recalled. "The man kind of looked at me. And then he took the job."

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH/Bruce L. Bartlett and Christopher M. Leavy; 
Atlas Growth and Income Fund

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
THE two managers of the $388 million Atlas Growth and Income fund work together, but each follows his own investment discipline.
 Bruce L. Bartlett, the lead manager, picks growth stocks, while his co-manager, Christopher M. Leavy, says he is a value investor. "Growth guys and value guys are very different," Mr. Bartlett said. "We put on our pants differently. But we're closer than most." 
 Regardless of the approach each uses, Mr. Leavy said, "We're both very sensitive to the earnings prospects of the companies we own."
Like many growth-and-income funds, the Atlas fund now emphasizes growth stocks because corporate dividend yields are generally low. As a result, it is classified in the "large growth" category by Morningstar Inc. It returned 5.1 percent a year, on average, for the three years ended Thursday, versus 0.5 percent for its peer group and 2.1 percent for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, according to Morningstar. It lost 21.4 percent in the 12 months ended Thursday, versus losses of 33.7 percent for its peers and 17 percent for the index.
The managers meet at least weekly to review the fund's 68 stocks. Mr. Bartlett, 51, and Mr. Leavy, 30, work for Oppenheimer Funds in New York, which manages the fund for Atlas Advisers in San Leandro, Calif. They are also co-managers of the $3.6 billion Oppenheimer Total Return fund, using similar investment strategies; the charter of the Atlas fund, however, prohibits it from buying tobacco stocks.
Mr. Bartlett looks for companies with revenue growth of at least 10 percent a year and earnings growth of at least 15 percent -- both now and over the next three to five years, on average.
"We're trying to differentiate between companies that have strong earnings growth and companies that can sustain their growth," he said.
He also combs balance sheets to gauge earnings quality. A material decrease in a backlog of orders, for example, indicates deteriorating revenues and earnings, he said.
Mr. Bartlett separates this research from valuation analysis. "I don't want to be prejudiced by a stock's price before digging into the business itself," he said. "You can be hesitant to jump into an expensive company, and attracted to cheap ones."
His earnings focus has led him away from technology stocks, now just 11 percent of assets versus 19 percent for the S.& P. 500, and toward financial issues, now 27 percent versus 18 percent for the index.
"Financials are very insulated from the capital-spending recession we're currently experiencing, and benefiting from the declining interest rate environment," he said.
By contrast, Mr. Leavy calls himself a classic value investor who looks for companies with price-to-earnings or price-to-book multiples below those of the S.& P. 500. But cheap is not enough; he wants to seegrowth, too.
"What separates value companies is that some will produce big earnings gains down the road, and others will fail to do so," he said. His analysis centers on projecting earnings or cash flow over the next three to five years, and evaluating what the company would be worth to someone acquiring it.
One stock that meets the criteria of both managers is Freddie Mac, the mortgage packager. The fund bought shares in October 2000 for $57.52, adjusted for splits. Mr. Bartlett expects earnings growth of more than 20 percent in each of the next three quarters, over the corresponding periods of the previous year, based on a strong housing market and declining interest rates. Freddie Mac shares are relatively cheap, Mr. Leavy said. "The valuation is in line with other quality financials," he said, "but the projected growth rate is higher." Now trading at $67.56, it sells for 16.31 times 2001 earnings.
Mr. Bartlett also likes Kohl's, the discount chain that sells apparel and household goods. The company, based in Menomonee Falls, Wis., has been expanding from the Midwest to the Eastern Seaboard, Mr. Bartlett said. He expects earnings and revenue growth of more than 20 percent a year over three to five years.
He bought shares in October 1999 at $35.21; they now trade at $58.40.
Mr. Leavy likes the News Corporation, the Australian media company whose American depositary receipts are traded on the New York Stock Exchange. "The stock sells at a significant discount to what we think it's worth," he said, "if you add up the value of all of its assets" -- including newspapers, satellites and the Fox Entertainment Group.
The company is negotiating with General Motors to gain control of Hughes Electronics, which runs the DirecTV satellite television business. Mr. Leavy expects that some satellite assets will be spun off, shrinking the valuation gap, and he anticipates improving cash flow at Fox, driven by higher syndication revenue. He bought the Class A A.D.R.'s in October 2000 at $33.84; they now trade at $30.64.

HEADLINE: The Tabloid Public Is Not the Majority 

BYLINE:  By Andrew Kohut; Andrew Kohut is the director of the Pew Research Center for the People and the Press.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
The country has been inundated with news about Chandra Levy, the missing Washington intern. The coverage has seemed almost nonstop on cable television news, and the story has been Topic A on the chat shows. Even Dan Rather, who had resisted covering what he considered a tabloid story, had to give in and let his news show include a summary of the search for Ms. Levy and the initial reluctance of Representative Gary Condit to help Washington police by talking with them about his last meetings with her.
 The relentless, sensational coverage might make observers despair about the tastes and values of the American public. But in fact, most Americans are not captivated by the Chandra Levy story. 
 The latest nationwide news interest survey by the Pew Research Center for the People and the Press finds only 16 percent of Americans "very interested" in the story -- a low number not only in absolute terms, but compared with the percentages of people highly interested in other celebrity scandals that we have polled about over the years: the O. J. Simpson story had 48 percent of respondents "very interested" at its peak, and the Bill Clinton-Monica Lewinsky scandal had 36 percent.
Even less prominent incidents generated more intense interest than Chandra Levy's disappearance: for example, the "very interested" figure was 32 percent for both Mike Tyson's rape trial and Marion Barry's legal problems, and 27 percent for William Kennedy Smith's rape trial in Florida.
So what's going on here? Are the news executives misguided about what appeals to their audiences? The answer is no. Television news producers get instant feedback from the ratings, and they know what makes the needle move. But at the same time, what works for cable television shows watched by relatively small audiences does not necessarily have broad public appeal.
A central problem in television journalism today is that audiences are so fragmented that it takes only a small increase or decrease to make a big economic difference to the networks. If a cable show regularly draws 600,000 viewers, an increase to 900,000 is a very big deal. And all that's required is a story that appeals to the minority of the public that is attracted to news about celebrities in trouble -- regardless of disinterest or even outrage about extensive coverage from the majority of the public.
There is a tabloid audience that goes from one saga to the next. Last year, at the height of the Elian Gonzales news craze, a nationwide Pew survey found that an extraordinary 61 percent of that story's core audience had also been strongly attracted to news about the death of John F. Kennedy Jr. in a plane crash in 1999. The overlaps did not stop there: fully 73 percent of those drawn to news about Mr. Kennedy had been close followers of the unending accounts of the untimely death of Britain's Princess Diana in 1997. And it comes as no surprise that large percentages of each of these core audiences had also been closely attentive to the O. J. Simpson murder trial and the Clinton-Lewinsky scandal.
Our poll found that one-third of the public followed three or more of these stories -- about Elian, Mr. Kennedy, Mr. Simpson, Princess Diana, and Mr. Clinton and Ms. Lewinsky -- very closely. The vast majority of the public (67 percent) was much less interested: 34 percent gave none of these tabloid best-seller stories a lot of attention, and 33 percent were closely attentive to only one or two of them.
So far the Chandra Levy audience has not matched those for the tabloid heavyweights of the recent past, but these are slow news times even on the tabloid scene. The Levy-Condit story has become prominent enough to bring many of the commentators whose faces became so familiar in the O. J. Simpson case back to the TV screen.
Cable news and talk shows and the print tabloid media have little to lose and much to gain in the short run by pitching to the hard-core audience for celebrities' misfortunes. But past surveys show the vast majority of the public is put off by coverage of these stories that is so extensive as to be inescapable for viewers.
Most Americans blanch at the blatant exploitation of the people being covered, and they indicate in surveys that they feel the press pursues stories like these not to protect the public interest, but to enlarge audiences. These same surveys show significant numbers of Americans doubting the worth of the traditional watchdog role of the press.
One can only question the wisdom of alienating a large percentage of a public that now has the ability to screen out the news it does not want by turning to the Internet. And despite the short-term gains from the tabloid news coverage, cable and broadcast news audiences continue to decline.

In 1,500 Earnings Reports, Mixed Signals

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DAY 

 BODY:
Corporate earnings ruled Wall Street last week, as almost 1,500 companies reported their profits and offered forecasts into their futures. The results left a mixed and murky picture. 
 Investors celebrated positive earnings from companies like Nokia and Dell Computer. But much of the week had negative earnings news, which reached its apex late Thursday when Microsoft said sales and profits would be sluggish in coming quarters. EMC, Intel and AOL Time Warner also reported profit shortfalls. 
 Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, unsettled investors further, warning that the economy might "require further policy response." That led to speculation that the Fed was more likely to cut interest rates when it meets on Aug. 21.
 For the week, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 37.59 points, or 0.36 percent, to 10,576.65. But the Nasdaq composite index fell 55.42 points, or 2.7 percent, to 2,029.37. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 4.83 points, or 0.4 percent, to 1,210.85.
 In the bond market, optimism about further cuts in interest rates helped push down the yield on the 10-year Treasury note to 5.11 percent from 5.22 percent the previous week. SHERRI DAY

HEADLINE: Logging Plan for West's Burned Forests Incites a Debate 

BYLINE:  By JIM ROBBINS 

DATELINE: HAMILTON, Mont., July 18 

 BODY:
It was a year ago that wildfires roared through the forests of the rugged Bitterroot Valley here, consuming 70 homes and more than 355,000 acres of forest. But controversy sparked by the fires still smolders. 
 The Forest Service, which manages most of the forest land in the valley, is considering letting loggers harvest as many as 73,000 acres of blackened trees that are standing like a ghost forest on the burned hillsides. 
 Craig Bobzien, the acting deputy forest supervisor for the Bitterroot National Forest, said logging would prevent thousands of trees from blowing down and creating a fire threat for homes scattered throughout the ponderosa forests in a scenic mountain valley that has been a magnet for retirees and others seeking a rural existence. 
"We'd like to reduce the fuels from 50 to 60 tons an acre, to 15 to 20 tons an acre," Mr. Bobzien said. "Fighting fires in the forest is preferable to fighting fires in people's backyards. Last year, we were fighting in people's backyards."
But conservationists say the logging being considered here, and in other burned areas of the West, amounts to government capitulation to the timber industry and can do serious damage to the environment.
"Logging is proposed everywhere, under the guise of thinning and fuel reduction," said Robert Ekey, the northern Rockies regional director of the Wilderness Society in Bozeman, Mont. "And some of the cutting can't be justified ecologically at all."
The proposed sale of logging rights in the Bitterroot, which should be decided in September, is seen as a national test case. It would be the biggest such project, which the Forest Service calls burned-area recovery, in the lands devastated in last year's record fire season, when 92,000 fires blackened an estimated 7.4 million acres. 
Conservationists and some scientists say the biggest threat to the forest from postfire logging is damage to soil from heavy equipment, new roads and dragging logs, as well as damage to streams as disturbed soil washes into them. 
Some scientists say it is best for the land to be left alone. Dr. Wayne Minshall, a professor of ecology at Idaho State University, has studied the effects of fire on streams for 35 years. While in the first few years after a fire the ash, mud and burned trees can kill fish and widen channels in streams, over several years the streams recover on their own and become biologically more robust. 
"Human efforts to mitigate," Dr. Minshall said, "exacerbate the impacts" of the fire. 
But Ellen Engstadt, executive director of the Montana Wood Products Association, who recently toured a burned area in the Helena National Forest, said: "If anyone goes out there and says it's healthy and it will recover itself, he or she is crazy. It's a part of good solid forest management to get out there and do some work."
And Mr. Bobzien said that great care would be taken to cut and drag logs in winter, when the ground would not be disturbed, and to create buffers around streams, where timber would not be cut.
Logging is a contentious issue in this 70-mile-long valley just south of Missoula. In the 1970's, the Bitterroot was the focus of pitched local and national battles between environmentalists and the Forest Service over the practice of clear-cutting. 
The valley had the state's fastest-growing population, according to the 2000 census, and many of the residents came here to enjoy life in one of Montana's most scenic mountain valleys.
At the same time, the valley has a tradition of logging and lumber production. Many of those operations have closed in recent years, but have been replaced with a thriving economy focused on building log houses. 
Logging and forest rehabilitation are at odds with the philosophy of Yellowstone and other large Western parks governed by the National Park Service, where burned forests are allowed to recover on their own. But publicly owned forests have a mandate to allow multiple uses, which include commercial activities like logging. 
Ms. Engstadt said burned trees need to be cut soon, because after 18 to 24 months they dry and start cracking and lose their value as two-by-fours and other commercial products.
Some in the industry point out that Montana has already sold trees and begun logging on burned state land, while the fate of cutting on federal land is still in limbo. "There's a great suspicion that a lot of the discussion going on is a delay tactic, which will reduce the opportunity for salvage," said Pat Connell, the vice president for resource operations of Rocky Mountain Log Homes. 
Mr. Bobzien, meanwhile, seems resigned to the contentious debate. "We're going to be sitting in our rocking chair talking about fire and fuels," he said.

HEADLINE: Drag Racing 21st-Century Style 

BYLINE:  By PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES 

 BODY:
Every weekend night, Newman Shiue, 21, an electrical engineering student at U.C.L.A., leaves the apartment he shares with two roommates, a stuffed Winnie-the-Pooh and his Bruce Lee posters, and heads to North Hollywood in his sleek white Acura Integra GSR. 
 Mr. Shiue and dozens of other young men converge on "the track," a wide, deserted stretch of road in a dingy industrial area. Like the others, he zigzags around potholes to avoid scraping the lowered chassis of his street racer, its chrome exhaust pipe shimmering in the night. 
 About 70 cars, many of them Hondas and other "rice rockets," as modified Japanese imports are sometimes called, lined both sides of the track on a recent Friday night. Like a demonic Virginia reel, the racing began: an Integra paired with a Mazda, then a Mustang with Mr. Shiue's supercharged Integra. As 1 a.m. neared, the air was thick with the smell of rubber. 
When the police arrived, it took less than a minute for the racers, wheels shrieking, to vanish into the murk. By 2:05 they were at it again.
Similar scenes are repeated in dozens of cities every weekend, from Los Angeles to Bayside, Queens, in the latest retelling of an old story about young Americans and their cars. Where the open roads and dry lake beds here once lured street racers in 1930's Ford roadsters stripped of their fenders, running boards and luggage racks, and later in rumbling V-8's and brilliant, candy-colored lowriders, today's James Deans are young people like Mr. Shiue.
They spend $10,000 and more to add turbochargers, 18-inch rims, computerized fuel controllers and supercharged engines to their mothers' grocery-schlepping Hondas and Acuras. Mr. Shiue's Integra can go 140 miles an hour and do a quarter-mile in 14 seconds.
"Speed is an addiction," Mr. Shiue (pronounced Shoo) said one afternoon recently as he tinkered in a friend's garage. "I beat an M33 Porsche Boxster. These guys are so cocky -- they're driving a Porsche. I drive this little $20,000 economy car, and I take them out. I spank them."
Just as lowriders, with their flashy hydraulic suspensions, took root in Latino culture, import racing reflects the new demographics of California. "First, the white population had influence, with their V-8 muscle cars," said Dominic Chang, owner of Robocar Motosport in West Covina. "Then came the Hispanic lowriders. Now it's Asian culture."
The import-racing scene first emerged among young Asian-Americans in Southern California, but has become increasingly mainstream and multiethnic as it has spread across the country. Its pioneers were "carheads" like Mr. Shiue's cousin Edward Wu, 25, who grew up in Gardena and now sounds like a geezer. "Back then," Mr. Wu said, meaning the mid-90's, "it was a big deal if you had a muffler. Now it's, 'What kind of engine you got?' "
To old-timers like Pete Chapouris, 58, a hot rod builder in Pomona, Calif., there is more than a flash of recognition. "The Civic is the new '32 Ford," Mr. Chapouris said. "It's the need for speed -- to go faster, impress the girls, blow your buddies off." The new hot rodders "have no reference to what went on 50 years ago," he added. "They're just doing it because."
The transformation of Honda Civics and other compact cars into racers -- or cars that look like them -- has become a major industry.
Retail sales of turbochargers and superchargers, aggressive-looking body kits, high-performance tires and other accessories climbed 59 percent last year, to $1.2 billion, according to the Specialty Equipment Market Association, a trade group. At least four magazines and numerous Web sites chronicle the movement. Races show up on ESPN2.
Major automobile makers market high-performance turbocharged sedans, such as the Integra Type R and Subaru WRX, that can do a 12-second quarter-mile en route to the supermarket. Racers can buy computerized engine-management systems and programming software for injecting power-boosting nitrous oxide into a car's fuel lines.
Mr. Shiue and his friends consider themselves purists, shunning body kits and other flamboyant touches. A clean look also draws less attention from the police, since many modifications are illegal.
They mocked as ridiculous the race scenes in "The Fast and The Furious," the new movie about the import-racing scene.
"It's a Hollywood version of what they think kids are doing," Mr. Wu said. "It's not how much junk you put on your car. It's the cars that look messed up that are really fast."
They also complained about the dearth of Asian-American characters. "They're shutting out who originated all this," Mr. Wu said. "They're using the wrong people."
The film does depict how multiethnic the scene has become. This was also on full display one recent night in the parking lot of Imperial Rose Plaza, a shopping mall in Brea, Calif., as hundreds of young people gathered with their cars.
Sabour Amirazodi, 18, a student at Cal State Fullerton, pulled up in a Honda Civic with a blue neon interior and a cable of turquoise lights running around the dashboard. "This is kind of like an art fair," Mr. Amirazodi said.
The movie has also spawned police crackdowns around the country. In the Sun Valley section of North Hollywood, home of two tracks popular with Mr. Shiue and his friends, the police cited 212 spectators, arrested 7 drivers and race "flaggers," and impounded 91 vehicles the night the film opened.
No national statistics on street-racing fatalities are available, but law enforcement officials say the dangers are serious. Racing accidents in North Hollywood have killed 25 people, including spectators and passengers, since 1995. Someone is killed or badly injured there at least once a month, said Kenneth Garland, commander of the Foothill Division of the North Hollywood police.
In Ontario, Calif., the police recently installed rows of 3-inch-high bumps on four major racing streets to discourage racers. Fremont, near San Francisco, imposed stiffer penalties on racers and spectators.
The crackdowns echo those of the late 1940's and 1950's, when "the hot rod menace" inspired the formation of the National Hot Rod Association, which advocates organized drag races. Drag strips were built here with the help of civic groups like the Lions Club. But four major strips in Southern California have closed in the last 20 years, and many racers say that is a major reason they take to the streets. The only legal amateur drag strip in the area is about 40 miles north of Los Angeles.
In San Diego, where street racing has killed at least 14 people in three years, San Diego State University started a pilot program, "Race legal," which sponsors amateur drag racing at Qualcomm Stadium.
In Broward County, Fla., the sheriff's office sponsors legal drag racing for amateurs at Moroso Motor Sports Park in West Palm Beach. "You can't tell an adolescent, 'You can't race,' " Dean Mirra, a deputy sheriff, said. "So we tell them, 'Take it to the track.' "
Despite the risks, said Dave Coleman, an editor of the magazine Sport Compact Car, street racing would survive even if every corner had a drag strip.
"The two guys at the stoplight will still want to go for it," Mr. Coleman said. "It's just the competitive nature of human beings."
